response.headline: Program to Aid Kidney Victims Faces Millions in Excess Costs
response.abstract: Section of Soc Security bill enacted in fall '72 that provides financial coverage for treatment of some kidney diseases discussed in light of recent discovery that such coverage may cost $1-billion by '80s; alternative to increased spending will be deaths of as many as 5,000 Amers annually from acute kidney disease; original cost estimates ranged from $35- to $75-million in 1st fiscal yr of operation and $250-million in 4th yr; calculations by Fed experts have set costs at $135-million, rising to $1-billion in '80s; spokesman for Sen Burdick, bill's co-sponsor, says he never would have backed amendment had he known that it was going to cost that much; co-sponsors Sens Long and Chiles say that they had been fully aware of costs and had backed plan to prevent people from dying needlessly; Sen Bennett, only legislator who spoke out against kidney provision, says 'Cong is always passing bills without good long-range cost estimates'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CITY TOLD TO OUST 95 IN U.S. PROGRAM
response.abstract: US Labor Dept on Jan 10 informs NYC that at least 95 munic employes hired under Emergency Employment Act of '71 are ineligible and must be dismissed; NYC Deputy Mayor E K Hamilton repts that city has cooperated fully in investigation of standards under which it hired unemployed persons; Labor Dept pays 90% of employes' wages under act; investigation, which began last Sept, shows that city authorities differ with Washington officials over eligiblity standards for some employes under act; Hamilton also says city has conceded that in NYC HDA proper guidelines were not enforced; Labor Dept announces that it will require city to discharge 95 persons it found to be ineligible; Hamilton asserts some employes have already left city service; estimates that about $300,000 in salaries paid to disputed employes will have to be returned to Washington; Labor Dept also says city must prove eligibiltiy of 26 other employes whose status is being questioned; in addition, hiring dates of all 2,544 employes hired under act must be validated to ascertain whether hiring freeze imposed last Aug was violated
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MURPHY SHIFTING 97 OF HIS 110 MEN IN WALL ST. AREA
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr Murphy says on Jan 10 that he will issue status rept on investigation of theft of large quantities of narcotics from NYC Police Dept within near future, news conf
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: British Civil Servants Protest Heath's Wage Freeze
response.abstract: thousands of Brit Govt employes, including clerks and secretaries in Prime Min Heath's Cabinet Office, on Jan 10 stop work to hold meetings and rallies protesting pay losses they are suffering under Heath's 90-day wage and price freeze; meetings and rallies last up to 2 hrs and have nationwide impact; protests, 1st work stoppages ever mounted by Brit civil servants, are indication of shortening tempers of workers both in and out of Govt; workers' scheduled pay raises were held up since freeze took effect Nov 6, '72; civil servants were expecting 20% raise on Jan 1; freeze fixes wages of public and private employes at Nov 6 levels and prohibits all increases, including those that were scheduled to be given, until permanent controls against inflation can be enacted by Parliament; freeze did not cover fresh food, and increases in fruit, vegetable and meat prices in last 2 mos have hit family budgets hard; similar protests are scheduled by other industries; Heath and Cabinet members will outline their plan in meetings with labor and indus reprs on Jan 11 and with retailers on Jan 12; plan will then be put into final form and submitted to Parliament; illus of protester carrying sign of Civil and Public Services Assn in London
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: B‐52 PILOT FACES MILITARY INQUIRY
response.abstract: US SAC hq, Omaha, Neb, announces, Jan 10, B-52 pilot and crew comdr Capt M J Heck, now stationed in Thailand, faces possible ct-martial on charge of refusal to fly a combat mission over N Vietnam; Heck is serving his 4th combat tour in Indochina; SAC spokesman says Heck is 'first and only' B-52 crew member investigated on a charge of refusing to obey an order to fly a combat mission since B-52s first went into action over Indochina in June '65; SAC denies rept that other B-52 crew members had quietly been sent back to the US for balking at flying mission over heavily defended Hanoi area; Heck incident occurred Dec 27
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Milk Aide Says it Lawyer For Nixon Sought Funds
response.abstract: H W Kalmbach, Pres Nixon's personal lawyer, is identified in ct papers as major solicitor of dairy indus contributions to Nixon's re-election campaign that followed Adm decision to raise milk price supports; ct papers are deposition of G L Mehren, gen mgr of Associated Milk Producers Inc, Tex-based milk mktg cooperative that gave at least $197,500 of over $400,000 that flowed from nation's 3 largest dairy farm co-ops to campaign; say that Kalmbach asked 'quite unequivocally' for gifts and then sought to shut at least part of them off when dariy leaders, as required by law, sought to make contributions public; White House refers all inquires to Kalmbach, partner in Calif firm of Kalmbach, De Marco, Knapp & Chillingworth; Kalmbach is unavailable for comment; deposition by Mehren and another by R O Isham, assoc gen mgr of milk co-op, are filed on Jan 9 in US Dist Ct, Washington, by W A Dobrovir, public interest lawyer and atty for consumer advocate R Nader; allegations contained in pending Nader suit and contents of Mehren deposition outlined; Kalmbach por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WATERGATE TRIAL HEARSHUNT OFFER TO PLEAD GUILTY
response.abstract: E H Hunt Jr offers on Jan 10 to plead guilty to charges that he conspired to spy on Dems last yr; Judge Sirica reserves decision on whether to accept Hunt's plea until Jan 11; Hunt's attys say that he will plead guilty to conspiracy, to 1 count of 2d-degree burglary and to 1 count of wiretapping at offices of Dem Natl Com offices in Watergate; prosecutor implies and Govt sources confirm that 3 other counts also charging burglary and eavesdropping will be withdrawn by Govt; thus Hunt would not appear at trial; in opening arguments on behalf of most of defendants, their attys give strong indications that they will try to convince jury that men had no 'criminal intent'; Govt, outlining its case in detail for 1st time, tells jury that Pres Nixon's campaign orgn paid 1 of Hunt's co-defendants $235,000 in cash for 'intelligence operation' last yr; prosecutor tells Sirica that in agreeing to Hunt's plea he had warned that Govt would seek to call defendant before grand jury and question him extensively about case; Asst US Atty E J Silbert, in description of case, refers to pol aspects of Watergate affair but, while he mentions several officials of Com for Re-Election of Pres, he attributes lawbreaking only to defendants; details; Hunt illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KISSINGER AND THO CONFER A 3D DAY; NO PROGRESS SEEN
response.abstract: Kissinger and Le Duc Tho meet for 4 hrs in 3d session of renewed cease-fire talks, Jan 10; technical experts hold an all-day session; absence of progress in private talks indicated by several developments; USSR sources say that Hanoi has not changed and will not change its main position rejecting any formula giving legal recognition to the partition of Vietnam; USSR sources in Paris are pessimistic about likelihood of agreement in current round of talks; USSR Amb to France P A Abrasimov played an important part in helping to renew talks; informed sources say talks have reverted to earlier argument about definition of the line dividing N and S, whether it is a real border, or, as provided in '54 Geneva agreements, only a 'provisional mil demarcation line' open to pol penetration; problem concerns the fundamental issue of the war, whether there are to be 2 Vietnams, one Communist and one anti-Communist, or whether S Vietnam is to be opened to influence from the North and eventual reunification with it; French sources say that in view of difficulties of the talks, they are doubtful about the possibility of an early spring Eur tour by Nixon; tour reptdly is being postponed at request of Eur leaders, for fear of violent anti-US demonstrations if the US is still at war in Vietnam; Nixon reptdly would not come until there is a cease-fire; there is no official comment on the cease-fire talks; formal peace talks session will be held Jan 11
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 180‐Million T.W.A. Case Against Hughes Is Upset
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10—Howard R. Hughes, the mysterious billionaire recluse, won a stunning $180‐million victory over the airline he once controlled, Trans World Airlines, in the Supreme Court today.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KICKBACKS FOUND ON HEALTH TESTS
response.abstract: Case of physician ordering battery of tests for patient, ignoring results and treating non-existent disease is described in light of recent disclosure by NYC Health Dept of arrangement between many drs and laboratories in which drs receive kickbacks for ordering unnecessary, expensive tests for patients
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MANDATORY WAGE‐PRICE CONTROLS ENDED EXCEPT IN FOOD, HEALTH, BUILDING FIELDS; NIXON CALLS FOR VOLUNTARY COMPLIANCE
response.abstract: Pres Nixon on Jan 11 ends wage and price controls, except for those involving health care, food and construction, replacing them with system relying mainly on 'voluntary cooperation'; surveillance will be focused on wage trends for health care
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: State's Drug Panel Backs a ‘Hard Line’ Against Traffickers
response.abstract: NYS Assemblyman Hardt, chmn of special state comm on drugs, says on Jan 11 that comm will imminently recommend to Legis new penalties for drug traffickers that are 'tough' but not as severe as those being sought by Gov Rockefeller; sees hard-line law-enforcement approach emerging as only solution to narcotics problem; notes there are possible const flaws in Rockefeller proposal and recommends that distinction be made between small-time addict-pusher and big-time drug dealer; commends Rockefeller for effort to bring 'full burden of the law to bear on illicit drug pushers'; urges passage of legis for proper disposal by police of contraband drugs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hunt Admits All 6 Charges As Judge Bars Partial Plea
response.abstract: E H Hunt Jr pleads guilty on Jan 11 to all 6 charges against him in Watergate case after Judge Sirica refuses to accept his Jan 10 offer to plead guilty to only 3 charges; Hunt is freed on $100,000 surety bond to await sentencing; says that to his personal knowledge there was no wider conspiracy involving Govt 'higher-ups'; says that Govt's detailed outline of its case against him and 6 others is substantially correct and that he did what he did because he believed it to be in best interests of country; Fed jury hears 1st testimony against 6 remaining defendants facing charges of conpiracy, burglary and eavesdropping; major witness is Brigham Young Univ student T J Gregory, who said that Hunt recruited him early last yr to spy on Dem Pres hopefuls Muskie and McGovern; says he received $175-a-wk for passing information to Hunt and that he saw G G Liddy and J W McCord in company of Hunt on several occasions; jury was out while Hunt pleaded guilty but it developed that juror G Oleaga had heard news of plea; juror is replaced; illus of Hunt with lawyer W O Bittman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: B‐52 Pilot Who Refused Mission Calls War Not Worth the Killing
response.abstract: Capt M J Heck, B-52 pilot who refused to bomb N Vietnam after his 175th mission, say he refused because 'the goals do not justify the mass destruction and killing,' int, Jan 11; by prior agreement, circumstances under which he was int cannot be revealed; authorities say Heck is at U Taphao air base, Thailand; Heck submits resignation, Jan 11, to USAF; also, as alternative, seeks noncombat status as a conscientious objector; says 'there is enough suffering just in S Vietnam to warrant a discontinuation of the war'; says the massive bombing of the North may have been the 'last straw'; comment on how he reached his decision on Dec 26, on bombing of civilians and on heavy US plane losses; comment on his career and his aspirations in civilian life; Heck por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KISSINGER AND THO CONTINUING TALKS
response.abstract: Kissinger and Le Duc Tho meet for 6 hrs in private Paris peace talks, Jan 12; are joined for 1st time by technical staffs, who had been meeting separately; there is no direct word on subject of talks; formal peace talks session held; discussion there concentrates on whether there is to be one Vietnam, influenced by Hanoi, or whether country is to remain divided; Communists warn of impending big offensive by Saigon's armed forces against Vietcong-held territory in the south; say large-scale preparations are under way, especially in Quang Tri Prov; Saigon, with US support, demands that DMZ be recognized as border between 2 sovereign govts; Communists insist that DMZ is 'temporary mil demarcation line,' as provided in '54 Geneva accords; illus of Xuan Thuy, Le Duc Tho and Kissinger arriving at talks
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Questions and Answers
response.abstract: questions and answers on Phase 3 econ policies announced by Nixon on Jan 11
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ARMY RESHUFFLES COMMANDS IN U.S.
response.abstract: Army Sec R F Froehlke announces on Jan 11 'most sweeping reorgn' since '62 costing $100-million and involving elimination of 15,000 mil and civilian jobs and saving $190-million per year, Jan 11 news conf; adds changes will help control growth of mil-industrial complex; high level Continental Army Command and Combat Developments Command, concerned with training and mil technique, are slated for elimination; Army's Munitions and Weapons Commands will merge and Electronics Command will be shifted to Fort Monmouth, NJ; other changes noted; Froehlke por with Gen C W Abrams at news conf
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: EDUCATION BUDGET EXPECTED TO CUT MANY PROGRAMS
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's educ budget for fiscal '74 will propose elimination of all Fed aid to libraries
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘Lid’ on Wages Feared
response.abstract: most labor leaders approve Pres Nixon's emphasis on continued wage and price controls in food processing and retailing
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON FUND PANEL MUST FACE COURT
response.abstract: US Justice Dept on Jan 11 files suit against C W Johnson, who lost bid for Dem nomination to Cong from Ohio's 17th Cong Dist in primary election May 2; charges that he violated Fed Elections Act
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: American League to Let Pitcher Have a Pinch‐Hitter and Stay In
response.abstract: Owners of 24 major league baseball teams, meeting in Chicago on Jan 11, vote to allow Amer League to use 'designated pinch-hitter,' who may bat for pitcher without forcing him to leave game; plan will be tried on experimental basis for next 3 seasons by Amer League, but will not be used in Natl League or in World Series or All-Star game; owners, players and officials comment on move
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Slight Impact Seen On Rents in the City
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's abandonment of Fed rent guidelines on Jan 11 will have little immediate effect in NYC because many tenants are protected by city rent controls; action is expected to have greater impact in suburban areas, particularly NJ, where rent control is practically non-existent; NYC HDA Admr Kerr says removal of controls is 'tragic' and that even if controls were inadequate they did help to some extent; NYC Housing Comr Leventhal says lifting of Fed guidelines will primarily affect tenants who move into decontrolled apts
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Some Officials Surprised
response.abstract: business execs generally applaud Nixon's move to Phase 3 of econ stabilization program as good step to less rigidly controlled econ; some surprised that move came so soon; timing praised by some; some economists skeptical on anti-inflation goals; some leaders comment on developments in specific industries; C A Gerstacker, R C Gerstenberg, D M Jones, J Needham, T Gaines and L Santow quoted on gen program; Sun Oil Co pres H R Shabaugh says Phase 3 will have little effect on tight petroleum supply but that in long run removal of controls is major step in creating conditions to encourage oil development
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FEDERAL RESERVE APPROVES A RISE IN DISCOUNT RATE
response.abstract: Fed Reserve Bd approves Jan 12 increase in discount rate from 4 1/2% to 5% at all 12 Fed Reserve Banks, effective Jan 15; bd statement on action detailed; action underlines general expectation in money mkts that monetary policy will be gradually tightened in '73 as anti-inflation measure, and particularly so now that Pres Nixon has eased Phase 3 wage-price controls
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: More Guilty Pleas Hinted Amid Watergate Secrecy
response.abstract: There are indications in Watergate trial on Jan 12 that some of 6 defendants want to change their pleas to guilty; H B Rothblatt, defense counsel for B L Barker, F A Sturgis, E R Martinez and V R Gonzales, says he opposes any guilty pleas; defense informant says that 4 men had felt they were under certain pressure to withdraw from case but refuses to specify source of pressure; denies it came from Adm or from Com for Re-Election of Pres; US Appeals Ct 3-judge panel holds, 2-1, that Govt cannot disclose details of information obtained in alleged eavesdropping on Dems without approval of party officials who had been overheard; secret session held; Rothblatt refers to 'technical problems' and when asked why trial would not resume on Jan 13, says there are problems that cannot 'be resolved logistically'; C Morgan Jr, atty for Dem party officials, is seeking to overturn ruling by Judge Sirica last wk allowing Govt to introduce contents of conversations as evidence at trials
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Wide Drug Detection Program Being Set Up in Harlem School
response.abstract: White House repts on Jan 12 that drug detection production program, which will require intermediate school students in Harlem, NYC, to submit to urinalysis to determine whether they are using drugs, is being prepared by Special Action for Drug Abuse Prevention; agency asst dir Dr Brill says program is viewed as possible model for rest of nation; program, which will be implemented at Frederick Douglass Intermediate School, will be based on 'parental and peer pressure'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MEANY ROLE CITED IN ENDING FREEZE
response.abstract: labor leaders, on Jan 12, privately describe Nixon's decision to drop most mandatory anti-inflation controls as major victory for G Meany that will do much to promote labor peace in '73; say decision to drop controls and to name Dunlop as dir of Cost of Living Council was arranged, in part at least, by Meany and Sec Shultz; Shultz reptdly agreed to press for dropping of controls in return for promise by Meany and other labor leaders to return to participation in stabilization program and to cooperate in seeking noninflationary wage increases this yr; labor sources say key to leaders satisfaction with Phase 3 program is apptmt of Dunlop, who is respected and trusted by trade union leadership; not all officials convinced Phase 3 represents a labor victory or that Dunlop is completely trustworthy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Structure of Protein‐Building Molecule Determined
response.abstract: Group of MIT scientists determines shape of class of molecules that plays essential role in all life processes; molecule is transfer ribonucleic acid, or RNA; its task is to assemble material of all living things; it is said to be 1st nucleic acid crystal whose 3-dimensional structure has been determined by X-ray probing; structure is L-shaped, with each arm of L a segment of double helix, twisting like 2 spiral staircases around 1 another; tRNA molecules have basic structural similarities; because abnormal tRNA is found in tumor cells, project has been supported by Amer Cancer Soc, as well as Natl Insts of Health, Natl Science Foundation and Natl Aeronautics and Space Adm; major puzzle remaining is how nature devised this method to maintain continuity in mfr of proteins; drawings
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stocks and Bonds Show Sharp Drop
response.abstract: stock and bond mkt fall sharply in active trading Jan 12 as investment community weighs possible implications of Phase 3 econ program
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: G.E. and Soviel Sign Pact For Technology Exchange
response.abstract: USSR and General Electric Co on Jan 12 sign agreement providing for joint development of power generation tech, exchanges of specialists and production samples of turbines and other equipment; co vp Dr T O Paine lauds agreement, news conf, Moscow; discusses some development aims, emphasizing development of gas turbines; history of co's dealings with USSR noted; Paine por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Surge of Price Increases Forecast by Businessmen
response.abstract: businessmen and economists predict on Jan 12 a surge of price increases ahead following Nixon's relaxation of wage-price-profit controls; comments by A E Jones, N Robertson, G M Wenglowski, E F Andrews, L H Olsen, R E Dewar and G R Vila cited; few cos begin raising prices, mostly under old rules; C J Grayson illus in meeting as head of price div of Cost of Living Council; L R Moen, R T McNamar, G H Boldt and R W Kopp illus in meeting of pay div
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WEEKEND SESSION PLANNED IN PARIS
response.abstract: Kissinger and Le Duc Tho meet for 6 1/2 hrs, Jan 12; no details issued on subject of talks; Kissinger reptdly is expected to return to Washington about the middle of next wk without necessarily breaking off talks; this is seen as indication that final agreement is not expected during this round of talks that some kind of further series is contemplated after Nixon's inauguration on Jan 20; experts sessions continue; joint French-USSR communique issued, Jan 12, after a two-day meeting in Byelorussia between French Pres Pompidou and USSR party leader Brezhnev expresses 'their deep concern at the prolongation of the war and the foreign intervention in Indochina, and the delays brought to a pol settlement of the conflict'; W Ger Govt spokesman says Chancellor Brandt shares views of Min H Schmidt who had expressed concern about US role in war in speech Jan 11 at Newberry, SC
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: POVERTY AGENCY PACES MORE CUTS
response.abstract: Nixon Adm sources rept on Jan 12 that OEO Dir P V Sanchez will be nominated Amb to Panama
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 68‐CENT INCREASE IN THE REALTY TAX IS PREDICTED HERE
response.abstract: Citizens Budget Comm on Jan 12 predicts record 68c increase for each $100 of assessed valuation in NYC's real estate tax for '74 fiscal yr, which starts July 1; says new rate will increase 10.4% over present $6.52 for each $100 of assessed valuation to $7.20; projection is based on Controller Beame's estimate to city's Budget Bureau; comm asst exec dir H J Ranschburg says 'tax increase is detrimental to the best interests of tenants and landlords alike'; Budget Dir Grossman says comm estimate assumes that city will use all of its real estate taxing possibilities; holds that this is not certain; graph of NYC real estate tax rate from '64 to '74
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CITY WITHDRAWING PROM HIRING PLAN
response.abstract: Mayor Lindsay announces Jan 12 that NYC is immediately withdrawing from New York Plan, established 2 yrs ago to increase number of minority workers in construction trades; says city is 'disappointed' with results; presents alternative program and sends lr to Labor Dept requesting that Fed Govt set strict goals and timetables for minority employment on all Fed-financed construction in NYC; will also submit legis to both City Council and NYS Legis to require all contractors on city- and state-assisted construction to submit 'affirmative-action' plans for minority employment; reacting to announcement, C Cottrell, regional dir of Labor Dept, L Levine, NYS Industrial Comr, and T J Broidrick Jr, chmn of New York Plan, hold joint news conf; Broidrick says program has been 'unfairly criticized', that city did not pay its share of cost until 1 mo before program expired; Levine fears move will result in awarding contracts to non-union contractors; Cottrell hopes for talks that would lead to new plan
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: More East Germans Are Fleeing to West
response.abstract: W Ger's policy of improving relations with E Ger seen having unexpected effect of encouraging more E Gers to flee to West; during 2d half of '72, in which enactment of 4-power Berlin agreement and transit treaty between E and W Ger were initiated, 1,245 E Gers escaped to West-highest number in 6 yrs; specialist in W Ger Min of All-Ger Affairs attributes increase to effect of W Ger's Eastern policy upon hopes and fears of many E Gers; increase in escapes comes at time when more Gers may cross border legally, result of treaty concluded between 2 Gers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Inaugural‐Concert Work Deleted as ‘Not in Spirit’
response.abstract: Composer V Persichetti's inaugural-concert work based on Pres A Lincoln's 2d inaugural address is deleted from program by Pres Inaugural Com because text might embarrass Nixon; portions of address quoted; Gen R E Lee comments
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES, 5 TO 3
response.abstract: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13—A pair of first‐period goals by Steve Vickers within 48 seconds and agile goaltending by Eddie Giacomin lifted the New York Rangers to a 5‐3 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in a nationally televised National Hockey League game today.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CITY ACTS TO RAISE SAFETY IN SCHOOLS
response.abstract: NYC Mayor Lindsay on Jan 13 announces 3 steps in school security that will help bring sense of peace and stability to city classrooms, United Parents Assn conf, NYC; 1st step is proposal by Lindsay to allocate $5-million in capital funds for '73-74 budget; 2d step is request to Fed Housing and Urban Development Dept to reallocate $9.8-million in Model Cities funds to hire 1,000 community service officers for placement in schools; 3d step involves testing of SCAN (Silent Communication Alarm Network) in 3 schools this spring; system will permit teachers to give warning of danger by use of pen-size ultrasonic transmitter that signals master receiver panel; Lindsay says single greatest obstacle to progress in educ is fear, and that making schools tranquil is 1st priority to enable other programs to proceed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ONE JUROR BALKS IN HIJACKING CASE
response.abstract: juror G Hass asks to be excluded from further deliberation, citing abuse and pressure on her because she favors acquittal on grounds of insanity; Fed Judge Rosling says he will ask Fed agents to look into motives of Hass; hijacking by Trapnell recalled; Trapnell illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lumber Costs Smashing Control Barriers
response.abstract: lumber and plywood prices, which rose sharply during '72, are expected to continue to rise in '73, with higher costs being passed on to new house buyers; cost of some wood products has risen 50% since beginning of '72, despite rigid Fed price controls; Fed officials and some home builders blame wood indus for situation, while indus claims that Fed Price Comm is to be blamed; home builders spokesmen assert that higher wood products prices have added to costs of homes; say that some builders are being driven to use steel and aluminum; complain of shortages of various types of wood; lumber indus spokesmen say increased prices for builders is result of high 'labor and other costs'; increased prices also attributed to rise in Canadian imports, which are not subject to price control
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Paris Riot Police Disperse Anti‐Meir Demonstrators
response.abstract: Mier illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Los Angeles Faces Auto Curbs
response.abstract: EPA, under ct orders, will impose plan to meet standards of Fed Clean Air Act that is expected to include gasoline rationing, mandatory conversion of some commercial vehicles to non-gasoline fuels and restriction of auto use; Fed official says plan will test willingness of people to sacrifice for air quality; Calif officials hold EPA plan will be unworkable and force Cong to rev air quality standards or postpone '77 compliance deadline; Los Angeles Air Pollution Control Dist dir R L Chass and EPA regional dir P De Falco say neither city nor any other met area will meet Fed standards on schedule; EPA has only accepted implementation plans of 21 states 'in sense that no regulation will be imposed on them'; remaining states have until Feb 15, '73 to file detailed plans on reducing pollution; 18 of remaining states have large urban complexes
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Are These O'Casey's Brawling Irish
response.abstract: S O'Casey play The Plough and the Stars, presented by Lincoln Center Repertory Theater, revd by W Kerr
keywords: REVIEWS AND OTHER DATA ON SPECIFIC PRODUCTIONS

response.headline: PRICE RULE EASED FOR FOOD STORES AND PROCESSORS
response.abstract: Fed Govt officials announce on Jan 13 that new regulations under Phase 3 of Nixon's econ stabilization program will ease price rules for food distributors and processors; say that retail food prices are expected to rise in next few mos; Adm plans to create a food indus wage stabilization bd; bd is expected to be patterned after Construction Indus Stabilization Com; food indus has felt itself at a disadvantage in resisting union wage demands; fears that it would suffer permanent loss of business if lenghty shutdown occurred; under Phase 3, many food cos will be exempt from record-keeping requirements, making price enforcement more difficult; rule on supermkt markups has been revised in line with what stores wanted; IRS has opposed such a change for many mos; indus will also be permitted to add to prices, dollar for dollar, Govt-mandated operating cost increases; it appears that in food, as in most other sectors of econ, Nixon Adm in Phase 3 is focusing on big cos; theory is that they wield most econ power and that if they restrain their price and wage rises, smaller cos will be forced by competitive pressures to do likewise
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KISSINGER ENDS ‘USEFUL’ SESSIONS WITH THO AND RETURNS TO REPORT; SAYS NIXON WILL DECIDE NEXT STEP
response.abstract: Comment on developments in Kissinger-Le Duc Tho private peace talks in Paris; comment on issues Nixon deems crucial for a 'peace of justice and conciliation and on problems of truce acceptance by S Vietnamese Pres Nguyen Van Thieu; Kissinger illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 Watergate Defendants Reported Still Being Pai
response.abstract: At least 4 of 5 men arrested in June '72 in Watergate raid are still being paid by persons as yet unnamed; defendant Sturgis acknowledges that payments continued after his arrest but that his funds were sharply reduced in last few mos, meeting in Miami nearly 2 wks ago with NY Times reporters; another source says that payments to 4 men now range from $400 a mo up; other points brought up in NY Times ints with Fed investigators, pol figures and defense lawyers include: acknowledgement by high officials of Com to Re-Elect Pres that they are unable to account for $900,000 in cash raised for Pres Nixon's '72 campaign--far more than the $235,000 mentioned in ct as cost of activities of Watergate group; Nixon supporter working in Dem hq, apparently either recruited or infiltrated by intelligence team, taped open latches on doors leading to basement of Watergate offices, allowing the 5 men to enter bldg; Watergate team member E R Martinez was active CIA employe at time of break-in and kept diary which was subsequently found; further details of intelligence operation, described in ct this wk by chief Asst US Atty E J Silbert, including allegation that bugging had extended to Dem Sen's offices and that former Atty Gen Mitchell had been kept informed of intelligence group's activities, discussed; D L Shumway, dir of public affairs for Repub campaign com, told that rept would appear in NY Times, describes allegations in connection with com as false and preposterous; Sturgis biog; NY Times has been told that at time of his arrest, Sturgis was carrying false passport and other false documents that source believed were prepared by CIA at Hunt's request; Sturgis believes that funds are coming, in part, from accounts activated by still-operating Com to Re-Elect the Pres through variety of intermediaries; other money, said by Sturgis to come from right-wing businesses and individuals, is also reptdly available; details of Watergate break-in according to conversations with St George and Sturgis and another source close to defendants; Sturgis corroborates allegations in St George outline about wider bugging than that mentioned in Watergate indictment; Sturgis confirms that McCord was responsible for electronic eavesdropping, Sturgis for photographing documents, Gonzales as locksmith and Martinez and Parker for security; defendants illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: N.C.A.A. Scraps 1.6 for a Scholastic Ruling
response.abstract: NCAA, at Jan 13 meeting in Chicago, revises its controversial 1.6 academic requirement for athletes to 2.0 on 4.0 system; also limits number of football scholarships at a coll to 105 and basketball scholarships to 18; other developments noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: East Germany Is Like west Germany—15 Years Ago
response.abstract: Prof H Krisch descriptive article on E Ger gives his impressions after 18-day visit; concludes E Ger in '72 is like W Ger in '57; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: The Reaction
response.abstract: comment on problem of restraining inflation in Nixon's Phase 3 econ stabilization program; consensus among economists, and among experts in indus and labor, is that restraint will depend on how soon and how hard Adm cracks down on unions and cos that exceed anti-inflation standards
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Business in a Front Seat For Today's Super Bowl
response.abstract: W N Wallace comments on preparations for Jan 14 Super Bowl; compares teams; illus
