response.headline: The Official History of the 48th Railway Battalion: A Dirty Story
response.abstract: Humorous article on demise of US Army's 48th Ry Scenery Battalion, unit whose function is said to be protecting natl security by placing smoke-spewing factories, auto graveyards and scrap heaps at ry approaches to all Amer cities; cartoons
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: An ‘Extraordinary’ Fog Envelops Accounting
response.abstract: Article discusses confusing acctg practices used by several corps in their annual repts to shareholders and SEC's proposed disclosure rules to eliminate these practices by requiring corps to describe in detail unusual charges or credits to income, when they occurred and what cash outlays are involved; acctg methods of Indian Head Inc, J H Heinz Co, Natl Cash Register Co, Boise Cascade and RCA Corp described; acct L A Bernstein and SEC repr J C Burton comment; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: OPPOSITION RISES TO AMENDMENT ON EQUAL RIGHTS
response.abstract: Ratification of equal rights amendment to Const, which was passed early in '72 by Cong, outlawing all forms of sex discrimination that are based on law or Govt action, is uncertain; well-organized and apparently well-financed opposition groups have appeared; opposition in '72, when 22 of necessary 38 states approved amendment, was minor; opponents are effectively using assertion that amendment would subject women to mil draft and would abrogate laws that require men to support their families; Mrs D Meissner, exec dir of Natl Women's Pol Caucus, 1 of pro-amendment groups, sees difficulty in achieving ratification but predicts victory; apparent leader of opposition, Mrs P Schlafly, pol conservative, will not predict defeat for amendment; her por; she says her orgn, called Stop ERA, has several thousand members and is active in 26 states, in 8 of which it is particularly strong; advocates of amendment list 7 other states in which it faces difficulty; assert that Mrs Schlafly is receiving funds from J Birch Soc; she denies it; only other individual who has emerged as natl leader of opposition is Mrs J Davison, founder of orgn called Happiness of Womanhood; she says her husband pays her bills; Mrs Schafly, who admits she has no financial problems, says that advocates of amendment send people to lobby at taxpayers expense, reference to Citizen's Advisory Council on Status of Women, Labor Dept subsidiary; council chmn Mrs J G Gutwillig denies charge; minimizes draft and family support issue
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Miami Wins in Bowl for Perfect Season
response.abstract: Miami Dolphins win NFL champ by defeating Washington Redskins, 14-7, in Super Bowl on Jan 14; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Northeast Is Bracing Itself For Possible Energy Crisis
response.abstract: NY Times survey of nationwide impact of fuel shortage; Northeast may still face fuel crisis in event of cold weather; Petroleum Indus Foundation repts no Northeast homeowner has yet been deprived of fuel oil but situation could worsen if cold weather persists; repts stocks of home heating oil in Midwest and Northeast are down to 148-million bbls, compared to 178-million in '72; says increase in price of number 2 oil is needed to spur production; plant closings, fuel delivery cutbacks, suggestions on how to conserve fuel and indus execs comments on shortage noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: South Bronx: A jungle Stalked by Fear, Seized by Rage
response.abstract: 1st in a series of 4 articles on life in S Bronx; NYC HRA Admr Sugarman says area welfare centers are busy; denies charges that city is using S Bronx as vast 'dumping ground' for welfare cases; Morrisania dist of S Bronx has 507 welfare recipients among every 1,000 residents, but that is not highest rate in city; Williamsburg sec of Bklyn has 520 welfare recipeints for every 1,000 residents
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. CRIME REPORT CALLS FOR REFORM
response.abstract: Natl Advisory Comm on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals, in rept issued on Jan 14, recommends that no new major insts for juveniles be built under any circumstances and that existing ones be phased out in favor of local facilities and programs; recommends changes within prisons in areas such as disciplinary procedures, inmates' grievance procedures, freedom of speech, religious beliefs and practices, reforms of sentencing process and allowing media access to inmates; key suggestion is for unification of all correctional facilities into single agency in each state; recommends that each state, within 5 yrs, develop plan for implementing alternatives to institutionalization with emphasis on community-based alternatives to confinement
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Martin Luther King Day
response.abstract: Public schools will be closed today here and in numerous cities, including Newark, Chicago, Los Angeles, St. Louis and Atlanta, to mark the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Details are on Page 32.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pressures to Plead Guilty Alleged in Watergate Case
response.abstract: source close to Watergate case says on Jan 14 that 4 of 5 defendants are under what he terms 'great pressure' to plead guilty to charges of eavesdropping on Dem Natl Com hq last June; source refuses to name those who are said to be putting pressure on defendants, all of whom are from Miami area, but says that substantial promise of money was made to men; H R Rothblatt, lawyer for 4 defendants, refuses to discuss repts of pressure but acknowledges that he will withdraw from case if 4 men decide to plead guilty; E H Hunt Jr has already pleaded guilty
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Divorce Insurance Gains Varied Support in State
response.abstract: NYS Sen D Halperin drafts bill for study comm to weigh offering divorce ins; bill was originally offered in '72 but never got out of com; he sees prospects improved, citing pressure from such orgns as Natl Orgn to Improve Support Enforcement, founded by Mrs D Du Broff over 1 yr ago; she holds that such ins should be mandatory and govt-sponsored but expects that initially it will be provided by private cos on voluntary basis; says that policy, if marriage lasts, could be cashed in after certain period of time; Halperin comments
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Orleans Sniper
response.abstract: A week after six persons were slain by sniper fire at a New Orleans hotel, two questions are unanswered: Was there more than one sniper? If so, how was an escape made past a swarm of policemen? A study of what is known about the case appears on Page 18.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON SENDS HAIG TO SAIGON TO TALK ABOUT CEASE‐FIRE
response.abstract: Nixon illus in Key Biscayne, Fla, Jan 14, talking with Kissinger and Gen A M Haig Jr
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MRS. MEIR TO VISIT POPE PAUL TODAY
response.abstract: Israeli Premier Meir will meet Pope Paul VI on Jan 15; visit is 1st between head of Roman Cath Church and head of Israeli Govt; hundreds of Italian policemen are mobilized on Jan 14 to provide security for Meir, who arrived from Paris where she was attending meeting of Socialist Internatl; Israel and Vatican maintain no diplomatic relations, but informal contacts have been underway for long time; source in Vatican say that Pope and Meir will discuss above all status of holy places in Jerusalem and in other parts of Holy Land and chances of peaceful settlement of Middle East conflict; Vatican has insisted since birth of Israel that Jerusalem be placed under internationally guaranteed statute to protect holy places; Israel enacted special law in '67, after city's reunification in 6-day war, guaranteeing protection of holy places and free access to them for members of all religions; Israeli Embassy spokesman in Rome says Pope's invitation to Meir was conveyed to her through Israeli Amb in Rome A E Najar; Meir is scheduled to pay courtesy call on Pres G Leone and to confer with Premier G Andreotti
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Strict Auto Curb on Coast Doubted by Ruckelshaus
response.abstract: EPA Admr Ruckelshaus on Jan 15, emphasizing he is under Fed ct order, proposes 80% traffic reduction in Los Angeles basin, made effective by gasoline rationing, as only way to meet '77 air quality standards, news conf, Los Angeles; asserts he has 'grave reservations' about its feasibility; says proposal is subject to modification after forthcoming hearing on EPA plan for Calif to meet requirements of Clean Air Act and if regulations prove impossible Calif, whose Congressmen have overwhelmingly supported act, can seek legislative relief; cites Los Angeles as unique situation, but warns that some other cities may have to employ some traffic restrictions to meet standards; suggests car pooling and improved mass transit to meet transportation problem posed by regulations; EPA suggests rationing gasoline by either coupon system or 'first-come, first-served' system at gasoline stations, with their supplies limited and places controlled to prevent profiteering; repts '77 projections show Los Angeles will exceed hydrocarbon standards from all sources by 531 tons a day and if all other conceivable control measures were taken, auto pollution would still leave excess of 260 tons a day; says establishing 'vehicle-free zones,' increasing gasoline and parking taxes and limiting auto and motorcycle registrations may be used to lessen vehicle use; says long-range solution to pollution problem may be local and state land use policies that discourage low-density, spread out development involving extended car travel, limiting hwy construction and redeveloping to spread out pollution sources; stipulates that all '71-74 commercial vehicles will have to convert to low-polluting fuels by '75; Dr A J Haagen-Smit, Gov Reagan, Air Resources Bd exec dir J A Maga and Los Angeles County Supervisor E Debs comment; Mayor Yorty asserts proposal is impracticable and would bring econ to halt
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: P.S.C. PLAN OFFERS PNON&AIDCNRRGE
response.abstract: demonstration by 300 people sponsored by Community Parents Assn is held on Jan 15 at NYC Educ Bd hq to demand that Dr H B Scribner be retained as School Chancellor; Scribner announced last month that he would leave post because of widening confidence gap between himself and bd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stock Prices Plummet
response.abstract: Stock prices registered their fourth largest decline yesterday in more than two years. Traders' fears were attributed to prospects of renewed inflation and uncertainty about President Nixon's Phase 3 economic plans. The Dow‐Jones industrial av eraged slumped 13.77 points to close at 1,025.59. Earlier in the day, prices had climbed on Vietnam peace hopes. Details on Page 51.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Hijacking Case Ends in a Mistrial
response.abstract: trial ends in hung jury on Jan 15 after G Hass, member of jury, votes for acquittal despite alleged harassment by fellow jurors; Hass, who says her decision was based 'exclusively on my understanding of the evidence and upon nothing else,' is informed by Fed Judge Rosling that there will be Fed investigation into her participation in case because of 'information which has come to my attention;' lawyers for Trapnell had argued that hijacker was not guilty by reason of insanity, but Fed attys maintained Trapnell had feigned mental illness; case revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Gangs Spread Terror in the South Bronx
response.abstract: Part of NY Times series on street gangs in S Bronx, NYC, notes gangs of late '50s and early '60s disbanded after their members became heroin addicts and dropped out; finds gangs are credited for their harsh treatment of drug pushers, but that few are drug-free; finds some are used by drug dealers as armies to consolidate their power
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Garden Track Meet Will Drop U.S. Anthem to Avoid Incidents
response.abstract: J Abramson, dir of Olympic Invitational track and field meet to be held at Madison Sq Garden, NYC, on Feb 16, announces that natl anthem will not be played before meet; says that playing of anthem is not obligatory since its relevance to sports events has never been established; Madison Sq Garden official says that it will be 1st time that sports event will be held at Garden without anthem being played; controversy over playing anthem before sports events discussed; recent controversial incidents concerning anthem and athletics noted; illus; chart of words and music of anthem
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT HALTS ALL BOMBING, MINING AND SHELLING OF NORTH; POINTS TO ‘PROGRESS’ IN TALKS
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, citing 'progress' made in cease-fire talks in Paris, suspends mining, bombing and all other offensive action throughout N Vietnam on Jan 15; White House press sec Ziegler announces suspension after several hrs of consultations between Pres Nixon and H A Kissinger, news conf; this is first time that a Nixon spokesman says publicly that progress was made in latest round of Paris talks; Ziegler acknowledges repts that a cease-fire agreement was reached but does not confirm the existence of an agreement because of 'mutual agreement' with Hanoi that US will not discuss substance of Paris talks; says Kissinger will return to Paris in 'relatively near future'; Kissinger flew from Paris Jan 10 after 6 days of talks and conferred with Nixon in 3 meetings Jan 14; Nixon, Jan 14, sends Gen A M Haig Jr to Saigon to consult with Pres Thieu about Paris talks; Nixon directive on halt of mil action goes into effect at 10 AM Jan 15 and applies to action N of the 17th parallel; does not apply to mil action in S Vietnam and other countries; Ziegler, in response to query whether Hanoi will suspend mil action in South in return, says US action is 'unilateral'; says directive does not extend to deactivation of mines in N Vietnamese harbors; temporary bombing halt on Oct 25 and resumed heavy bombing on Dec 18 revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: I.B.A. TO SELL UNIT TO CONTROL DATA IN SETTLING SUITS
response.abstract: Control Data Corp and IBM announce on Jan 15 settlement of Control Data's antitrust suit against IBM and latter's subsequent counterclaims; agreement calls for IBM to sell its Service Bureau Corp subsidiary to Control Data for $16-million in cash; IBM will also pay Control Data about $60-million for various expenses and services over next 10 yrs; settlement detailed; suit's outcome is surprise to many indus observers who expected more opposition on part of Control Data pres and chmn W C Norris; effect of settlement on Justice Dept's antitrust suit against IBM is major question because dept had relied heavily on information obtained by Control Data; Norris, IBM chmn F T Cary, and several indus observers comment on settlement, which is generally considered favorable to both cos
keywords: DATA PROCESSING (INFORMATION PROCESSING) EQUIPMENT AND SYSTEMS
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 MORE ADMIT GUILTAS SPIES IN WATERGATE
response.abstract: Jan 16-31: 4 of 6 remaining defendants in Watergate trial plead guilty on Jan 15 in Fed ct to all 7 counts of indictment charging them with conspiracy, 2d-degree burglary and wiretapping; 4 are B L Barker, F A Sturgis, E R Martinez and V R Gonzales; E H Hunt Jr pleaded guilty on Jan 11; Judge Sirica questions 4 defendants about their motives for spying and about possible involvement of others and sends them to jail in lieu of $100,000 surety bonds each, to await sentencing; Sirica is openly dubious about several of defendants' responses, particulary when they said they were uncertain about source of money that was supplied to them; men deny that 'higher-ups' put pressure on them and that they were offered money to change their pleas; deny they ever worked for CIA; Sirica reads into record short lr from 4 defendants to their atty H B Rothblatt in which they said they had been asking to change their pleas since Jan 7 and that Rothblatt had not complied; Sirica names A L Newmyer to represent 4 as ct-apptd lawyer; Martinez denies he was paid to participate in spying conspiracy but acknowledges that Barker gave him $400 or $500 to cover his 'expenses'; Gonzales indicates that Barker and Hunt had said that spy operation would advance liberation of Cuba, his native land; Barker, when questioned about $114,000 in passed that passes through account he controlled in Repub Natl Bank of Miami and which had been given to Pres Nixon's campaign orgn, says he cannot state who sent that money; asserts that all of $114,000 was sent to him by mail and that he had been asked to convert it to cash; denies he used any of money to finance spying activities or for anything else; Sirica denies motion by defendants for mistrial; illus of defendants Liddy, McCord, Barker, Gonzales and Sturgis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mrs. Meir Confers With Pope in Vatican
response.abstract: Pope Paul VI, during his meeting with Israeli Premier G Meir on Jan 15, recalls history and suffering of Jewish people
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Patient and His Doctor: Quandary for Medicine
response.abstract: Article on M Blackstone, famous and wealthy entertainment publicist during '60s who is now cared for by Bowery Mission; relatives charge that Blackstone's mental and physical collapse is result of yrs of treatment by Dr M Jacobson, NYC physician who administers amphetamines to wealthy and famous patients for sole purpose of boosting their moods; Blackstone illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ENLARGED COUNCIL VETOED BY MAYOR
response.abstract: Mayor Lindsay on Jan 15 vetoes bill that would have created 6 new NYC Council Dists to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on Council; contends that there had not been sufficient public notice, awareness and debate on bill, which would have raised number of Councilmen to 43 from 37; notes that many community leaders have complained that they lacked sufficient time to study maps and hold community-level talks prior to public hearings; Council leadership spokesman terms Lindsay's position 'much nonsense'; holds there are sufficient votes to override veto; says Council will probably act next wk; 6 proposed new dists are in Bushwick-Williamsburg and Bedford Stuyvesant-Brownsville secs of Bklyn, Hunts Point area of S Bronx, Jamaica-St Albans and Springfield Gardens areas of Queens, triboro dist that includes parts of S Bronx, E Harlem and Ridgewood, Glendale, Middle Village and Maspeth secs of Quuens, Staten Island linked with lower West Side of Manhattan and another part of Staten Island linked with Bay Ridge sec of Bklyn
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Westchester Towns Pressed on Housing
response.abstract: E J Logue, pres of NYS Urban Development Corp, on Jan 16 announces that corp plans to proceed with its controversial plans to build low-income housing in 9 Westchester County towns; 4-mo moratorium on project expired Jan 15; Logue says he will hold further discussions with all towns in hopes of starting construction on some projects this spring; G Oettinger, Supervisor of New Castle, says his town is ready to fight corp in ct if it attempts to build in New Castle; Logue says that despite Fed housing freeze on subsidies, 9 projects would be still be 'marketable' as middle-income housing at rents of about $55 per room; por of Logue
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEWS INDEX
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATORS PRESS NIXON ON SECRECY
response.abstract: Sen Dem Policy Com tentatively approves resolution on Jan 16, limiting Nixon Adm's use of exec privilege, that would require any White House aide or Cabinet member to 'appear and answer all questions' unless Sen com formally consented to written plea from Pres to excuse official from testifying; under doctrine of exec privilege, White House staff members and, in some instances, officials of Cabinet rank have been shielded from Cong interrogation on ground that their confidential communications with Pres are 'privileged' because disclosure would impair orderly functioning of Govt; under resolution, Adm official who did not wish to testify and cited doctrine of exec privilege would still have to appear before Sen com, barring Pres explanation for his refusal to answer questions
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Widens Trade Role, Triples Exports to Soviet
response.abstract: US Embassy in Moscow repts on Jan 16 that US exports to USSR rose from $134-million in 1st 11 mos of '71 to $449-million in similar period of '72; says Soviet exports to US rose only from $54-million to $83-million, indicating severe imbalance of trade likely in yrs ahead unless USSR completes arrangements for large-scale sale of natural gas and other raw materials to US; econ specialists say that Soviet-Amer trade has been financed primarily by private credits; note Govt-backed credits will be needed if current rate of growth in Amer exports is to be maintained; Soviet officials are said to be pleased by prospect for major expansion in Soviet-Amer trade and chance to tap Amer tech but show uneasiness about prospective imbalance in trade; Soviet-Amer trade relations specialist E C Shershnev says it is impossible for USSR systematically to finance its purchases from US with hard currency earnings from exports to other countries, article in latest monthly issue of USA; holds one solution would be for US to remove restrictions on mutual trade, alluding to Soviet demands for equal tariff treatment in US mkt as well as large-scale credits from Export-Import Bank; says both sides should take measures for formation of balanced, mutually profitable and most efficient trade structure; sees greatest prospects in use of various forms of productive cooperation, or joint ventures
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STATE BUDGET $8.8‐BILLION; SPENDING UP $933‐MILLION, BUT NO TAX RISE IS SOUGHT
response.abstract: Gov Rockefeller presents his 15th annual budget message to NYS Legis on Jan 16
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Rage Permeates All Facets of Life in the South Bronx
response.abstract: NY Times series on life in South Bronx notes conditions under which teaching and learning takes place in ghetto schools; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lunokhod 2 on Moon
response.abstract: The Soviet unmanned craft Luna 21 has landed on the moon and delivered Lunokhod 2, the Russians' second remotely controlled vehicle, to the lunar surface to begin explorations. Details on Page 14.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BETHLEHEM STEEL REQUIRED TO BAR RACIAL INEQUITIES
response.abstract: Labor Dept, charging Bethlehem Steel Corp with failure to overcome effects of racial discrimination, on Jan 16 orders corp to make sweeping changes in seniority system at its plant in Sparrows Point, Md; Labor Sec Hodgson says system has been found to perpetuate effects of past discrimination in assignment of blacks to jobs and depts with limited advancement opportunities; says wage patterns at plant also favored white workers; co and union decline comment; ruling reverses 2-yr-old recommendation by Labor Dept panel that no change be made in system because plant's normal business would be unduly disrupted; order applies to black workers hired at plant on or before March 31, '68; Govt asserts hiring practices since then have not been discriminatory; order detailed; Hodgson illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: City and Unions Both Paid 127 Labor Leaders in '71
response.abstract: Manhattan grand jury on Jan 16 issues rept charging NYC adm with mismanagement for having allowed 127 union officials to remain on city payroll in '71 while they were receiving union salaries; practice, which jury terms 'violation' of exec order in effect since '57, means city paid about $1.5-million in '71 in salaries to officials who were simultaneously receiving about $500,000 from unions; jury asserts such an expenditure was 'unwarranted'; Manhattan Dist Atty Hogan releases rept
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIEU EXPECTED TO ACCEPT TRUCE PACT OFFICIALS SAY, THOUGH PROBLEMS REMAIN
response.abstract: brief summary of peace situation in Vietnam
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Defendant to Plead He Acted to Forestall Violence
response.abstract: Watergate lawyer G Alch says on Jan 16 that 1 of 2 remaining defendants will attempt to justify his actions on ground that he had feared violence against Pres Nixon and other leading Repubs; says J W McCord Jr will present evidence that he acted under form of 'duress'; G G Liddy is only other defendant who has not pleaded guilty; Alch says theory on which his defense of McCord will be based is variant of 'self-defense' argument; says there were 'potentially violent groups who were supporting Dems and who were in contact with party candidates; mentions Natl Peace Action Coalition, People's Coalition for Peace and Justice and Vietnam Veterans Against the War; People's Coalition calls statement 'ravings of common burglar' and Peace Action Coalition calls it 'pathetic attempt' to cut down demonstrations at Pres Nixon's inauguration; Alch makes it clear that he will suggest that McCord participated in intelligence operations to collect data on any potentially violent events possessed by Dems; number of policeman describe their arrest of 5 men at Watergate and their discovery of vast assortment of evidence
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Garden to Hear Anthem At Track Meet, After All
response.abstract: officials of Olympic Invitational track and field meet, bowing to public protest and private pressure, announce that natl anthem will be played at Feb 16 meet to be held in Madison Sq Garden, NYC; reversal comes after Garden management had announced that anthem will be played at all its future sporting events, thus nullifying contrary policy decisions by meet promotors; also comes after US Olympic Com had been deluged with 'irate' lrs and telephone calls from public protesting plans to drop playing of anthem at meet; in related development, NYC City Council introduces bill, sponsored by 20 Councilmen, including Troy and Silverman, that would make it unlawful to commence any sporting event open to public and for which admission is charged, without 1st playing natl anthem; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STOCK EXCHANGES ORDERED TO ADMIT INSTITUTION FIRMS
response.abstract: SEC on Jan 16 orders all stock exchs to accept as members any institutionally-affiliated brokerage cos that do at least 80% of their business with public, opening way for cos owned by mutual funds, pension funds and other large financial insts to hold exch seats; sets March 15 for exch's compliance with its order by writing it into their own membership rules, ordering member cos to give notice within 30 days of that date of their intention to comply or risk loss of their seats; new order provides 3-yr phase-in period for a few exchs, such as PBW Stock Exch, that accept inst investors as members and requires members of these exchs to file within same 30-day period statement of their intention to comply with uniform rule as well as detailed plan to achieve compliance; comm's definition of affiliated brokerage co detailed; speculation that comm's action may be contested in cts because of its departure from principle of exch self-regulation noted; SEC Chmn Casey comments; Sen H A Williams Jr 'extremely disappointed' with action
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIEU REPORTED TO BE OBJECTING ON 4 KEY ISSUES
response.abstract: S Vietnamese source, Jan 17, says Pres Thieu objects to 4 key issues in proposed truce accord, although he accepts the broad outlines of a draft accord; issues are: vagueness in protocols about which prisoners are to be released after a cease-fire, stationing of mixed mil comms around Vietnam, limitations on activities of mil and police units in S Vietnam and Hanoi's refusal to recognize as Saigon's territory the half of the DMZ that lies S of the demarcation line which runs through the middle of the zone; objections deal not with the main accord but with protocols; Thieu is still expected to approve the accord; objections reptdly have been conveyed to Gen A M Haig Jr, Nixon's special repr, who presented Thieu with the Vietnamese text of the draft accord on Jan 16; Haig leaves for Cambodia; objections fully detailed; in apparent effort to resolve these issues, Thieu has sent mil delegation headed by Lt Gen Vinh Loc to Paris to work on the protocols; Vietcong units in S Vietnam are being informed that a cease-fire is coming around Jan 20; mil activity remains at a low level; Saigon Govt denies CBS rept from Saigon that a cease-fire will be declared on Jan 19; map indicates cities where Thieu and Hanoi want truce supervisory units stationed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: W ome n Smokers Warned Of Fetal and Infant Risks
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 —There is strong evidence that pregnant women who smoke cigarettes are thereby increasing the risk of death of their babies, a Public Health Service report said today.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Slaying of a Black By Policeman Stirs Rich Jersey Town
response.abstract: Killing by Bernardsville, NJ, Ptl W Sorgie of 21-yr-old Negro W Wells, who grew up in Bernardsville's affluent white community, leaves community with feeling of anger, fear and frustration, particularly among young; Wells was shot to death during tavern fight in which he reptdly was not involved; Sorgie has been removed from duty with pay, pending results of county probe; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Future Looks Bleak for the South Bronx
response.abstract: Last of series of M Tolchin articles on S Bronx area of NYC questions whether present construction is too late to halt 'malignancy' that is result of decades of neglect; over last 3 yrs, NYC received $60-million in Fed funds to revive area but despite this infusion of money, divisiveness between blacks and Puerto Ricans, who comprise population of area, delayed badly-needed construction; rebuilding did not begin until 1969; now Batances Houses, with 1,000 dwelling units, is completed and Davidson Houses, with 1,530 low-income units, is under construction; area depends upon Fed aid because private builders shun S Bronx but Nixon Adm's recent freeze on housing subsidies will make it impossible to build critically needed low-income housing there; cost of rebuilding S Bronx is formidable and rebuilding housing alone is estimated at $3-billion; R Moses believes area should be leveled and people relocated elsewhere but M Gill, banker engaged in community programs, believes future of NYC depends upon solving problems in S Bronx; map; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 90‐Day Halt in L.I.R.R. Strike Arranged by Brennan
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's nominee for Labor Sec, P J Brennan, announces on Jan 17 that he has convinced URR unions and mgt to halt strike for 90 days while negotiations continue; strikers are scheduled to return to work on Jan 19, with 1st trains to run on Jan 20; workers will receive 6% wage increase retroactive to Jan 1, '72; MTA Chmn Ronan pledges that there will be no fare increase in '73; Brennan, Ronan and LIRR pres W L Schlager Jr illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Oil Import Limit Relaxed To Help Ease Fuel Crisis
response.abstract: Pres Nixon on Jan 17 suspends quota on number 2 heating oil through Apr 30 and authorizes increased imports on finished and crude oil products for states east of Rocky Mts at rate of 2.7-million bbls a day for rest of '73; Emergency Preparedness Dir Lincoln repts tight fuel situation will last all winter, news conf; scores refiners for shifting emphasis from gasoline to heating oil too late; urges refiners increase production by 5%, citing recent 6% production increase; implies price of heating oil should increase to spur refinery production, noting that freezing heating oil products at low point at outset of wage-price controls has contributed to shortage; API pres F Ikard says refinery's output ration of gasoline and heating oil can be varied slightly, but not sufficiently to make drastic supply difference; implies crude oil imports will make little impact because domestic refineries are working at capacity; Reprs Reuss and Aspin make public telegram to Nixon urging him to require Amerada Hess Corp to immediately import heating oil from its Virgin Island refinery to mainland; Reuss aide repts Amerada has rebuffed prospective customers; Amerada chmn L Hess says he has sought Interior Dept advice on allocation of fuel; Amoco Oil Co repts it has instructed dealers to give homeowners only half tank of oil instead of full tank; co vp R Leet say it will take 15 days for oil imported to east coast to reach middle west
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WATERGATE TRIAL IN CLOSED SESSION
response.abstract: Watergate trial goes into secret session on Jan 17 when key Govt witness A C Baldwin 3d is asked to name people he said he had overheard talking on wiretapped telephone in Dem Com's hq; Baldwin says he was ordered by defendant J W McCord Jr to monitor incoming and outgoing calls and that he listened to about 200 conversations last May and June; Baldwin indicates that wiretap was on telephone in office of Dem Party's Assn of State Dem Chmn exec dir R S Oliver; closed session is result of pre-trial conf in which Judge Sirica rejected atty C Morgan Jr's contention that all contents of overheard conversations should be suppressed; US Appeals Ct, however, overruled Judge Sirica on issue and all Baldwin's proposed testimony on overheard conversations is taken up in closed hearing; before closed hearing, Baldwin testified that on May 1 he accepted job offer from McCord, then security coordinator for Pres Nixon's pol orgns; Baldwin, former FBI agent, says none of wiretapped conversations were tape-recorded and that he included 'detailed contents' of each conversation in notes and turned over copies of log to McCord; says he once delivered logs to bldg occupied by Com for Re-Election of Pres; says his 1st assignment at Pres re-election com was to guard Mrs J N Mitchell, wife of com head; McCord's atty G Alch submits memorandum to Judge Sirica on Jan 17 outlining his contention that defendant was justified because he feared violence against Pres and other Repubs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Heath Asks Wide Controls In Phase 2 Inflation Fight
response.abstract: Prime Min Heath on Jan 17 announces GB's most comprehensive program of anti-inflation measures since World War II, including curbs on prices, wages, rents and dividends, news conf; plan calls for new pay bd and price comm with powers extending up to 3 yrs to restrain soaring inflation; marks Brit's Phase 2, following current short-term freeze on wages and prices; present freeze is extended to allow time for approval by Parliament; when freeze ends, limits on pay increases must be held to avg of about 7% in next yr, about 1/2 rate before freeze; action comes after Heath's failure to win support from union leaders for voluntary restraints; Phase 2 will last at least until autumn; some Brit union leaders threaten to challenge new curbs; prices are expected to rise because of imported commodities; illus of Heath addressing newsmen
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Council Bill Forbids Making Handguns; Passage Expected
response.abstract: NYC City Council's Public Safety Com passes on Jan 17 Lindsay adm sponsored bill designed to outlaw manufacture and assembly of cheap handguns, commonly known as Saturday Night Specials; Police Dept spokesman says that only major mfr of these weapons in city is CDM Products, which assembled and sold out of state estimated 50,000 handguns in '72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cahill Opposes Life For Drug Pushers
response.abstract: NJ Gov Cahill says on Jan 17 that he opposes mandatory life sentences for convicted drug pushers, as recommended by NYS Gov Rockefeller, contending that anyone seeking stiffer prison terms for such offenders 'must realize that the addicted pusher would do anything, regardless of the penalties, to support his habit,' news conf; says laws should differentiate between addict-pushers and those who traffic in narcotics to obtain money
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEWS INDEX
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: F. D. A. PROPOSES SWEEPING CHANGE IN FOOD LABELING
response.abstract: FDA announces on Jan 17 sweeping changes in food labeling practices to give consumers a bettor idea of nutritional value of foods consumed; says that it will announce in next few mos a 2d group of food labeling rules; claims that new rules will emphasize voluntary rather than compulsory compliance by indus; asserts, however, that in some cases compliance will be mandatory; consumer groups, although generally lauding new rules, maintain that voluntary nature of rules is a major flaw of relabeling program; food processors and packagers respond favorably to FDA rules; FDA officials estimate that rule changes will affect virtually all of nation's processed food, a mkt valued at $50-billion; FDA Comr Edwards calls action 'a new umbrella' over food labeling laws; adds that new labels will be more 'understandable and comprehensive'; leading nutritionist Harvard Prof J Mayer comments; 'US recommended daily allowances' will be substituted for 'FDA minimum daily requirements' as guiding line for determining major ingredients of balanced diet; new FDA regulations detailed; FDA officials say that health foods have 'no known nutritional values,' but they remain on mkt without nutritional claims; another proposed regulation sets standards of identity for dietary supplements; minor proposals dealing with exemption and inclusion of other types of foods cited; FDA's gen counsel Hutt says in next 2 mos regulations will be set forth dealing with frozen dinners and low-calorie foods; Ad Hoc Com on Food Labeling asserts that FDA has taken step forward but should have made labeling mandatory; table of recommended daily allowances of dietary supplements for various age groups; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MARCOS TIGHTENS GRIP IN MANILA BY NEW CHARTER
response.abstract: Philippines Pres Marcos, on Jan 17, consolidates his virtually unlimited power by proclaiming new Const to serve as basis for his regime, announcing indefinite continuation of martial law which he enforces as Comdr-in-Chief and suspending interim assembly that was to have served as legis under new Const; moves raise prospect of yrs of authoritarian rule for Philippines, gives Marcos right to concurrent titles of Pres and Premier; Marcos, on Jan 17, declines to be pinned down as to how long he intends to keep joint status and joint powers, speech to hand-picked assembly of about 2,000 natl reprs meeting at pres palace; reprs urge him to keep his special powers for 7 yrs; convey formally the results of opinion-sampling carried out by assemblies; Marcos, in emotional speech, tells them he rejects idea of cutting loose from all const and forming revolutionary govt; stresses that he had declared martial law legitimately and believes Govt should be based on const; in int after meeting says he will rev situation in '73 as regards continuation of his special powers; illus; spokesman for reprs at meeting says local assemblies approved new Const by large majority, favored continuation of martial law, indicated they did not favor interim assembly established by new Const and wanted Marcos to remain in power, without new elections, for long period
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Council Overrides Mayor, Enacts Bill to Add Districts
response.abstract: NYC Council, 28-7, overrides on Jan 18 Mayor Lindsay's veto of reapportionment bill designed to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on Council; Lindsay contended that there had been insufficient notice, awareness and debate by public on measure; new law will add 6 Councilmanic dists, 5 of which are expected to go to blacks or Puerto Ricans; Councilman E L Sadowsky, Queens Dem, describes Lindsay veto as 'cynical pol gesture'; new dists listed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Jury Finds Corona Guilty Of Slaying 25 workers
response.abstract: jury of 10 men and 2 women on Jan 18 convicts J V Corona of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers near Yuba City in 71; jury deliberated for nearly 1 wk before returning guilty verdict; Corona's atty R E Hawk immediately moves for retrial; Judge R E Patton sets Jan 29 as date for motions on matter; case and trial revd; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 7 Slain at Muslim House In Capital
response.abstract: 2 adults and 5 children are slain on Jan 18 in Washington, DC, house once owned by pro basketball player K Abdul-Jabbar, and presently used as hq by Hanafi sect of orthodox Moslems, sect he belongs to; 2 adult women, identified as B Khaalis and A Khaalis, are in critical condition after being shot in head; Abdul-Jabbar, who sold house to Muslims 2 yrs ago, calls slayings work of lunatics; illus

response.headline: DURATION UNSURE
response.abstract: White House press sec Ziegler announces at news briefing, Fla White House, Jan 18, that Kissinger will resume talks with Le Duc Tho and Min Xuan Thuy on Jan 23 to complete text of a peace agreement; no indication given of what is meant by completing the text; this is first time that US acknowledges existence of a draft agreement; announcement is issued simultaneously by Hanoi delegation in Paris following phone talks between Nixon, Kissinger and Haig, who has been meeting in Saigon with Pres Thieu; Ziegler says Haig, who visited leaders in Cambodia, Laos and Thailand, will confer again with Thieu on Jan 20
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ellsberg Jury Told Data Could Have Aided Enemy
response.abstract: Lt Gen W G DePuy testifies on Jan 18 that 1 of documents released through publication of Pentagon papers, '68 Joint Chiefs of Staff study, could have helped N Vietnamese and Vietcong plan last yr's Tet offensive; concedes, under cross-examination, that parts of document in question had been made public without injuring US mil position in Vietnam; reads sections of rept that he feels would damage natl security; says that section of study entitled 'enemy capabilities' could indicate to N Vietnamese if Amer and S Vietnamese intelligence is competent
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Goldwater and Stennis Tell Saigon Not to Balk
response.abstract: Sens Goldwater and Stennis, Jan 18, urge Saigon Govt not to create obstacles to peace US-Hanoi peace accord; warn that Saigon will lose support in US for further econ and mil aid if Pres Thieu blocks a settlement; both says they have no inside knowledge of peace talks details; both have close contact with US Defense Dept and White House; some of their colleagues believe they would not have made such strong statements without having had information from within US Govt that Thieu was presenting difficulties; 58 Sens led by Sen Javits offer legis aimed at restricting President's authority to involve US in undeclared wars; bill is direct outgrowth of Vietnam, but its restrictions apply only to future conflicts; pors of Sens Goldwater and Stennis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A.T&T. TO GRANT 15,000 BACK PAY IN JOB INEQUITIES
response.abstract: AT&T agrees on Jan 18 to give $15-million in back pay and $23-million a yr in raises to women and minority males against whom it has allegedly discriminated in job assignments, pay and promotions, as result of settlement of Govt's discrimination suit against co; suit involves number of principles never before put into effect in any such settlement, including concept that financial restitution must be made to certain female and minority-group employes, even though they have never applied for better-paid jobs because they knew it was co policy not to give them those jobs; about 15,000 employes are expected to share in back pay and 36,000 in raises; co officials rept that $15-million, which will be charged against '72 profits, will reduce co's per-share earnings of $4.30 by less than 2c; D Copus, head of panel on AT&T in Equal Employment Opportunities Comm, and W J Kilberg, asst solicitor of Labor Dept, say that AT&Ts agreement will serve as warning to other cos with discriminatory employment practices; settlement means that co is no longer threatened, as allegedly discriminatory employer, with revocation of its Govt contracts, and that equal employment agency will drop its attempt to block rate increases for co; AT&T vp D K Easlick says he does not think that settlement will start 'rash of rate increases' but that public will ultimately have to pay; equal employemnt agency has contended that discrimination forced up co's costs by creating artificial shortages of applicants for certain types of jobs; Natl Orgn for Women (NOW) issues statement calling $15-million in back pay 'chickenfeed' compared to $4-billion that it says is really owed to co's women employes; protests failure of agreement to require co to treat pregnancy like any other temporary disability, with employe's job assured upon her return after use of accumulated sick leave; CWA pres J A Beirne protests lack of definite deadlines for meeting goals of employment of specified percentages of women and minorities in specified job's
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AIR FORCE PICKS FAIRCHILD ON L.I. TO BUILD NEW JET
response.abstract: USAF announces on Jan 17 that it has selected Fairchild Industries Inc to produce A-10 combat aircraft, designed exclusively for providing close air support to front-line troops; aircraft described
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIEU'S POSITION
response.abstract: Saigon source close to truce negotiations says, Jan 19, that Gen Haig left Saigon Jan 18 with Pres Thieu's agreement to the gen principles of a cease-fire accord but without resolving disagreements on several questions about carrying out the accord; source speaks before joint US-Hanoi announcement that Kissinger will resume talks with Le Duc Tho on Jan 23; repts Haig left for Cambodia; another source says Thieu explained his reservation to Haig at Jan 17 meeting; Thieu's objections said to center on questions relating to release of Vietnamese POWs, stationing of mixed mil comms around S Vietnam to supervise cease-fire, limitations on activities of mil and police units in the South, and the definition of the DMZ; Haig reptdly said that many of the accord details had already been agreed upon and perhaps could not be changed; Saigon is reptdly unlikely to remain adamant about changes; Thieu sends Tran Van Don to Paris Jan 18 and will send mil group headed by Gen Vinh Loc on Jan 19; Min Tran Van Lam says in radio int taped before Haig's arrival that Saigon will not sign accord bearing Provisional Revolutionary Govt signature; int published Jan 18 in Govt-controlled paper Tin Song; sources close to accord text say it does not refer to the Communists as the PRG; accord will also apply to Laos and Cambodia, but it is not clear whether cease-fire there will be simultaneous with or follow one in S Vietnam; Thieu has insisted on a halt in all 3 countries at same time; Saigon mil comdrs say they expect Communists to open one more big offensive to press for advantage just before a cease-fire; Thieu briefs mil comdrs to prepare for this and subsequent phases of a cease-fire; Saigon source says that pro-Saigon Govt Sen Nguyen Van Ngai, who told Amer TV audiences earlier in wk that no peace agreement was likely, is in bad odor with Saigon because Saigon wished to create impression of good-will and flexibility in view of possibility that US Cong will act to end the war if Nixon Adm does not
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Metropolitan Reattributes 300 Paintings
response.abstract: Met Museum reattributes about 300 Old Master paintings, downgrading many, in major re-evaluation of its collection; changes in attribution, which have been under consideration in some instances for several yrs, involve many of museum's best-known works; sweeping nature of changes, which affect about 15% of museum's Eur painting collection and which have been made recently without museum's customary fanfare by merely rewriting the labels, is believed to be without precedent among major art insts; in most instances, new attributions are given to member of Old Master's workshop to conform with consensus of contemporary scholarship; paintings such as Velazquez's Portrait of Philip IV and Rembrandt's Old Woman Cutting Her Nails are now considered 'workshop pictures' by museum, pictures executed in the studio, probably by assistant or follower; E Fahy, museum curator in charge of dept of Eur paintings who came to museum with responsibility of rehanging Met's paintings in new wing, says museum decision to take labels off frames and put new ones on walls to side or beneath paintings means label copy could be completely rewritten and amplified with much more information about each picture; J Walsh, Fahy's asst, says that of museum's 38 Rembrandts, 8 were reattributed at time of rehanging, 6 were recently changed and 2 are considered doubtful; notes older generations of experts took more permissive view of matter of attributions than most scholars today; other art scholars comment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Public‐Housing Income Limit Is Raised
response.abstract: S Golar, chmn of NYC Housing Authority, announces at news conf on Jan 18 that higher income limits have been set for entry into public housing projects in NYC in effort to keep them from becoming econ and racial ghettos; says income limits are 20% higher with approval of state and Fed Govts, which share cost of bldg and operating projects; action permits enlarging pool of 155,000 families now on waiting list, which is 88% black or Spanish-speaking; Golar says it is important to maintain integrated community and that raising income limits will increase pool of white applicants and higher-income black and Puerto Rican applicants; chart gives old and new admission income limits according to size of apt and type of project
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LAIRD URGES PACT OH VIETNAM ARMS
response.abstract: US Sec Laird urges pact between USSR, China and US to hold down future deliveries of weapons to Vietnam, impromptu farewell news conf, Jan 19; says this is one of the most important negotiating efforts that should follow a cease-fire; says USSR's wish for expanded trade with US is 'strongest weapon' US has for such negotiations; hopes for lasting peace from Paris talks, but is not willing to predict an end to fighting in Indochina one, five or even ten yrs from now; says Nixon Adm has provided Saigon Govt with all it needs for its defense; silent on whether US will be willing in the future to use air and sea power in Vietnam if Saigon should prove incapable of protecting itself; silent on whether US plans to cut back on its air and sea power in the Indochina area after a cease-fire; says USS Saratoga is returning to US, but adds that USS Constellation is headed out to replace her; cites his disappointment on assuming office 4 yrs ago to find there was no approved plan to provide Saigon with weapons and training to defend itself against Hanoi; says there was only a plan for defense against the Vietcong
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Output Rose in 1972 As Inflation Rate Slowed
response.abstract: Commerce Dept repts on Jan 19 that '72 'real' GNP rose 6.5% and that inflation was at lowest rate since '66; GNP, in preliminary rept, rose $101.7-billion to $1,152-billion; percentage increase of 9.7%, including effect of rising prices, is largest in 2 decades; annual rate of 'real' growth in 4th qr was 8.5%, faster than pace for yr as whole; inflation, as measured by GNP price index, was 3% for yr and 2.7% for 4th qr; figures indicate nation's best over-all econ performance since middle of last decade; also indicate pace of econ expansion was accelerating in final mos of yr; Acting Asst Sec Manus says most of Nixon's econ goals for '72 were achieved or exceeded
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon Takes Oath Today for 2d Term
response.abstract: Pres Nixon will be sworn into office for 2d term on Jan 20; inauguration is most expensive in Amer history: cost is officially estimated at more than $4-million; Nixon will take oath on temporary stand outside east front of Capitol, then ride in parade; estimated 20,000 demonstrators are expected in Washington; People's Coalition for Peace and Justice deliver carton of peace-now petitions containing more than 50,000 signatures to White House guards on Jan 19; Nixon will take oath on same 2 family Bibles he used when he was sworn into office as Vice Pres in '53 and '57 and as Pres in '69; Vice Pres Agnew will also be sworn into office; illus of Pres Nixon and official inaugural seal
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Policeman Killed, 2 Wounded in Siege In Brooklyn as Robbers Hold Hostages
response.abstract: 4 robbers trapped in John & Al's Sports Inc, Bklyn sporting goods store, with arsenal of weapons and 11 terrified hostages, shoot and kill NYC Ptl S Gilroy and wound Ptl J Adorno and F Carpentier in raging gunbattle on Jan 19 with hundreds of police; gunmen, identified as 4 blacks in their 20s, release 2 hostages, J Malavet, 20, and M Zayas, both unharmed; 9 other hostages remain inside store; Malavet repts to police that 1 of gunmen was injured during shootout with police and this rept is confirmed when gunmen call for police to send dr into store; police refuse request; police officials at scene, including Deputy Comr Kellerman, say that no further attempt to invade store will be made at present time; illus

response.headline: Key to Apartheid Is Complexity of Laws
response.abstract: NY Times survey on S African radal doctrine finds that apartheid policy has evolved through legal bureaucracy, differentiating S Africa from hatred, discrimination and racial practices common to much of rest of world; notes that while Govt has moved in some ways toward more stringent application of racial policies, in certain matters it has become more moderate; 1 factor that makes racial situation almost unique is that it is so closely linked to pol power; white policy, to some extent, is still directed at maintenance of soc status quo, but to significant extent that policy is directed at creation of new pol order designed to solve' problem of minority status; more than 2.3-million white Afrikaners and 1.5-million English-speaking whites make up about 17% of population; there are more than 15-million black Africans, more than 2-million people of mixed blood, known as coloreds, and about 640,000 Indians; apartheid under late Prime Min Verwoerd evolved into more coherent doctrine called separate development, which is meant to solve S Africa's racial and pol problem by exploiting black nationalism; each of 9 major Bantu tribal groups is to become nation and its homeland is eventually supposed to become ind country; homelands currently have varying degrees of limited self-govt; policy of influx control and residence by blacks in white areas described; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Theft Haul At Building Sites Put In Millions
response.abstract: Thefts of expensive construction equipment are causing construction indus and law-enforcement officials increasing concern; P J Walsh, security dir of Bldg Trades Employers Assn, places annual loss in NYC at about $3-million; dist atty's office estimates loss of material and equipment at about $10-million annually; estimates do not include cost or work stoppages or contract penalties that result from thefts; indus reprs have been meeting with city officials and law-enforcement agencies in attempt to find ways to curb thefts; many contractors attribute losses to workers or drug addicts; law enforcement officers suspect organized crime is major factor but have not been able to establish any direct links; part of traffic in stolen goods is interstate and some may be internatl

response.headline: LAZAR FORESEES IMPROVED TAXIS
response.abstract: NYC Taxi Comm Chmn Lazar says taxicabs will be safer and more comfortable within next 2 mos and that '73 could bring 'an end to the gypsy-cab problem,' int with NY Times eds and reporters; says about 5,000 livery license plates, used by most operators of so-called gypsy cabs, were not renewed in '73; discloses that additional 1,000 nonmedallion cabs have been licensed by city as 'limousines,' with 3,000 additional applications for limousine licenses pending; says limousine license plate entitles its holder to carry passenger for hire but not to answer hails from st; A Andrews, Bklyn atty who represents nonmedallion drivers, agrees that number of gypsy drivers probably has dwindled but doubts that non-renewal figure was 5,000; accuses police and comm inspectors of 'entrapment and harassment' in their attempt to drive nonmedallion drivers off sts; Lazar insists that comm inspectors only go after flagrant violators of law against cruising by nonmedallion cabs; is 'much heartened' by stepped-up police action against gypsy operators; reveals that 1,000 Chevrolet taxis have been banned because they do not meet comm specifications; contends he was 'really taken in by GM'; says Chrysler Corp engineers have told him that they could design and build ideal taxi for NYC if taxi owners would commit themselves to purchasing 3,000 cars each yr; praises Checker cabs and notes that more and more fleets are switching over to them; says he probably will leave comm 'in another year'; illus

response.headline: Jersey Investigates Alleged Conspiracy Against Legislator
response.abstract: NJ law-enforcement authorities on Jan 21 rept that they are investigating an alleged conspiracy to plant narcotics in home of Dem NJ legislator and have identified aides of Repub State Sen as prime suspects; alleged victim, K A Gewertz, Gloucester County Assemblyman, asserts conspiracy is 'cold, calculated, well-planned conspiracy to destroy me personally, along with my family'; high state police officials say that arrests are imminent and that suspects include close associates of State Sen J M Turner, Gloucester County Repub; Turner declares he is 'dumbstruck'; shouts that he is victim of plot to destroy him politically; last fall, authorities were tipped to alleged attempt to plant amphetamines in Gewertz's home and in his automobile; asked Gerwertz if they could search his home; subsequently found drugs

response.headline: Robbers Give Up Vow to Die For ‘Victory and Paradise’
response.abstract: 2-day ordeal of blazing gunfights, death and terror at John & Al's sporting goods store ends on Jan 21 with daring roof escape by 9 remaining hostages and, several hrs later, peaceful surrender of 4 entrapped gunmen; police identify 4 gunmen by their Muslim names as S A Agdullah, D A Ar-Raahman, S A Rahemm (C E Robinson) and A Almussudug; police say that they are searching for 5th member of group, who is said to have been driving getaway car and escaped when police interrupted holdup; hostage J Riccio, 1 of store owners, comments on how hostages escaped; M Robinson and G Thomas, relatives of gunmen, are instrumental in having gunmen surrender; Lindsay and Police Comr Murphy praise police for their efforts in handling siege and Dr T W Matthew for his work in treating wounded gunman and serving as liaison between gunmen and police; Bklyn Dist Atty Gold says gunmen will be charged with murder of Ptl Gilroy, attempted murder of Ptl Adorno and Carpentier, kidnapping of hostages and robbery of store; hostages listed; chronology of events during 47-hr siege; diagram of hostages escape route; illus

response.headline: Air Force Doctors Said to Take Part In Indochina Raids
response.abstract: 2 unnamed mil physicians, one in personal visit and the other in a lr to the office of Sen H E Hughes, in last 12 days, charge that some of their med colleagues have actively participated in dozens of bombing raids against enemy targets in S Vietnam and Laos; 2 drs, still on active duty in USAF, say USAF flight surgeons had operated weapons systems aboard F-4 Phantom jets; 2 drs provided their names but asked that they not be made public; Hughes says he was provided with names of about 6 other USAF drs who would further document the allegations; Hughes releases lr to NY Times and discusses dr's visit in int; Col C E Raisor, special assistant to USAF Surgeon Gen, is extremely 'dubious' about the allegations; says 7th Air Force hq in Saigon has been asked to investigate; excerpt from dr's lr cites how a flight surgeon was urged prior to his combat flight not to carry his identification and Geneva Conv cds; Hughes says he asked Sec Laird to investigate; says drs who chose not to fly were occasionally subjected to pressures from superior officer and colleagues

response.headline: 3.7 MILLION CARS RECALLED BY G.M. TO CORRECT FLAW
response.abstract: GM on Jan 22 recalls 3.7 million '71 and '72 full-size Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile models to install shield at bottom of cars to keep gravel from bouncing into steering mechanism; insists trouble is rare and rejected idea of recall in '72; recd repts of 96 incidents allegedly tied to problem; says 23 accidents occurred and 12 persons were injured because of jammed steering mechanism; recall is 1 of largest but does not match recall of 6.7 million GM cars in '71 or 4.4 million Fords last June to correct safety defects; R Nader has criticized GM for its failure to recall cars to correct steering problem, and Natl Hwy Traffic Safety Adm issued consumer warning bulletin last Aug; GM says it does not believe safety hazard is serious but offers to repair cars without charge; says it has no repts of deaths resulting from accidents; estimates each installation will cost about $3
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Iceland Evacuates 7,000 on Isle After an Ancient Volcano Erupts
response.abstract: Iceland: Volcano on island of Heimaey, Iceland, dormant for over 1,000 yrs, erupts, forcing evacuation of 7,000 residents; police authorities say boats and planes are being used to evacuate inhabitants of Vestmannaeyjar to safety on mainland; rept hail of ash from volcano of Helgafell is making operations from island's airstrip dif ficult; rept stream of molten lava also threatens to seal off harbor, trapping boats; note lava is flowing away from town, into Atlantic, but that situation could change at any time; rept nation's fishing fleet, Coast Guard vessels and other merchant ships have been ordered to island; rept small earthquake on Jan 22 heralded eruption; telephoned repts to Reykjavik say fissure 2-3,000 yds long opened and is spewing out lava and ash; USAF has reptdly promised to sendhelicopters; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pilgrims' Jet Crashes in Nigeria; 180 Are Feared Dead, a Record
response.abstract: Royal Jordanian Airlines: Chartered Boeing 707 owned by Royal Jordanian Airlines with 202 passengers aboard--mostly Nigerian Moslems returning from pilgrimage to Mecca-crashes during landing at fog-shrouded airport in Kano, Nigeria, on Jan 22 killing 180, worst air crash in history of civil aviation; witnesses describe crash; pilot and other crew members reptdly are among survivors; other similar crashes listed; map of craft's route from Mecca, Saudi Arabia, to Kano, Nigeria
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: National Guidelines Set by7‐to 2 Vote
response.abstract: US Sup Ct, 7-2, on Jan 22 overrules all state laws that prohibit or restrict woman's right to obtain an abortion during 1st 3 mos of pregnancy; Ct, in historic resolution of controversial abortion issue, drafts new set of guidelines that will result in broadly liberalized anti-abortion laws in 46 states but will not abolish restrictions completely; establishes detailed timetable for relative legal rights of pregnant women and states that will control their acts; specifies that for 1st 3 mos of pregnancy, decision to have abortion lies with woman and her dr, for next 6 mos of pregnancy state may 'regulate abortion procedure in ways that are reasonably related to maternal health and for last 10 wks of pregnancy, period during which fetus is judged to be capable of surviving if born, any state may prohibit abortions, except where they may be necessary to preserve life or health of mother; Ct action will not affect existing laws in NY, Alaska, Hawaii and Washington, where abortions are legally available; basic Texas case decided by Ct will invalidate strict anti-abortion laws in 31 states; 2d decision involving Ga will require considerable rewriting of more liberal statutes in 15 others; Justice Blackmun wrote majority opinion in which Chief Justice Burger and Justices Douglas, Brennan, Stewart, Marshall and Powell joined; Justices White and Rehnquist dissented; White calls decision 'exercise of raw judicial power'; Ct's decision opposes Pres Nixon's views, expressed in lr to 'Cardinal Cooke last May; majority of justices reject idea that fetus becomes 'person' upon conception and is entitled to due process and equal protection guarantees of Const; in decisions on Ga and Texas cases, plaintiffs based their protest on assertion that state laws limiting availability of abortion had circumscribed rights and freedoms guaranteed them by Const: due process of law, equal protection of laws, freedom of action and privacy involving personal and family matter; cases described
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Leader of Hanafis Calls for Muhammad Ouster

response.abstract: ruling appears to quash hopes of Right to Life and other anti-abortion groups for full-scale debate in NYS Legis in 73 on repealing state's liberalized abortion law; NYS law permits women to have abortion on demand until 24th wk of pregnancy; Assemblyman Cook says decision renders efforts by anti-abortion lobbyists to force it to floors of Sen and Assembly 'useless show of strength'; Assembly Speaker Duryea says it would be 'futile' to bring repeal legis up for debate again; well-organized opponents of liberalized abortion law succeeded in having it repealed in both houses in '72 despite pledge by Gov Rockefeller that he would veto repeal measure; E J Golden, chmn of NYS Right to Life Com, says 'virtually all protection under law has been stripped from unborn child'; Assemblyman Blumenthal, who pioneered enactment of '70 liberalized law, and Repr Abzug hail decision

response.headline: STRICKEN AT HOME
response.abstract: L B Johnson, 36th US Pres, dies on Jan 22 of apparent heart attack suffered at his ranch in Johnson City, Tex; was 64; funeral will probably be held on Jan 25 at Natl City Christian Church in Washington, DC; body will lie in state at Johnson Library in Austin from noon Jan 23 to 8 AM Jan 24, with honor guard, and then will be taken to Washington, where it will lie in state at Capitol until funeral; Johnson will be buried at LBJ Ranch; Johnson left legacy of progress and innovation in civil rights, Social Security, educ, housing and other soc programs; dies in waning days of a Vietnam war which seemingly caused his decision on March 31, '68 not to seek 2d term as Pres; became Pres on Nov 22, '63, following Pres Kennedy's assassination; dies 2 days following inauguration of R M Nixon; account of death; Johnson's recent activities noted; Johnson por; illus of Johnson and wife

response.headline: KISSINGER IN PARIS; CEREMONIAL SITE CHOSEN FOR TALKS
response.abstract: Kissinger arrives in Paris Jan 22; will start talks with Le Duc Tho Jan 23 at Internatl Conf Center; choice of location suggests that 2 sides consider Jan 23 session important; Kissinger goes to residence of Saigon Min Tran Van Lam, who arrived from Saigon, the first time he came to Paris during the talks; Lam is expected to sign for S Vietnam when the other foreign mins gather in Paris for the formal ceremony; Mrs Nguyen Thi Binh confers with Hanoi negotiators; S Vietnamese representing exile factions have been almost totally excluded from the peace talks; some of the groups have announced there are large segments of the S Vietnamese population who support neither Pres Thieu nor the Communists; groups have been unable to coalesce and prospects are that they will have little to say in crucial period just after a cease-fire when Saigon and Vietcong jockey for pol position; Kissinger illus leaving US for Paris

response.headline: MITCHELL LINKED TO $199,000 FUND
response.abstract: Watergate witness H W Sloan Jr, former treas of Finance Com to Re-Elect Pres, says on Jan 23 that $199,000 was paid to defendant G G Liddy, atty for Pres Nixon's campaign orgn, with approval of former Atty Gen J N Mitchell and former Commerce Sec M H Stans; says he is unaware of what Liddy did with money and gives no indication that either Mitchell or Stans knew reason for disbursements; Judge Sirica questions Sloan himself; Sloan describes encounter with Liddy at re-election com offices day following Watergate arrests during which he says Liddy stated 'My boys got caught last night'; J S Magruder testifies that Nixon orgn budgeted about $235,000 for intelligence operation, assigned to Liddy, which was to learn plans of radical groups that might disrupt pol rallies for Nixon's leading supporters and that might 'possibly bodily harm' Pres surrogates and to discover intentions of demonstrators at Repub Natl Conv; says there were other intelligence assignments; Magruder establishes for 1st time that Liddy was hired by re-election com on recommendation of J W Dean 3d, counsel to Pres; R C Odle Jr and H L Porter also testify

response.headline: War Leaves Deep Mark on U.S.
response.abstract: J Reston on effect of Vietnam war on US; says impact of war is likely to influence US life for many yrs to come; says war caused decline in respect not only for civil authority of govt but also for the moral authority of the schools, press, church and even the family; says it weakened respect for the executives 'who got the nation involved in the war in the first place,' for the Cong who let it go on and for dem process of debate, which failed to influence the course of the war; foresees considerable contention in US over whether challenges to authority are good or bad; sees Amer less confident about many things they took for granted; article also discusses effect of war on internatl relations; says it is less clear that war lessons have been learned in Washington; says habit of centralizing foreign-policy decision in White House, where so many Vietnam blunders were made, persists, as does the heavy influence of mil on foreign policy; lists various consequences of the war Nixon will have to deal with in US

response.headline: Stocks Tumble Despite Accord
response.abstract: The nation's financial markets moved sharply lower yesterday following President Nixon's disclosure Tuesday night that a cease‐fire agreement had been initialed. Investors were said to be focusing on the outlook for inflation, tight money and high interest rates under Phase 3—instead of on the approaching cease‐fire. Wall Street had been anticipating an end to the Vietnam war.
