response.headline: BONN BUYS AGAIN TO ASSIST DOLLAR
response.abstract: W Ger specialists suggest on Feb 6 that latest flood of speculative dollars into country was stirred by rept that country's trade surplus in '72 amtd to 20.25-billion marks (more than $6-billion); note most of trade surplus was offset by such things as 12.4-billion marks of transfers and services deficit of 6-billion marks
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2 PRIMARY DATES ARE SET FOR CITY
response.abstract: NYC voters will go to polls in June 28 primary election to vote for some NYS officials
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 3 BANKS RESCIND LOAN‐RATE RISES UNDER PRESSURE
response.abstract: Under heavy pressure, from the Administration, three major banks reduced yesterday their prime lending rates to 6 per cent, thus rescinding the quarter‐point increases they posted on Monday.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 25,000 Welfare Families In Projects Get Rent Cuts
response.abstract: NYC Housing Authority Chmn S Golar announces on Feb 6 that rents for more than 25,000 welfare families living in NYC public housing will be reduced by an avg of $40 a mo beginning June 1 because of new Fed subsidy payments to city's Housing Authority; welfare payments for these families will not be reduced, giving them an avg $40-a-mo increase in disposable income; in addition, rent reductions are retroactive to Dec 22 '71, so that affected families will also receive refund payments averaging more than $400; retroactive payments will total nearly $9-million and will be paid for out of $44.8-million subsidy provided to Housing Authority on Feb 6 by US HUD Dept; subsidy is to help authority close anticipated gap between income and operating costs in federally subsidized apts this yr; Golar, while welcoming Fed subsidy funds, charges that laws authorizing them--which prohibit reduction of affected families' welfare payments--unfairly create 2 sets of welfare families in city; asserts unequal treatment extends to within city's public-housing population because 20,000 welfare families in projects will not have rents cut; only welfare tenants in federally subsidized public housing are affected by new subsidies; tenants in apts built with state or city assistance are not involved; of NYC's 159,000 public-housing apts, 88,000 were built with Fed subsidies and 71,000 with state and city aid; according to HUD, rent reduction and increased net income for benefiting families are a result of Cong actions in '69 and '71; before reduction, welfare tenants in public housing were paying an avg of $99-a-mo rent
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: White House Aide Termed A Liddy‐Segretti Contact
response.abstract: Govt official says at least 3 White House officials knew of and initially aided pol intelligence operations led by G G Liddy and E H Hunt Jr as early as Feb '72; says G C Strachan, former staff asst to H R Haldeman, Pres Nixon's chief of staff, served as initial contact between Liddy's intelligence operations and pol espionage and sabotage campaign allegedly managed by D H Segretti; charge is 1st linking White House official to Liddy and Hunt, members of Watergate bugging team; White House officials have repeatedly denied any involvement in or knowledge of such activities before June 17 arrests at Dem Natl hq; Strachan allegedly supplied Calif telephone number of Segretti to Liddy some time last Feb supposedly after Liddy complained that separate Segretti operation was 'hurting us'; at time of Liddy contact, Strachan was working closely with D Chapin, Pres Nixon's apptmts sec, who has acknowledged to Govt investigators according to source, that he and Strachan were White House contact points for Segretti; source says Chapin, Strachan and Segretti became friends in early '60s at college
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kenny Is Paroled; Ill Health Is Cited
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 —John V. Kenny, a former mayor of Jersey City and Democratic leader of Hudson County who was sentenced to prison last May for Federal income tax evasion, was granted parole today after serving less than half of his 18‐month sentence.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. STEPPING UP ATTEMPT TO GAIN LAOS CEASE‐FIRE
response.abstract: White House press sec Ziegler announces on Feb 6 that H A Kissinger's forthcoming Asian trip will include stop in Laos for talks with Laotian leaders on efforts to bring about an early cease-fire in guerrilla warfare
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Official Upholds Nixon By JAMES M. NAUGHTON
response.abstract: new Deputy Atty Gen J T Sneed tells members of Sen Judiciary Subcom on Separation of Powers on Feb 6 that Pres Nixon has implied constitutional right to refuse to spend money as Cong directs; Sen Subcom says Nixon Adm is trying to rewrite Constitution; Repub Cong leaders declare after meeting with Nixon that Pres is determined to hold down Fed spending and can veto 'very substantial' number of appropriation measures if they conflict with White House goal; schedules floor action for Feb 7 on proposal that would require Nixon to release $225-million in rural conservation fund that White House has withheld from current budget; Sneed says proposal to force Nixon to seek Cong approval each time he wants to impound appropriated funds is probably unconstitutional and would reduce Pres to status of 'chief clerk'; disavows '69 memorandum in which former Asst Atty Gen W H Rehnquist advised White House that refusal to spend appropriated money 'is supported by neither reason nor precedent'; illus of Sen Ervin and staff member R Edminston
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stennis Has Surgery
response.abstract: Senator John C. Stennis, who was shot a week ago in a holdup, underwent emergency surgery, yesterday for internal complications. His condition was described as “grave” at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Page 44.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Meskill's New Budget Calls for Tax Cut
response.abstract: Conn Gov T J Meskill on Feb 6 says spending for pollution control will increase in '74, budget message
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PENNSY IS FACING A MIDNIGHT STRIKE
response.abstract: UTU and Govt on Feb 6 warn that Penn Central RR is faced with strike on Feb 8, when 30-day cooling-off period in dispute between rr and union over size of train crews expires; rr trustee says line will not delay implementation of plan to reduce size of crews from 3 men to 2; effects of possible strike noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SLAYING SUSPECT SEIZED IN MANHUNT
response.abstract: J Hoover surrenders to team of police searchers 7 hrs after allegedly killing his sister's fiance G R Winch and critically wounding his brother K Hoover and friend K Widdis; shootings occurred in Parsippany-Troy Hills Township, NJ; police decline to speculate on motive for shootings but noted Hoover had history of mental illness; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Flu Vaccine May Fight Strains of Future
response.abstract: Research team at Pasteur Inst in Paris produces influenza vaccine that researchers believe will be effective against strains of the disease yet to evolve; expects it to provide protection against flu viruses that will not appear in human population before '78; influenza virus strains drift' or evolve so that antibodies generated in body for original strain become less effective; vaccine producers are engaged in continuous race to keep up with drift; 'forced' evolution of virus in laboratory was proposed in order to produce future strains and vaccines against them before they appear in population; is accomplished by constantly attacking virus in laboratory with antibodies, but by the time vaccine is produced, virus is changed and unaffected by antibodies produced by earlier form; vaccine producers expect this is true of new vaccine; Pasteur group, headed by Dr C Hannoun and including Dr F de Saint Groth, appears confident that vaccine is effective, based on laboratory development of Hong Kong flu from its original '68 form along parallel lines to those of its development in population; contends vaccine jumps 5 yrs ahead of natural drift of virus; illus of Hannoun
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO REQUIRE NIXON TO RELEASE FUND
response.abstract: US HR, in defiance of Pres Nixon, votes on Feb 7 to require Agr Dept to spend $210-million that Adm had refused to release for Rural Environmental Assistance Program; vote, however, fails to get 2/3 majority facing possibility of Presidential veto; action considered 1st major test of Pres' refusal to spend some $8-billion appropriated by Cong for domestic programs; Sen is expected to go along with HR on rural conservation program; conservation program, in existence for over 4 decades, provides direct grants to farmers for soil and water conservation practices; Agr Sec Butz testifies that rural environmental program involves only 20% of nation's farmers in any given yr; says that if conservation practices were considered important enough, farm communities could allocate funds for program from gen revenue-sharing grants received from Govt; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Emergency Service Ready To Help Stranded Riders
response.abstract: commuters and transportation auths on Feb 7 begin preparing alternate means of transportation during Penn Central strike; car pools are formed, hundreds of extra buses scheduled, parking restrictions in city eased, and additional commuter service is planned on lines not affected by Penn Central walkout; affected lines listed; alternate services detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Catholic Funeral Cortege Raked by Ulster Gunmen
response.abstract: N Ireland erupts in widespread violence on Feb 7 after gunmen fire into procession of hundreds of Roman Caths following coffins of 3 members of Provisional wing of IRA who were killed recently by Brit troops; 2 people are injured in procession; aside from those wounded at funeral, Brit soldier is shot and 8 gunmen are reptd hit by fire from Brit troops; 1 Prot dies later and 3 unidentified bodies are found; fireman is shot fatally while fighting fire in downtown Belfast; rampant shooting, rioting, looting and intimidation coincide with 1-day strike called by Prot militant groups; just about everything stops in Belfast except fighting; Prot extremists appear to be warning Brit Govt that they will not tolerate 'sellout' to Cath minority on future of N Ireland; Prot youths attack home of Cath priest Rev J Courtney and wreck inside of his church; W Whitelaw, Brit admr of N Ireland, says demonstrations and violence will not influence Brit policy; 1-day strike was called by W Craig, former Home Affairs Min who is leader of Vanguard Movement, Prot group, after Brit troops detained 2 Prots under emergency powers for involvement in tossing of hand grenade into busload of Cath workmen, 1 of whom was killed; detention law had previously been applied only to suspected Cath terrorists
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 500 Police Told to Write Name Signed on Drug‐Theft Vouchers
response.abstract: 500 NYC policemen have been requested by Police Dept to write out 10 times signature of J N Nunziata, narcotics detective who has been connected with thefts or large quantities of drugs from dept, and who allegedly committed suicide in '72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SUNDAY RELEASE OPEL'S EXPECTED
response.abstract: Pentagon sources say Feb 7 that Communist forces plan to release 27 Amer prisoners of war Feb 11 from jungle camps in South Vietnam; Defense Dept spokesman Deputy Asst Sec Friedheim later denies report; Communists hold 456 Amer prisoners of war in N Vietnam, 7 in Laos, and 99 in South Vietnam
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Chapin Said to Have Told Nixon Aide to Pay Segretti
response.abstract: Govt sources say that former White House aide D L Chapin told FBI that he directed H W Kalmbach, Pres Nixon's personal atty, to pay D H Segretti for alleged spying and sabotage activities against Dems, in '71 and last yr; sources acknowledge that number of key questions about Watergate bugging incident remain unanswered as neither Chapin nor Kalmbach was called to testify before grand jury; key question is who ordered Chapin to tell Kalmbach to start paying Segretti and how, if at all, payments were recorded; NY Times reptd on Feb 7 that G C Strachan, aide to H Haldeman, White House chief of staff, knew of pol intelligence operations led by G G Liddy and E H Hunt Jr as early as Feb '72, 4 mos before arrest of 5 men inside Dem hq; White House press sec Ziegler says on Feb 7 that Haldeman had in no way been involved with either Liddy-Hunt intelligence operation or apparently separate 1 headed by Segretti, news conf; refuses to comment on allegations linking Strachan to knowledge of Liddy-Hunt operation; information about Chapin and Kalmbach is 1st indication that Chapin was involved in directing some aspects of financing behind pol espionage and sabotage operation with funds Fed officials believe came from Repub campaign contributions; it is also learned that Chapin, using code name 'Chapman,' supplied pol intelligence to former Atty Gen Mitchell; in deposition in connection with civil suit, made public on Feb 6, Mitchell says Nixon campaign received confidential information supplied by newsman traveling with Dem Pres candidates last yr; says newsman was only identified in repts as 'Chapman's friend', code name that was also used for same kind of information in '68 Pres campaign; Chapin illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ELLSBERG JUDGE BARS ONE CHARGE
response.abstract: Judge W M Byrne Jr, presiding in Pentagon papers case, on Feb 7 precludes Govt from presenting evidence on 1 of top secret volumes in case because exculpatory evidence exists on it; document in question is memorandum on '54 Geneva Accords; Byrne orders that all Govt witnesses appear before him before they give testimony; says he wants to find out whether they have been told not to allow defense attys to int them in preparing to defend case; count 8 in indictment in trial accuses Ellsberg of taking Geneva Accords memorandum illegally from Rand Corp office in Santa Monica, Calif, 'for the purpose of obtaining information about the national defense'; Govt, to prove espionage, must show defendants' alleged illegal acts were related and damaging to natl defense; Byrne says he precluded Govt from presenting evidence about Accords because Govt had not told him that its own analysts had concluded that document could have no effect on natl security when released
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEWS INDEX
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Israelis Hear Iraqis Executed Nine Jews
response.abstract: Repts reaching Israeli Govt say 9 or 10 prominent members of dwindling Jewish community in Iraq were executed in prison during last few wks; victims are said to include well-known physician E Khazam, lawyer Y A Aziz and several prosperous businessmen in Baghdad; repts, which Israeli official describes as '99% certain,' say victims were taken from their homes in wave of arrests that began in Sept '72; say victims' property was confiscated, their homes boarded up and word 'gone' smeared in red paint on their front doors; Iraqi Govt has refused to confirm even reptd arrests despite numerous requests from foreign govts and humanitarian orgns; only official Iraqi comment was carefully worded statement issued by Iraqi Embassy in Paris recently that 'no single Jew is in a Iraqi prison for political or religious reasons'; repts are raising fears in Israel that wave of arrests and persecution similar to that of '69 may be under way in Iraq; 14 persons, including 9 Jews, were accused of espionage in Jan '69, tried by mil ct and hanged in public squares in Baghdad and Basra; Israeli authorities estimate that there are 400 Jews left in Iraq, compared with 4,000 before '67 Arab-Israeli war; Israeli officials say liberalized policy made official on Nov 15, '72, when Iraqi UN Special Political Com repr declared that Iraq's Jews were free to emigrate, has been revised; in addition to doctor and lawyer, those reptd executed in Jan are said to include A Shamash, S Rejwan, Y Rejwan, E A Daud, S Sadka, M Sitiat and E Shemtov
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DOLLAR OFF AGAIN; BONN CURBS BANKS
response.abstract: dollar weakens against world's major currencies on Feb 7; Bundesbank sharply reduces lending capacity of W Ger's banks in effort to curb inflationary effects of flood of dollars pouring into country; is forced to intervene in mkt but takes in only $50-million, which helps sustain dollar slightly above its floor price of 3.15 marks through day until 4 o'clock, when dollar suddenly plunges; news dispatch from Brussels indicates that Chancellor Brandt is considering establishment of system of 2-tier exch controls similar to ones already operating in France, Belgium and Italy; rept is clarified later by W Ger Sec Apel, who says W Ger might consider 2-tiered system, but only if it were adopted uniformly by all EEC countries; Brandt, speaking at luncheon given in his hon by Belgian Premier Leburton in Brussels, appeals to EEC countries to prove their solidarity by taking united action to end monetary crisis threatening agreed dollar parity with mark; in NYC, most major foreign currencies remain strong against dollar; W Ger mark shoots through its official ceiling during brief span early in day until Fed Reserve enters mkt to support dollar; trading is said to be less busy than in recent days; Japan is reptd to have bought $250-million in foreign-exch mkt to keep dollar from falling through its floor price against yen
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NO NEW TALKS SET
response.abstract: 28,000 UTU members strike Penn Central on Feb 8 in dispute over size of train crews, halting all service for 103,000 commuters in NYC met area and affecting freight and passenger traffic in 16 states; union and mgt trade charges of responsibility for strike; sources rept that Sen Javits and Repr H O Staggers will introduce emergency legis to end strike; alternate transportation services listed; deserted Penn Station illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Jet Hits Apartments
response.abstract: A Navy jet fighter slammed into the roof of a wooden apartment building in Alameda, Calif., in a ball of flames last night, touching off a fire that engulfed the building and spread to two adjacent ones. Witnesses feared that few of the estimated 80 tenants could have survived. Details on Page 85.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon Said to Seek Authority to Impose Imports Surcharge
response.abstract: Nixon Adm to include in proposed trade legis authority to impose import surcharge during payments deficit and authority to cut tariff during payments surplus; proposal has no direct connection with current monetary crisis; Adm also is reptdly considering authority to impose import surcharge on particular countries refusing to take action to correct chronic payments surplus; proposal may be interpreted as attempt by US to impose monetary reform ideas on rest of world; HR Ways and Means chmn W Mills is reptdly sympathetic to idea; proposal of either authority could spur internatl monetary negotiations
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Spring Camps Delayed
response.abstract: Baseball training camps, which were scheduled to open next week, were declared off limits by the club owners until agreement is reached in their labor dispute with the players. The owners said they had offered’ to arbitrate individual salary disputes. Details, Page 17.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Central Commuters Take Short Stoppage Smoothly
response.abstract: article finds that most commuters were not seriously inconvenienced by 1-day Penn Central walkout, especially because many of them did not even attempt to get into Manhattan; commuters illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Federal Inquiry Reported On Bergen G.O.P. Politics
response.abstract: US Atty H J Stern opens investigation into Repub pol and govt of Bergen County, NJ; records of J Kaplan, former top official in Nixon Adm, have been subpoenaed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PILOT WHO BALKED GETS A DISCHARGE
response.abstract: Capt M J Heck who refused on Dec 27 '72 to fly more bombing raids over North Vietnam, has been granted discharge from Air Force; discharge is approved by Deputy Asst Sec J C Goode; Heck's layer M M Karpatkin and mother comment; 1st Lt D J Evans Jr is also granted discharge after having refused to fly mission on Dec 18 '72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: House Panel Tells Rogers Aid to Hanoi Is Unpopular
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8—Secretary of State William P. Rogers was warned by members of a House committee today that the Nixon Administration's proposals to provide postwar economic aid program to North Vietnam were encountering growing public opposition.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DEVALUATIONFEAR SPURS A RENEWAL OF DOLLAR SALES
response.abstract: Dollar continues in deep trouble on Feb 8 as devaluation fear spurs renewal of dollar sales; W Ger Bundesbank buys up single-day record $1.6-billion in new demonstration of Govt's determination to support dollar and keep mark from floating upward; Japanese banking authorities buy $105-million, bringing their total purchases since last wk to more than $1-billion; dollar remains under strong downward pressure in relation to major foreign currencies on NY foreign exch mkt; W Ger mark again pushes through its official ceiling of 31.7460 cents amid indication of intervention by Fed Reserve early in day; exch traders in Eur say new wave of dollar selling is caused in part by statement by US Repr Mills welcoming possibility of devaluation; statements published by US Govt showing record US trade deficit in '72 are also being taken as strong indication that dollar devaluation accomplished through Smithsonian agreement of '71 is apparently not going to bring about hoped-for reduction of US balance-of-payments deficits; W Ger Finance Min spokesman says on Feb 8 that there is still no possibility of letting mark float or revaluing it, but banking sources strongly doubt that battle Govt is putting up against tides of dollars flooding into country could continue much longer; W Ger official reserves are stronger now than in '71 crisis, when Govt was forced to let mark float after 3 days of crisis trading, and can take strain for while, but money pouring into econ through bank's dollar purchases is worsening country's acute inflation, which is considered most pressing problem; traders in internatl mkt note principal sellers of dollars at beginning of latest crisis were banks seeking speculative profits, along with Mideasterns, who have acquired large dollar holdings through oil revenues; say all holders of dollars are selling now
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BASIS FOR A TRUCE NEXT WEDNESDAY REPORTED IN LAOS
response.abstract: Diplomatic sources rept on Feb 8 that Laotian Govt and Communist-led Pathet Lao have agreed in principle on cease-fire to take effect Feb 15; Premier Souvanna Phouma ends talks with Pathet Lao repr Phoumi Vongvichit; H A Kissinger, scheduled to arrive in Vientiane on Feb 9, is expected to finalize terms of accord; ex-rightist leader Gen Phoumi Nosavan reptdly has proposed new leadership for Laotian right, presumably his own; Nosavan was forced into exile in Thailand after failure at '54 coup; US will not tolerate any effort by right wing to undermine Govt or peace agreement
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Police Intelligence Records Here Are Purged of a Million Names
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr Murphy announces Feb 8 that names of more than 1-million people and orgns have been purged from intelligence files of NYC Police Dept and that new guidelines had been developed to tighten controls over collection and dissemination of intelligence; purge resulted in names of persons in intelligence index being reduced from 1,220,000 to 240,000 and names of orgns in index reduced from 125,000 to 25,000; intelligence folders on persons were reduced from 3,500 to 2,500 while intelligence folders on orgns were reduced from 1,500 to 200; both cards and folders were 'definitely destroyed' according to police spokesman; Murphy says purge was effort he began in Nov '70; suit was filed in May '71 which alleges dept's intelligence activities have been 'overbroad and unconstitutional' and is still pending in Fed Ct; por of Murphy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEW INQUIRY DUE FOR WATERGATE
response.abstract: Asst US Atty E J Silbert says on Feb 8 that all 7 defendants in Watergate case will be ordered to appear before grand jury in attempt to 'explore every conceivable avenue' of possible high level involvement, int; says special attention will be paid to G G Liddy, described by Govt as leader of pol intelligence operation that led to bugging attempt on Dem natl hq last yr; says grand jury will be reconvened immediately after sentencing of 7 defendants; says he and his colleagues decided to press case against 7 men after concluding that FBI found no 'hard evidence to indicate involvement of others'; says neither Liddy nor E H Hunt Jr would cooperate with prosecution and notes his reasons for not granting them immunity; notes that, pending any further information, reconvened grand jury will not consider any aspects of alleged spying and sabotage operations since Justice Dept has determined that D H Segretti's reptd activities violated no laws; Pres asst J D Ehrlichman confirms that he received word of possible White House involvement in Watergate break-in with day or 2 of burglary; word of advance warning, which came before 1st public hint of White House involvement, was contained in deposition made by C W Colson, White House special counsel, in connection with civil suit filed by Dems against Repubs after Watergate arrests; Repub Sens name Sens Baker, Gurney and Weicker to Sen's special com to investigate Watergate bugging case and separate pol espionage and sabotage allegedly conducted by D H Segretti on behalf of White House officials; Dem com members will be Sens Inouye, Montoya and Talmadge; com will be headed by Sen Ervin; Silbert illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONGRESS HALTS RAILROAD STRIKE, BARRING A WALKOUT FOR 90 DAYS; COMMUTER TRAINS RESUME TODAY
response.abstract: Cong on Feb 8 adopts joint resolution ordering 90-day halt in strike by 28,000 UTU members against Penn Central RR, nation's largest line; also tells Adm to draw up within 45 days comprehensive plan for reorgn of Northeastern rail transport; Penn Central says regular commuter service will resume by morning of Feb 9; spokesman says Pres Nixon will sign bill as soon as it reaches him in Calif; US Sen Williams' testimony in favor of bill noted; Williams and Sen Javits, co-authors of resolution, illus; empty platform illus; Penn Central system map; UTU pres A H Chesser illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Frame‐Up Plot Laid To a Jersey Senator
response.abstract: TRENTON, Feb. 8 — State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of having conspired to frame a Gloucester County Democratic Assemblyman by having narcotics planted in his house.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Monetary Developments

response.headline: BRANDT SEEKS AID IN MONEY CRISIS; $2‐BILLION BOUGHT
response.abstract: Brandt confs by telephone on Feb 9 with Nixon, Heath and Pompidou, asking for their cooperation in continuing monetary crisis; substance of discussions are not disclosed, but Govt spokesman says Brandt is now in constant contact with 3 leaders; foreign exch mkt closes with W Ger's dollar purchases setting new daily record of $2-billion; dollar slips to new low levels against floating Swiss franc in Zurich, while central banks in Belgium, Denmark, Netherlands and Japan have to intervene with new purchases to keep dollar from slipping below its floor parity; Japanese central bank buys $240-million, bringing its total purchases during past wk to $1.2-billion; growing disenchantment is reptd in W Ger banking circles over iron determination of Min Schmidt to hold to mark-dollar relationship no matter how costly it might become; many bankers are reptd to feel that float of mark would be preferable to growing number of controls govt has been putting on currency and capital movements during crisis; W Ger Govt announces it will seek immediate legis raising from 50% to 100% the amt of currency W Ger cos will have to deposit interest-free with Bundesbank when they make foreign loans; illus

response.headline: RIGHTS UNIT SAYS NIXON STILL LAGS
response.abstract: US Comm on Civil Rights, for 4th time in 3 yrs, finds that Pres Nixon Adm's enforcement of laws and regulations affecting Negroes and other minority groups is inadequate, comm rept released on Feb 9; rept asserts that comm 'study has reinforced findings of 3 preceding repts that Govt's civil rights program is not adequate or even close to it'; holds Nixon is responsible for situation; language of rept is very blunt and tone is seen as noticeably more pessimistic than 3 previous studies despite 'few encouraging signs'; comm, whose duties are described, says in rept that inertia of agencies in area of civil rights persisted; holds that no high level of priority and commitment to civil rights enforcement was found; rept also finds that Equal Employment Opportunity Coordinating Council, created by Cong last yr, has not dealt with any substantive issues in 1st 6 mos of its existence; improvements in US Agr, HEW and HUD Depts and Environmental Protection Agency noted; list of regulatory agencies rept criticized for not enforcing civil rights regulations and continuing to deny full scope of their civil rights responsibilities includes CAB, FPC, ICC, SEC, and FCC; list of other agencies investigated and found generally negative on civil rights; rept is last study made under leadership of Rev T M Hesburgh, whom White House forced to resign as comm chmn in Nov; Hesburgh had been sharply critical of Nixon Adm; comm announces it plans to complete another study next summer; holds that while comm's efforts have not produced significant results, it must remain committed to reviewing periodically civil rights enforcement activities of Fed agencies; R L Ziegler, Nixon press sec, declines comment on comm rept

response.headline: AIRLIFT IS BEGUN
response.abstract: Repatriation of Amer POWs from N Vietnam begins Feb 12; 3 US med-evacuation planes and advance plane bearing support team and officials officials at Hanoi's Gia Lam airport, an loaded with POWs after a ceremonial turnover and take off for and arrive at Clark Air Base, Philippines; one POW, Comdr B D Woods, not scheduled for Feb 12 release, is added to list at Four-Party Joint Mil Comm request because his mother is critically ill; repatriation is 1st phase of POW exchange to be completed within 60 days of signing of cease-fire pact signed Jan 27; approximately 1/4 of 592 POWs Communists say they hold included in Feb 12 repatriation; those remaining are to be released in installments in proportion to withdrawal of remaining US troops from S Vietnam during 60-day period; some 1,300 Amers listed as captured or missing in action remain unaccounted for; 2 US Govt officials in charge of POW matters unexpectedly left Clark Air Base for Hanoi, Feb 12, with 18-man advance team; they are R E Shields and F A Sieverts; security tightened around Clark Air Base and at hosp where POWs will be housed and examined for 3 or 4 days before return to US; preparations for repatriation, known as Operation Homecoming, began in May '69; operation detailed; details on length of capivity of those released; welcoming preparations at Clark Air Base described; hosp officials warns hosp staff against speaking to any of 131 newsmen covering POWs return; all statements and opinions by people at base are authorized only when made in presence of one of 66 public relations officers and enlisted men flown in to deal with press; illus of planes and map of plane routes

response.headline: 28 VICTIMS FOUND, 12 STILL MISSING IN S.I. EXPLOSION

response.headline: Money Situation in Brief
response.abstract: THE DOLLAR dropped sharply in limited foreign exchange trading following Monday nights surprise announcement of a 10 per cent devaluation. The decline was about 15 per cent against the Japanese yen, which Tokyo agreed to let float upward to find its own value according to supply and demand. Against the floating Swiss francs, the dollar decline was about 11 per cent. But trading was tentative; and confused, with foreign exchange markets still unsettled and the outlook for currency values still unclear.

response.abstract: Nixon Adm advocates of strong strip mining regulations reptdly have suffered almost total defeat within President's circle of advisers; although Pres has said he will reintroduce proposal for enlightened regulation of surface and underground mining, Adm's newest measure does not appear as strong as measure which was ignored by Cong in '72; unidentified Adm official calls proposal 'ridiculous'; Environmental Protection Admr Ruckelshaus reptdly warned Office of Budget and Mgt that bill would simply be 'set aside' by Cong; Repr J D Dingell, in lr to Pres Environmental Quality Council chmn R E Train, charges bill's drafters ignored Ruckelshaus's comments and produced weak bill which will appeal to mining interests but not to public; says stronger program could be implemented with minimum of cost to Govt; bill apparently reflects views of Commerce Dept, which generally sides with coal mining interests; indus spokesmen have warned that tough strip mine controls could drive coal off energy mkt; conservationists comment on bill; bill's regulations discussed

response.headline: YEN CLIMBS 14% IN HECTIC TRADING: TANAKA CRITICIZED
response.abstract: Opposition members in Japanese Parliament, on Feb 14, demand resignation of Premier Tanaka and his Cabinet because of their 'pol responsibility' for abrupt change in exch rate; Tanaka says he is not responsible for currency float and will not resign
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STATE'S ECONOMY IS RISING‘AT LAST’
response.abstract: NYS Council on Econ Advisers, in annual rept released on Feb 14, says nonagr employment began upswing in summer of '72; notes 'disturbing trend' in NYS involved many workers moving out of state to other labor mkts; council holds census data shows net outmigration among older residents 'with consequent loss of greater potential in skill and maturity,' but also marked net inflow among 25- to 40-yr-olds; repts 'most dramatic' outflow occurred upstate; council predicts a rise in employment in '73 of 1.7%, to 7.86-million people; also foresees continued drop in unemployment, which avgd 5.9% in NYS in '72; says unemployment should 'substantially equal' natl rate of 5.1% in '73; chart shows fluctuations in nonfarm jobs in NYS and US, '69-72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cahill Aide Cleared In Cover‐Up Inquiry
response.abstract: TRENTON, Feb. 14—Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. was cleared today by the State Commission of Investigation of any inference that he or his staff had covered up information that ultimately led to the extortion conviction of former Secretary of Stale Paul J. Sherwin.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dollar Above New Parity In Heavy Foreign Selling
response.abstract: dollar selling is reptd heavy on Feb 14 in world's foreign exch mkts, but prices are strong and well above dollar's new devalued parities with such currencies as W Ger mark, French franc and Dutch guilder; dollar weakens against Japanese yen, Swiss franc and Brit pound; dealers say they see no strong indication of mkt sentiment in business they are doing except anxieties and continued nervousness; price of gold rises $3.30 to record $72.30 an ounce on London bullion mkt; France, Austria, Australia and Hong Kong set new values for their currencies to reflect full 10% devaluation of dollar sought by US; Scandinavian countries and Spain are reptdly holding back to examine implications for their own econs while others, such as Greece, decide to devalue along with dollar and still others, such as Switzerland, determine to continue floating without fixed parity until turmoil subsides; Japan buys dollars heavily on reopened Tokyo exch to keep yen's movement away from its old dollar parity to less than 14%; many US trading partners are reptd to have moved in line with US wishes for 10% devaluation of dollar, including W Ger, Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg and Malaysia, with dollar selling above its newly fixed parities against currencies of these countries in rather confused trading on exchs; exch transactions in various EEC countries detailed; Portugal sets new dollar parity 6.4% higher than old one, and Spain, Sweden, Norway and Denmark are expected to make similar moves; Greece, Israel and Mexico have determined to devalue in terms of gold just as US did; illus on Frankfurt money exch
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON TO PROPOSE A PLAN TO ASSURE ENERGY SUPPLIES
response.abstract: Pres Nixon says on Feb 14 that he will propose plan to assure adequate energy supplies at acceptable econ and environmental cost, 1st of series of State of Union speeches, radio; asserts US consumes more energy than it produces
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: UNION FRAUD LAID TO RETIRED JUDGE
response.abstract: D L Malbin, retired acting justice of NYS Sup Ct in Bklyn, NYC, former NYS Sen J E Parisi and 28 officers and trustees of an independent union are charged on Feb 15 with using union's funds for living and entertainment expenses; Malbin, who served 40 yrs on bench in various cts, is accused of 7 counts of aiding and abetting conspiracy that reptdly cost union's gen, welfare and pension funds more than $50,000; after his retirement in '66, Appellate Div apptd him 1st admr of a panel to provide lawyers for indigent defendants in Bklyn, Queens and Staten Island; Parisi is similarly accused on 9 counts; conviction on each count carries maximum prison sentence of 5 yrs and $10,000 fine; 165-count indictment, unsealed before Judge J F Dooling Jr in Fed ct, Bklyn, is climax of a yr-long investigation by US Labor Dept and Bklyn Strike Force Against Organized Crime; charges center on asserted illegal use of union funds for personal expenditures at annual convs beginning in '68; union, with hq at 100 Livingston St, Bklyn, is said to be run by small group of men, including pres I M Horowitz, 2 relatives of reputed members of the Mafia, a convicted robber and officials who had been expelled or had resigned from other unions; union is estimated to have 20,000 members in NYC met area; if convicted, Horowitz faces up to 100 yrs in prison; he was pres of Local 222 when it was part of Internatl Jewelry Workers Union
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: States and Doctors Wary On Eased Abortion Ruling
response.abstract: NY Times survey on various actions taken by state govts and Amer med profession in light of recent Sup Ct decision on abortion; state-by-state rev indicates that 9 states have introduced legis that would bring their laws into conformity with decision and equal number are working on new legis; in more than 12 states, Attys Gen or local cts have declared existing laws null and void, but in at least 5 states legal or judicial authorities have supported old restrictive laws; in several states, Attys Gen rept they are waiting for state legis or local cts to act; only Va has rejected bill that would have brought law into line with Ct ruling; med profession has taken little action; legislators in at least 15 states are seeking to introduce resolutions that would ultimately give fetus const rights; it appears likely that resistance from right-to-life movement may delay establishment of abortion facilities in some areas, particularly in states where med leaders share movement's views
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PHASING OUT OF FARM SUBSIDY
response.abstract: Pres Nixon on Feb 15 proposes that Cong gradually eliminate payments to farmers to subsidize their crops; plan, which has cost Govt more than $48-million, would end system under which Govt has set limits on how much a farmer may grow and remain eligible for subsidies; Nixon asserts that by allowing increased supplies of farm products, food prices could be held in check; farm bloc leaders in Cong are expected to show strong resistance to plan; Agr Dept says that Nixon Adm had in mind a transition period of about 3 yrs before direct subsidies are ended; Nixon holds that aim of farm plan is to reduce farmers' dependence on Govt payments, to give farmers more freedom in planting decisions and to pave way for increased crop exports; claims that system of acreage allotments to limit farm production is outdated; Agr Asst Sec Brunthaver says that, except for land being held out of cultivation, there will be no controls on specific crops; notes that under plan farmers will be free to plant whatever they please
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ROGERS SAYS U.S. IS FIRM ON CUBA
response.abstract: Canada and Cuba sign agreement on Feb 15 aimed at extradition and punishment of airplane hijackers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cambodia, Mired in War, Looks to U.S. as Only Help
response.abstract: H Kamm survey of current situation in Cambodia; repts Cambodians are fearful that peace will continue to elude them and have come to believe that Lon Nol Govt is incompetent, that the army is too impotent to make peace or war and cannot protect vital interests of Cambodians; finds Cambodians are looking hopefully, even pleadingly, to US to solve their problems; holds US policy has changed, that it does not wish to serve as viceroy or proconsul of Cambodia but encourages Cambodian opposition figures to confront Lon Nol with their views and make repub democratic form of Govt work; repts Cambodians are fearful of expressing opposition; links Lon Nol Govt's growing arbitrariness and open power of his brother Brig Gen Lon Non; cites examples of Lon Nol's decisive pol influence and impact on current scene
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pentagon Says Strikes This Week Increased by About 100 Daily
response.abstract: US Defense Dept on Feb 15, announces significant increase in US air strikes against N Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troop and munitions movements in Laos; Brig Gen D James gives details; other Defense Dept officials say there has been substantial rise in Communists' movement of mil materiel from N Vietnam into Laos as well as increased fighting between contending sides in Laos as each tries to improve its position before a cease-fire; believe cease-fire is not far off despite temporary impasse in talks
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Wholesale Prices Increase Sharply; Rise Led by Food
response.abstract: Labor Dept repts on Feb 15 that agr sector of Wholesale Price Index for Jan rose by 2.9%, seasonally adjusted; considered big jump for 1 mo though less than near record increase of 5.2% in Dec; dept says that price increases were widespread in Jan at farm level due to 'severe weather and exceptionally strong export demand'; graph
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 RAIL LINES ASKED FOR WESTERN U. S.
response.abstract: ICC Judge N C Klitenic, in final rept on application of Chicago & North Western Ry for permission to acquire Chicago Rock Island RR, proposes on Feb 15 consol of 25 Western and Midwestern rrs into 4 major systems to carry all US rail traffic from Mississippi River to Pacific Ocean; says move, which would leave Atchison Topeka, Burlington Northern, Southern Pacific and Union Pacific as 4 major systems in area, would lead to unification of nation's rrs into limited number of highly efficient, strong and competitive lines serving major producing and consuming areas throughout their length; rept broadly outlines possible saving of hundreds of millions of dollars that proponents of such mergers insist could be achieved; Klitenic addresses himself specifically to Rock Island case, which may not be resolved for yrs if ICC adheres to his major proposals; Union Pacific in '64 made counter-proposal that it be authorized to buy Rock Island and sell southern half of system to Southern Pacific; rept proposes that comm now condition its approval of Union Pacific-Rock Island merger on Union Pacific's willingness to take over Chicago & North Western if that road wishes to become part of greater Union Pacific system; Klitenic would also require Union Pacific to give Atchison Topeka trackage rights to acquired Rock Island lines into Kansas City and St Louis; Atchison Topeka would then offer to include Western Pacific and Denver & Rio Grande lines in its system, as well as taking in lines of Missouri Pacific and its subsidiary, Texas & Pacific; latter inclusion would provide for concurrent sale of Texas & Pacific's El Paso-Fort Worth line to Southern Pacific; Klitenic further recommends that Southern Pacific offer to take Missouri-Kansas-Texas RR into its system, along with Kansas City Southern and its subsidiary, Louisiana & Arkansas; makes no recommendation regarding logical home for St Louis-San Francisco Ry, which has vigorously opposed Union Pacific-Rock Island unification; Klitenic illus; schematic drawings of 4 proposed rail systems and recommended merger areas
keywords: CHICAGO ROCK ISLAND & PACIFIC RR CO.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Issues Dividing 2 Sides Appear to Harden—Americans Faulted
response.abstract: Laotian Govt and Communist-led Pathet Lao fail on Feb 15 to reach agreement on Laotian cease-fire and indicate that issues between them have grown more serious; principal Govt negotiator blames US; charges an agreement had nearly been reached but Amers began insisting on certain guarantees which Pathet Lao have rejected; Amers reptdly are insisting upon clarification of many issues including exact role of Internatl Control Comm as Laotian peace-keeping agency; major unresolved issues include composition of future coalition Govt, question of who are the neutralists and Pathet Lao demand that US be named as aggressor in peace accord; US Deputy Asst Sec Sullivan arrives in Vientiane on Feb 15 for 24-hr stay including dinner at which Premier Souvanna Phouma will be present
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SHULTZ SAYS. U.S SEEKS NEW DROP IN DOLLAR VALUE
response.abstract: US Sec Shultz says on Feb 15 that Nixon Adm is seeking further devaluation of dollar in world currency mkts, news conf; declines to define specific amt by which Adm would like to see value of dollar reduced in relation to currencies of other nations but says Govt is pressing other nations with currencies floating in world money mkts; holds announcement of devaluation could undermine US position since US Adm might decide that it would like more than that specified; says bluntly that devaluation has not been enough and indicates Adm has seized upon recent currency crisis as opportunity to realign value of dollar as well as make progress toward long-range goals of reform in internatl trade and monetary negotiations; Morgan Guaranty Trust Co repts 'trade weighted' value of dollar on Feb 15 is 5,85%; in other development, Sen McClellan announces that Shultz, Chmn H Stein and Dir R L Ash will testify before Sen Appropriations Com; charges devaluation of dollar will cost Amer taxpayers $2-billion
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lindsay Proposes intensified Drive On Drug Pushers
response.abstract: NYC Mayor Lindsay on Feb 15 calls for intensified attack on city's illicit drug dealers that would include apptmt of 48 narcotics judges, restrictions on plea bargaining and parole and unification of 3 levels of city's narcotics enforcement agencies, testimony before NYS Legis Codes Com; maintains proposal is 'tougher, more workable and more effective than any other in the nation,' noting that it entails more 'aggressive' rehabilitative treatment of addicts, alteration of police, ct and probation practices, and emphasis on incarcerating 'large scale drug profiteers' rather than small-volume sellers; proposal outlined
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Noted Heart Surgeon Convicted Of Income Tax Evasion Charges
response.abstract: Dr C W Lillehei, who pioneered in open-heart surgery at Minn Univ in '50s, on Feb 16 is convicted of 5 charges of income tax evasion, Fed Ct, St Paul, Minn; was accused of omitting more than $250,000 in income from his tax returns for '64 through '68 and of owing more than $125,000 in taxes; case detailed; illus

response.headline: MILLS PROPOSES 15% ADDED TARIFF
response.abstract: Repr W D Mills, proposing on Feb 16 several concrete steps to deal with continued uncertainty in internatl financial mkts and continued large US deficit in balance of payments, proposes that Govt offer 'attractively structured savings bond' to individuals who will be receiving tax refunds in '73

response.headline: Factory Output Rises
response.abstract: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the nation's industrial production rose by five‐tenths of 1 per cent in January. In another report, the Commerce Department said housing starts continued in January at the record ‐ breaking pace of 1972. Details, Page 41.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: JUDGE BIDS H.E.W. FORCE 17 STATES TO DESEGREGATE
response.abstract: Fed Dist Ct Judge J H Pratt on Feb 16 orders Nixon Adm to begin enforcement proceedings against allegedly segregated public colls and school dists in 17 states; ruling comes in suit filed in Oct, '70, on behalf of 25 black students and parents by NAACP Legal Defense and Educ Fund; Judge Pratt presents HEW Dept with strict timetables under which dept must start hearing to determine whether progress is being made toward desegregation in cited colls, schools and school dists, and orders dept to submit 6-mo progress repts as part of process; failure to comply could lead to cut-off of Fed funds; affected states are Ark, Del, Fla, Ga, Ky, La, Md, Miss, Mo, NC, Okla, Penna, SC, Tenn, Tex, Va and W Va
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Calley Conviction Upheld By Army's Review Court
response.abstract: US Army Ct of Mil Rev, Feb 16, upholds murder conviction of Lt W L Calley Jr for his role in the My Lai killings on Mar 16, '68 and approves his sentence of 20 yrs confinement at hard labor; finds he personally participated in and ordered subordinates to participate in the mass summary execution of unarmed My Lai villagers; Calley's lawyer, G W Latimer, says the case will be appealed to the US Ct of Mil Appeals, a civilian ct, and if unsuccessful there, he may try to bring case to the US Sup Ct on const grounds; says there is possibility Pres Nixon may decide to consider the case now that the mil rev has been completed; White House announces that Nixon will personally rev and make the final determination in the case; says case requires 'more than the technical rev' provided by the Uniform Code of Mil Justice; says Nixon will not rev the case until Calley has exhausted his appeals or decided on his own motion not to contest a decision handed down by one of the rev panels in the appeals process; case revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Meskill Signs Bill For Gasoline Tax To Aid Bus Lines
response.abstract: Conn Gov Meskill on Feb 16 signs into law bill enabling transit dists in Conn to collect penny-a-gallon tax on gasoline to cover deficits in public bus services; law, sought by Gov to help restore service in 64 towns where buses have been idle since last fall, passed Gen Assembly after heated debate; it is still uncertain that law will be accepted by towns, many of which have been insisting that Meskill use state funds to cover bus cos' losses, as he is authorized by law to do; 4 of 9 towns that make up Greater Hartford Transit Dist are reptdly threatening to pull out if they are to impose new tax; in transit dists that add new levy, service stations will collect it with regular tax and send it to state for redistribution back to dists; New Haven Mayor B F Guida says New Haven and at least 3 adjoining towns will 'absolutely not' be party to any transit dist; Meskill illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STUDENTS BEATEN BY ATHENS POLICE
response.abstract: univ students clash with police in Athens on Feb 16 in widening of conflict between regime and what it regards as 'student agitators;' many students are reptd beaten and about 100 arrested in clash following 5-hr student meeting protesting against new law that threatens dissident students with loss of deferments from draft; about 2,000 of Greece's 75,000 students are believed involved in current protest action; 88 students leaders were ordered during wk to give up their studies and rept for 24 mos of mil duty; 11 others are scheduled to go on trial on Feb 17 on charges of resisting arrest and insulting behavior; protest action of Feb 16 at Athens Univ's Law School bldg was called to protest against arrests and new draft law; dissidents occupy 2 upper floors of bldg and pull Greek flag to half-staff; force of 400 police near univ swing sticks when students begin to dispurse, beating up students and some passersby; about 100 students are shoved into police cars; earlier in day Athens ct martial imposes 58-mo prison sentence on S Panagoulis for evading draft; Panagoulis is already serving 54-mo sentence for attempting to free his brother Alexandros, who is under death sentence, convicted in abortive bid to kill Papadopoulos
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STATE IS WARNED ON TRIAL DELAYS
response.abstract: NYS Appeals Ct, on Feb 16, warns other branches of Govt that it will begin wholesale release of defendants from jail unless cts receive adequate financing to provide those defendants with speedy trial, case involving 4 defendants from Bklyn, NY; ct, in effect, invites defendants who have been jailed for lengthy periods pending trial to challenge delays; indicates that where cause of especially long delays is found to be ct congestion, rather than a 'justifiable excuse' by either defendant or prosecution, it will dismiss case; holds ultimate remedy must be provision by appropriate branches of govt of material and personnel resources required to handle increasing caseload; ct is not precise in spelling out time period in which case must be tried but holds, in essence, that delays caused by ct congestion are permissible for a while; observers see record speed with which case was decided indicative of ct's attitude; decision, 'per curiam' ruling, was accompanied by separate concurring opinion of Chief Judge Fuld; longstanding debate over right to speedy trial revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Blue Cross Rates to Rise 7.4% for. 1.5 Million Here
response.abstract: NYS Ins Dept on Feb 16 announces that Blue Cross of Greater NY has been granted avg increase of 7.4% in hosp ins rates for more than 1/3 of its subscribers in 5 boros and 12 other counties; increase, which affects 1.5-million community-rated subscribers, will go into effect April 1; Blue Cross's original request in Dec '72 for avg increase of 9.3% had been severely criticized as exorbitant by city officials and organized labor; largest increase approved was for 350,000 group family subscribers; their monthly cost will rise 12%, from $22.26 to $24.93; Greater NY Blue Shield receives avg rate increase of 16.8%; Blue Shield of Western NY receives increases averaging 38.2% on its 'class 50-51' contracts; Ins Dept castigates Greater NY Blue Cross pres Dr L J Raider, suggesting that he might not be fit to be chief exec; Blue Cross increase was 2d granted for community-rated subscribers in last 9 mos; group recd 14.8% rate increase in May '72; latest increase also involves 'senior care'; Blue Cross has also sought additional 4% to finance new contract improvements; improvements listed; Blue Shield increase will affect those subscribers who pay their premiums either individually or through payroll deductions--1/3 of service's 6.4-million subscribers in NYS's lower 17 counties; schedule indicating old and new monthly rates for various categories of Blue Cross coverage
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: POLLUTION STUDY SCORES AUTO MEN
response.abstract: Natl Acad of Sciences study concludes US auto indus is probably capable of meeting '75 standards but is concentrating on most expensive and least satisfactory control method; asserts carbureted, stratified engine, described as superior in regard to emissions, could be ready by '75 and is better and less costly than dual catalyst system presently being developed; fears concentration on catalyst method will delay development of alternative engine and will cost nation billions of dollars; carbureted, stratified engine described; acad researcher asserts Honda Motor Co has almost achieved '76 standards using stratified engine without catalyst; Dr P Handler, in lr to submitted to Cong with rept, holds cost of equipping cars with catalysts to meet '76 standards could be $23.5-billion; says cost in dollars and fuel of catalytic system should be natl incentive to develop better methods; Ford Motor Co repr agrees with rept com finding about durability of catalysts and other elements or present control tech; auto cos' attempts to delay implementation of standards noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Regional Truce Teams Unable to Act
response.abstract: Internatl Control Comm and Joint Mil Comm maintain regional hq in town of My Tho, but they are inactive; control comm says it cannot begin to function effectively until the mil comm is working; control comm members were at first stopped by S Vietnamese officers from visiting Communist members of the mil comm; found them living in poor conditions; mil comm will be reduced to its S Vietnamese and Vietcong members only on March 28; control comm has no deadline; control comm members comment on situation; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TRUCE COMMISSION URGES BOTH SIDES TO HALT FIGHTING
response.abstract: Joint Mil Comm makes urgent appeal to Communist and Saigon commands 'to promptly issue orders' to halt any further fighting in S Vietnam, statement, Feb 17; 3d wk of cease-fire ends with fighting still continuing and in some places showing signs of an increase; statement is first tangible unanimous pub effort by comm to come to grips with problem; comm urges both sides to strictly respect the cease-fire and settle all questions by peaceful negotiations; orders both sides to order forces to cease any armed patrols into areas controlled by opposing armed forces; wants both sides to stop flights by bombers and fighter planes except on training missions; calls for an end to 'armed attacks against any person either mil or civilian by any means whatsoever'; there is no immediate response to appeal from either side; Amer analysts still dismiss most of the thousands of cease-fire violations alleged by the Saigon Govt as what one analyst calls 'niggling'; comment on various aspects of the violations; Canadian members of the Internatl Control Comm have insisted publicly that solution to problem is for the mil comm; illus of 2 members of a truce team conferring with an Amer in Can Tho
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cans of Mushrooms Recalled by F.D.A. For Botulism Check
response.abstract: FDA repts on Feb 17 that an inst-size can produced by United Canners Co has been found to contain poison that produces botulism; announces that 29,500 cans of product are being recalled; cautions users to be alert to brand names and codes of lots being recalled; cans were distributed in NYS, Penna, Ohio, Wis and Ill; claims Stouffers Food Co received some of product, but asserts co has taken steps to stop all distribution of any of its products containing mushrooms; urges users, mainly restaurants and pizza parlors, who find they have lots being recalled should return them to distributors; agency lists labels and distributors for cans recalled; cities where shipments were distributed cited

response.headline: U.S. Killer Reported Hired In a Plot Against Marcos
response.abstract: US Sen Foreign Relations Com staff rept made public on Feb 17 says that Philippines Pres Marcos believes that last fall, shortly before he imposed martial law, he was target of right-wing assassination plot involving hired killer from US; rept, prepared by J G Lowenstein and R M Moose, com members who last Nov made an inspection trip to Philippines, says top Philippines Govt official, believed to have been Marcos himself, informed them that Marcos imposed martial law after uncovering assassination plot and that key figures involved were Vice Pres Lopez, S Osmena Jr, Marcos's opponent in '69 Pres election, and 3 Amers; rept says official arranged for them to receive document describing 'a web' of plots against Marcos Govt including 'rightist revolution and coup d'etat'; document detailed plot, claimed E Adevoso, opposition Liberal party official, headed revolutionary junta whose aims were to discredit Marcos and then kill him; part of plan was to designate Vice Pres Lopez as caretaker Pres during transition period; plan reptdly was approved by Osmena, Liberal party and their alleged Amer supporters, particularly L Tractman who had been convicted of smuggling in US; rept states further that Tractman, in June '72, and 2d Amer R Pincus brought 3d Amer A McC Lehman to Manila and introduced him as a professional killer; Lehman's reptd arrangements to kill Marcos detailed; Philippines Govt, on Nov 15, had announced arrest of Lehman and stated he had confessed to assassination plot; Lopez is imprisoned in Philippines, Osmena reptdly is in hiding in US; rept says top Philippines official says there was no public mention of plot because conspiracy extended into highest Govt circles; does not vouch for accuracy of acct of reptd plot and notes that US Embassy officials say they had no knowledge of it; also points out fact that Marcos Govt might have an interest in promoting story of rightist plot to justify imposition of martial law; Lopez and Osmena pors
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.abstract: Saigon mil spokesman Col Le Trung Hien says, Feb 17, S Vietnamese troops were ordered to stop fighting in compliance with an urgent appeal issued by Joint Mil Comm; Communist command reptdly issues similar orders; effect of appeal is not immediately discernible; Saigon charges Communists committed 167 cease-fire violations in 24 hrs ended at 6 AM Feb 18; Hien denies that Saigon is guilty of cease-fire violations; says fighting will end if Communists 'simply stopped violating the agreement'; comm's appeal for end to flights by mil aircraft seen to indicate only Saigon's aircraft, the only aircraft in S Vietnam; Saigon Air Force has been flying 100 to 200 tactical air strikes a day in support of ground forces and reptdly in response to Communist artillery barrages; comm appeal revd

response.abstract: article notes latest monetary crisis is over; says Italy, GB, France, W Ger and Switzerland are all afflicted with severe inflation and may all face future attack on their currencies; holds next crisis is not likely to be as big and as dangerous as recent one; says all but big money speculators came out loser in latest crisis; holds outcome of crisis has been undermining of confidence in stability of internatl monetary system; says latest US action refinforces view that countries with surpluses in their ledgers have responsibilities as well as deficit countries in achieving better equilibrium

response.abstract: An Air Force jet arrived in Hanoi, North Vietnam, today to pick up 20 more American prisoners of war. The return of the 20 will bring the number of freed Anserican prisoners to 163, eight civilians and 155 servicemen. The remaining captives are to be released by March 29. Details on Page 5.

response.headline: Austrian Sled Leads in 4‐Man Title Event

response.headline: VIETNAM FIGHTING GOES ON UNABATED DESPITE APPEAL
response.abstract: Fighting in S Vietnam shows no signs of abating, Feb 18, despite appeal by Joint Mil Comm for immediate halt; fighting appears to have increased since Feb 17; Saigon charges Communists committed 194 more violations of cease-fire during 24 hrs ended at 6 AM, increase over the recent daily average of about 165 violations; Col Le Trung Hien says Saigon has halted all flights by mil planes since appeal was made; Saigon repts 21 Communist soldiers were killed in 2 clashes near Due Pho on Feb 18; in same area on Feb 17, 51 Communists and 6 S Vietnamese were killed; details on other clashes; Internatl Control Comm members say they feel helpless to conduct any real peace-keeping function so long as the fighting goes on; Saigon says it is continuing to relase Communist POWs; says 982 were ferried across Thach Han River, bringing total number of released POWs to 5,496; says it still holds about 19,000 other Communist POWs; says Hanoi has released 711 S Vietnamese POWs and will release 320 more Feb 20
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Europeans Act to Curb the Sex Market
response.abstract: Article on various Eur govts' less tolerant attitudes toward pornographic enterprises operating in their cities; decrease in permissiveness has become visible in Denmark, W Ger, Britian, Italy, France and Yugoslavia; recent trends in Eur are similar to those in NYC and elsewhere in US, where 'backlash' among public has given support to antiobscenity moves; reaction in Eur arises in part out of fears of criminality and drug peddling, which are often associated with the sex business; illus of pornographic bookstore in Soho area of London
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BONN CUTS BUDGET AND RAISES TAXES
response.abstract: W Ger Govt on Feb 18 announces it is removing from Fed budget $20-million it was to have paid W Gers and W Berliners as compensation for visa fees imposed by Communist authorities on those who visit relatives and friends in E Ger; move is expected to discourage visits to E Ger
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sadat Aide to Visit China; Another Will Meet Nixon
response.abstract: Feb 19: Egyptian Foreign Min Zayyat will fly to People's Republic of China later in Feb as part of world-wide diplomatic campaign that is taking Pres Sadat's natl security adviser H Ismail to US; Ismail leaves for GB on Feb 18 for talks with Prime Min Heath and Foreign Sec Sir Douglas-Home; will fly to US on Feb 22 and confer with Pres Nixon and Sec Rogers on Feb 23; Zayyat's prospective visit to China will be substitute for Egypt visit by Chinese Min Chi Peng-fei; Zayyat is also going to India; Egyptian official says diplomatic offensive is directed against Big Five--USSR, US, China, GB and France--as well as leaders of so-called Third World; sources say Ismail will stress to US leaders Egypt's desire for peace while making it clear that it will not accept loss of territory; Egyptian decision to send Ismail is understood to have been prompted by Rogers's statement on Feb 15 that Adm will welcome visit of high-placed Egyptians
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Ski‐Lift Failure Kills Brooklyn Man And Hurts 2 Others
response.abstract: H Lucas is killed and E Kahn injured on Feb 18 at Mt Peter Skiing Center near Warwick, NY, when ski-lift chair they were in broke loose from lift cable and fell 45 ft to ground; E S Alpert is injured during 4 1/2-hr rescue operation, in which rescue team brought 35 marooned skiers to safety; accident occurred when lift cable slipped from guide wheels attached to 1 of supporting towers along lift's route up slope; obstruction was created in mechanism causing 5 chairs, 1 of which was occupied, to pile up at tower and break from cable; lift mgr P Louhman comments; map; diagram; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kissinger and Chou Talk for Five Hours
response.abstract: Kissinger leaves Peking for Tokyo after talks with Mao and Chou that Western diplomats in Peking say apparently resulted in major breakthrough in Chinese-Amer relations; diplomats express surprise and excitement over Kissinger's long meeting with Mao; sr Chinese official says it is too early to talk about a Chinese embassy in Washington; Chinese line up at newsstands to buy Jenmin Jih Pao, which, for 3d consecutive day carries pictures of Kissinger on its 1st page; meeting with Mao also shown on TV; such press treatment reinforces for Westerners in Peking importance of visit in Chinese eyes; Hsinhua issues text of exch between Mao and Kissinger, which includes Mao request that Kissinger convey his regards to Nixon; one envoy says that for this to be published by Hsinhua and to appear in Chinese news media is another clear indication that Sino-Amer relations have reached a new stage
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 20 More Freed P.O. W,'s Greeted at Clark Air Base
response.abstract: 20 Amer POWs welcomed, Feb 18, at Clark Air Base, Philippines, on arrival from Hanoi; Hanoi released group ahead of schedule as a goodwill gesture, following Kissinger's visit there last wk; release in Hanoi took place after a tense 2-hr argument between POWs and POW camp officials over who should be set free and whether the release was a hoax; official US mil version of repatriation calls it normal; Comdr J G Pirie, acting as spokesman for the 20 men, continues the patriotic tone set by spokesmen for the 143 POWs released on Feb 12; expresses pride in US and Nixon; information officer Lt Col R F Abel, who was on evacuation plane with men, describes jubilation during trip; their health pronounced 'very good'; newsmen observe men in hosp but no questions are allowed; men illus waiting to board plane at Hanoi airport
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.abstract: portrait of Philadelphia's Overbrook HS describes school's problems of violence, drugs, racial conflict and educ inadequacy that have caused many whites to flee to suburbs, situation which is seen as typical of what is happening in urban educ in Amer; effects of current Philadelphia teachers' strike on school noted; illus
