response.headline: MARKET TO MEET
response.abstract: BRUSSELS, March 2—Western Europe intensified preparations today for joint defense against the wild influx of dollars as the European Economic Community called an emergency meeting of the Council of Ministers Sunday to deal with the third monetary crisis of the last three weeks.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Parched State in India Living on Little but Hope
response.abstract: Article on plight of farmers living in state of Maharashtra (India), where 3 consecutive droughts have left many people destitute and hungry; notes that Govt critics accuse state and natl adms of too little help and too late; says irrigation projects and equipment are minimal in state, despite 3 previous famines since '47; World Bank agr expert W Ladejinsky says that by time state is done with '72-73 'abomination' it will probably spend a large share of what might have taken to create a protective irrigation system in afflicted areas; claims if such funds were used for irrigation throughout past 10 yrs, problem could have been averted; holds that state's and natl govt's assistance efforts are 'undeniable' even though supplies are minimal; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘DOLLAR IS SOUND’
response.abstract: Pres Nixon says on Mar 2 that there will not be another devaluation of dollar, news conf; says dollar is sound in view of fact that inflation in US is running at slower pace than elsewhere in indus world and says US will survive 'attack by internatl speculators'; says he would regard dollar as 'a good bet' in world money mkts; notes there is nothing that can be done to bring speculators under control; says US can keep dollar as sound as possible at home and keep econ as sound as possible so that run on dollar does not mean weakness of Amer econ or of dollar; concedes that his 'sophisticates in Treas Dept shudder' when he uses term 'internatl speculators' on ground they believe monetary crises are not determined by speculation and unrest; holds Adm is going to continue efforts to get other major countries to participate more with US in getting internatl monetary system which is flexible enough to take care of what he believes are temporary attacks on one currency or another; will meet with econ advisors Sec Shultz, Chmn Stein, Dir Ash and Chmn Burns; informed sources say there is no indication that US is being called upon by Eurs to do anything significant in current turmoil and that decisions on what to do next will be made in Eur over Weekend; White House spokesman G Warren cautions reporters against assuming that Nixon's meeting has been occasioned by currency turmoil; officials are reptdly skeptical that EEC members can agree on joint float of their currencies against dollar; meanwhile, Sen Banking Com approves without amendment bill giving formal effect to recent 10% devaluation of dollar by increasing price of gold to $42.22; number of experts in monetary field continue to express some puzzlement at latest crisis on ground that pattern of world exch rates was probably realistic; E M Bernstein says in int that pattern of rates is now about right, noting he thinks Swiss franc has probably floated a little too high and Japanese yen had not yet floated high enough; says he thinks that if all currencies were now set free to float, W Ger mark and Dutch guilder would rise a little further but other rates would not change much
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HANOI PULLS OUT SOME TRUCE UNITS
response.abstract: Communists, Mar 2, pull out joint comm delegates from northern part of S Vietnam; N Vietnamese spokesman Lt Col Bui Tin complains of lack of security and poor food and quarters; move will make work of control comm virtually impossible; N Vietnamese inform US delegation to mil comm that next group of 108 POWs will be released Mar 4; Vietcong informs US delegation that it will release 34 POWs Mar 5; efforts to arrange more exchanges of Vietnamese POWs remain at impasse; S Vietnamese mil spokesman Lt Col Le Trung Hien says S Vietnam has offered to free all 5,081 civilians it says it holds provided Communists will simultaneously release mil POWs and increase number of civilians they have listed as holding; Vietcong announces Mar 1 that it has discovered it holds 500 more South Vietnamese mil prisoners than it had previously listed, bringing total to 4,785; Vietcong delegate Lt Gen Tran Van Tra is flown to Communist hq at Loc Ninh Mar 2 in US helicopter
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BELIEVED SPARED
response.abstract: Sudanese Govt on Mar 3 announces that Black September guerrillas executed US Amb C A Noel Jr, US charge d'affaires G C Moore and Belgian charge d'affaires G Eid who have been held hostage since Mar 1; Sudanese Govt says that 2 other hostages, Saudi Amb A al-Malhouk and Jordanian charge d'affaires A Nazir, are still alive; during day, Sudanese Deputy Premier and Interior Min M Bagir and other Cabinet mins spent several hrs negotiating with terrorists by telephone; Jordanian Govt announced on Mar 2 that it will not bow to guerrillas' demands for release of A Daoud, guerrillas originally also demanded release of S Sirhan, who is serving life sentence in US for '68 assassination of Sen R F Kennedy; also demanded release of number of other people held in Jordan, of all Arab women detained in Israel and of Baader-Meinhof urban guerrilla group held in W Ger attack on embassy revd: illus of Noel, Moore and Eid
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Federal Force Rings Wounded Knee
response.abstract: Govt officials on Mar 2 rept that shots struck FBI car, part of Fed force that continues to surround Wounded Knee, SD, news conf; it is not known if car was occupied at the time; 2 armored personnel carriers that have been held in readiness since Feb 28 were sent with Fed marshals aboard to take up positions 5 mi north and south of Wounded Knee; R E Erickson, special asst to Atty Gen who is in charge of operations, says he is not optimistic over progress of negotiations; says Indians have killed some cattle and are showing disregard for property; Erickson's news conf apparently indicates grim assessment of situation by Govt; Erickson, chief US marshal W Colburn and 7 reprs of Justice Dept's Community Relations at various times hold discussions with Indian reprs; US marshals force official H Webb says Fed officials agreed at meeting on Big Foot Trail about 5 mi from Wounded Knee to find lawyers named by militant Indians, presumably to aid in further negotiations; says it was also agreed that if Fed marshals do not advance from their roadblock positions, Indians will not fire any more shots; R Wilson, who was elected in '72 as Tribal Counsel Chmn, is central figure in struggle; was among 1st to denounce Amer Indian Movement and takeover of bldg; 3 members of Tribal Council recently made unsuccessful attempts to impeach Wilson on charges of nepotism, misuse of tribal funds, violations of US Const and false arrest; council voted to uphold Wilson; Indian leader A Desersa, whose house was firebombed on Mar 1, says he has called for some 1,500 supporters of movement to come to Pine Ridge to 'settle the issue'; illus of Indians in Cath Ch in hamlet

response.headline: Caribbean Seeks Way to Give Islanders Share in Tourism Benefits
response.abstract: NY Times survey of English-speaking Caribbean islands finds that a variety of pressures are forcing island govts to strive for regional cooperation and a share of tourism dollar for the islands' natives; map; unemployment high in most islands; development of regional cooperation difficult because islands are at different stages of development; recent formation of Caribbean trade assn, CARIFTA, and political cooperation evidenced in recent recognition of Cuba by 4 islands considered steps in right direction; history of islands detailed; conditions in Barbados, Antigua and St Vincent described as illustrative of different situations existing in Caribbean area; illus

response.headline: Fee Outlook Jars Brokers
response.abstract: article details huge implications of freely negotiated rates for small investor and brokerage cos; describes present financial condition of brokerage community, which is finding it increasingly difficult to survive in wake of shrinking profits, and absence of small investors in part as result of present high comm rate system for small trades; notes price range for NYSE seat has fallen despite sharp gains in avg daily trading vol; notes recent Cong action to abolish fixed comms and Needham's support of competitive rates coupled with his proposal to eliminate 3d mkt, which he sees siphoning business away from exch members; notes questions raised by people in Wall St concerning Govt attitudes about abolishing fixed rates when they see negotiated rates as probably giving insts more clout and even greater cost advantage over small investors; discusses outlook that competitive rates may mean even higher rates for small investors, shrinkage in number of brokerage cos in business, and increasing mkt domination of inst investors; 62-72 graph of NYSE seat price and daily trading vol

response.headline: Office Market Improves Slowly
response.abstract: Survey of NYC's office-space market, based on ints with brokers, builders and city officials, shows leasing activity increased in '72 but indicates substantial inventory of vacant space; about 3.4-million sq ft of office space was leased in '72, an increase of 18% over '71, but decrease from annual avg of 7.7-million sq ft for yrs '66 through '70; J J Studley Inc notes that almost 30-million sq ft of office space has been completed in last 2 yrs, with about one-third remaining vacant; city's total amount of office space is about 225-million sq ft; charts list bldgs completed in '72, those scheduled for completion in '73 and '74 and those projected for '75 and after, giving bldg address, name of builder, number of stories and sq ft of rentable space; list of office completions from '47 through '72; illus

response.headline: U.S. Is Studying Its Options in Sudan
response.abstract: US State Dept task force headed by A H Meyer keeps steady contact on Mar 3 with developments in Sudan after killing of Noel and Moore, but there seems little that can be done to capture commandos without endangering remaining hostages in Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum; Eid is reptd on Mar 3 to have been slain; Pres Nixon sends Govt plane to Khartoum carrying 3 children of slain US diplomats; State Dept says that W B Macober Jr, sent to Khartoum by Nixon, has reached Ethiopia but dust storm prevented his arrival in Sudan; US officials in Khartoum are understood to have informed Sudanese that US revulsion at killings would heighten if authorities allowed terrorists to escape

response.headline: NORTH VIETNAM FREES 3D GROUP OF U.S. PRISONERS
response.abstract: newsmen H Faas, photographer for AP, and C Callery, camera crewman with NBC, who were invited to Hanoi to witness the release of Amer POWs, are refused entry at Gia Lam airfield, Hanoi; are told that, the invitation notwithstanding, they needed entry visas; earlier, the 2 were denied press privileges by the US and S Vietnam; Hanoi officials confirm that the third group of Amer POWs will be freed Mar 4 as scheduled; US authorities barred 2 men from flying on US plane that was to fly truce reprs to Hanoi, saying the mil comm had not yet agreed to any press policy; both made their way to Laos, en route to Hanoi, but Hanoi Embassy denied them visas on the ground it had not been informed of the matter; USSR plane carried them to Hanoi without asking them for a visa

response.headline: wages ‘The Magic Number Is A Blur’

response.headline: Japan's First Defense Plan Since the War Is Disclosed
response.abstract: Authoritative Japanese Govt officials rept on Mar 3 that Japan's armed forces have drafted their first mil doctrine in 22 yrs setting forth fundamental plans for defending Japan from any attack by USSR or Communist China; basic theme of doctrine points up vulnerability of Japan to mil attack and the declining confidence of Japanese in Amer commitment under US-Japan Mutual Security Treaty; officials say doctrine assumes attack from USSR would be conventional and Japan's mil forces would try to hold on until Amer help arrived but would surrender if it did not; rept doctrine further assumes attack from China would take form of internal insurgency to which Japan is even more vulnerable but which its forces would try to crush without much aid from US; say doctrine recognizes that state of Japanese-US relations and US-USSR relations at the time will have major bearing on whether and how fast US will act and intervene if USSR attacks; officials insist contingency plan is purely mil in character and does not reflect Japan's diplomatic posture towards USSR or China; notable omissions in doctrine are provisions to send Japanese mil forces abroad, to have nuclear arms or to expand mil forces beyond those projected in 4th 5-yr mil plan being considered in Parliament; Japanese officials say drafting of new strategic doctrine stems from Asia policy proclaimed by Pres Nixon calling on Asian nations to shoulder major responsibility for self-defense; hold Nixon policy is unclear on US commitment to Japan; note Japanese mil doctrine has not been officially adopted by Govt nor has it been made public because of opposition parties; mil forces have accepted strategy set forth in plan; specific roles for each branch of Japan's mil services, as set out in mil doctrine, detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A TERRORISTS GIVER IN SUDAN; FREE 2 HOSTAGES
response.abstract: Mar 4: 7 Black September guerrillas, who killed US Amb C A Noel Jr, US charge d'affaires G C Moore and Belgian charge d'affaires G Eid on Mar 2, surrender on Mar 4 to Sudanese Govt; Saudi Amb A al-Malhouk and Jordanian charge d'affaires A el-Nazir, who were held by Palestinian guerrillas since Mar 1, are reptd safe; bodies of 3 diplomats are recovered from Saudi Arabian Embassy; special plane is expected to take bodies of Americans back to US; there is no immediate word on how guerrillas will be dealt with by Sudanese Govt, which supports Palestinian cause; illus of 2 masked terrorists standing on balcony of Saudi Embassy in Khartoum

response.headline: MARSHALS TRADE FIRE WITH INDIANS
response.abstract: militant Indians holding Wounded Knee, SD, settlement on Mar 3 say they will abandon their takeover of village if Justice Dept agrees to proposal drawn up by Indians, their farmer hostages and local clergymen; say Justice Dept must also agree not to make mass arrests; Justice Dept announces cease-fire; says armored personnel carriers will be removed; coalition's 4-point proposal calls for Indians to vacate town, for Fed officers to leave area immediately, for restitution of personal property damage and for group of SD clergymen to observe such procedures; illus

response.headline: ‘Gazumping’ Phenomenon in London Fades

response.headline: Nixon's Presidency: Crisis for Congress
response.abstract: 64-EDC-DGM-BYLCommager, Henry Steele; 2d in series of articles on Pres Nixon's use of powers of Presidency and its effects on Govt and natl life discusses crisis between Pres and Cong, at heart of which is Pres Nixon's recent move to reorder domestic priorities by impounding funds and liquidating some agencies despite Cong mandates; says it also involves gen erosion of powers from Cong to Pres, process that has accelerated in Nixon Adm; says that what is at stake is whether Cong will survive as strong and effective branch of Govt and whether more power will continue to accumulate in Pres without accompanying restraints and means of accountability to public; some developments pointing to erosion of Cong authority include: Pres Nixon's budget message which said that in order to control inflation and carry out his camapign pledge not to seek tax rise, he would not fund some programs enacted by Cong and would curtail others; Pres Nixon's broadening of use of exec privilege to protect himself and members of his Adm from Cong and public inquiry; reorganization of exec branch by Pres thereby curtailing Cong access and authority in some areas of Govt; article says that fight with Cong is essentially over which branch of Govt will decide which programs will be cut and by how much
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LEFT SHOWS GAIN IN FRENCH VOTE; GAULLISTS DOWN
response.abstract: French Left scores heavy gains in Mar 4 elections, but most likely not enough to upset Gaullist Govt; with 22.4-million of 25.5-million votes counted, Gaullists win 38.1%, leftist coalition 43.2%, including 21.1% for Communists and 22.1% for Socialists, extreme left 3.2%, centrist Reformers 12.4% and extreme right 2.6%; 82% turnout highest in yrs; much is dependent on 2d round voting and accompanying bargaining; Govt's ability to draw votes from Reformers seen as key factor; run-off expected to be hard-fought and possibly close; 90% of 490 Assembly seats forced to run-off; few Socialists, Communist and centrist Reformers win election due to multitude of candidates; some best-known Govt candidates winning in '68 1st round are forced to run-offs; centrist Reform leader M Poniatowski to demand more cooperative policy toward EEC partners and more regional decentralization in France in return for swinging support to Gaullists; C de Gaulle's successors lacked his appeal to mobilize voter support with result sign of further pol change

response.headline: Europeans, Seeking Wider Money Talks, To Close Markets
response.abstract: EEC member countries decide Mar 4 to close foreign-exchange mkts while establishing defense in latest internatl monetary crisis; decide to invite US, Japan, Canada and other countries to Mar 9 conf; mkt closings will result in de facto float of currencies; EEC is considering linking its 9 currencies in float against dollar in proposal called Eur solution; French Min Giscard d'Estaing sees US responsible and proposes Amer solution in which US would support dollar in foreign-exchange mkts; EEC communique sees crisis not caused by parity disequilibrium but by existence of vast sums mobilized by speculators; W Ger Min H Schmidt says if joint float is not adopted, mark will be forced to float independently; GB Chancellor A Barber says GB's participation in joint float will depend on new acceptable rate for pound, right of EEC countries to change rates after consultation with Council of Mins and support for weak currencies in joint float without limit on amount or obligation to repay; Barber's conditions seen moving Eur long way toward common reserve pooling; illus

response.abstract: Mar 6: Sudanese Foreign Min M Khaled on Mar 5 says that Black September commandos who killed Noel, Moore and Eid will have early trial on murder charges; says he will not pre-judge what action of ct might be; notes there will be an investigation, trial and murder charges; denies repts that 8 commandos had extracted promise from Sudanese Govt that no capital charges will be filed against them; Pres Nimeiry appoints 3-man investigating comm headed by prosecutor gen A Imam; Presidential jet takes bodies of Noel and Moore to US; US mil plane flies Eid's body to Cairo; Sudanese in increasing numbers are suggesting that commando attack was inspired and planned by Libya and had nothing to do with issue of Palestine; Govt-controlled Khartoum newspaper Al Sahafa attributes attack to 'external fronts'--euphemism used to describe activities by Libya and other Arab govts with whom Sudan's relations have been tense; says 6 commandos arrived in Khartoum from Libya and that officials of local Al Fatah office were in charge of them; notes Fatah leader F Yassin left Khartoum for Libya on day of attack; illus of Noel's coffin, Mrs Noel and Mrs Moore and several of their children

response.headline: Nixon's Presidency: Centralized Control
response.abstract: 3d in series of articles on Pres Nixon's use of powers of Presidency and its effects on Govt and natl life discusses Nixon's plans to reorganize exec branch, which Cong refused to pass; notes complaints from Nixon's critics that in his massive reorganization he has weakened his system of advisers and Cabinet members; notes that movement of decision-making from depts, which are relatively open, to White House, which is inaccessible to many groups, is increasing more rapidly under Nixon; notes that white House assts have strong influence not only over exec depts but also over supposedly independent regulatory agencies in several ways; Adm official says that agencies that really amount to entire ministries operate out of White House under names public rarely hears; article notes Nixon's dismissal of several of his apptees because of disagreements; discusses new Cabinet; illus of chain of command; illus of Mgt and Budget Office Deputy Dir Malek

response.headline: Air Collision Kills 68 in France During a Strike of Controllers
response.abstract: Spantax Airlines: Iberia Airlines DC-9 and Spantax Airlines Coronado-990 collide during flight near Nantes, France, on Mar 5 during strike of French air traffic controllers; Coronado-990 makes emergency landing at mil airfield near Cognac, France, but DC-9 explodes and creashes killing all 68 aboard; air traffic controllers blame French Defense Min for accident; Iberia cancels all flights over French airspace; passenger aboard Coronado describes accident; map of crash site

response.headline: U.S. Dollar Strengthens In Major‐Currency Float
response.abstract: world currency mkts function well in private trading Mar 5 as govts allow currencies to float with official foreign exchange dealings closed; chief result is strengthening of dollar; effective devaluation of dollar at noon Mar 5 is 7.16% from values agreed at Smithsonian Inst in Dec '71; experts see historic de facto system of 'floating' exchange rates emerging with less govt interference than ever before

response.headline: 1972 CRIME TOTAL IN CITY FELL 18% AS VIOLENCE ROSE
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr Murphy holds news conf on Mar 6 to announce 18% decline in serious crimes for '72, however there was increase over '71 shown for murder, rape and felonious assault; Murphy concludes 'streets are a little safer than last yr'; disbelief expressed at Murphy's statements by Dem mayoral aspirants Reprs Koch and Biaggi; Police Dept statistics detailed; graphs; concept of index crimes criticized on grounds it is racially biased; another criticism is that they measure only crimes reptd to police; Murphy claims decline is due to improved criminal cts operation, drug addiction treatment programs and work by anticrime units; crime experts comment; illus

response.headline: Counsel to Nixon Attended F.B.I. Watergate Quizzing
response.abstract: Acting FBI dir L P Gray 3d says on Mar 6 that Pres counsel J W Dean 3d was present when White House employes were interviewed by FBI agents about Watergate bugging case, testimony before Sen Judiciary Com; says Dean's attendance was 'not normal procedure' and that it occurred against his personal wishes; says he was informed that Dean was there in his official capacity; deputy White House press sec Warren acknowledges that Dean sat in on all of ints with White House officials, but that there was no action by anyone at White House to hinder Watergate investigation; documents provided by Gray to com indicate that FBI questioned J D Ehrlichman, D Chapin and C W Colson at White House; Gray says that memorandum requested by Dean last July summarizing status of Watergate investigation to date was prepared and sent to Atty Gen Kleindienst rather than directly to White House; assumes it reached Dean; FBI says, in memorandum requested by Dean, that its ints of members of Nixon re-election com were hampered by 'insistence' that com atty be present; another document discloses that M H Stans told FBI agents last yr that he was 'aware from gen conversation' that Watergate defendant Liddy was assigned to security gathering job and that certain cash disbursements would have to be made available to him; discloses that Colson told FBI agents last Aug that he authorized Hunt to make trip to Denver, home of D D Beard, 'in connection with ITT matter'; Gray repeats his pledge to permit any Sen to examine FBI's complete Watergate files and asks for com's 'guidance' in insuring that nothing is discussed publicly that would affect natl security, motions or appeals growing out of criminal trial or 'right to privacy of those innocent persons whose names and activities are contained in our raw int repts'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ellsberg Witness Asserts Military Falsified Reports
response.abstract: CIA analyst S A Adams testifies on Mar 6 at Pentagon papers trial that he had attended confs in Saigon and Hawaii and at CIA, in which mil purposely diminished estimates of enemy strength in Vietnam; says that there were pol pressures in mil to display enemy as weaker than he actually was; says that monthly estimates of enemy's mil strength were so inaccurate that 2 official sets of estimates had to be put together each mo by the Army and by CIA; says his own studies of enemy strength indicated that correct order of battle would have shown at least 400,000 enemy troops, not 240,000 as was cited in '68 Joint Chiefs of Staff memorandum
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Accusation in Khartoum
response.abstract: Mar 7: Sudanese Pres Nimeiry on Mar 6 accuses head of Khartoum office of Al Fatah, Palestinian commando orgn, of having been key planner of attack by Black September terrorists on Saudi Arabian Embassy in which US Amb C A Noel Jr, US charge d'affaires G C Moore and Belgian charge d'affaires G Eid were slain; says that hq of all Palestinian orgns in Sudan will be closed, and vows that 8 Black September guerrillas will be tried for murder under Sudanese law, which provides death penalty for murder; notes that Fatah repr F Yassin left Sudan on Libyan airliner few hrs before Saudi Embassy was invaded by terrorists on Mar 1; asks that Yassin be extradited by 'Arab country where he may now find himself'; asserts that Yassin was invited to go to Libya; statement is interpreted as implied charge that Libya instigated commando operation; Sudanese officials say privately that purpose of terrorist attack on embassy was to disrupt Sudan's celebration of 1st anniversary of peace agreement that ended civil war between central Govt in Khartoum and rebels in south, wreck conciliation in Sudan between Arab-Moslem north and pagan and Christian black south, and disrupt Sudan's relations with US and other countries; Nimeiry s speech is regarded as strongest attack to date by Sudanese leader against Libyan Govt of Col Qaddafi; relations between 2 countries have been strained since it became clear that Nimeiry had no intention of joining Libya, Egypt and Syria in Fed of Arab Republics; Nimeiry appeals to Fatah leader Y Arafat, head of Palestine Liberation Orgn, to publicly condemn Black September; asserts that Palestinian A Salem, 2d-ranking official of Khartoum office of Fatah, was in charge of terrorist operation once it got under way
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Deadlock on Prisoners Is Broken In Apparent Saigon Compromise
response.abstract: Impasse on exchange of Vietnamese POWs is broken Mar 7 at meeting of mil comm; Vietnam offers to release 6,300 prisoners in 2nd phase of exchanges; Communists will release more than 1,000 S Vietnamese POWs; promise to ascertain if they hold more POWs than have been listed so far; recently S Vietnam scaled down number to be exchanged to 3,000 in attempt to force N Vietnamese and Vietcong to admit they were holding more than the 4,700 S Vietnam POWs they acknowledge; controversy continues over how Vietcong delegates to mil comm should be permitted to travel to team sites; S Vietnamese refuse to pick up Vietcong delegates at proposed pickup sites; are reluctant to concede that site proposed is in zone of Vietcong control; on Mar 5 chief delegates agree to ensure certain rights and security of Communist delegates
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Offer by King Hussein
response.abstract: Jordanian King Hussein, responding to Arab appeals for clemency, on Mar 6 suspends death sentences against 17 Palestinian commandos if their guerrilla orgns halt subversion against Jordan; says 'Arab cause' against Israel is being undermined in world opinion by extremist actions by Black September terrorists, such as killing of Noel, Moore and Eid; Hussein responded to killings on Mar 4 by signing decrees confirming death sentences against commandos, who Jordan says were led by A Daoud, member of Central Com of Al Fatah, main guerrilla group, and charged with entering country secretly to prepare uprising against Hussein; it is declared aim of Black September, believed to consist of Fatah members and leaders, such as S Khalef, to assassinate Hussein, whom they term lackey of US; Amman radio broadcasts Hussein's reply to Kuwaiti ruler Sheik Sabah al-Salem al-Sabah, who sent repr to Hussein to appeal for clemency, offering to call off planned execution if commando orgn, led by Fatah, agreed to 'put an end once and for all to their plots against Jordan'; Daoud and his fellow commandos remain in Jordanian hands while they await response of Palestinian commando groups
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon's Presidency: A Nation Is Changed
response.abstract: 4th and last of series of articles on Pres Nixon's use of powers of Presidency and its effects on Govt and natl life discusses reversal of long-term trend--money and authority are flowing back to states and Pres and his men are dismantling programs built by 4 decades of Dem govt; says Nixon has expanded in number of ways enormous influence that White House brings to bear on public opinion; notes indications that Pres Nixon intends to be highly active Pres for rest of his Adm; notes wide impact New Federalism is having on educ, agr, science, antipoverty efforts, race relations and cities; some authorities believe that Nixon's influence on Sup Ct may ultimately have greater effect on US than what Nixon does with Fed money; it is considered almost certain that Nixon will have an ideological majority on Sup Ct before his term is out; Nixon has gone further than other modern Presidents in publicly attacking ct rulings and has publicly advocated legis to find ways to get around Sup Ct rulings; Nixon's influence on media and non-Fed insts noted; Nixon's gains with organized labor noted; illus of Nixon with reporter S Pett
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lame Duck Mayor Faces Power Slippage
response.abstract: Mayor Lindsay, who becomes lame duck Mayor as result of his decision not to seek 3d term, is seen facing power slippage, exodus of top city officials, dismantling of some cherished programs, slower-paced govt bureaucracy and politicians and bureaucrats who believe that they can thwart him with impunity; R F Wagner, former 3-term Mayor who became lame duck when he announced he would not seek re-election in June '65, asserts 'there's no question about it, you haven't the same control'; notes onset of sluggishness in govt, starting at top; holds there is 'an inclination to slow down a bit'; Lindsay is not regarded as traditional lame duck; is widely expected to run for another office so that politicians who cross him are seen doing so at their peril; Deputy Mayor E K Hamilton holds Lindsay will attempt to remain strong Mayor until Dec 31

response.headline: U.S Offers Europe Help In Settling Money Crisis
response.abstract: US offers on Mar 9 to cooperate with EEC to help settle latest monetary crisis and to insure jointly an orderly exch-rate system; finance mins and central-bank govs meeting in Paris issue communique indicating no substantive decisions have been made on crisis but imply certain changes in US monetary policy; set Mar 19 as date for reopening of exch mkts; agree that crisis is due to speculative movements of funds and indicate satisfaction with existing relationships between currency values; communique says mins and govs believe crisis underlines need for reform of monetary system but omits refs to parities or fixed rates; key questions are whether EEC can maintain its monetary unity in such new system and whether new rules can be written to define conditions for exch rate moves to avert currency wars; Min Giscard d'Estaing tells reporters that exch rates set on Feb 12 would be defended; Sec Shultz says he made no commitment of any kind except to work constructively with others; says EEC's list of measures it suggested to US requires 'careful thought' and that he can make no commitments about any possible Amer policy moves until US sees what Eurs do; rules out suggestion that US raise its interest rates to attract more dollars home; appears to rule out revocation, sought by Eurs, of Amer plans to phase out controls over outflow of capital by '74; denies any parallel between present situation and '30s; will remain in Paris for private talk with Giscard d'Estaing; Eurs are reptd to have suggested US intervene in exch mkts to defend dollar's parity; Under Sec Volcker is reptd to have told C Pierre-Brossolette that US interest rates would be rising to control econ expansion

response.headline: School Funding Viewed As Chaotic and Unjust
response.abstract: Quasi-governmental group Educ Comm of the States on Mar 10 issues rept portraying current system of financing pss in almost all states as chaotic and unjust, NY Times survey; findings will provide ammunition for group's members in their urgent effort to bring equity to property-tax financing system; members of group are govs, 2 legislators, school officers and laymen from each of 43 states plus Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands; virtually every state is under pressure of Texas case, Rodriguez v. San Antonio Ind School Dist, and Calif case, Serrano V. Priest, to make property taxes more equitable; both cases challenge const of tax financing system that allows vast disparities in amount that school dists have for children's educ; abolition of property-tax financing of educ has been recommended by various govt and private groups beginning in early '60's; comm found, however, that there is strong opposition in every part of country to abolishing local property tax in favor of state and Fed financing; opposition is seen to lie in yrs of tradition and familiarity with present system, desire for local control of schools and realization that new sources of funding will be hard to find; possible effects of Sup Ct decision upholding Texas or Calif case noted; rept also finds that ratio of assessed valuation per pupil between wealthiest and poorest dists in each state ranges from 1.7 to 1 in ND to 182.8 to 1 in Kan; map of ratios; 30 states require no training or certification of local tax assessors; only 15 states provide money to localities to upgrade poor assessment practices; 21 states do not even require use of tax maps for assessment purposes

response.headline: GAULLIST CROUP RETAINS POWER FOR FIVE YEARS
response.abstract: Gaullist Govt wins renewed 5-yr mandate in Mar 11 final round of French legis elections with stronger showing than expected; with 483 of 490 seats decided, Gaullists win 271, Socialist-Communist alliance 178 and Reformers 28; Govt, in losing 277-seat majority, will be more dependent on coalition partners; Gaullists wider margin attributed to intense anti-Communist campaign, bringing out 82.5% voters, and to reptd deal between Premier P Messmer and Reformers' leaders J Lecanuet exchanging withdrawals in 100 dists, leaving single candidate running against left; projected composition of new Assembly makes it unnecessary for Pres Pompidou to rely on Reformers for assured control; Lecanuet and other Reformer leader J-J Servan-Schreiber re-elected solidly; Socialist leader F Mitterrand established as likely '76 leftist candidate; Min Giscard d'Estaing seen as favored Govt candidate; Pompidou and wife illus; Servan-Schreiber and Lecanuet pors
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Governor of Bermuda and Aide Are Assassinated
response.abstract: state of emergency declared in Bermuda following March 10 murder of Bermuda Gov Sir R Sharpies and his aide de camp, Capt H Sayers; illus; acting Gov I Kinnear gives police authority to detain suspects for 48 hrs without charge; Scotland Yard sends 9 detectives to Bermuda; unsolved murder 6 mos ago of Bermuda Police Chief G Duckett recalled; acting Gov Kinnear issues statement acknowledging tendency in tight-knit community to avoid implicating others; asks anyone knowing anything about the murders to come forth rather than risk 'rule of the gun' in Bermuda; effect of murders and state of emergency on tourism, island's main industry, unknown; decline in tourism in '68, following street riots by island's black inhabitants seeking greater share of tourism dollar, recalled; Gov Sharpies, in office 6 mos, had reputation as outgoing administrator; reaction to murders from island's pol leaders noted; illus of Sharpies in recent photos; Govt House
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Midwest Strained As Grain Sales Glut Railways and Ports
response.abstract: record shipments of grain have overloaded rrs and ports and spread severe financial problems along network reaching into major grain producing areas of Midwest; railwaymen, grain handlers, and farmers say that at current rate of movement not all of '72 grain harvest can be moved in time to make way for '73 crop; foresee grain surpluses; rail tie-up seen threat to farmers production plans; some of specific problems in Midwest discussed; several farmers comment on problems; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Need for Pennsy Doubted In Solving of Rail Crisis
response.abstract: Fed Railroad Admr J Ingram int by Robert E Bedingfield; por; disagrees with Penn Central senior trustee Jervis Langdon Jr's contention that competing lines cannot absorb traffic handled by Penn Central between such key points as Cleveland, Ohio, and Buffalo, NYS; says Transportation Dept may submit proposal to rip up 10,000 miles or more of 30,000 miles of track that belong to 6 bankrupt railroads in Northeast; may submit plan to cut down working force of railroads in area to number actually required to operate reduced plant; may look at layers of railroad management and demand sacrifices to match those of bond holders and railroad unions
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GERMANY RAISES MARK BY 3%, JOINS FRANCE IN FLOAT
response.abstract: W Ger Min H Schmidt announces Mar 12 that mark will be revalued upward by 3% when foreign exchange mkts reopen Mar 19; decision taken at Cabinet meeting headed by Chancellor Brandt is announced at end of 11-hr EEC finance mins meeting in Brussels; agreement reached for 6 of 9 EEC members, W Ger, France, Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and Denmark, to float currencies jointly against dollar; GB and Italy to float currencies independently while studying ways to bring currencies into line with joint float; Ireland to follow GB's lead; W Ger is raising mark's value to make jointly floated currencies less prone to rise; joint float may add stability to internatl system and accelerate Eur monetary union; Schmidt suggests EEC study possibility of underwriting GB's $8-billion debt to sterling-area govts; GB's conditions for participation in float included 'unlimited financial support' without conditions or obligation to repay; EEC to support float by establishing Eur monetary fund representing pooled reserves of participating countries
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: F.B.I. Agent Shot as Indians Warn U.S.
response.abstract: FBI agent C Fitzgerald is shot and militant Indian injured on Mar 11 when gunfire erupts at roadblock in Wounded Knee (SD); Fed agents restoring armed ring around village, which was occupied by members of Amer Indian Movement and their supporters on Feb 27; AIM leader R Means announces their secession from US and says any foreign official representing foreign power, especially US, will be treated as war agent; about 400 militants occupy village, most not armed; Indians detain 6 Govt officials when they attempt to investigate rumors that mail boxes had been burglarized, but they are released unharmed; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Again Blocks Roads
response.abstract: special asst to Atty Gen R E Erickson announces that armed Fed officers will re-establish roadblocks on all rds to occupied Wounded Knee, SD, on May 12 after both sides cancel meeting; move came after Mar 11 gun battle between Indians and FBI in which FBI agent was wounded; chief of Fed marshals' force W Colburn says Govt will have to take strong position against insurgents; officials hope that because of roadblock, hunger will force negotiations; Colburn and assoc Deputy Atty Gen C B Abelard plan 'no rash action' but note forced entry 'has to remain as an option'; S Holder, head of security arrangements for militants, notes Indians have declared themselves an independent nation and no longer recognize authority of US Govt; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PERONIST ELECTED ARGENTINE CHIEF, LOUSE REPORTS
response.abstract: Peronist H J Campora wins pres election in Argentina with 49% of vote; illus; many Peronist candidates for legis, provincial and municipal posts also victorious; 90% of those eligible turn out to vote; Peronists, banned from legal pol activity since Peron's deposition in '55, take over Govt on May 25; Campora's closest rival, R Balbin, gets only 21.2% of vote; Campora pledges to represent Peron 'with all fidelity'; Peron, forbidden by mil rulers to return to Argentina until after elections, hears of results in exile in Spain; despite moderate platform offered by Peronist coalition, many, remembering abuses of old Peron regime, fear return of Peronist govt; some, however, question ability of new Peronist coalition to act as cohesive force once in power; in Buenos Aires, police use tear gas grenades to disperse Peronist demonstrators
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON SAYS AIDES WILL NOT TESTIFY BEFORE CONGRESS
response.abstract: Pres Nixon says on Mar 12 that members and former members of his personal staff will decline to make any formal appearances before Cong coms, policy statement on exec privilege; statement indicates that Nixon is ruling out appearances before Cong of Pres counsel J W Dean 3d and former White House aide D L Chapin in Sen inquiry into pol sabotage during last yr's Pres race; Sen is expected to ask Dean to testify and may ask Chapin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Europe's Technicians in a Job Scramble
response.abstract: NY Times survey of rising unemployment among execs and technicians in W Eur; prime factors are co mergers and a recent recession; specific cases cited; affected people comment; illus; chart of rising unemployment among highly qualified in GB and France
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BERMUDA PRESSES HUNT IN MURDERS
response.abstract: Bermuda Govt extends police emergency powers in effort to speed solution to March 10 murder of Gov R Sharpies and aide de camp Capt H Sayers; no arrests announced but police detain several for questioning; all those detained reptdly are black; Scotland Yard sends 3d highest-ranking officer, Comdr J Morrison, to oversee investigation by largest force of detectives (9) ever sent by Yard to Bermuda; Govt taking same close-mouthed attitude it did following still unsolved murder 6 mos ago of Bermuda Police Chief G Duckett; Govt House, where murder of Sharpies and Sayers occurred, is 17-room residence, basically unprotected, of island's governor; Lady Sharpies expected to announce funeral plans tomorrow; officials reportedly assume murders were committed by Bermudians; tourism, island's main industry, seemingly unaffected by recent events
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Frankie Frisch Dies
response.abstract: Frankie Frisch, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, died in Wilmington, Del., yesterday at the age of 74. He had suffered critical injuries a month ago in an automobile accident near Elkton, Md. Details, Page 42.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Conservatives Pick Biaggi As Candidate for Mayor
response.abstract: Conservative party leaders on Mar 12 endorse H McShane, Queens Repub and lawyer, for NYC City Council Pres

response.headline: G.M. ASKS DELAY ON '75 STANDARDS
response.abstract: GM vp Starkman tells EPA officials at pub hearing Mar 12 that co cannot comply with '75 auto pollution limitations set by Clean Air Act of '70; urges 1-yr delay; says use of catalytic converter presents possible 'risk of business catastrophe'; por; other major auto producers are scheduled to testify at hearings; provisions of Clean Air Act outlined

response.headline: 3 Seized in Capital In Stennis Shooting
response.abstract: FBI and Washington (DC) police on Mar 12 announce arrest of 3 men in Jan 20 robbery and shooting of Sen J C Stennis; men identified as T I Marshall, J S Marshall and D Holloway; bonds of $100,000 have been set suspects, who are charged with Cong assault statutes, committing crime while armed and robbery; Stennis is reptd to be in 'much improved' condition

response.headline: Downey Back Home To Visit His Mother
response.abstract: arrives home at New Britain, Conn, Mar 12; goes to bedside of ailing mother; is greeted by Conn Gov T Meskill; homecoming described; Peking broadcast attributes release to confession of crimes and good behavior; por

response.headline: RAIL LABOR PACT WITH 14 UNIONS IS REPORTED NEAR
response.abstract: Railroads and 14 unions are on verge of signing new 18-month nationwide labor contract including provisions for wage levels and work rules; new contract will not affect local labor disputes, including strikes against Penn Central and LIRR, which are not parties to national negotions; railroads reportedly regard 5.5% guideline for raises as still applicable in Phase 3 of Nixon Adm's econ program; reportedly are willing to go beyond guideline to compensate unions for concessions on work rules; change in some of top negotiators on both sides is frequently cited reason for early and peaceful settlement of contract negotiations

response.headline: Mayor of Albany Accused Of Balking State Inquiry
response.abstract: NYS Comm of Investigation on Mar 13 charges that Albany Mayor E Corning 2d is trying to delay and hinder investigation into allegations of corruption in Albany police dept; Corning calls charges 'publicity stunt'; says comm is harassing police

response.headline: BIG MEAT PACKER ACCUSED OF BRIBES
response.abstract: NYC Dist Atty Hogan announces on Mar 13 indictment of Iowa Beef Processors Inc, co-chmn of bd of dirs C J Holman, Daitch Shopwell official M Steinman, and C P Sales, meat brokerage concern, on charges of having conspired to bribe union and supermarket officials to sell Iowa Beefs products in NYC; indictment charges that Steinman was key figure in scheme involving several supermarket chains and resulting in over $1-million in pay-offs since '71; Asst Dist Atty F Snitow says scheme threatened labor unions in area; Holman and Steinman plead not guilty before Sup Ct Justice X Riccobono; Hogan says investigation is continuing to determine whether organized crime figures have infiltrated NYC meat indus and unions; Steinman admitted in '69 investigation that he had close ties with crime figure John Dioguardi

response.headline: Boyle Is Implicated By Yablonski Killer
response.abstract: murder trial of William J Prater continues Mar 13; convicted killer Paul E Gilly says he, Claude E Vealey, and Aubran W Martin shot and killed Yablonski family on orders from Mrs Gilly, her father, Silous Huddleston, Prater, and W A Boyle; says Prater and Albert E Pass sought vengeance against Yablonski for attempting to oust Boyle from UMW presidency; says he was persuaded to kill Yablonski in return for union pension for his father
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Biaggi Enters Race And Attacks Bosses
response.abstract: Repr M Biaggi, formally announcing his candidacy for NYC Mayor on Mar 13, says that police corruption in city has been reduced because of legalized off-track betting

response.headline: Downey Is Doubtful His imprisonment ‘Benefited Anybody’
response.abstract: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 13—John T. Downey reflected today on his long imprisonment in China and said it had cost him a great part of his life, apparently for naught.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Revenue Sharing for Education Could Cost New York Millions
response.abstract: Nixon Adm briefing sheet recd by NY Times reveals that revenue-sharing proposal for educ would make drastic changes in way Fed aid is allocated to schools with disadvantaged children and could cost NYS and other large states millions of dollars; HEW Dept Sec Weinberger has pledged to fight for revenue-sharing, even though it is expected to meet considerable hostility in Cong; Adm officials have threatened to withhold money Cong provides for old educ programs if it does not become law; programs would be replaced by grants for 5 broad categories--educ for disadvantaged, educ of handicapped, assistance to schools with pupils who live on Fed property, vocational educ and supportive services such as school lunches and libraries; several proposals in plan that will mean less money for NYS are noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Con Ed Sure of Supply
response.abstract: Consolidated Edison expects its supply of electricity for the summer to be the best in three or four years, Charles F. Luce, chairinan, said yesterday. He predicted rate increases of 8 to 10 per cent a year for five years if the present inflation continued. Details on Page 55.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Thousands of Vietnam Veterans on Welfare Here
response.abstract: Article discusses thousands of Vietnam veterans in NYC who are receiving welfare through NYC Veterans Assistance Center for Income Maintenance; an estimated 4,000 to 4,500 Vietnam veterans now receive welfare through the center; total does not reflect all young veterans who have turned to welfare because they cannot find jobs in NYC; NYC Human Rights Comm begins hearings into problems of Vietnam veterans on Mar 14; welfare needs of veterans have grown so large that on Mar 16 NYC will open center exclusively for Vietnam veterans at 90 Myrtle Av, Bklyn; NYC HRA Deputy Admr C Morris asserts many men are reptg to center complaining about being on welfare and are interested in obtaining jobs; adds 'it is very plain that they do not want to be on welfare'; veterans comment on situation; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Senate Panel Calls Dean In a Challenge to Nixon
response.abstract: Sen Judiciary Com votes unanimously on March 13 to call Pres Nixon's chief legal counsel J W Dean 3d as witness at its confirmation hearings on L P Gray 3d to become FBI Dir; Com's request falls short of authority of subpoena and com members decline to say what steps they will take if White House continues to refuse to make Dean available; Sen Tunney says he believes it 'quite improbable' that com will vote to confirm Gray in absence of testimony by Dean on number of points raised in hearings; Gray has told com that he sent number of repts relating to FBI's Watergate investigation to Dean; Judiciary Com votes to call J Hoback, asst to Nixon Finance Com treas Sloan and T Lumbard, former Treas and Justice Dept atty who has alleged that Dean worked closely with Watergate defendant Liddy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: G.O.P. Liberals Weigh A Deal to Back Wagner
response.abstract: NYS Gov Rockefeller and NYC's 5 Repub county chmn meet privately on Mar 13 to discuss possibility of choosing former Dem NYC Mayor R F Wagner as Repub candidate for Mayor; no final decision is made as other names are considered; Liberals support idea; other names discussed include Controller A Beame and State Sen R Goodman; Dem aspirants for post are concerned that Wagner's entry might complicate already crowded race; possible Repub aspirants react with what is termed controlled dismay; Wagner discusses possible candidacy; por; Rockefeller is determined to keep pol enemy, Mayor Lindsay, out of race
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Campora Demands Peron Be Present at Oath Taking
response.abstract: H J Campora, pres-elect of Argentina, announces plan to visit former pres J D Peron in exile in Spain; ruling mil junta forbids Peron from returning to Argentina until new govt is sworn in; Campora insistant that Peron be present at swearing in; new Peronist team elected with 49% of popular vote; despite great support, new Govt must face country's shaky econ; severity of economic problems and inability to solve them thought to be reason why mil Govt willingly stepped down after 7 yrs in power; mil nevertheless unhappy about return to power of Peronists; in Madrid, Peron says he will not return to Argentina before swearing in of new Govt; expresses faith in armed forces; pol leaders in Brazil fear cooling off of relations with Argentina with new Peronist regime in power
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: REAL CEASE‐FIRE APPEARS ELUSIVE AS U.S. ENDS ROLE
response.abstract: Little prospect of a true cease-fire seen as both the Communists and the S Vietnamese continue to violate truce accord; Hanoi reptdly is stepping up infiltration of men and weapons; S Vietnamese have retaken almost 400 villages that they say the Communists seized in the hrs just before, or after the cease-fire began, and have kept truce officials from Communist govts under virtual house arrest in dilapidated mil compounds allowing several of them to be injured by Saigon-inspired mobs; US officials say one encouraging development is that the fighting has, for the most part diminished and that an uneasy and unwritten division of territory appears to be emerging in the countryside; a US diplomat says fighting has still not dropped below the threshold which would indicate a real cease-fire; Saigon repts 125 to 150 truce violations every day, and 12,590 Communist and 2,597 S Vietnamese soldiers killed since cease-fire went into effect on Jan 28; a US analyst says heavy Hanoi infiltration does not mean Communists have plans for imminent large-scale hostilities; says it may be several yrs before Hanoi puts all this equipment to use; US intelligence officers say captured Communist documents reveal that Vietcong fully intend to continue small-scale guerrilla activity; Vietcong has reptdly failed to produce its full complement of delegates to the joint mil comm; Pres Thieu reptdly has ordered his field comdrs and prov chiefs not to launch sizable operations to retake Communist-held territory and thus provoke probe by internatl control comm
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ISRAELIS WILL BUY MORE JETS IN U.S.; TOTAL IS PUT AT 48
response.abstract: US State Dept officials rept on Mar 13 that Nixon Adm will sell Israel 4 squadrons of fighter-bombers, including F-4 Phantoms and A-4 Skyhawks, with deliveries starting in Jan '74; say commitment is in addition to 42 F-4s and 80 A-4s promised to Israel under earlier agreement, and that US will provide help in production of Israeli Super Mirage
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HUSSEIN SPARES 17 PALESTINIANS
response.abstract: Jordanian King Hussein on Mar 14 says he has commuted death sentences passed against A Daoud, leader of Al Fatah guerrilla orgn, and 16 of his colleagues; death sentences were passed by ct-martial on Mar 4 and approved by Hussein; guerrillas were convicted of having entered Jordan illegally in Feb with aim of subversion against security of state; Hussein, major opponent of Palestinian guerrillas, reptdly approved death sentences in reaction to terrorist attack by Black September guerrillas on Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum, Sudan, on Mar 1, in which US Amb C A Noel Jr, US charge d'affaires G C Moore and Belgian charge d'affaires G Eid were slain; Hussein says he was prompted by 'sincere and honest appeals' that he spare lives of guerrillas
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON CRIME PLAN SENT TO CONGRESS
response.abstract: Pres Nixon sends to Cong on Mar 14 anticrime proposals, including proposals to halt airplane hijacking
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON PLANS SALES FROM STOCKPILES
response.abstract: Adm officials on Mar 14 reveal Pres Nixon has decided to sell large amounts of metals from nation's strategic stockpile in effort to drive down soaring prices, 1st such move by US; Pres will estab lower levels of such reserves, based reptdly on more peaceful atmosphere in world; among key metals affected are copper, lead, zinc, nickel, silver and tin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Senate Approves the Use Of Road Funds for Transit
response.abstract: Sen, 49-44, following tense debate, votes on Mar 14 to allow urban areas to spend their share of Fed hwy money to build rapid rail systems; proposal, amendment to $18-billion, 3-yr hwy construction bill, will permit for 1st time revenues from Hwy Trust Fund to be used for purposes not related to hwys; amendment, sponsored by Sens Muskie and H H Baker, would give met areas choice of spending $850-million they receive from fund each yr either to construct hwys, buy buses or build rapid rail systems; Nixon Adm supports mass transit plan but opposes 2 other proposals adopted by Sen, including amendment sponsored by Sen Williams to provide $3-billion more over 3 yrs from Gen Treas for construction of mass transit projects and $800-million over next 2 yrs to offset operating defects of existing systems and amendment sponsored by Sen Bellman to require that exec branch spend all money in hwy bill; Nixon Adm and several of its Dem predecessors have impounded, or withheld, hwy money in past and Nixon wants to retain this option; Sen rejects amendment that would have allowed $2.3-billion from fund to be spent on mass transit; Sen Weicker calls vote 'shattering victory over hwy lobby'; Sen Randolph, 1 of strongest advocates of more hwys, accuses Weicker of 'castigating rd bldg'; Sen Williams contends more money for construction means little if existing systems cannot afford to run; illus of Sens Muskie and Baker
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Connor, S.I. Borough President, Quits G.O.P. to Run as Democrat
response.abstract: Staten Island Boro Pres R T Connor on Mar 14 announces that he is switching from Repub to Dem party
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Jersey Issues Maps Contesting Private Rights to Riparian Land
response.abstract: NJ unveils Mar 14 first of series of tidal-flow maps that will form basis for challenges to private ownership of property in sections of Newark, Elizabeth, Hoboken and other cities; maps will show lands covered by riparian rights originally granted to state by King of Eng 200 yrs ago; Environmental Protection Comr R J Sullivan says maps will support state's claim to real estate worth millions; maps are expected to lead to lawsuits; proceeds from sale or lease of riparian land by state will go to Public School Fund
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Alleged Gallo Aide Held in Mob Killing
response.abstract: Wuyak, Sam: R Bongiovi is charged on Mar 14 with murder of S Wuyak, night mgr of Broadway Pub in NYC; police theorize that killing might have links to killing of J Gallo in Apr '72; sources say that Bongiovi and 2nd man were talking with mgr and after Wuyak mentioned friendship with J Yacovelli, reputed boss of Colombo Mafia family, he was led to rest room and shot; Asst Dist Atty R Tannebaum says killing is in line with underground execution-type murder; Bongiovi was former bodyguard of Gallo and was with him night he was killed; possible link between Wuyak's and Gallo's killings noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U. S. EASES CURES ON PAKISTAN ARMS
response.abstract: US State Dept spokesman C W Bray 3d on Mar 14 announces that US has relaxed its embargo on arms shipments to India and Pakistan; says decision permits Pakistan to receive some 300 armored personnel carriers worth $13-million and spare parts and 'nonlethal' mil equipment for previously supplied arms worth $1.2-million; says relaxation of embargo, made at request of Pakistan, will not alter mil balance or stimulate arms race between Pakistan and India, which holds overwhelming mil position; dept officials say decision was made by Nixon Adm for pol and psychological reasons rather than mil ones; say adm hopes Pakistan will become more amenable to settlement of its pol problems with India and Bangladesh as result of renewed US support; Indian Foreign Min S Singh criticizes US decision; says peace once again is threatened on subcontinent; India will be allowed to complete its purchase of some $91-million in communications equipment for air defense system that was blocked by embargo; US policy on sales to India and Pakistan revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Court Backs Con Ed On Storm King Plan
response.abstract: NYS Appeals Ct upholds state ruling that Storm King Mountain power plant would not endanger water quality standards; map of proposed plant location; Consol Ed has been trying to build plant for 10 yrs; co is pleased with decision; conservationists say that they can still prevent construction of plant
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Air Fee Approved
response.abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to add 34 cents to the cost of each airline flight to defray the cost of airport searches ordered by the White House to deter hijackers. Page 85.

response.headline: COUNSEL TO NIXON TELLS SENATE UNIT HE WON'T TESTIFY
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's chief legal counsel J W Dean 3d on Mar 14 declines invitation to appear before Sen Judiciary Com in connection with nomination of L P Gray 3d to be FBI Dir, in lr to Sen Eastland; Dean cites Pres Nixon's Mar 12 statement that all members of his personal staff will decline to make such appearances before Cong as ground for his refusal; agrees to accept and answer written questions from com that are directly related to Gray nomination but offers no assurances that he will answer any he finds unrelated; Judiciary Com cancels scheduled session on Mar 14 after witness T Lumbard withdrew his Mar 13 decision to appear; Lumbard says he did so after deciding that his testimony would be 'of marginal importance'; former FBI Asst Dir T E Bishop and former Finance Com to Re-Elect the Pres employe J Hoback also decline to testify

response.headline: Brooklyn G.O.P. Opposes Coalition Race for Wagner
response.abstract: Bklyn Repub orgn opposes Gov Rockefeller's attempt to build Repub-Liberal coalition to support former Mayor R F Wagner for NYC Mayor; contends Wagner candidacy could undermine local Repub candidates; some Repubs see Rockefeller's efforts as way to stop Lindsay and Repr M Biaggi; all careful plans of Rockefeller and Liberal leader A Rose could be jeopardized by revolt of Bklyn Repubs, headed by new county Chmn G L Clark; Clark and other leaders voted to refuse to circulate any designating petitions for Wagner and discussed challenging his designation in Repub primary; speculation as to why Wagner would consider trying to return to office

response.headline: NIXON SUGGESTS HIGHCOURT RULING ON REFUSING DATA
response.abstract: Mar 16-31: Pres Nixon says on March 15 that his chief legal counsel J W Dean 3d is protected by 'double privilege, the lawyer-client relationship as well as the Pres privilege' in view of fact that Dean also served as 'counsel to number of people on White House staff,' news conf; says he will not allow Dean to appear before Cong coms; says Adm has not 'drawn a curtain down' and that Dean will furnish information when any of it is requested provided it is pertinent to investigation; characterizes Watergate bugging case as 'espionage by 1 pol orgn against another'; reprs for White House and re-election com have previously said that 7 men indicted for bugging were acting independently; Sen Baker says appearance by Dean 'would be essential to full investigation' of Watergate; Sen Weicker says he would vote to subpoena White House officials before Watergate panel; Nixon illus

response.headline: One Killed and 26 Injured In a Crash on the L. I. R. R.
response.abstract: 1 woman is killed and at least 26 persons injured on Mar 15 when 4-car LIRR passenger train overshoots station in Lake Ronkonkoma, LI, and crashes into freight locomotive parked in staging yd; police ambulances and rescue units converge on site from 6 surrounding towns; eyewitnesses assert train's brakes failed as it entered station, but rr spokesman says cause of accident has not been determined; 1st 2 cars of train were derailed by impact but none were overturned; injuries were apparently caused when passengers were thrown from seats by force of crash; map of crash site
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STATE TAKE‐OVER OF OFFTRACK BETS IS URGED IN STUDY
response.abstract: Delafield Comm, apptd by Gov Rockefeller to study future of thoroughbred and harness racing and OTB, on Mar 15 recommends that NYS take over and sharply limit activities of NYC's Offtrack Betting Corp on ground that OTB may 'kill' horse racing indus in NYS; proposes that OTB operations be taken over by new State Horse Racing Bd and that its revenues be channeled through NYS Govt; comm, taking view that attendance and betting action at state's race tracks must be increased, recommends sizable pkg of tax breaks for ontrack bettor and higher costs, including 5% betting surtax, for offtrack bettor; Mayor Lindsay's office and OTB Corp denounce proposals as boon to illegal bookmakers and vow to fight proposals in Albany, where legis battle is certain; proposals outlined; comm chmn C B Delafield emphasizes that govt has viewed racing too much as revenue source, news conf; contends that if OTB is restructured to 'complement, not compete with' the tracks, effect will be to increase revenues for both state and city govt; H J Samuels, pres and chmn of NYC OTB, says he is 'shocked' by some of the proposals, particularly recommendation for state takeover; rept does not break down fiscal effects of separate proposals, but offers net estimate of enactment of complete pkg; predicts revenues would drop from expected total of $206-.8-million to $202.2-million in '73, including estimated loss of $11.9-million at the tracks; estimates that effect of 5% surtax would be to increase ontrack handle 5% and decrease offtrack handle 15%; study comm members listed; illus; charts
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Women's Rights Amendment Wins Connecticut Ratification
response.abstract: Conn Sen votes, 27 to 9, to ratify Equal Rights amendment to US Const; Conn House also votes for ratification, reversing its '72 vote for rejection; approval of 38 states needed for amendment to become part of US Const; action of Conn Legis balances action taken by Nebraska Legis to reverse its ratification vote; number of states voting for ratification so far remains unchanged at 28

response.headline: Eight May Face Courts‐Martial For Antiwar Roles as P.O.W.'s

response.headline: U.S. AND 13 OTHERS ADOPT MEASURES ON DOLLAR CRISIS
response.abstract: US, EEC, Japan, Switzerland and Canada agree on Mar 16 on loosely formulated package of measures designed to ease problem of excess dollars abroad and to assure reopening of official currency dealings under orderly conditions on Mar 19; issue communique indicating more controls on short-term capital flows, more action to bring dollars back to US and intervention by US and other nations if necessary to try to hold pressent exch rates; communique notes pledge by US and each of other countries to be prepared to intervene at their initiative in their own mkt, when neccesary and desirable, acting in flexible manner to support their own currency; communique stresses need for success of natl efforts to contain inflation and says 14 nations are resolved to pursue fully appropriate policies to this end; holds any future intervention will be financed, when necessary, through use of mutual credit facilities (swaps), noting they could be enlarged to insure fully adequate resources; notes US authorities are revg actions to facilitate inflow of capital into US and that US has agreed to consider encouraging flow of Eurocurrency funds back to US; says 14 nations have decided to reduce amt of official reserves placed in Eurodollar mkt and makes note of studies looking forward to getting all IMF members to limit their placements in Eurodollar mkt; Sec Shultz keeps US options open in agreement; indicates US is prepared to act to restore orderly mkt conditions; predicts 'reasonable conditions' in mkt, news conf in US Embassy where he is accompanied by Fed Reserve Bd Chmn A F Burns, Under Sec Volcker and Fed Reserve Bd member J D Daane; illus; Burns denies rumors in NY that US as concession to Eurs has agreed to raise Fed Reserve Bd's discount rate to bring excess dollars home; notes US has $11.5-billion of outstanding short-term swap credit lines; authorities are reptd hoping that new defense, together with action taken by EEC in linking currencies of 6 members in joint float, will buy time for what is now considered to be 'urgently' needed reform of monetary system to curb magnitude of any future disruptions of exch mkt; Min Giscard d'Estaing describes conf results as 'very positive' while Min Schmidt notes 'amazing degree of cooperation' displayed by US and EEC countries; Giscard d'Estaing notes France, Belgium and Netherlands are already tightening their exch controls; says France is following W Ger's example by barring interest payments on non-resident bank accts and making it so expensive for banks to service such accts that they will probably have to charge their foreign client for taking his money; Sweden and Norway announce they will also join float of 6 EEC currencies; best assessment of mkt specialists is that arrangements might produce period of calm and reflection and even temporary strength in dollar, but that inevitably the defense weapons will be tested by speculators; communique reptdly shows that US wants to call truce to so-called policy of benign neglect while meeting shows new spirit of cooperation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Contributions
response.abstract: WASHINGTON‐Four months after the Nixon landslide, money is still moving in and out of the President's Re‐election Campaign Committee. But it is not the record, amount—nearly $50‐million collected, nearly $5‐million left over—that keeps the issue in the headlines. The intriguing questions are: Why did the committee recently return $655,000 to three big contributors? Why, long after the election was over and the giant surplus was well‐known, did an additional. $246,000 dribble into the Nixon treasury in January and February?

response.headline: Asia's Poor: Miiizons in Despair

response.headline: Dollar Is Strong as Tokyo Market Opens
response.abstract: Tokyo foreign-exch mkt reopens Mar 19 after 2-wk suspension in trading during internatl monetary crisis; dollar is surprisingly strong in heavy trading, opening at 262 yen before rising to 264 yen in spot trading; Bank of Tokyo estimates vol of trading at $120-million; show of strength is believed to result from shortage of dollars in Japan's large trading concerns; bankers and economists expect dollar to fall to about 250 yen, which would be effective devaluation of 23% over rate before yen was floated on Feb 12, as result of joint float of 6 EEC currencies; level would also represent effective upward shift of yen by about 44% over rate that prevailed before Aug '71; reaction to monetary agreements reached in Paris is generally 'calm but wary'; few bankers or businessmen think that agreement is more than beginning to stabilization of monetary situation; continued rise of yen is expected to be 1 more mark against Japanese Premier Tanaka, who had pledged that there would be no 2d upward revaluation of yen; Tanaka formally expresses his 'regrets' to Parliament for having failed to head off dollar devaluation and yen float in Feb

response.headline: MORE BUS SERVICE IS URGED TO HELP POOR GET TO JOBS
response.abstract: Regional Plan Assn rept, released Mar 18, urges in its most controversial sec that policies on auto use be tailored so that efforts to save environment would not be made at expense of low-income workers; says that workers' use of cars to get to jobs brought 'substantial gains in travel time, in wider job choice and in income'; proposes such measures as subsidy for down-payments on small cars, reduction in auto ins costs for low-income persons, increased parking space in low-income areas and re-evaluation of policies that have led to 'virtual moratorium' on new expressway construction in city
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LON NOL ORDERS STERN MEASURES
response.abstract: Cambodian Pres Lon Nol on March 18 suspends publication of all newspapers and periodicals except those published by Govt as 1 of series of stern measures taken after attempt was made to assassinate him in bombing raid on Pres palace
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cahill Vetoes ‘Shield’ Bill For the Press as Extreme
response.abstract: NJ Gov Cahill on March 19 vetoes bill that would have effectively granted absolute immunity to newsmen in NJ, allowing them to refuse to disclose any news information, confidential or otherwise, to such bodies as grand juries, investigating comms or legis coms; bill was widely heralded as strongest news-source-protection legis in US; veto is expected to have impact on Cong efforts to draft parallel Fed news-source protection law in Washington; supports NJ's existing law that protects reporters from disclosing confidential news sources to investigative bodies; Cahill contends that new proposal goes too far; says there are other well-accepted rights of citizens that come into conflict with principle of press freedom; NJ chapter of ACLU calls veto 'cruel blow to a free press'; Sen J E Crabiel attacks veto and declares that he will support any legis effort to override it; Sen J H Wallwork says that he is disappointed with veto but does not intend to lead any fight to override it; says he will push for legis study of over-all problem of news-source protection, as urged by Cahill; rev of jailing of reporter P J Bridge for refusing to disclose his source; illus of Wallwork
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: The Jobless and Their Problems Jam Asian Cities
response.abstract: J P Sterba series on conditions in southern Asia; discusses plight of hundreds of millions of marginal men in underdeveloped countries who have been unwittingly victimized by population explosion, are untouched by postwar development efforts and suffer from urbanization and joblessness; cites conditions in sec of Jakarta, Indonesia, which most Amers have never seen and would never experience; points out that presently fewer than 25% of Asians live in cities but rise to 50% is seen by end of century if present trends continue; chart compares urban populations; map shows Asia's most populous cities; illus of children at entrance to dwellings made of bamboo and cardboard in Jakarta
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SOME BIG BANKS LIFT PRIME RATE TO 6¾% FROM 6¼
response.abstract: A group of major banks, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, increased their prime lending rates yesterday by one‐half of a percentage point to 6¾ per cent, thus provoking a new confrontation between the Nixon Administration and the banking industry.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MURPHY TO LEAVE BEFORE YEAR ENDS
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr Murphy on Mar 19 announces that he will not serve as comr beyond end of Mayor Lindsay's term, which expires Dec 31, '73; says that he is considering number of job offers but has not set date of his departure; Murphy's career revd; Lindsay praises Murphy; illus
