response.headline: Saigon Peace Candidate Released After 5 Years
response.abstract: S Vietnamese pol prisoner Truong Dinh Dzu, peace candidate in '67 pres election, released from jail, Mar 26, after nearly 5 yrs imprisonment; is reptdly sick; remains in seclusion; release seen as attempt by Pres Thieu to improve his pub image before his visit next wk with Pres Nixon and US Cong leaders; among prominent figures still held as pol prisoners is Tran Ngoc Chau, serving a 10-yr sentence imposed in '70 for having had 'treasonable' contacts with his brother, a spy for Hanoi; Chau is an anti-Communist and principal architect of the pacification program; Thieu has been criticized heavily, particularly by some Amer Congressmen, for keeping pol opponents in jail; comment on Dzu's arrest in '68 and his pol career; his por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FIRING STEPPED UP AT WOUNDED KNEE
response.abstract: Negotiators step up efforts on Mar 27 to bring an end to month-long take-over of Wounded Knee, SD, by dissident Indians as confrontation with Govt forces becomes virtually open warfare; members of Fed Community Relations Service spend most of day at Indian camp in Wounded Knee as US marshals and FBI agents and Indians exchange gunfire; Justice Dept officials say that cease-fire is being arranged with Indians this afternoon; plane lands near hamlet and unloads weapons and ammunition for Indians; Asst Atty Gen K Frizzell says that plane might have come from Canada; adds Indians made several forays toward Govt lines, coming within 150 yards at one point; asserts Govt has not set deadline for Indians holding Wounded Knee to surrender, but that further delay 'invites further violence'; Oglala Sioux Tribal Council chmn R Wilson tells reporters that 2 key Amer Indian Movement leaders R Means and D Banks slipped through Govt line last night while Fed agents were pinned down by heavy gunfire; Wilson, who vowed to drive militant Indians off Sioux reservation, says he was told by Justice Dept official that Means and Banks had fled; Frizzell says he cannot confirm escape of 2 men, both of whom have been indicted by Fed grand jury for their part in Wounded Knee take-over; Deputy Chief US Marshal W Hall says that meeting scheduled for today with leaders of dissidents was canceled after Indians objected to some proposed arrangements; another attempt will be made tomorrow; Oglala Sioux Indians set up roadblocks on Mar 26 to prevent food from being taken to Wounded Knee; US Dist Judge A Bogue rescinds ct order to allow food into area because of roadblocks; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stock Prices Climb
response.abstract: Share prices registered their biggest advance in 16 months on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The DowJones industrial average soared 17.01 points to 944.91, and turnover increased to 17.5 million shares from 15 million on Monday. Page 63.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S.WILL CONTINUE RAIDS IN CAMBODIA TILL A CEASE‐FIRE
response.abstract: White House on Mar 27 says US will continue bombing of Cambodia until Communists stop mil operations and agree to cease-fire; press sec Ziegler outlines Adm's position in response to newsmen's questions about how long US will continue such bombings and where Pres derives constitutional authority for ordering raids; consensus of Cambodian and foreign mil experts is that without US air support, Cambodian Army would collapse; Ziegler emphasizes that air operations are being conducted in response to request from Cambodian Pres Lon Nol; Sen Foreign Relations Com chmn Fulbright demands that Adm provide public explanation of purpose and authority for continued Cambodian mil activities; says if such explanation is not forthcoming he will call full public hearing with Sec of State Rogers; Cambodian mil situation revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 7 Union Leaders Accused Of Racket in Fur District
response.abstract: 7 furriers' union leaders indicted an charges of conspiracy, extortion and threats of violence in 'a pattern of racketeering activity' in NYC garment district; indictment also charges 4 fur mfrs with making payoffs to union leaders to permit mfrs to subcontract work to nonunion shops in violation of labor agreements; those indicted are: G Stofsky, chief exec officer of Furriers Joint Council of NY, C Hoff, Aer Gold, C Lageoles, A Logios, J Ziebal and C Apostolides, also with Furriers Joint Council; fur mfrs indicted are: B H Hessel, S Cohen, S Sherman and K Schwartzbaum

response.headline: Capital's Arena Stage to Tour Soviet
response.abstract: Nixon Adm officials rept that US will send Arena Stage, Washington, DC, repertory theater to USSR in fall with 1st Amer dramatic presentations in 15-yr history of Soviet-Amer cultural exch; refuse to disclose names of 2 plays group will produce, except to say that both are by Amer authors; assoc dir of group A Schneider will visit USSR in May to scout for theaters to accommodate group's in-the-round productions; producing dir Z Fichandler will visit Moscow to take part in internatl theatrical conf; Adm officials rept that Soviet audiences will be able to use earphones to hear simultaneous Russian translations of 2 plays
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 32 Reach the Philippines
response.abstract: Final stage in release of Amer POWs begins, Mar 27, as 32, freed by Vietcong, arrive at Clark Air Base, Philippines, Mar 28; 9 more Amer POWs and a Canadian missionary, captured in Laos, are picked up in Hanoi Mar 28; 40 additional POWs, captured in N Vietnam, to be picked up Mar 28; last 67 Amer POWs known to be held by Hanoi to be released Mar 29, bringing to 589 the number of US mil and civilian prisoners feed by Communists since Jan 27; group of 32, 27 servicemen and 5 civilians, are described as the last to be held by the Vietcong; sr officer of group, Col B E Purcell, on behalf of group, expresses gratitude for their freedom; names of some of those due from Laos listed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2D NORSE VESSEL LOST OFF JERSEY
response.abstract: Anita (Freighter): Norwegian freighter Anita, carrying 32 crew members and cargo of coal bound for Bremen, W Ger, is reptd missing off NJ coast where Norse Variant is believed to have sank; USCG was notified on Mar 25 by Anita's agent R Scarlett that he had not established communications with ship since her departure from Norfolk, Va, on Mar 21; USCG spokesman says task force found 2 life rafts on Mar 26 inscribed with Anita's name, but cautions find is not evidence that ship is lost; adds radio workers transmitted signals at 10-min intervals on Mar 25 and 26, but received no response; search continues in area off Cape May, NJ, where haze, fog, and 9-ft seas are reptd; ship's owner E H Samuelson announced in London on Mar 27 that ship was missing
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT VETOES $26‐BILLION BILL FOR HANDICAPPED
response.abstract: US Sen, 72-19, on Mar 27 passes bill that challenges Adm's plans to end several major health programs, among them Hill-Burton program for hosp construction; if supporters of measure can hold vote margin, they will be able to override Presidential veto
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: F.C.C. Will Study ‘Obscene’ Shows On Radio and TV
response.abstract: FCC on Mar 27 announces that it will investigate broadcasting of allegedly obscene radio and TV programs; announcement follows vote by comm last wk to conduct inquiry into possible violation of Fed laws against such programs, including telephone call-in shows dealing with explicit sexual topics, which are popular on many radio stations; Comr N Johnson is only member to vote against investigation, which he calls 'inappropriate' exercise of FCC's regulatory power; inquiry, for which no starting date has been set, will be closed to public unless comm 'determines that public sessions would serve the public interest'; adm law judge, who has not been named, will conduct hearings and will be given power to subpoena records and witnesses; FCC spokesman cites number of public complaints, which have more than tripled since Dec, and pressure from Cong as chief factors influencing comm's decision to investigate; says hearings will also touch on few instances in which allegedly obscene films were broadcast over commercial and cable TV stations; says Nevada TV station KVVU broadcast pornographic films during late evening hrs, but took them-off after receiving complaints; says group of Syracuse Univ students recently showed film Deep Throat over student-run cable TV station; film was recently declared obscene by Manhattan judge and ordered removed from exhibition in NYC theaters; Sens and Reprs during last 2 mos have expressed special concern about radio call-in shows, which enjoy their greatest popularity in Calif; HR Communications subcom chmn Repr T H Macdonald, noting that he recently called on FCC Chmn Burch to put stop to programs, says he is delighted that Burch acted with such dispatch
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: I.M.F. Committee Agrees On Money Reform Goals
response.abstract: Commerce Dept repts on Mar 27 that US suffered $476.2-million trade deficit in Feb; US and foreign officials reptdly expect 2-part devaluation of dollar against most other major currencies to start bringing substantial improvement in trade figures late in '73 or in '74
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Jurors Hear Hunt, Former Nixon Aide
response.abstract: Watergate conspirator E H Hunt Jr appears on Mar 27 before Fed grand jury; his atty maintains that Hunt knows of no involvement by 'higher-ups' in Adm circles; Sen com investigating pol espionage in last yr's Pres campaign announces that J W McCord Jr will testify under oath in secret session on Mar 28; McCord told Sen com's staff that 2 figures in Nixon Adm had prior knowledge of his wiretapping operation; 2 are J W Dean 3d and J S Magruder; White House denies this; Repub Sens Buckley, Tower and Cotton call on White House to provide information on Watergate affair and on repts of related efforts to disrupt Dem campaign; White House press sec Ziegler hints on Mar 27 that Dean, while refusing Sen summons, might appear before grand jury if called; says there is 'no substance' to rept from Capitol Hill that Dean offered to resign as Pres' counsel; Hunt's role in Watergate plot discussed; decision to call McCord in private session before Sen's Select com to Investigate Pres Campaign Activities apparently provoked some debate on 7-member panel; Sen Weicker, who said on Mar 26 that he had been independently persuaded of White House involvement in case, is understood to have demanded public hearing for McCord; Weicker was outvoted, 5-1; Sen com hires C Bellino to investigate financial dealings in case; repr of Nixon's re-election com says orgn is considering employing additional personnel to help in pending hearings and in extensive civil litigation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Elusive Maya Glyphs Yielding to Modern Technique
response.abstract: 3d article in NY Times series discusses breakthroughs currently being made in decoding complex ancient Mayan hieroglyphic writing in bark paper books, on stone monuments known as stelae and on pottery found in Mexico and Guatemala; various glyphs, or symbols, described; new linguistic techniques and archeological findings have provided many new clues, although some scholars say decoding is still long way off; of about 800 known glyphs, only 10 to 40% have been decoded; enigmatic nature of Mayan culture and massive looting of stelae from ancient sites have given added stimulus to decoding efforts; Maya Hieroglyphic Inscriptions Study project, headed by I Graham, has been formed to record remaining carvings photographically; project described; Maya written language dates from about 300 AD and is believed to have influenced Aztec and other languages; Bishop D de Landa, who arrived in Mexico soon after Spanish Conquest in 16th century, reptdly burned all but 3 Mayan codices presently in Eur museums; codices, which date to about 1300 to 1500 AD, deal entirely with religious and calendrical matters; theories and methods of scholar J E S Thompson, who has made major contributions to codices' decipherment, noted; other scholars, notably T Proskouriakoff and H Berlin, are studying stelae carvings, which differ from codices, for insight into everyday matters of Mayans; their approach, which depends on history of stelae's particular locations, described; 3d group of scholars is employing linguistic approach based on controversial work of Y Knorosov done 20 yrs ago; Knorosov's theories compared with Thompson's; Yale Univ Prof F Lounsbury espouses 'eclectic' approach, which combines elements of both schools of thought; current project at Mexico Univ utilizing computer and linguistic methods described; work of O Schuman, who is trying to recreate ancient Mayan spoken language from his knowledge of modern dialects, discussed; illus of various Mayan scholars; illus of script from page of codex; illus of several glyphs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.abstract: Sen Foreign Relations subcom opens hearings on multinatl cos

response.headline: Lindsay Appoints a Supporter President of Tax Commission
response.abstract: NYC Mayor Lindsay appts A J Ranieri on Mar 28 as acting Tax Comm pres, temporarily replacing N A Levy, who is on unpaid leave; Citizens Union has criticized apptmt, saying it had urged selection of someone free of 'partisan pol involvement'; NYS Investigation Comm, in recent rept criticizing Levy and city adm for 'mixing pol and sensitive tax assessment procedures,' says Ranieri was pol 'aligned' with Mayor Lindsay in '69 and apptd to Tax Comm upon 'recommendation' of Lindsay Assn coordinator T Mastroianni; Mastroianni is now Deputy Parks Comr; Lindsay spokesman defends apptmt, saying Lindsay's 'sole consideration' was picking experienced comm member during current crucial hearing period; S Jacobi is apptd to replace Ranieri on comm; brief sketches of Ranieri's and Jacobi's careers; Ranieri por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Indians Said to Block Surrender by 100
response.abstract: Fed Govt spokesman repts on Mar 28 that 100 of Indians holding hamlet of Wounded Knee, SD, have offered to surrender, but hard-core dissidents, vowing to die, are said to be keeping them in village at gunpoint; Asst Atty Gen K Frizzell asserts '5 or 6 seem to want 2d Wounded Knee'; says 100 who are willing to surrender are being led by P Bissonet, head of a Sioux civil rights group, and by L Crow Dog, medicine man at Rosebud Sioux Reservation; meeting field in Rapid City, SD, to discuss when and how Wounded Knee might be surrendered ends in failure; FBI, which with US marshals is guarding perimeter around Wounded Knee, moves 3 more armored cars to within sight of hamlet after rept that Govt expected renewed conflict with Indians; cease-fire has been in effect since noon Mar 27, and only 1 shot was heard last night; however, Frizzell says a Govt informant reptd that D J Banks, 'war chief' of Amer Indian Movement, had said 'today is day we go for broke'; most repts coming out of Wounded Knee have been unofficial, as Govt has not allowed reporters to enter since Mar 25; Frizzell asserts Banks and R C Means are leading faction that refuses to allow Bissonet and Crow Dog to surrender their followers; at meeting in Rapid City, SD, Amer Indian Movement leader A Desersa denies that there is any conflict among Indians still holding Wounded Knee and demanding that Fed Govt honor all Indian treaties
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LEGISLATORS PASS THE STATE BUDGET
response.abstract: NYS Legis on Mar 28 approves state budget that includes $2.47-billion in school aid, increase of $98-million over '72

response.headline: L.I. CONCERNS GET SPACE CONTRACTS
response.abstract: Grumman Aerospace Corp and Fairchild Hiller Corp are chosen by USAF on Mar 28 to build wings and tail fin for manned space shuttle, decision that will result in infusion of approximately $53-million into ailing areospace indus on LI, NY; Govt sources rept Grumman has won competition for wing contract, which will total $40-million or more, and that Fairchild will construct tail fin at cost of $13-million; artist's concept of space tug ferrying satellite payload from space shuttle's orbital stage

response.headline: Koch Abandons Mayoral Race, Citing Trouble in Raising Funds
response.abstract: US Repr Koch on Mar 28 announces that he is withdrawing as candidate for Dem nomination for NYC Mayor; asserts that he is unable to raise enough money to give him 'a chance of winning'; notes that he is not 'dejected,' adding that he enjoys being Congressman; declines to endorse any of his former pol foes; says he is going to take 'pol recess' for 10 days; NYC's 5 Repub county leaders meet in Albany on Mar 28 to select orgn choices of running mates for State Sen Marchi, who is seeking Repub nomination for Mayor

response.headline: 49 More Americans Free; One a Prisoner Since '65
response.abstract: 49 more Amer POWs freed in Hanoi arrive, Mar 29, Clark Air Base, Philippines; among them are 9 Amers and a Canadian missionary captured m Laos; hosp planes take off for Hanoi to pick up remaining 67 men held in the North; illus of Lt Col W Talley on arrival

response.headline: RICHARDSON SEES CLEAR AUTHORITY TO BOMB CAMBODIA
response.abstract: US Sec Richardson, on Mar 28, maintains that Pres Nixon has clear const auth to continue bombing in Cambodia to clean up 'lingering comer of the war,' talk with newsmen on mounting criticism of bombing; does not specify what auth is but says it is not dependent upon presence of Amer forces in Vietnam; says 'main point' is simply that cease-fire has not been achieved in Cambodia and US is continuing 'to support our ally there'; Sen Mansfield takes direct issue with Richardson's statements; says Nixon would have no const auth to order bombing raids in Cambodia once all Amer combat forces are withdrawn from S Vietnam; Sen Javits drafts Sen speech questioning propriety and legality of continued bombing; Sen Fulbright prepares lr to Sec Rogers demanding explanation for auth for it; State Dept officials rept that Adm is drafting white paper giving its position in what is developing into another confrontation between exec branch and Cong over Pres war-making powers; White House has stated that bombing in Cambodia will continue until Communist forces in Cambodia agree to a cease-fire; Richardson's description of Cambodia as 'ally' discussed in light of fact that Cambodia has even been removed from protection of SEATO and that at the time of US incursion into Cambodia in '70, Nixon and other Adm officials insisted sole purpose was to help defend Amer and S Vietnamese troops in Cambodia, not Cambodian Govt; Asst Sec Green suggests bombing has pol purpose of pressuring N Vietnam to accept cease-fire in Cambodia
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Vietnam Peace Hope Dim As the Last G.I.'s Leave
response.abstract: 60-day first phase of Vietnam cease-fire comes to end, Mar 28, with fighting continuing, peace-keeping machinery in satate of disarray and prospects for real peace apparently remote; end of this phase is marked by complete withdrawal of US troops after more than 8 yrs of involvement; Western and Vietnamese officials comment; events during 60-day period revd; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CORD REPORTED TO LINK MITCHELL TO BUGGING PLOT
response.abstract: Watergate conspirator J W McCord Jr says on Mar 28 that former Atty Gen Mitchell had prior knowledge of Watergate plot, in closed Sen hearing; Cong source cautions that McCord's sworn testimony is based on 'hearsay' and that no documentary evidence to support it was offered; Mitchell has repeatedly denied involvement; Washington Post says that according to McCord, C W Colson also knew in advance of Watergate activities; Sen Baker says McCord named J W Dean 3d and J S Magruder at hearing; Govt moves on Mar 28 to force E H Hunt Jr to answer questions dealing with involvement of any others and with espionage activities related to case; Judge Sirica grants Hunt immunity; announces that because McCord went to Sens and will also appear before grand jury, he sees 'no need to go forward with private conf that was arranged; illus of Mitchell and McCord

response.abstract: Sen's narrow defeat of bill extending authority for wage and price controls that would have frozen interest rates noted

response.abstract: AFL-CIO pres Meany says on Mar 28 if food prices are not lowered, unions are not going to settle for wage increase that will not even pay for workers' 'increased food bill'

response.headline: NIXON SETS MEAT PRICE CEILINGS AT BOTH WHOLESALE AND RETAIL; ASSERTS COSTS ‘SHOULD GO DOWN’
response.abstract: Treas Sec Shultz says on Mar 29 that Pres Nixon, in move to check rising food prices, is sending to Cong a request for authority to reduce or suspend tariffs and import quotas on commodities whose prices have been going up rapidly; in related action, Distributive Workers of Amer Dist Council 65 pres D Livingston asks Cong for a subsidy plan whereby Govt would pay difference between prices people can afford and prices charged by various sections of food indus; estimates that plan would cost about $4-billion a yr; graph shows rise in food prices and all commodities during '72

response.headline: Thousands Watch 67 Prisoners Depart
response.abstract: Tens of thousands of N Vietnamese watch, smile and wave, Mar 29, as last of 67 Amer POWs fly out of Hanoi; do not shout insults; for the first time Hanoi admits a large group of Western correspondents--28 in all--to cover the POWs release and do some sightseeing; Hanoi gives impression of being completely at peace; illus of Lt Comdr A H Agnew, last POW to be released
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: S.E.C. White Paper Seeks Stock Market‐Restructure
response.abstract: SEC on March 29 unveils 'white paper' to restructure securities mkts with aim of establishing central mkt system that would encompass network of brokers and dealers in offices and on exch floors, linked together by electronic communication; says primary objective of central system is development of strong competition among participants; pledges to take every reasonable step to insure new central mkt system will provide welcome environment for small investor; major comm proposals include: regulation to maintain integrity of communications system; regulation of competing mkt makers within system; regulation to insure that system will maintain best auction mkts; new 'auction trading rule' that would provide price priority protection for all public orders throughout system and 'public preference rule'; heart of new central mkt system would be comprehensive communications linkage between mkt centers consisting of composite transaction reptg system and composite quotation system displaying bids and offers of all qualified mkt makers in listed securities; plan would require adoption by all exchs of nonmember access rule permitting discounts to be negotiated up to substantially higher level than 40% of comm rate now in effect
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Forces Out of Vietnam; Hanoi Frees the Last P.O.W.
response.abstract: Last Amer troops leave S Vietnam, Mar 29, after a decade of Amer mil intervention; remaining after final plane leaves Tan Son Nhut air base are about 800 Amers on the truce observation force who will leave Mar 30 or 31; US involvement, however, seen far from ended; Gen F C Weyand presides over furling of colors of US Mil Assistance Command; in speech to command says 'You can hold your heads up high for having been a part of this selfless effort'; in second speech, delivered in Vietnamese, says that US mission has been accomplished, that he departs with pride in what US has achieved and in what the achievement represents; 7,200 Amer civilians employed by US Defense Dept are in S Vietnam; majority of them are already at work with Saigon armed forces trying to fill the gap in special skills the Vietnamization program has been unable to provide; Saigon officer repts more than 100 mil incidents in last 24 hrs despite cease-fire; US officer, Col E Himma says 'there's going to be a full-blown war starting up after we leave; the fighting has never stopped anyway'; there are congratulatory messages from Washington and Pacific Hq and a note of regret from Adm T H Moorer that the war had not enjoyed 'the full measure of support it deserved'; US experience in the war revd; comment on mil course of war, mil tactics and casualties; illus of departing Amers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: McCord Testifies His Fellow Plotters Linked High Nixon Aides to Watergate
response.abstract: Summary of recent events in Watergate case notes major points in J W McCord's testimony, based on hearsay, before Sen com this wk, including assertion that former Atty Gen Mitchell served as 'over-all boss'; that J W Dean 3d sat in on a planning meeting with 2 men ultimately convicted as consprators, heard their plans, and later reptd that operation was approved; that H R Haldeman 'knew what was going on' at Nixon's re-election com; that former Asst Atty Gen R C Mardian was in contact with McCord and that he thought C W Colson recd detailed plan for Watergate operation from E H Hunt Jr; McCord is believed to have told select com that he was 'unclear' as to what role Colson played but was 'knowledgeable' about Watergate plot; Mitchell issues statement on Mar 29 through Pres' pol unit noting his resentment of 'slanderous and false statements' concerning Watergate matter reptd as being based on hearsay and leaked out; reaffirms his denials of involvement; White House deputy press sec Warren reiterates that no one in White House had any knowledge of or was involved in Watergate matter; sources note that burden of McCord's testimony included assertion that Liddy began to talk about forthcoming meeting to brief Mitchell on Watergate operation 2 or 3 wks before it was held, that charts were prepared covering proposed budgets for covert activity for which Liddy allegedly paid $7,000; that Liddy told McCord, in Feb meeting also attended by Hunt and Dean, that Mitchell discussed spying effort and proposed budget for it; says Com for Re-Election of Pres was engaged in wiretapping activities in addition to those uncovered at Watergate; says 1 of 'related operations' discussed in Mitchell's office in Feb involved obtaining photographs of documents in Dem party's files; says photographic activity was to have been responsbility of Barker, Martinez, Gonzales and Sturgis; says he met with Mitchell daily to discuss security of his family, protection for bldg in wheih Repub com was housed, arrangements for Repub Natl Conv and other matters; McCord allegedly said that F La Rue, Repub com official, had nothing to do with Watergate; says that he asked A C Baldwin 3d to put name of a guard at Nixon hq on envelope containing logs of wiretapped conversations and that guard would later forward information to McCord; says he delivered logs to Liddy and that he had seen copies of logs on desk of Liddy's secretary S Harmony
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Rap Brown Guilty
response.abstract: Rap Brown and three codefendants were found guilty yesterday of armed robbery and assault in the holdup of a West Side bar. The jury said it was “hopelessly deadlocked” on the charge that the defendants had also tried to murder three policemen after the holdup. Page 14.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NO‐STRIKE ACCORD REACHED ON STEEL
response.abstract: Steelworkers local union officials at conf, Pittsburgh, on Mar 29 approve unprecedented agreement which virtually assures labor peace in steel indus at least until '77; accord, worked out with 10 major steel cos in yrs of talks, provides for binding arbitration of unresolved issues in '74 negotiations and prohibits strikes by union or lockouts by cos; union pres I W Abel and indus spokesman R H Larry comment; 10 steel cos agreeing to pact are: Allegheny Ludlum, Armco, Bethlehem, Inland, Jones & Laughlin, National, Republic, US, Wheeling-Pittsburgh and Youngstown Sheet; agreement reptdly will reduce stockpiling and reduce layoffs and unemployment; provides wage increase of at least 3% in each of next 3 yrs and 1-time bonus of $150 in return for no-strike pledge
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONSUMERS RALLY FOR MEAT BOYCOTT
response.abstract: some Midwestern farmers, organizing movements to counter nationwide meat boycott, plan to withhold livestock from mkts; NJ Agr Sec Alampi criticizes both movements, noting that problems must be settled 'in mkt place'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Former P.O.W.'s Charge Torture by North Vietnam
response.abstract: Ex-Amer POWs, in ints across US, tell stories of mental and physical torture at the hands of their N Vietnamese captors; rept being beaten, tied, shackled and starved until they provided information about US war plans or signed antiwar statements and confessions of war crimes; many say that most devastating treatment was prolonged periods of solitary confinement; men rept on their ordeals after the last of the Amer POWs land at Clark Air Base, Philippines; up to now, were silent on treatment for fear of jeopardizing release of POWs still imprisoned; say torture and other harassment declined dramatically after Oct '69; US officials attribute improvement to US efforts begun early in '69 to muster world opinion toward improving treatment of POWs; comments by Col R Risner, Capt W Rivers, Comdr R A Stratton, Lt Col J A Dramesi, others cited; Stratton illus

response.headline: Council Votes 3‐Year Extension Of Rent Control for Million Units
response.abstract: NYC City Council on Mar 29 approves 3-yr extension of rent controls affecting more than 1-million apts; at same time most members emphasize they want legis to repeal or place moratorium on maximum base rent program and to repeal vacancy-decontrol law; Councilman Weiss notes that since vacancy decontrol went into effect 144,000 units have been decontrolled; says soon there will be no housing left to control
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIEU DUE TO ASK NIXON ASSURANCE
response.abstract: S Vietnamese Pres Nguyen Van Thieu prepares to set out for US Mar 31; Saigon officials say his principal purpose is to obtain directly from Pres Nixon minimal assurances underwriting the survival of a non-Communist S Vietnam; believes he seeks US pledge to intervene with air power in case of a N Vietnamese invasion and a US guarantee of enough econ aid to meet the costs of reconstruction; opposition politicians say Thieu seeks pub raffirmation of US support not only for Saigon but for himself; actions by Thieu in recent days seen a conscious policy of refurbishing his pub image to make it easier for Nixon to confer the sought-for support; Saigon officials say Thieu intends to liberalize pol life after yr of wartime rigor and to make adm more efficient and to eradicate corruption; opposition believes moves by Thieu to be little more than tokens designed to attract US attention and hopes that Nixon will insist on more genuine liberalization; opposition leader Tran Van Tuyen comments
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AIDE TERMS NIXON WILLING TO ASSIST BUGGING INQUIRIES
response.abstract: White House indicates on Mar 30 its readiness to compromise with Sen investigation of Watergate case on issue of furnishing witnesses and information from Pres Nixon's personal staff; White House press sec Ziegler announces at same time that Pres has issued affirmative order to all members of his staff to testify if called before Fed grand jury that is continuing to look into case; appearances by White House staff members will be ltd to closed sessions in both investigations; White House appears to be showing concern about bipartisan attacks on Adm's conduct in case for 1st time; change is believed to be, in part, a result of concern that White House might be covering up involvement of Pres aides and others close to Pres in Watergate break-in; Ziegler makes statement denying that staff members were involved; insists White House position has always been 1 of cooperation; question is raised as to why, if White House is interested in preserving separation of powers, Pres would order his aides to appear as sworn witnesses before judicial body but not legis body
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Judge Presses Call for More Witnesses
response.abstract: Judge Sirica presses Govt on Mar 30 to summon more witnesses before Fed grand jury 'in view of substantive developments' in Watergate conspiracy; questions prosecution attys about whether they plan to call 6 persons who are thought to be important figures in Nixon Adm, ct proceeding in which Sirica postpones sentencing of McCord until June 15; Asst US Atty Silbert says he proposes to hear evidence from all 7 Watergate conspirators and will call others if 'factual' developments warrant it; Sirica grants immunity from further prosecution to G G Liddy and orders him to testify before grand jury; Liddy's atty P Maroulis says he thinks his client will 'maintain his position' of silence and expects contempt proceedings against Liddy on Apr 2
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PROCESSORS DOUBT PRICES WILL FALL
response.abstract: meat indus packers and wholesalers say on Mar 30 that Pres Nixon's measure imposing ceiling on meat prices will keep supermkt meat prices at current high levels and do not expect prices to go down in near future; claim that if prices of livestock, which are not controlled, do not go down shortages of popular cuts of meat are to be expected; Illini Beef Packers Inc pres V J Lohman calls action a 'disaster'; holds repercussions will be 'enormous' and meat prices will hold at present levels; Iowa Beef Processors Inc spokesman says co is still trying to determine how ceiling will affect their prices, noting that plants are currently operating but sales have already 'been hurt' by consumer resistance; asserts that co has started to slow down operations; Amer Meat Inst denounces ceiling control as move that would only create more problems, not more meat; inst pres DeGraff says that retailers and processors have been under price restraints since '71 and claims ceilings will not contribute to bringing down meat prices; Swift & Co also denounces Nixon's move; says prices have increased because of 'extraordinary demand' created by consumers that existing supplies cannot satisfy; Oscar Mayer & Co claims it does not expect any difference in its problems as long as prices do not rise beyond Feb avg; observers outside packing and wholesale levels assert that fears will diminish if price levels remain close to current levels
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Betty Furness Appointed To Bess Myerson's Post
response.abstract: Mayor Lindsay on Mar 30 names B Furness as NYC's new Consumer Affairs Comr; she replaces B Myerson, who resigns after 4 yrs in post; consumer activists view selection of Furness as an excellent one since 57-yr-old former TV personality has been outspoken defender of consumer interests for several yrs; Furness declares that Lindsay has proved himself 'enormously sympathetic' to consumer cause; has previously served as consumer adviser first to Pres Johnson and later to Gov Rockefeller; was originally offered city job 4 yrs ago but turned it down, fearing it would be 'monumentally difficult'; resigned from state post when she found that her power was meager and budget severely limited; State Atty Gen Lefkowitz, with whom she had clashed while heading state consumer agency, hails her apptmt to city job, which pays $35,000 annually; Furness and Myerson illustrations
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Levitt Homes in New Jersey Under Attack
response.abstract: Levitt & Sons Inc is facing serious problems because of construction defects in subdivision called Contempra in Freehold Township, NJ; subdivision consists of 226 homes; about 160 buyers have moved into houses and to date NJ Div of Consumer Affairs, which has never before acted in real estate case, has received 110 complaints from Contempra residents; Mrs M Fenwick, div dir, says 2 meetings have been held with Levitt reprs and she expects 'resolution' of problem soon; Monmouth County attempted to ban issuance of certificates of occupancy for Contempra homes but Levitt won ct action to overturn ban; H Sperry, Contempra project mgr for Levitt, concedes there is 'heat problem' and has hired own heating consultant; residents have complained of temperatures in houses that drop to 40 degrees in winter and rise above 100 degrees in summer, of flooded 'conversation pits' and shoddy workmanship that requires reinforcement; owners comment; map; illus

response.headline: A Lid on Meat Prices
response.abstract: WASHINGTON —President Nixon's decision to put a lid on the nation's soaring meat prices has left the public with important questions: How will the ceilings work? Will they have the perverse effect of preventing prices from going down? Could they cause shortages and black markets?

response.headline: COMMUNISTS FIND TRUCE‘SABOTAGED’ BY U.S AND SAIGON
response.abstract: Chief Hanoi delegate to mil comm, Maj Gen Le Quang Hoa, and chief US delegate, Maj Gen G H Woodward, leave Saigon; peace‐keeping role of Four‐Party Joint Mil Comm has been taken over by the Two‐Party Joint Mil Comm, composed of S Vietnam and the Vietcong; statements issued by Hoa and Vietcong delegate, Lt Gen Tran Van Tra, charge that Saigon, 'encouraged by the US,' continues the war and undermines peace‐keeping operations; warn that Saigon and the US undermine the peace; Woodward statement concedes that cease‐fire is still widely violated, but places no blame on either side; Saigon issues no statement on work of comm, which ended on Mar 28; Hoa and Tra insist that the Communists are strictly implementing the truce accord; Vietcong Col Vo dong Giang charges that Saigon has committed 67,542 violations of the cease‐fire; Saigon charges Communists have committed some 10,000 violations; Hoa says US 'continues its mil involvement' by turning its mil personnel 'into disguised civilian personnel to assist the Saigon army; both sides agree that the Four‐Party Joint Mil Comm successfully completed the release of Amer POWs and the withdrawal of Amer mil personnel; Saigon announces that besieged ranger base at Tong Le Chan is still being shelled; illus of N Vietnamese repr trying to prevent photographing of delegates preparing to return to Hanoi
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Tokyo Is Urged to Fight Image of ‘Ugly Japanese’
response.abstract: High‐level Japanese com headed by Fuji Bank chmn Y Iwasa recommends wide‐ranging public relations effort to counteract what critics say is image of 'the ugly Japanese'; com, set up by Japan Econ Research Inst, voices concern that Japan has suffered decline in its internatl reputation; holds that Japanese public relations, which have always avoided 'the displeasing' and remained within realm of propriety, have 'created misunderstandings and blurred communications;' com repts epithets used against Japan are directed at its econ activities abroad and charges that it is reviving its militarism; concedes there are sufficient grounds for heavy criticism; warns of detrimental effects on Japan if anti‐Japanese feelings become widespread; says Japanese points of view, unintelligible to Westerners, must be rationally and articulately presented to rest of world; recommends that Japanese corps make overseas public relations 'a matter of top‐mgt policy'; notes Japanese tourists abroad are criticized for their unattractive behavior and proposes Japanese educ system stress truly internatl outlook, including foreign language instruction; also recommends that Japan develop internatl media of its own that will extend to wide‐range of people and nations outside country; corn's candid recognition of Japan's difficulties follows earlier like criticism by T Hashimoto, Liberal Dem party official, and articles including that by Prof M Irie warning on anti‐Japanese sentiments and strongly criticizing Japanese postwar 'vulgarity and life‐style'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Revolt of The Masses
response.abstract: article on reasons behind Pres Nixon's decision to impose ceilings on meat prices notes that pressures from consumers in form of boycotts, labor pressure for wage gains to keep ahead of prices and Cong sympathy for lower income groups, who want to freeze prices, have contributed to Nixon's action; illus; chart shows consumer food price rises from '67 to '73
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATORS QUERY HALDEMAN'S ROLE
response.abstract: Apr 1‐15: Sen investigators of Watergate conspiracy say on Mar 31 that they want elaboration on J W McCord Jr's testimony dealing with White House chief of staff H R Haldeman; McCord has been quoted as saying that Haldeman was 'fully aware' of espionage operations against Dems; others say McCord's testimony did not go that far; 1 informant says that subject of Haldeman was raised at last minute of Mar 27 select Sen com hearing by Sen Weicker, who asked McCord whether Haldeman was aware of McCord's position as security coordinator at Pres Nixon's re‐election com; source says McCord gave 'very affirmative' response and recalled that he once sent Haldeman a 24‐page memorandum dealing with different security matters; it is understood that Weicker has met at length with A C Baldwin 3d, who worked directly under McCord in monitoring wiretaps on Dem telephones and in preparing logs indicating contents of overheard conversations
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Garelik, Short of Money, May Quit Mayoral Race
response.abstract: NYC City Council Pres Garelik reptdly is considering whether he should seek re‐election instead of continuing his foundering campaign for Dem NYC mayoral nomination; faces several obstacles if he chooses to run for re‐election, but some politicians say that Garelik could substitute for Deputy Mayor E A Morrison on Liberal party petitions since Morrison is thought to be stand‐in City Council Pres candidate

response.headline: Some Sales Reported Off —Drive to Last a Week
response.abstract: meat boycott leaders claim on Apr 1 that projected wk‐long effort to drive meat prices down has gotten off to a good start; stores on Lower E Side on NYC rept sales down by as much as 50%; NYC restaurant owners say there have been more than usual requests for meatless dishes from patrons; NY Consumer Assembly exec dir D Elberson praises beginning of boycott but notes that boycott's end result is not certain; Repr M Biaggi says he is in favor of boycott and suggests rollback of prices to end of '72 levels; NYC school‐lunch program dir J Jacobs claims that less meat has been served in public schools in last few mos because of rising meat prices; holds schools plan to observe boycott; Congressmen and consumer advocates score Pres Nixon's imposition of meat price ceilings; some Congressmen announce legis proposals to roll back prices to at least Dec '72 levels; Agr Sec Butz defends ceilings, which will go into effect on Apr 2

response.headline: State Reports Prices Peaked Weeks Ago
response.abstract: NYS Agr and Mkts Dept repts on Apr 2 that meat prices in NYC met area reached their peak 3 to 6 wks before Pres Nixon's imposition of ceilings on meat prices; Nixon supporters maintain that Pres acted before prices could move higher and critics hold that he waited until prices leveled off from their peaks; prices for certain cuts of meat in NYC and Hartford (Conn) met areas given; chart shows meat price rises to present ceilings in NYC met area
