response.headline: U.S. SEEKS ‘NEW ATLANTIC CHARTER’ TO RESOLVE STRAINS WITH EUROPE; URGES ‘PRINCIPAL’ ROLE FOR JAPAN
response.abstract: Dr Kissinger repts on Apr 23 that US plans to build 'new Atlantic charter' with its Eur allies this yr to overcome econ, mil and diplomatic strains that have developed recently; in major policy address to AP annual meeting in NYC, says Nixon is embarking on a personal and direct approach to leaders of W Eur to reviatlize Atlantic alliance and says Japan should share in this process as a 'principal partner'; noting that '73 has been called 'Yr of Eur,' proposes new Atlantic charter, setting goals for future, be worked out by time Nixon travels to Eur in fall; comments on specific complaints by Eurs and stresses Eurs have been taking US for granted while not showing enough understanding of US problems; holds US, in seeking new 'unifying framework' for ties, will continue to support Eur unity, will not unilaterally withdraw from its mil commitments in Eur, will continue to seek relaxation of tensions with Communists, will not injure interests of Eur allies but expects in return their policies will consider US interests; citing energy problems as example, says US wants to work cooperatively on new, common problems; holding Eur cannot be an exclusive club, says Japan must become a partner; says Eur's econ success, instead of bringing US and Eur closer together, has produced 'certain amount of friction'; stresses importance of resolving issues in trade and monetery fields; Kissinger and H B Klein illus during his speech
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Plea for Partnership
response.abstract: J Reston analysis of Kissinger speech on 'new Atlantic charter' for a US-Eur partnership that would include Japan; similarities and differences with late Sec Marshall's '47 proposal for a Eur recovery plan discussed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BIAGGI FACES LOSS OF CONSERVATIVES
response.abstract: A. Conservative party official said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi must “vindicate himself thoroughly” when he answers reports that he invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Aides Report Nixon Seeks Quick Watergate Windup
response.abstract: sources say that Pres Nixon's hopes for overcoming damage that Watergate scandal is inflicting on his Adm rest on speedy disclosure of those Govt officials involved and avoidance of protracted hearings by Sen Watergate com; says that trouble for Nixon is that 2 or 3 of those so involved are resisting complete disclosure and are thus endangering ability of Presidency to function as it should during remainder of Nixon's term; White House deputy press sec Warren denies on Apr 23 that Nixon had any prior knowledge of Watergate break-in; aides will not say who the 2 or 3 officials or former officials are; some close to Nixon fear that delay would mean drawn-out hearings before Sen com in which Adm would be 'dragged through the mud'; say Nixon's mood in last few days has been one of angry impatience to get matter settled; increasing indications that White House staff shake-up will occur as result of Watergate case noted; Nixon is in seclusion in Key Biscayne as is press sec Ziegler; Warren says Ziegler is occupying himself with duties of press sec in addition to other duties Pres has given him
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘TAMPERING’ CITED IN PUBLIC‐TV ROLE
response.abstract: T B Curtis, Public Broadcasting Corp chmn until he resigned abruptly 1 wk ago, says on Apr 23 that White House 'tampered with' corp's ind bd, in express contradiction to assurances that he had recd, int; says it is imperative that bd 'reassert its independence and integrity' by devising procedures that will effectively insulate it from pol pressures; contends that White House Telecommunications Policy Office Dir Whitehead did not respect bd's integrity as he said he would; Curtis's resignation on Apr 14 came in wake of decision by bd to defer action on carefully worked out compromise plan determining operating structure of public broadcasting; plan was designed to adjust relations between PBC and nation's 233 public TV stations; it would have assured that stations would retain large measure of control in public TV's national programing; Curtis was surprised that bd did not agree to plan; thinks bd members were ready to when White House interposed; says 4 members told him that they had been called but does not name individuals who allegedly interfered with deliberations; int detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dr. English to Resign by Dec. 31 As Chief of City Hospital System
response.abstract: Dr. Joseph T. English, the 39‐year‐old psychiatrist who has spent nearly three tumultuous years as chief of the city's new public hospital system, announced yesterday that he would leave the post by the end of Mayor Lindsay's term next Dec. 31.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BREZHNEV MEETS WITH SENATON
response.abstract: Soviet Communist party leader L I Brezhnev meets for 3 1/2 hrs with 7 members of US Sen Commerce Com members on Apr 23 to press for US trade; com members say they were impressed with sincerity of Brezhnev's desire for major and rapid build-up of Soviet-Amer trade and with his personal assurances that educ tax for emigrating Jews had been suspended; Sen Moss tells reporters that he thinks Jackson amendment, which would withhold equal tariff treatment, Govt-backed credits and approval for over-all Soviet trade agreement if USSR restricts emigration or imposes more than 'nominal' departure fees, will have 'tougher time' after Brezhnev's latest moves; group meeting with Brezhnev includes Sens Hartke, Cannon, Beall and Baker who, along with with 72 other Sens, are co-sponsors of Jackson amendment; Sen Beall indicates he originally supported Jackson amendment because of his opposition to heavy educ taxes and now thinks that Jewish groups will have to be satisfied; Sen Baker quotes Brezhnev as saying Moscow does not intend to let Jewish issue stand in way of trade and will do what is necessary to remove it as point of contention; Sen Griffin says Brezhnev confirmed information relayed earlier to Nixon that educ tax had been suspended; says he hopes Jackson amendment will not be offered on Sen floor; several Sens speak warmly of Brezhnev's candor, directness, thorough information and cordiality during meeting, noting they found him in good spirits and looking healthy; Sen Beall suggests that Nixon could take lesson in how to handle Cong from Brezhnev, who he says spent more time with Sens than Nixon usually does; Sen Hartke notes Brezhnev is prepared to go a practically unltd route and is interested in long-term relations; holds there is no question that USSR is looking for rather rapid, sharp and substantial development in trade with US; Brezhnev illus with Hartke and Beall; group of more than 100 Moscow Jews releases appeal on Apr 23 to leaders of Amer Jewish orgns not to withdraw their support for Jackson amendment while educated Jews are being barred from emigration; says those who are refused exit visas under pretext of natl security or without any move at all must not be sacrificed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon ls Reported to Have Phoned Dean To Tell Him, ‘You're Still My Counsel’
response.abstract: Source close to J W Dean 3d says that Pres Nixon telephoned his personal reassurances to Dean on Apr 22 wishing him 'happy Easter' and telling him 'You're still my counsel'; says Nixon discussed number of White House legal matters, not connected with Watergate inquiry, with Dean; White House deputy press sec Warren says that he has no knowledge of call and that he is unable to say whether Nixon telephoned other White House aides who have become ensnarled in Watergate controversy; Repr Reuss charges that Asst Atty Gen Petersen 'torpedoed' HR inquiry into break-in last fall by contending then that it would endanger rights of 7 original defendants; Justice Dept defended Petersen's opposition to inquiry as proper and necessary; Repub re-election com turns over 3 cartons of campaign spending documents to Fed ct on Apr 23, 2 days after Common Cause filed motion to hold Repubs in contempt-of-ct pending production of records; H Kissinger pleads for public understanding in Watergate revelations, speech, annual AP luncheon, NY; says it is difficult 'to avoid a sense of the awfulness of events and the tragedy that has befallen people alleged to have done these things for whatever reasons'; T A Kennelly, 1 of 2 attys representing G G Liddy, tells newsmen that he is withdrawing from case because his client would not listen to him; Cong sources disclose on Apr 22 that another secret '72 campaign fund was kept in S Calif bank under direction of H W Kalmbach; sources, in confirming acct in Washington Star-News, say upward of $200,000 in cash was handled through at least 4 separate bank accounts controlled by Kalmbach; Judge J J Sirica orders grand jury investigation into leaks of secret testimony; action follows publication of 4 articles by columnist J Anderson that were apparently based on grand jury transcripts; Sirica refuses request by J W McCord Jr to travel to Eng for TV appearance; Anderson issues statement defending his columns; sources say that C W Colson held at least 1 discussion with Nixon before Nov election and urged him to dismiss those aides who had possibly been involved to limit any potential pol damage; White House flatly denies rept, which was initially published in Washington Post; Colson denies giving warning to Nixon; Dean illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sexually Explicit Radio Shows W ilia Under Criticism by F.C.C.
response.abstract: Radio talk shows that deal explicitly with sex have been disappearing from air since Mar 28 when FCC Chmn Burch attacked what he called 'topless radio' for broadcasting 'prurient trash'; original, most widely syndicated show, B Ballance's Feminine Forum (Los Angeles), was abruptly transformed day after Burch's speech; women callers accustomed to picking up telephone for graphic, on-the-air discussions suddenly found Ballance considerably less flirtatious; number of other broadcasters with their own local versions of Feminine Forum also have backed away from explicit sex theme; among them are WHN (NYC) and WDEE (Detroit); others, including WWDC (Washington), KLIF (Dallas) and WHER (Memphis) dropped or softened programs before Burch's warning; most radio execs say their programs were enormously popular but that growth of their stations depends on FCC approval
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MACKELL RESIGNS IN FACE OF MOVE TO FORCE HIM OUT
response.abstract: Queens Dist Atty T J Mackell resigns on Apr 23, 12 days after he was indicted on charges of covering up criminal investigation and 5 days after Gov Rockefeller said he had begun proceedings to remove him from office; resignation, and Rockefeller's acceptance of it, means that Mackell will start now to receive annual pension estimated by city experts at $26,000 to $27,000; Mackell would have lost pension if he had been removed by Rockefeller; is, under law, entitled to pension regardless of final disposition of criminal charges against him, once resignation is accepted; Rockefeller, in accepting resignation, states that he was about to commence removal proceedings but that they are no longer necessary; notes that he intends to name new Dist Atty in next 2 days; illus of part of Mackell's resignation lr
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Army Reports Few In War in 1970‐'72 Are Addicts Today
response.abstract: US Defense Dept, in effort to dispel widely held belief that Vietnam veterans are a major factor in current heroin epidemic across US, on Apr 23 cites $400,000 Govt study by Univ of St Louis which indicates that fewer than 4,000 of 300,000 enlisted men who served in Vietnam between '70 and '72 are civilian drug addicts; study finds high proportion of Army enlisted men had experimented with or used drugs while in Vietnam, but that most of those who were addicted while in mil service had been rehabilitated and that only small proportion continued to use drugs on returning to civilian life; findings detailed; Asst Defense Sec Dr Wilbur offers Outside estimate' that of 315,500 enlisted men who served in Vietnam 4,075 may presently be drug dependent, but cautions that this was probably a 'worst case projection' since group included a large number of men who served before heroin epidemic in Vietnam in latter part of '70; says there were probably 2,000 to 3,000 drug addicts among those who served during period; illus with Washington Univ official Dr L Robins
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Jury Here Hears Mitchell; He Denies a Tie to Vesco
response.abstract: former Atty Gen Mitchell testifies before Fed grand jury on Apr 24, NYC, apparently about $200,000 cash contribution from R L Vesco to Pres Nixon's '72 election campaign; M H Stans, who was chmn of Finance Com to Re-Elect the Pres, reptdly has previously testified twice to jury; Mitchell declines to reveal subject of testimony; illus; says he answered all queries; says he never met Vesco to discuss financial problem with him
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON WOULD SIGN A NEW ‘CHARTER’ IN EUROPE IN FALL
response.abstract: high Nixon Adm officials say on Apr 24 that Kissinger's call for 'new Atlantic charter' was meant to signal W Eur leaders that Nixon wants to sign major document of agreed principles when he visits their countries later this yr; say Nixon contemplates charter similar in format to 'basic principles' he signed in Moscow last May with Brezhnev; White House reptd pleased with broad coverage of Kissinger's speech in Eur press; Sen Javits welcomes speech; Voice of Amer broadcast it live and sent copies abroad for distribution

response.headline: $1‐Billion Is Asked for Stewart Airport
response.abstract: MTA on Apr 24 makes public long-awaited blueprint, which recommends $1-billion transformation of Stewart Airport, Newburgh (NY), into 4th major jetport in NYC met area; major recommendations of rept discussed; map depicts location of Stewart, Kennedy and La Guardia airports
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Saturday Review in Bankruptcy; Norman Cousins to Run It Again
response.abstract: publishers of 4 Saturday Review magazines file bankruptcy proceedings on Apr 24 and announce plans to merge publications with World Magazine to form single biweekly called Saturday Review/World; N Cousins will head new pub; Saturday Review exec com chmn F S Wyle breaks news to staff
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DATA FROM TAPS REPORTEDLY SENT TO WHITE HOUSE
response.abstract: Sources dose to Watergate case say on Apr 24 that Fed investigators have determined that White House officials were regularly kept informed last May and June of some of information obtained through illegal wiretapping of Dem Natl Com hq; say that typed repts of overheard conversations, which were prepared by sec working at Nixon's re-election com, were not transmitted to White House but that com official apparently edited, in effect, typed rept so as to send only most significant pol information to White House; it is known that at least 3 White House aides maintained regular contact with re-election com during campaign: Haldeman, C W Colson and communications deputy dir K W Clawson; it is not known who recd edited repts; it is not known whether reptd White House recipients of wiretap information were fully aware of its origin; sources say that documents contained highly confidential information about Dem planning for their natl conv as well as details on delegate selection; testimony of A C Baldwin 3d, who monitored wiretaps, discussed; Watergate conspirator reptdly told Sen com that he was convinced that at least 1 copy of wiretap logs went to office of ex-Atty Gen Mitchell; notes that grand jury has learned that J S Magruder also had access to repts; S Harmony, sec to G G Liddy, allegedly testified before grand jury that she used secret special stationery to retype repts on conversations of Dem party officials that had word 'Gemstone' printed on top
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Atlanta Strikes an Integration Bargain
response.abstract: Atlanta (Ga) adopts controversial minimum-desegration school plan calling for token busing and leaving most of city's schools either predominantly white or black; NAACP Atlanta branch head Lonnie King was instrumental in drawing up plan, which promises to give blacks 50% of key jobs in school adm in return for minimal disturbance of status quo; Rev J E Lowery (SCLC) calls plan superior to other proposals; Rev J Boone calls plan anti-black; most vocal opposition comes from NY hq of NAACP and NAACP Legal Defense and Educ Fund; Atlanta Bd of Educ pres Dr B E Mays says NAACP fears plan might set natl pattern; graph shows rise in number of black pupils and decline in number of white pupils in Atlanta schools from '51 to '73
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sharp Response to Hanoi Disclosed by Washington
response.abstract: US makes public, Apr 24, a sharply worded reply to Hanoi's charges of cease-fire violations, accusing Hanoi of 'direct and inexcusable' breaches of the truce accord, note sent to Paris Internatl Conf on Vietnam participants in response to Hanoi note of Apr 16 contending that US and S Vietnam 'brazenly and systematically violated many essential provisions' of the accord which was endorsed by 12 parties to the Paris peace conf; US charges against Hanoi include: illegal movement by Hanoi of materiel and troops into S Vietnam and N Vietnamese mil attacks in S Vietnam; charges made by Hanoi in its note and US responses cited
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lon Nol Brings Opponents Into Cambodian Council
response.abstract: Cambodian Pres Lon Nol agrees to form 4-man council to govern Cambodia Apr 24; will share exec leadership with Gen Sisowath Sirik Matak, In Tam and Cheng Heng; pors; US has been pressuring Lon Nol to unite anti-communist pol forces in Cambodia in light of growing Communist mil threat; all 4 members of council were collaborators in ouster of Prince Norodom Sihanouk in '70; In Tam says he believes Gen Lon Non will be leaving on mission to US soon
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stock Prices Plunge
response.abstract: The stock market suffered one of its worst setbacks in nearly three years yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow‐Jones industrial average slid 14.60 points and closed at 940.77. Wall Street's malaise deepened after Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, hinted Monday afternoon that the Administration would consider a tax increase to combat inflation. Page 57.

response.headline: Byrne Quits Court to Run For Jersey Governorship
response.abstract: TRENTON, April 24 — Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne, who a Mafia figure in New Jersey once said “couldn't be bought,” announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

response.headline: JAPAN BARS VISIT OF HIROHITO TO U.S.
response.abstract: US State Dept hopes that date can be set next yr for visit of Japanese Emperor Hirohito to US; says that Japanese Govt informed US--in Tokyo and in message to Sec Rogers--of decision against visit this yr; officials not surprised by Japanese decision, noting that visit had become domestic pol issue

response.headline: Man, 26, Is Slain Leaving a Bank On West 102d St.
response.abstract: Berman, Thomas: T Berman, son of Abraham & Straus vp E M Berman, is slain on Apr 23 after leaving bank on Upper West Side when he refused to give assailant money he had just withdrawn; was apparently counting money on street when he was accosted; assailant fired 1 shot and fled, taking no money

response.headline: COURTS TO STRESS PUBLIC RELATIONS
response.abstract: ranking NYS judges plan to disclose inner workings of cts; they also plan to set up public relations dept to help them make disclosure; through dept judges plan to describe successes and failures of cts, give opinions on controversial judicial matters and answer questions; they will even provide information on investigations of judges; 2-member staff is planned

response.headline: AGNEW CONFIRMS HIS FAITH IN NIXON ABOUT WATERGATE
response.abstract: Vice Pres Agnew reiterates his faith in Pres Nixon on Apr 25 but concedes for 1st time that some of speculation on Watergate scandal might eventually be substantiated, brief press conf; says 'We are inundated with rumor, hearsay, grand jury leaks, speculation and statements from undisclosed sources. It is entirely possible that some of this may be proven later to be accurate. And, if it is, it must be confronted forthrightly at that time'; text; illus

response.headline: KISSINGER WILL MEET THO IN PARIS TO DISCUSS WAYS TO MAKE TRUCE EFFECTIVE
response.abstract: White House press sec Ziegler, Apr 25, announces H A Kissinger will meet Le Duc Tho in Paris to discuss ways to achieve 'strict implementation' of the truce; talks will be preceded by preliminary Sullivan-Thach talks starting Apr 27; Nixon Adm officials hope revived Paris talks will lead to new efforts to bring about compliance with truce accord; one official says that by the time of the meeting it should be evident whether Hanoi intends to launch a major offensive against S Vietnam before the start of the rainy season in late May and early June; US has been concerned about possibility of such an offensive; decision to hold new talks is reptdly result of an Amer initiative taken in the past wk; truce situation revd

response.headline: Japanese Have No. Plans To Invite Nixon for Visit
response.abstract: Japanese Min Ohira makes it clear, after Govt decided against visit by Emperor Hirohito to US, that Japan has no plans to invite Pres Nixon to visit Japan any time soon; indicates that it is up to Pres rather than Premier Tanaka's Govt to take initiative for visit; speaks at conf with foreign newsmen, who had protested being excluded from Apr 24 news conf; in reply to query on inv given to Chinese Premier Chou En-lai to visit Japan, says there is 'constant dialogue' between Tokyo and Washington and that matters need not be handled with 'excessive formality'; notes Hirohito's schedule for Oct; many Japanese critical of cancellation; Ohira por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Haldeman's Role Viewed As Reduced by Watergate
response.abstract: White House chief of staff H R Haldeman appears on Apr 25 to have lost much of his power as repts mount that staff shake-up, including resignations, is being planned; Haldeman has been reptd to be under investigation by grand jury looking into burglary and bugging of Dem Natl Com hq and into alleged attempts to protect some who might have played role in crime; Capitol Hill sources say ex-Defense Sec Laird was offered job of rebldg White House staff but turned it down; Wise Repub leaders close to Laird say they believe he can be persuaded to return to Washington for special duty if Nixon asks him; White House press sec Ziegler discloses under questioning that regular morning meetings of top aides which Haldeman has conducted for more than 4 yrs were broken off about 3 wks ago and have not been resumed; denies this development is connected with Watergate case; says aides involved, H Kissinger, G Shultz, J D Ehrlichman, R Ash and others, feel their time could be better spent in meetings with their subordinates; other sources point out that breakoff of what had become White House inst coincides with more recent explosive developments in Watergate case; other indications that Haldeman's power is declining noted; White House repts indicate that Nixon is spending most of his time on Watergate case and has become chief investigator of case; Ziegler illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘Wettest’ Spring on Mississippi Spreads Flood Crises
response.abstract: Miss River flooding continues Apr 25 as flood officials term spring 'wettest' in midwest recorded history and warn of more trouble from Rock Island, Ill, to south of New Orleans; options are lessening for limiting flood damage by siphoning off rising waters into uninhabited floodways; Army Corps of Engineers estimates monetary losses thus far at $170-million with 10 million acres reptd under water and 25,000 homeless; flooding situations in Grafton, Ill, near Gulf of Mex and Hannibal, Mo, noted; most of flooding has resulted from breaks in state, county and private levees, majority of which flank Miss tributaries such as St Francis in Ark and Yazoo in Miss; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Biaggi to Bid Judges Scan Assets Data; U.S. Offers Wider View of Jury Record
response.abstract: Repr Biaggi on April 25 promises to ask 3-judge panel to look at his secret Fed grand jury testimony and rept 'whether or not I took the Fifth Amendment or any other privilege on my personal finances and assets, taped TV broadcast; resumes his mayoral campaign that had halted for wk after NY Times and The Daily News reptd that he had declined to answer grand jury questions; asserts that he had waited until Apr 25 because he had to 'find a way that wouldn't hurt the good name of innocent people'; US Atty W N Seymour issues statement that takes note of restrictions Biaggi had placed on content of testimony and manner in which he proposed to release it; states that his office has no objection to release of grand jury mins or summary of mins with names of 3d persons referred to deleted to avoid unfair inferences; Biaggi apparently declines Seymour proposal; declares that Seymour has no authority to make mins public; asserts that to do so would 'strike at heart' of grand jury system; Seymour notes that he had not said he had authority to release mins but that he would not object to ct application to release it; Councilman Troy, Biaggi's campaign mgr, says that he is 'tickled pink' by Biaggi statement; Conservative party leaders are divided in reaction to statement; State Sen Marchi, Repub mayoral candidate, contends Biaggi is imposing too many 'hedges and conditions'; Repr Badillo says he believes Biaggi statement is 'very fair'; Assemblyman Blumenthal remarks that he has never heard of legal procedure proposed by Biaggi in his 20 yrs as lawyer; adds that he does not want issue of Biaggi's honesty to cloud campaign; Controller Beame asserts that Biaggi plan is not best way to handle situation; holds its is 'questionable' legal maneuver that is limited in scope and might hide truth; Biaggi buys TV time on 3 network affiliated stations--WCBS, WNBC and WABC--and on WPIX to deliver his public rebuttal; declares that he is victim of 'a plot, of attempted pol and character assassination'; accuses Liberal party leader 'boss Alex Rose' and NY Times; asserts 'I'm calling their bluff; discusses 'anguish' that he maintains he and his family suffered; criticizes what he calls 'another scheme to stop Biaggi' and points to meeting between Rose and former Mayor Wagner involving plan to make Wagner 'fusion' mayoral candidate; asserts only other person present at meeting was J B Oakes, NY Times ed page editor; Oakes states that he had lunch with Wagner and Rose but to discuss NYC pol, not to promote Wagner candidacy; notes that he has had similar luncheons with Blumenthal, Beame, Badillo and Biaggi; Biaggi consulted with at least 4 men in preparation of TV program--Century Natl Bank pres L Marchini, atty A H Christy, ad exec P Dusenberry, and campaign press sec M Matz; after program, Biaggi makes 1st public appearance in wk at Manhattan center, where he addresses nearly 300 ry and airline workers; Biaggi illustrations
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Saigon and Vietcong Offer Proposals for Settlement
response.abstract: Vietcong and Saigon Govt reprs, Apr 25, Paris, trade new plans for a pol settlement in S Vietnam, just 2 days before the end of the 90-day period set by truce accord for a solution to their dispute; both sides say there has been 'absolutely no progress' in their talks so far; Saigon presents 10-point proposal with a firm calendar ending with natl elections on Aug 26; Vietcong attacks plan as 'mere propaganda' but does not reject it outright and agrees to examine it; Vietcong presents 6-point proposal it says goes 'to fundamentals' and avoids 'sensationalism' of deadlines; there is continued chasm between the two positions despite appearance of many points of similarity; details in both plans cited; 2 sides agree to meet again next wk
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CATTLE FATTENER BANNED BY F.D.A.; BEEF PRICE TO RISE
response.abstract: FDA on Apr 25 bans cattle-fattening hormone DES, which is known to cause cancer in some animals; DES has been given to about 2/3 of Amer cattle to stimulate their growth, thus leading to larger animals or shorter fattening period; Agr Sec Butz says that ban will result in increased beef prices; Hess & Clark pres Dr A Andrews claims that ban is 'definitely going to have an upward effect' on beef prices because DES is 'very best cattle growth drug ever produced'; characterizes ban as 'rather stupid' noting that 5 other cos that make DES had objected to ban on hormone, which has been in widespread use for over 20 yrs; FDA acting Comr S Gardner says that new studies conducted on behalf of Agr Dept had found minute traces of DES, 120 parts per trillion of animals tissue; emphasizes that new studies do not demonstrate any public health hazzard but that tests question basis on which drug was approved; DES has been shown to produce cancer in laboratory animals; Agr Dept points out that growth stimulants Synovex-H, Synovex-R and Ralgro remain available for use in cattle, but notes that these products may be more expensive than DES; Fed experts estimate that beef animal given DES reaches mkt weight of 1,000 pounds about 35 days sooner than those not given hormone, which in turn saves about 500 pounds of cattle feed; Animal Health Inst official D Ringler says ban places potential of beef price increases at 15 cents per pound
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HAIG IS A WITNESS IN ELLEN CASE
response.abstract: Gen A M Haig Jr, vice chief of staff of US Army and Pres Nixon's top mil aide, testifies on Apr 25 at Pentagon papers trial as surprise witness; is not asked 1 question about papers or about D Ellsberg and A J Russo Jr; Haig's appearance was apparently approved by White House and it was taken as indication of importance that Adm still attaches to case; Haig was called for purpose of impeaching expertise of 2 previous defense witnesses, Dr A S Whiting and Dr M H Halperin; Ellsberg, on steps of courthouse, greets Haig in friendly manner shaking Haig's hand; Russo calls out to Haig that he (Haig) is 'genocidal warrior'; Haig illus

response.headline: Federal Study Indicates Crime Far Exceeds Reported Levels
response.abstract: US Law Enforcement Assistance Adm study indicates that in some categories number of crimes committed could run as high as 5 times number officially reptd by victims; ints conducted in 5,000 homes and 1,200 businesses in San Jose, Calif, and Dayton, Ohio, show that number of rapes and robberies experienced were twice as high as reptd, and aggravated assaults were 5 times number recorded by local police; study supports theory that poor people and people in poor neighborhoods are far more likely to be victims of burglaries and robberies than those in affluent areas; young males are more likely to be victims of assaults than other people; assault is more likely to involve friends or relatives than strangers; study speculates that reasons for non-reporting of crimes are involvement of friends or relatives, belief that crime is too 'petty' for police, and fear of retribution for calling police; study is basis for $10-million natl crime survey that began last July, built around Natl Crime Panel made up of 60,000 homes and 10,000 businesses; monthly ints are held to determine incidence and character of crime experienced; results will provide measure of natl crime and bring to light changes in criminal patterns as they occur
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IS CUT MARKEDLY AS EXPORTS GROW
response.abstract: US Commerce Dept repts on Apr 26 that US balance of export-import trade showed its best performance in Mar and in 1st qr since late '71; repts Mar trade deficit dropped sharply to $53-million from $476-million in Feb, but cautions that some temporary factors are involved; Sec Dent says better figures should not necessarily be interpreted as indicating that sustained improvement in US trade position is under way; Commerce Dept analysis calls results 'encouraging' but warns that good part of expansion of exports in Mar and in 1st qr may have been transitory; dept repts that trade deficit was reduced by nearly 50% in 1st qr to $833-million, compared to $1.5-billion in preceding qr, and was smallest since 3d qr '71; says total exports in Mar were at record level of $5,379,500,000 while Mar imports totaled $5,432,100,000; says 1st-qr '73 trade returns are encouraging but that it must be noted that imports still rose sharply by 9.3% from preceding 3-mo period; separate rept issued on Apr 26 says that trade deficit, measured on 'balance of payments' basis of measurement, was $920-million in 1st qr compared to $1,685,000,000 in 4th qr; graph depicting US trade

response.headline: GRAY SAYS HE DESTROYED FILES FROM HUNT GIVEN HIM WHEN HE MET EHRLICHMAN, DEAN
response.abstract: FBI Acting Dir Gray has told friends that he destroyed documents taken from Watergate conspirator E H Hunt Jr after it was suggested at June 28 White House meeting with J D Ehrlichman and J W Dean 3d that papers 'should never see the light of day'; Ehrlichman confirms on Apr 26 that meeting took place and that documents were given to Gray by Dean but insists that he did not know contents of papers and did not order them destroyed; says when he learned 'new facts' about documents on Apr 15 he reptd them to Pres Nixon same day; Gray has said that he cannot testify that cither Dean or Ehrlichman 'ordered' him to destroy papers, but that he believes Dean cautioned him that papers 'should never see the light of day'; associates say Gray recently learned that just before he arrived at White House, Ehrlichman asked Dean why it was necessary for FBI Acting Dir to handle papers; Ehrlichman is understood to have asked Dean, 'You drive over the bridge every night, why don't you throw them over?'; Gray has insisted that neither Dean nor Ehrlichman informed him of what was in Hunt files and that he destroyed them without examining their contents; Gray has said that he put files into manila envelope, took them home and left them in closet while he went to San Diego during latter part of wk; spent weekend at home and took envelope to FBI hq on July 3; there, according to associates, he tore up envelope without opening it and dropped remains into container whose contents are burned or shredded at end of each day; Gray reptdly recd description of contents within last few days; Asst Atty Gen Petersen is reptd to have told Gray that Dean now contends Hunt files held fake diplomatic cables; Hunt's file is believed to have dealt principally with Sen E Kennedy's '69 accident on Chappaquidick Island; whereabouts of other documents reptd to have been in Hunt's possession has never been definitely established; on June 19 Dean instructed staff sec to Pres Nixon B Kehrli to go to Hunt's office in old Exec Office Bldg and collect anything there; according to ct papers filed by Govt prosecutors, Kehrli searched room on June 19 and found nothing but unused office supplies and locked safe; papers say GSA employes were summoned to open safe and, while it was alleged Secret Service agent was present, no FBI agents were there; ct records say Dean's principal asst F Fielding arrived after safe was open, helped put safe's contents in cartons and took boxes to Kehrli's office in West Wing of White House for safe keeping overnight; on June 20 cartons were taken to Dean and he searched through them 'to determine whether there was any classified material therein'; prosecution repts that there was and that all material seized 'was subsequently turned over to FBI'; it was not until June 26 that contents came into investigators' hands; associates discuss possible reasons for Gray's actions; illus of Dean, Gray, Ehrlichman and Hunt
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Impact Found Slowing Work in Capital
response.abstract: White House staff reptdly is barely functioning in wake of Watergate scandal causing decisions on public matters to pile up; staff member says main business for 3 days last wk was discussion of how to 'salvage' Presidency; press sec Ziegler says work of Govt and White House staff is going on with Nixon getting in very early and staying very late; HEW Dept Sec Weinberger says HEW operations are not affected; other agencies rept delays on matters that move through White House staff process; Cong members predict that White House dominance in such matters as appropriations will be altered when Cong reconvenes after Easter recess; Repub leader questions whether Nixon can maintain solid Repub support in Cong on such matters

response.headline: EVIDENCE SNARLS ELLSBERG TRIAL
response.abstract: Fed Dist Judge W M Byrne, presiding over Pentagon papers trial, on Apr 26 sends jury home after discovering that Govt has again withheld evidence from ct and defendants; incident is 2d during trial in which jury was sent home; asst prosecutor W B Reese tells ct that there is no conscious or deliberate effort on prosecution's part to withhold material, which consists of ints by FBI agents and other Govt investigators of several Rand Corp employes, including R Moorstein, R H Best and J Butler; excusal of jury involves type of material referred to as 'Jencks' material, which derives its name from case involving C E Jencks, NM labor leader who was convicted in Jan '54 of falsely signing non-Communist affidavit under Taft-Hartley Act; conviction was appealed to Sup Ct, which ruled 7-to-1 on June '57 that FBI repts that formed basis of testimony by Govt witnesses in criminal trials must be turned over to defense or case must be dismissed; Cong in '57 passed Jencks Act, which said that only authenticated or substantially verbatim pretrial ints by prosecution witnesses have to be given to defendants and those ints have to have direct bearing on witnesses testimony
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.abstract: Brit Sec Douglas-Home, in Apr 27 speech in Scotland, says GB welcomes Kissinger's proposal for 'new Atlantic charter' as realistic and timely but makes it clear that Eur does not intend to link monetary, trade and defense issues in single negotiations; does not hide unease felt in Eur capitals that US wishes to win trade and monetary concessions as price for US nuclear defense; suggests each issue fraying relations must be handled in separate talks; says 'time scales of their discussions differ'

response.headline: GOVERNOR'S BILL ON DRUG TRAFFIC VOTED BY SENATE
response.abstract: NYS Sen on Apr 27 passes 41 to 14, Gov Rockefeller's modified antinarcotics legis, which calls for mandatory minimum prison sentences, limited plea bargaining and system of 'mandatory life sentences' for narcotics traffickers; extends mandatory minimum sentences to other than narcotics offenses; opponents of bill, mostly Dems, denounce measure as a flawed and contradictory approach toward dealing with narcotics pushers, adding that speed with which measure was enacted is latest example of 'gubernatorial arrogance'; other criticisms noted; modified antinarcotics legis outlined

response.headline: Haldeman and Ehrlichman Reported Fighting Ouster
response.abstract: White House assts H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman are reptdly fighting hard to retain their jobs despite being implicated in Watergate case; illus; both aides accompanied Pres Nixon to Meridian, Miss, for a speech, and reptdly met with Nixon during return flight to discuss resignation of L P Gray as FBI Acting Dir; several sources rept Nixon is under increasing pressure to fire Haldeman and Ehrlichman without waiting to see if they will be indicted by Watergate grand jury; State Sec Rogers reptdly urged Nixon to move quickly and decisively, as did Repub Natl Com Chmn G Bush; Haldeman and Ehrlichman are reptdly arguing that Nixon should do nothing unless one or both are indicted; Haldeman is suspected of involvement in both planning and subsequent cover-up of break-in at Dem Natl Com hq, while Ehrlichman has been implicated only in cover-up; Sen R Dole, former Repub Natl Com chmn, calls for immediate resignation of Haldeman and Ehrlichman, saying 'right now the credibility of the Adm is zilch, zero'

response.headline: Stock Prices Slump To Low for Year
response.abstract: The stock market suffered another sharp setback yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow‐Jones industrial average toppled 15.57 points to 922.19, a new closing low for 1973. The Dow's decline of 41.01 points for the week was one of the largest losses for any week in Wall Street history.

response.headline: SHOT KILLS INDIAN AT WOUNDED KNEE
response.abstract: insurgents holding Wounded Knee, SD, rept on Apr 27 that 1 of their men was killed and another wounded in gunfight in which US marshals used gas as well as rifles to try to subdue militants; rifle fight began on Apr 26 and continued until mid-morning on Apr 27 when insurgents requested cease-fire; T Oxendine, Govt spokesman, says only 'nontoxic tear gas' was used; vigilantes reptdly joined fight, firing at marshals and FBI agents; observer says that both Fed forces and insurgents fired at vigilantes; R Wilson says none of his followers were involved in fighting; asserts we 'have no vigilantes'; dead man is identified as L Lamont; about 30 of Lamont's relatives protest detention of Lamont's sister in jail; she was arrested on Apr 26 for allegedly participating in illegal demonstration; G Gereau, member of staff of Sen Interior and Insular Affairs Com, is pinned down for about 6 hrs during fight; says he tape-recorded 2 hrs of gun fight and sent tape to Sen H M Jackson, com chmn; R C Means is arrested in Los Angeles after Fed Judge Bogue revokes Means's $25,000 bond; Means faces 11 counts stemming from take-over; P Bissonette, leader of Amer Indian Movement, is arrested in Rapid City, SD, on charges of insurrection; L Crow Dog sends word from Wounded Knee, where he is acting as spiritual adviser, that insurgents will not negotiate with Justice Dept until F Clearwater is buried in village; Oglala Tribal Council, which rules Pine Ridge Reservation, formally agrees not to allow Clearwater's body to be buried in village; Amer Indian Movement leaders vow that they will march in throngs onto reservation with Clearwater's body this weekend; Justice Dept officials say marshals and FBI agents will help tribe enforce its ban on march and burial of Clearwater if it becomes necessary; Hellstern and Chief US Marshal Colburn leave Wounded Knee for Washington for consultation; K Frizzell, new Solicitor of the Interior Dept, meets with traditional head men and chiefs of other Sioux tribes who have gathered on Pine Ridge Reservation to discuss ways of bringing end to confrontation; says he is very encouraged; Rev Abernathy reptdly eludes police to meet briefly with head men and chiefs; says he is very encouraged; illus of sister of L Lamont at Lamont's coffin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A SUDDEN DECISION
response.abstract: FBI Acting Dir L P Gray 3d resigns on Apr 27 as result of Watergate crisis and is immediately replaced by W D Ruckelshaus; Ruckelshaus says that he asked for and recd from Pres Nixon assurances that 'no matter who is involved (in Watergate affair) there would be no sparing of anyone'; says he does not expect to serve for more than 2 mos or so and feels that post should go to someone with law-enforcement background; Gray's resignation follows disclosure that he destroyed documents obtained from White House counsel J W Dean 3d after receiving them at meeting with Pres asst J D Ehrlichman and Dean; Gray says his immediate departure from FBI is 'required to preserve in both image and fact the reputation, the integrity and the effectiveness' of FBI; says FBI 'has been in no way involved in any of those personal acts or judgments that may now be called into question'; Sen Weicker says on Apr 27 that he is 'convinced that Gray was abused...by those whom he had every reason to trust'; says Gray used bad judgment in destroying documents; J S Magruder resigns his Commerce Dept post on Apr 26; J J Bierbower, Magruder's atty, will not say Magruder left because of Watergate affair; illus of Gray, Ruckelshaus and Ziegler

response.headline: DEAN IS REPORTED ASKING IMMUNITY
response.abstract: Sources close to Watergate case say White House counsel J W Dean 3d has told Fed prosecutors he will not testify about alleged wrongdoings of his colleagues, J D Ehrlichman and H R Haldeman, if he is not granted immunity from further prosecution; Dean's reptd refusal puts him in opposition to Pres Nixon, who told newsmen on Apr 17 that no individual holding 'a position of major importance in Adm should be given immunity'; newsmen have been told by Dean's friends that he has evidence linking Haldeman and Ehrlichman to effort to obstruct Fed inquiry into break-in at Dem Natl Com hqrs in Watergate bldg; J J Wilson, recently hired atty for Haldeman and Ehrlichman, refuses to comment on possibility of grand jury appearances by his clients; Dean's reptd refusal to testify without immunity is seen creating problem for US attys prosecuting case, since immunity might jeopardize their case against Dean and they have no assurance his testimony will convict Haldeman and Ehrlichman, should they be indicted

response.headline: Welfare Study. Minimizes Impact of Migrant Blacks
response.abstract: US Census Bur demographer L H Long repts findings of new study of '70 Census showing that Southern blacks who have moved by hundreds of thousands to crowded inner cities of North, mostly over last 2 decades, are less likely to be poor or on welfare than their urban-born counterparts, rept to Population Assn of Amer; also finds that blacks who had moved from South since '65 were more likely to be poor or on welfare than either earlier migrants or urban-born; Long suggests that results of study make it appear unlikely that large number of blacks had been attracted to North by prospect of higher welfare payments, a notion that has been broadly accepted and espoused by Pres Nixon; concludes from data that black Southern migrants are 'more economically successful' than blacks born in Northern cities; contends that black women who were heads of households that had migrated from South were less likely to be on welfare or to have incomes under poverty level than those born in states in which cities were situated; other findings detailed

response.headline: Ellsberg Says His Trial Now Seems to Be Political
response.abstract: D Ellsberg says on Apr 28 that newly reptd link between Watergate conspirators and his Pentagon papers trial, involving disclosure of break-in at office of his former psychiatrist Dr L J Fielding, has convinced him that Pentagon papers prosecution was related to efforts to reelect Pres Nixon, int; cites alleged attempt to have him attacked by 2 Cuban nationals and called a traitor when he delivered speech at antiwar rally in Washington in May '72; 2 Cuban exiles say in int in Miami Herald that they had accompanied 4 of Watergate conspirators to Washington twice during last May on what they were told was CIA mission to disrupt antiwar demonstrations; say that Ellsberg was particular target of 1st trip on May 2, on which they were allegedly told to disrupt demonstrations during funeral of former FBI dir J E Hoover

response.headline: U.S. Said to Bar Bugging On Teamsters‐Mafia Link
response.abstract: Govt sources rept on Apr 28 that Atty Gen Kleindienst and Asst Atty Gen Petersen turned down request by FBI 8 wks ago to continue electronic surveilance that had begun to penetrate Teamsters union connections with Mafia; Kleindienst and Petersen reptdly made decision after 40 days of FBI wiretapping uncovered purported Mafia plan to reap millions of dollars in payoffs from welfare funds of Teamsters; they acted after having recd memorandum, prepared at direction of FBI Acting Dir L P Gray; memorandum, which made no recommendations, indicated sensitivity of investigation, which was reptdly producing disclosures potentially damaging to Teamsters pres F E Fitzsimmons, Nixon Adm's staunchest labor ally; Kleindienst-Petersen decision came less than 1 mo before C W Colson, special counsel to Nixon, left White House to join Washington law firm to which Fitzsimmons has transferred union's legal business; Colson, through his atty and law partner, D I Shapiro, denies knowledge of matter; electronic surveillance began on Jan 26 under order of Fed Dist Ct in Los Angeles authorizing FBI to tap phones in offices of People's Industrial Consultants, concern that is alleged Mafia front set up to channel Teamster welfare money to underworld figures; ct on Feb 14 authorized extension of taps until Mar 6; FBI affidavit submitted to Justice Dept attys said investigation indicated 'pattern of racketeering activity,' including series of kickbacks flowing from corps controlled by dr in league with mob through People's Industrial Consultants to officers of employe welfare benefit plan; affidavit cited information reptdly given to FBI by informant in contact with associate of A Dorfman, consultant to Teamsters' billion-dollar Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund, who began serving Fed prison term on Mar 28 for fraud and conspiring to receive kickback in connection with loan application made to pension fund; informant said that on Feb 8 Dorfman's associate introduced Fitzsimmons to P Milano, S Sciortino and J Lamandri, identified by FBI as members of Mafia, at Palm Springs, Calif, country club; Justice Dept sources say that 3 men presented to Fitzsimmons proposal for prepaid health plan, under which Teamsters' members would be provided with med care by Dr B Frome; say Fitzsimmons gave tentative approval to plan and then met with L Rosanova, alleged envoy for Chicago crime syndicate; says dept has evidence that Chicago branch of Mafia is determined to retain access it had to Teamsters' funds during J R Hoffa's pres; Rosanova and Fitzsimmons reptdly talked again in San Diego on Feb 12; Fitzsimmons flew to Washington with Pres Nixon a few hrs after meeting; Dr Frome on Feb 9 reptdly had telephone conversation with R DeRosa, muscleman for Milano who operates out of consulting co's offices; DeRosa told Frome that 'deal with Teamsters is all set'; tapped conversations detailed; Hoffa and Fitzsimmons por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: P.O. W.'s Felt Their Mission Was to Resist
response.abstract: Article revs public comments of nearly 100 returned Amer POWs about their experiences as POWs; several dozen men int in depth; repts of torture seem genuine, but physical brutality played a small part in the lives of many inmates, particularly those shot down more recently; it is still uncertain how POWs' commitment to resist enemy has colored their accounts of prison life; men captured in the North were often kept in old French prisons and sometimes spent yrs in the same cell; those captured in S Vietnam lived mainly in jungle camps and were moved constantly as captors moved; southern POWs were seldom able to communicate or organize among thesmelves; northern camps were organized, with the sr officers taking command; usually prisoners in N Vietnam presented a united front, but a few opposed the war and defied the authority of their srs in the name of 'conscience'; N Vietnamese were furious at US pilots who bombed their country; Amers were outraged at being captured by a backward, Communist country they considered inferior in all ways and habitually referred to their captors as 'sleazy gooks' and worse; initial mistreatment they got aggravated their animosity and brought them to point where they consciously 'forced' the N Vietnamese to be 'brutal' to them before they would obey any directives; an essential element of the POWs resistance struggle was a process one POW called 'reverse brainwashing,' whereby the reaction against anti-Amer indoctrination sessions by the Communists was to make the patriotism of the POWs even stronger; comment in ints by Lt Col A Lurie, Comdr C Clower, Lt Col J E Hiteshew, Lt D Rehmann, Rear Adm J A Denton and Lt Col L Shattuck; Denton, Rehmann and Shattuck illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TWO NIXON AIDES EXPECTED TO SEE U.S. PROSECUTORS
response.abstract: Sources close to Watergate case say White House aides H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman will meet with Fed prosecutors to discuss their possible roles in Watergate break-in and subsequent cover-up; summoning of Haldeman and Ehrlichman to meeting with chief Govt prosecutor, E J Silbert, is seen as 1st formal sign that they are under investigation by grand jury; Haldeman is known to be under inquiry to determine whether his office had role in initial bugging operation or any subsequent attempts to obstruct investigation; Ehrlichman was cited by L P Gray 3d, former FBI Acting Dir, as being present at meeting 11 days after Watergate break-in at which Gray was handed file containing documents belonging to one of Watergate participants and strongly urged to make sure files 'never see the light of day'; Gray has said man who handed files to him was White House counsel J W Dean 3d; Washington Post repts that Dean intends to swear under oath that he was ordered by Haldeman and Ehrlichman to coordinate cover-up and reptd regularly on its progress to them; other Watergate developments include Time (pub) rept that former White House counsel C W Colson recruited young men during '72 Pres campaign to pose as homosexual supporters of Dem Sen McGovern in attempt to link McGovern with 'gay liberation' cause; Colson denies this and other Time rept which says J S Magruder, former deputy chief of Nixon re-election com, told Fed prosecutors that Colson knew about Watergate plans in advance and even urged in telephone call to Magruder that they be expedited; Sen Percy says in TV int that he will introduce Sen resolution calling on Pres Nixon to appt pol independent prosecutor for Watergate case; Sen Weicker, member of Sen Watergate com, sharply criticizes what he calls implications made by White House that FBI Acting Dir L P Gray 3d was forced out; Weicker says Gray made his own decision

response.headline: LINDSAY SUGGESTS PLAN FOR TRANSIT TO REDUCE FARES
response.abstract: Mayor Lindsay on Apr 29 unveils plan to roll back bus and subway fares to 25c, cut commuter fares by 28.5% and provide for long-range financing of mass transit in met area; under proposal, new regional govt body, the New York Regional Transportation Dist, would be created, including NYC and counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland and Westchester, to raise funds and make disbursements for mass transit but would have no role in operation of transit facilities; plan would be financed by combination of Fed grants and matching funds from NYS; if Pres Nixon vetoes mass transit bill under which Fed funds would be provided, dist would be empowered to level payroll tax in NYC and surrounding counties; Lindsay says he will have legis submitted this wk in Albany and will begin immediate discussions with govt leaders in neighboring counties; maintains new dist would ideally include Conn and NJ; calls projected 55c NYC transit fare 'threat to viability of city's econ center'; estimates that new transit dist in its 1st yr could raise some $537-million which could be used to eliminate annual deficit of region's mass transit systems, reduce NYC fare from 35c to 25c, reduce all suburban commuter rr and bus fares by 28.5%, eliminate all double fares within city's subway system and provide some funds to 'finance innovations and experiments in regional transit operations; notes that if Fed funds are not forthcoming, equivalent sum, or more, will be raised through payroll tax; tax, 1/2 of 1%, will be levied on all employment in new dist, with 1/2 of tax to be paid by employers and 1/2 by employes; illus of Lindsay with Deputy Mayor Hamilton and NYC budget dir D A Grossman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SHAKE‐UP LAUDED BY CONGRESSMEN
response.abstract: Cong members join in widespread, bipartisan praise on Apr 30 for Pres Nixon's shake-up of his Adm's high command but many Sens and Reprs couple commendations with warnings that housecleaning of White House staff will not be sufficient to restore faith in Nixon Adm or Govt as whole; Repr J E Moss urges HR Dem leaders to open formal inquiry into possible impeachment of Pres Nixon; Dem Govs join in call for apptmt of special prosecutor in Watergate case, Huron, Ohio; Sen Repub leader Scott hints broadly and other declare flatly that Atty Gen-designate Richardson should take steps to turn over Watergate investigation to impartial prominent figure outside Nixon Adm; Scott says he is convinced that Nixon had no knowledge of extent to which people in White House or workers in Pres re-election campaign were involved in Watergate conspiracy or cover-up; Scott says he finds it 'most difficult to believe that the Pres was not aware of Watergate' and its implications during 10 mos that conspiracy has been before public; Repr O'Neill says HR leadership feels that impeachment idea is premature; says that in privacy of Cong cloakroom there has been widespread sentiment for effort to 'censure' Pres; Sens Ervin, Baker, Percy and Goldwater and Reprs Abzug and Anderson comment

response.headline: Biaggi Testimony to Jury Ordered Rdeased in Full
response.abstract: Fed Judge E L Palmieri on Apr 30 orders release of Dem mayoral aspirant Repr Biaggi's testimony before grand jury but holds up order when Biaggi's lawyer A H Christy says he will appeal to block disclosure; denies motion by Biaggi for panel of 3 judges to examine his testimony and state whether; he had taken Fifth Amendment 'solely' on questions about his personal finances; Biaggi has told Conservative party leaders that he had answered all questions put to him by grand jury; Palmieri declares that 'upon reflection, this ct can only conclude that this blatantly unsanctioned petition was made with an expectation of its denial by the ct, and for the purpose of publicly exploiting ct's denial of the motion'; notes that he agrees with US Atty W N Seymour Jr, who had asked for full disclosure, that Biaggi's motion constituted abuse of the ct; pol impact of Palmieri decision comes quickly; Biaggi dismisses City Councilman Troy as his campaign mgr; Conservative party leaders split over whether to continue to support Biaggi; Christy and Palmieri illustrations

response.headline: End of Era in Nixon Presidency
response.abstract: analysis of resignations of H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman as ending 1 era in Nixon Presidency; says things will be different but questions how different; says Haldeman and Ehrlichman helped design system, ran system, and, in time, came to symbolize system; says they dominated in White House in all areas other than foreign policy, where H Kissinger retains primary influence; says only shadow of old superstructure remains; characterizes Haldeman as technician and organizer, not an 'issues' man, who preferred men 'in his own image,' thus creating 'visible shrinkage in the variety of views and voices available to Pres'; notes that everything produced at lower levels passed through Haldeman's hands as did requests for personal meetings with Pres; says Ehrlichman was crucial link in this system as he screened all domestic proposals before delivering them to Haldeman; notes Haldeman's insistance that he did not try to shape Pres' thinking on substantive issues but that Ehrlichman did try; notes that Ehrlichman was more available to press than was Haldeman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEW DATA CITED
response.abstract: Pres Nixon tells nation in TV address on Apr 30 that he accepts responsibility for what happened in Watergate case even though he had had no knowledge of pol espionage or attempts to cover it up; speech follows resignations of 3 top staff members who have been implicated: J D Ehrlichman, H R Haldeman and J W Dean 3d, as well as that of Atty Gen Kleindienst; Nixon pledges every effort to achieve justice in case and alleges wrongdoing or cover-up attempts on part of those he delegated to run his '72 Pres campaign and those he apptd to investiate matter during campaign; implies that his own election officials, in Watergate espionage, were attempting to stop wrongdoing by Dems; says that hereafter investigation of Watergate matters will be delegated to his new Atty Gen, E L Richardson, while he, Nixon, turns his attention to grave foreign and domestic matters; says he will leave it up to Richardson whether to appt special prosecutor; speech is emotional appeal to save integrity of Pres for the 1,361 days, by Nixon's count, that remain in his term; Nixon's demeanor noted; attempts to establish his own innocence; says that for 1st time in his pol career, he did not run his own campaign; suggests that his own investigators lied to him; indications over weekend that suggested Pres Nixon would make speech noted; press sec Ziegler's announcement of resignations noted; illus of Nixon and Richardson
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ellsberg Judge Demands Affidavits on Bugging Tie
response.abstract: Fed Dist Judge W M Byrne Jr on Apr 30 orders 4 figures connected to Watergate bugging affair, former special counsel to Pres Nixon, J W Dean, former acting FBI dir, L Patrick Gray 3d, and G G Liddy and E H Hunt Jr, conspirators in Watergate bugging case, to produce affavits concerning any link between break-in on Sept 3-4, '71, at Beverly Hills, Calif, office of Dr L J Fielding, D Ellsberg's psychiatrist, and Pentagon papers trial; says he is not foreclosing possibility of summoning 4 men to ct to testify although he denies, for now, defense attys' request for immediate hearing on new evidence; indicates that he will probably require affidavits and perhaps testimony from former Atty Gen J N Mitchell, present Atty Gen R G Kleindienst, Nixon's former chief for domestic affairs J D Ehrlichman, Nixon's former chief of staff H R Haldeman, both of whom resigned today, former Pres special counsel C W Colson and former Asst Atty Gen R C Mardian; repts that about 1 mo ago he (Byrne) met with Erlichman and Nixon at Ehrlichman's suggestion, at which time he was offered new Govt position; does not disclose what position was, but Byrne's name has been mentioned as possible dir of FBI; starts broadening scope of his inquiry, in response to demands from defense attys L B Boudin and L I Weinglass, into link between Watergate and Pentagon papers; Dr Fielding's affidavit, in which he details visit on July 20, '71, by 2 FBI agents concerning Ellsberg and subsequent break-in to his office on Sept 4, disclosed; M J Martinez, mother of E Martinez, janitor of Fielding's bldg, also files affidavit describing how 2 men gained access to Fielding's office on night of break-in
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONNALLY. TO SHIFT TO THE G.O.P. TODAY
response.abstract: Former Tex Gov and Treas Sec J B Connally to announce at a news conf, May 2, Houston, his long-expected switch from the Dem to the Repub party; Connally associates say, in phone ints, that Connally intended to combine the declaration of party change with a defense of Pres Nixon's handling of the Watergate case; a friend says he doubts that Connally will be willing to accept a staff position in the White House; Connally's conservative views, a result in part of his Tex oil indus links, have propelled him steadily toward the Repub party; his switch is likely to produce a major partisan realignment in Tex; Austin, Tex, sources say that others are likely to follow Connally lead; E Clark cited as among those; comment on impact of Connally shift on natl scene

response.headline: 6 MAY BE INDICTED
response.abstract: Govt investigators say on May 1 that they now have evidence that high-ranking officials of White House and Com for Re-Election of Pres conspired after June '72 Watergate break-in to arrange careful cover story designed to obstruct Fed investigation; say evidence shows that obstruction of justice was coordinated by Nixon's 2 closest advisers--H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman, who resigned Apr 30--and ex-Atty Gen Mitchell, who headed re-election com at time; say J S Magruder, F C LaRue and J W Dean 3d were also involved in initial cover-up attempt; say cover-up was formulated during some secret meetings held at re-election hq in late June; say basic scheme called for all those involved in operation to deny any knowledge of it and for re-election com to issue public statements to that effect; say everyone involved in operation repeatedly lied to Fed investigators, prosecutors, other White House officials and to Pres Nixon; sources say all 6 men are expected to be indicted by Fed grand jury; say D L Chapin, G Strachan, H L Porter and K W Parkinson were also involved in cover-up and are now under investigation by grand jury; scheme, as allegedly worked out by Ehrlichman, Haldeman, Mitchell and Dean, included payments to arrested defendants, promises of exec clemency, series of public denials and arrangements with Magruder and Porter to perjure themselves druing trial of 7 Watergate defendants; sources say additional funds needed for payoffs were collected by H W Kalmbach, Nixon's personal lawyer, who also served as chief campaign money raiser; source says it has not been determined whether Kalmbach was aware of money's ultimate use; says perhaps grossest fabrication was coordinated account provided to Fed prosecutors and used by them as bulwark in subsequent Watergate trial, of initial rationale behind cash payments to G G Liddy; Govt was told by number of re-election com officials that $100,000 given to Liddy was to pay 10 intelligence agents $1,000-a-mo each for 10 mos in '72 to find out if anti-Repub demonstrations were planned; H W Sloan Jr, treas of re-election com, who gave cash to Liddy, was, according to investigators, only key official who apparently chose not to participate in cover-up, causing his superiors to alter some details of agreed-upon story; sources say Sloan had been urged to commit perjury during Watergate trial by testifying that he gave Liddy and his associates only $40,000 in $100 bills rather than $235,000 that was actually provided; investigators say that cover-up publicly began within 2 days of arrests inside Dem hq after newspapers identified J W McCord Jr as 'security coordinator' for re-election com

response.headline: F.B.I. Guard Put on Files Of 3 Departing Nixon Men
response.abstract: FBI agents on May 1 begin guarding files of Pres assts Haldeman, Ehrlichman and Dean who are leaving because of Watergate case; White House press sec Ziegler says no one is permitted to examine or remove papers from files unless agent is present; says this 'safeguarding procedure' is not meant 'to cast aspersions on any individual' and that Haldeman and Ehrlichman have agreed to procedure; Haldeman and Ehrlichman are seen leaving White House at midmorning in official limousine holding papers reptdly culled from their files under supervision to help them defend themselves before grand jury and Sen investigators; plan to protect files was decided upon at Apr 30 meeting by L Garment, who has temporarily taken Dean's place, E L Richardson, Atty Gen-designate and FBI Acting Dir Ruckelshaus; Nixon's mood during day noted; official says Nixon's fury was aroused at Cabinet meeting, not by Sen Percy's resolution, passed by Sen, calling for apptmt of special prosecutor in Watergate case; does not oppose special prosecutor but thinks Richardson ought to be able to decide that question without pressure from party colleagues; Ziegler says Richardson has firm mandate to accept or reject idea of 'special supervisory prosecutor' mentioned by Nixon on Apr 30; says Nixon might be backing away from his Apr 17 rejection of immunity from prosecution for major figures in case; says that to his knowledge H W Kalmbach is no longer handling business for Nixon; that Pres will hold frequent news confs in coming mos; that it has not yet been decided whether Haldeman and Ehrlichman will be replaced, with 'the new men carrying on in the same way'; Ziegler illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Biaggi Now Asks Release Of Jury Record, butin Full
response.abstract: Repr Biaggi, in sudden legal maneuver reversing his past positions, asks Fed ct Judge E L Palmieri on May 1 to allow full disclosure of his '71 grand jury testimony, including names of all other persons; Palmieri quickly rejects bid; Biaggi reversal comes only hrs after US Appeals Ct decides with unusual speed to hear arguments on earlier Biaggi move to block disclosure of his testimony; Palmieri states that it would be 'improper and unwise' for ct to permit publication of names of unconcerned 3d parties cited in testimony; tells Biaggi lawyer A H Christy that he would release testimony only if names are deleted; Christy says that he will appeal decision, along with Palmieri's earlier decision, which called for disclosure of grand jury testimony with deletion of names of other persons; controversy over Biaggi's credibility has become mayoral campaign issue; Conservative party leaders say they will seek to take away party's designation from Biaggi if it is learned that he lied to them about answering all questions put to him by grand jury; Appeals Ct panel that is hearing cases this wk consists of Chief Judge H J Friendly, Circuit Judge P R Hays and visiting Fed Dist Judge W J Jameson; Prof H Paolucci, Conservative party state vice chmn, files civil complaint in Fed Dist Ct to request investigation of original leaks to newspapers about grand jury testimony
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON ROLE CITED
response.abstract: former Pres asst J D Ehrlichman, in FBI investigation rept made public in Pentagon papers trial on May 1, repts he has told Fed investigators that break-in at office of Dr L I Fielding, D Ellsberg's psychiatrist, came as result of secret White House investigation he ordered at request of Pres Nixon; FBI rept, based on int by agents with Ehrlichman in his White House office on Apr 27, says that in '71 Nixon had 'expressed interest' in leak of classified information and 'asked him to make inquiries independent of concurrent FBI investigation which had been made relating to the leak of the Pentagon papers'; Ehrlichman, according to rept, said that G G Liddy and E H Hunt Jr, conspirators in Watergate case, had been 'designated' to conduct investigation; says that he did not know that Liddy and Hunt had broken into Fielding's office until after it had happened, did not agree with 'method of investigation', and told 2 men 'not to do this again'; rept says that there was information available that Ellsberg had emotional and moral problems and Liddy and Hunt sought to determine full facts by preparing 'psychiatric profile and conducting 'in-depth investigation of Ellsberg'; defense atty L B Boudin, prompted by disclosure of rept, moves for dismissal of case 'with prejudice'; Judge W M Byrne Jr says he will take motion under submission and that he believes that Ehrlichman material is exculpatory; defense attys contend that President's extra-official orders to investigate Pentagon papers case occurred while Ellsberg was under indictment and that this represents grave interference in judicial process; H Rowen, former pres of Rand Corp, testifies that there had been no special arrangements for handling of Pentagon papers at Rand, and that he had not acted to keep them out of Rand's regular top-secret control system; testimony is in direct contradiction to basic defense contention; Rowen says in '69 he had not authorized Ellsberg to store some of papers in his (Rowen's) own top-secret safe to help keep them from Rand's top secret control officer; illus of Ellsberg talking to newsmen outside courthouse; illus of Ehrlichman in White House office in March; pors of Liddy and Hunt
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. TO EXTRADITE El‐GUARD IN CAMP
response.abstract: US Chief Judge J Mishler on May 1 orders extradition of Mrs H Braunsteiner-Ryan, former guard-supervisor in Nazi death camps during World War II, to W Ger to face charges that she had murdered camp inmates; Ryan is 1st US resident whose extradition for alleged war crimes has been sought and granted; US Atty Morse discloses that he and other Govt officials are investigating possibility that denaturalization proceedings could De instituted against as many as 50 people in US; Mishler rejects Ryan's contention of 'double jeopardy,' deciding that murder charges against her are unrelated to other war crimes of which she had been convicted in '49 by Vienna ct; charges centered on her role as supervisor of Ravensbrueck concentration camp in Ger and supervising warden of camp at Majdanek in Poland; Mishler says current murder charges are not those that Ryan had been acquitted of in Austria; stays her surrender until May 4 to give her lawyer, J J Barry, time to appeal by way of writ of habeas corpus
keywords: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND FOREIGN NATIONALITIES
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Congress Pressing Drive For a Special Prosecutor
response.abstract: Sen adopts resolution on May 1, drafted by Sen Percy, urging Pres Nixon to seek Sen confirmation of nominee 'of the highest character and integrity from outside the exec branch to serve as special prosecutor' in Watergate case; 18 HR Repubs introduce similar resolution calling on Atty Gen-designate Richardson to 'immediately' use authority that Nixon gave him on Apr 30 to appt impartial prosecutor; House Judiciary Com Chmn Rodino says he will seek legis to enable Cone to remove entirely from Presidency the responsibility for investigating Watergate case; Repr Moss says that neither Nixon's actions nor judgment of HR leaders that he is acting 'prematurely' will deter him from seeking formal HR inquiry into possibility of lodging impeachment proceedings against Pres; Cong Dem leaders are, for most part, inclined to support Nixon and accept his guarantee that there will be no 'whitewash at the White House'; only 4 Sens, Percy, R C Byrd, P V Domenici and J Sparkman, are present when Percy's resolution is adopted unanimously; Sen Curtis and others attempt to seek reconsideration of Percy resolution; text of resolution; Percy illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ruling in Suit on Stock Trading Could End Mass Class Actions
response.abstract: US Appeals Ct 3-judge panel rules on May 1 that a person who files class-action suit must pay cost of notifying each person on behalf of whom suit is brought, even if that means notifying millions of people; Judge H R Medina, chmn of panel, calls ruling 'landmark decision' that would affect hundreds of class actions now before cts; asserts such cases are 'legalized blackmail' and that huge expense of such actions has brought pressure to settle in large amts irrespective of merits of claim; Eisen suit, which contended Carlisle & Jacquelin and DeCorret & Doremus (now Carlisle de Coppet & Co) had overcharged him and 6 million other odd-lot buyers $70 each because round-lot purchases do not have to pay extra charge when they buy at least 100 shares at a time, was originally dismissed in '66 by NYC Dist Ct Judge H R Tyler Jr as class action; Tyler subsequently ruled case could be brought as class action and ordered DeCoppet to bear 90% of cost of notifying from then-identifiable list of 2.5-million buyers and sellers, 7,000 be notified that lawsuit had been filed on their behalf
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT ORDERS TIGHTER CONTROLS OVER PRICE RISES
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, commenting on Phase 3 of wage-price program, on May 2 argues against freeze on food prices urged by some Congressmen; claims a freeze would create more problems for 'avg Amer than it would solve'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: INVESTIGATORS TERM C.O.P. SPYING A WIDESPREAD ATTEMPT TO INSURE WEAK DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE IN 1972
response.abstract: INVESTIGATORS TERM C.O.P. SPYING A WIDESPREAD ATTEMPT TO INSURE WEAK DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE IN 1972
