response.headline: Seymour Indicates Biaggi Balked Before Grand Jury
response.abstract: US Atty W N Seymour Jr strongly suggests before US Appeals Ct on May 2 that record shows that Repr Biaggi refused to answer questions before Fed grand jury 18 mos ago; declares that 'we know what happened before grand jury' and asserts that Biaggi's motion for panel of judges to say only whether he had invoked Fifth Amendment on his personal finances was attempt to put ct in position of 'vouching for something which was, at best, a half truth'; Seymour's statements are made during Biaggi appeal of rulings by Fed Judge E L Palmieri calling for release of his testimony before grand jury with names of other persons mentioned in minutes deleted; Appeals Ct reserves decision; Biaggi repeatedly declines during May 2 news conf to say whether he had answered all questions before jury; concedes that his mayoral candidacy has been 'jeopardized' by disclosures relating to his grand jury appearances; Biaggi's motion for full disclosure comes as surprise in view of his previous statements that his main reservation for not having minutes released was desire to protect other persons mentioned in testimony; asserts at news conf that his reversal of tactics is 'question of survival'; declares that despite his difficulties 'nothing whatever' will prevent him from continuing in mayoral race; M Gould, atty for Controller Beame, one of Biaggi's rivals for Dem nomination, contends that underlying issue in battle for release of grand jury minutes is whether Biaggi is fit to be Mayor of NYC; Appeals Ct Chief Judge Friendly asks Seymour if he has investigated how NY Times got its information about Biaggi's refusal to answer questions; Seymour replies that he is convinced that information did not come from anyone in his office because some of details in Times article were inaccurate; Biaggi releases net worth statement and 1st page of his income tax returns for '69, '70 and '71; statement shows that he and his wife have assets of $186,824 and liabilities of $135,000; Biaggi illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Army and Palestinians Clash in Beirut
response.abstract: Heavy fighting erupts on May 2 between Lebanese Army and Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut, Lebanon; Lebanese Defense Min says that 12 soldiers were killed and 40 wounded; there is heavy firing by army forces, including tanks, into populous Shatila refugee camp; Palestinian press agency, in broadcast from Syria, says 19 persons were killed and 89 wounded in camps; curfew goes into effect at 7:30 PM and shooting subsides; Palestinian guerrilla movement broadcast over Cairo radio announces that cease-fire was in effect at 7:00 PM; heavy firing begins again on May 3 on north side of Beirut; boom of artillery begins at 5 AM and continues for 2 hrs; army spokesman says fighting broke out when guerrillas attacked army forces that set up roadblocks to control movement in and out of Shatila camp after 2 Lebanese noncommissioned officers were kidnapped on May 1; 2 army men were reptdly being held as hostages for release of Palestinian guerrillas arrested by security forces, including 3 who were charged with placing explosive device, which did not go off, at Beirut Internat! Airport; 2 kidnapped soldiers and another soldier who was taken prisoner during fighting were reptdly handed over by guerrillas on May 2 to K Jumblatt, left-wing Deputy who heads movement that supports Palestinian resistance; Jumblatt took 3 men to army hq; this removed immediate cause of conflict but with heavy casualties suffered by army it is believed that crisis over relations with guerrillas will continue; crisis came after 2 wks of tension brought on by Israeli commando raid in Beirut on Apr 10 in which 3 Palestinian guerrilla leaders were killed in their homes; security measures to control Palestinian extremists have been tightened since Palestinian guerrilla leader Y Arafat announced that 'big vengeance' would be sought for Israeli attack, including retaliation against US interests in Middle East; fighting is initially confined to area around camps but later dynamite bombs are thrown from cars as they speed through central shopping dist and near Amer Univ; bombs go off in front of homes of Jumblatt and former Premier S Salam; 4 or 5 rockets explode near residence of US Amb W B Buffum, who went to US recently on leave; 1 civilian is reptd killed in front of offices of Palestine Liberation Orgn; curfew is put into effect until further notice; Defense Min says persons carrying arms who do not heed army orders to surrender their weapons will be 'shot on the spot'; Arab diplomatic source says that several hrs after fighting began, Arafat established contact with Lebanese Army commander Gen I Ghanem on cease-fire; it is not clear whether Arafat is in full control of various guerrilla orgns; kidnapping of 2 army men was reptdly carried out by Popular Dem Front for the Liberation of Palestine, small group that is often in disput with Al Fatah, largest Palestinian group which Arafat heads; Cairo radio broadcasts statement of Palestine Liberation Orgn's exec com, headed by Arafat, which accuses Lebanese Army of 'escalation of hostilities against Palestinian commandos'; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PANTHER, TROOPER SLAIN IN SHOOT‐OUT
response.abstract: NJ State Trooper W Foerster and Black Panther information min J F Coston are killed and Black Liberation Army leader J D Chesimard is wounded and captured on May 2 in shoot-out and chase on NJ Turnpike near New Brunswick; Trooper J M Harper is also wounded; incident began when Trooper Harper stopped car of Chesimard, Coston and another man for routine traffic check; Chesimard is wanted by FBI for armed bank robbery and by NYC Police in connection with Jan '72 slayings of Ptl R Laurie and G Foster, and hand-grenade attack on police car in Dec '71; was apparently being taken to new hideout in Philadelphia; 2d male suspect escapes following chase; man described; is target of manhunt involving 400 men, state police helicopters and bloodhounds; police find list of potential targets for black militant group in suspects' car; car illus; Foerster por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CHARGES ON FUNDS
response.abstract: Justice Dept on May 2 charges Finance Com to Re-elect the Pres with failing to rept and maintain records on $200,000 campaign contribution by NJ financier R L Vesco; charges are filed in US Dist Ct, Washington, DC; do not charge any individual; if found guilty, com would face maximum fine of $1,000 on each count, or $3,000; com issues statement declaring that matter involves 'a bona fide action' that its lawyers believed does not violate law; statement says that case reflects 'a differences of opinion' on definition of a 'contribution' and notes that contribution at issue had been returned to the donor 'several mos ago'; GAO referred 'apparent violations' of Fed Election Campaign Act involving Vesco contribution to Justice Dept for action on Mar 12, '72; in follow-up rept, GAO expressed impatience that no action had been taken; GAO Office of Fed Elections dir P S Hughes comments on Justice Dept action; Fed grand jury in NYC has been probing activities and apparently pol contributions of Vesco, who was charged on Nov 27 by SEC with having 'spirited' away some $224-million from 4 mutual funds; former Atty Gen Mitchell and M H Stans, former Commerce Sec, reptdly have appeared twice before grand jury; May 2 Justice Dept announcement does not mention Vesco by name but information about date and amt of contribution coincides with details of Vesco contribution that had been sent to dept by GAO; 3 counts detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ellsberg Judge Confirms 2 Talks With Ehrlichman
response.abstract: Former Pres aide J D Ehrlichman has reptdly admitted in FBI int, released on May 2 as part of evidence in Pentagon papers case, that he has seen previous FBI investigative repts on NY Times reporter N Sheehan, who 1st disclosed Pentagon papers on June 13, '71, in Times
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Connally, Joining G.O.P., Calls It More Responsive
response.abstract: Ex-Gov Connally, in announcing his switch to Repub party on May 2, denies allegations he and Pres Nixon timed conversion to gather praise from party regulars stinging from Watergate criticism; dismisses Watergate scandal as silly, stupid, illegal act'; says he considers pol spying and espionage carried out by supporters of Pres Nixon to be 'very reprehensible thing'; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: I.T.T. AIDED FUND MACKELL SET UP
response.abstract: sources within ITT rept that ITT has contributed more than $150,000 to tax-exempt foundation estab by former Queens Dist Atty Mackell; public hearings on matter are to begin May 3; foundation on one occasion reptdly picked up $548 hotel bill for Mackell and his wife at Virgin Isles Hilton during narcotics seminar in Caribbean; NYS Joint Legis Com on Crime in Apr accused Avis Rent-A-Car System Inc, 52% of whose stock is owned by ITT, of giving J N Monty, former key Mackell aide, free use of Cadillac while he was directing criminal investigation whose outcome benefited Avis; ITT public relations dir K Perkins defends co's contributions to Inst for Advancement of Criminal Justice, tax-exempt orgn, and denies they were in any way connected with 'Avis problem--if it is a problem'; legis com hearings will be headed by com chmn Sen Marino; will explore ITT contributions and handling of Avis matter by Mackell's office; NYS Deputy Atty Gen Nadjari has begun separate inquiry into circumstances surrounding handling of Avis case by Monty; in recent brochure on inst, Mackell is listed as chmn, ITT lawyer R Klein as vice chmn, and ITT sr vp H Aibel as member of govs bd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Norton Simon Art Sold for $6.7‐Million
response.abstract: Works by Cezanne and E Manet are sold for $1.4-million each at Sotheby Parke Bernet auction of works from collection of N Simon; 47 pieces are sold for combined total of $6,782,900 in 1st of 4-day series of sales; Cezanne is bought anonymously by phone, the Manet by Wildenstein & Co, perhaps as agents; Simon has explained that he is 'refining' his collections and that he is buying more Asian art; P Rewald, head of galleries' impressionist div, notes that many new records were posted, including 1 for sale itself which better similar '71 sale at Christie's in London by about $600,000; other works sold noted; illus of Cezanne and Manet work
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: College Costs Will Rise Sharply Again Next Fall
response.abstract: The cost of sending a son or daughter to college will rise sharply again next fall, as it has every year for the last decade, and campus administrators are warning parents and students to expect die price of higher education to continue climbing in the years ahead.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATORS EXPECT NEW PROSECUTOR
response.abstract: Dems on Sen Judiciary Com say on May 2 that they expect Atty Gen-designate Richardson to appt special prosecutor in Watergate case before his nomination comes before com; Sen Tunney says he will try to block com approval of nomination unless Richardson agrees in advance to name special prosecutor; most com members say they could support nomination if special prosecutor is named; Sen Cook says he has 'serious questions' about Richardson's nomination regardless of whether he chooses someone else to supervise Watergate investigation; says he does not understand why same considerations that led to Kleindienst's resignation as Atty Gen do not apply to Richardson; Kleindienst said that his close association with Adm officials who have been implicated in Watergate affair necessitated his resignation; Sens Curtis and Cotton prevent Sen from taking recorded vote on resolution expressing sense of Sen that special prosecutor be named; resolution was approved May 1 by voice vote; White House is reptdly furious with Sen Percy, cheif sponsor of resolution; Sen com investigating Watergate meets and, according to Chmn Ervin, 'reaffirmed its determination to start hearings as near' May 15 as possible; Sen Buckley defends Pres Nixon's handling of Watergate affair and denounces 'vultures circling (hoping)... to find corpse of the Presidency'; illus of Sen com members
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TEAMS OF AGENTS
response.abstract: Govt investigators say that espionage program in '72 election, originally authorized by H R Haldeman, included at its peak 3 networks of agents controlled by White House and Com for Re-Election of Pres; source says bugging of Dem Natl Com hq was only small part of over-all effort; NY Times quotes Govt investigators May 2 as saying that they have evidence that Haldeman, J D Ehrlichman and ex-Atty Gen Mitchell conspired with at least 3 other officials to arrange cover-up story to obstruct Fed investigation into full ramifications of Watergate break-in; Mitchell denies charge May 2
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: EXCHANGE TO SEEK BROKERS’ FEE RISE
response.abstract: NYSE dirs endorse May 3 plans to raise comm charges on transactions worth $100 to $5,000 by 10% and increase charges on orders between $5,000 and $300,000 by 15%; proposal, which would also permit individual cos to negotiate separate charges with their customers for custodial services, is designed to produce $300-million in additional revenue annually for member cos; pres Needham sees urgent need for increased revenues, citing aggregate loss of approximately $75-million for member cos in first 3 mos of this yr; exch dirs reaffirm authority of Needham as spokesman for exch in all policy matters, responding to recent criticism; Needham illus; Justice Dept, in Wisconsin, asks Fed Dist Ct to abolish exch system of fixed comms, its antirebate rule and its 40% discount for nonmember brokers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KALMBACH LINKED TO DESTRUCTION OF CAMPAIGN DATA
response.abstract: H W Kalmbach, until recently Pres Nixon's personal atty, reptdly has told Govt investigators that he destroyed all his campaign finance records before Fed Election Campaign Act of 1971 took effect on Apr 7, 1972; reptdly destroyed records to prevent any public disclosure of donors' names; destruction could be violation of 1922 Fed Corrupt Practices Act, which calls for maintenance of such files for at least 2 yrs; '22 act expired when '71 act took effect; whether data in destroyed records was duplicated in other records cannot be immediately determined; penalties under '22 act noted; some officials nave estimated that Com for the Re-election of the Pres collected over $22-million before Apr 7 reptg deadline; unidentified Kalmbach associate acknowledges that files were destroyed and gives explanation why they were destroyed; on May 1 White House press sec Ziegler told newsmen that Kalmbach was no longer handling legal matters for Nixon; Kalmbach's relationship with Nixon while he was counsel noted; M H Stans, finance com chmn of Nixon's campaign at time documents were destroyed, is unavailable for comment; Kalmbach is known to have provided cash payments to D H Segretti, leader of sabotage and espionage team that operated in late '71 and early '72; reptdly controlled secret fund of up to $500,000 that was used in part to pay for Segretti's pol spying and disruptions early in '72 Pres campaigns; Segretti operation is believed to have been controlled by former White House chief of staff H R Haldeman; Kalmbach reptdly was also asked to raise additional funds after June 17 break-in at Watergate; funds were used to help 7 arrested men pay their attys and keep defendants silent; Kalmbach reptdly is being probed by grand jury for his alleged role in what sources have described as conspiracy to obstruct justice in connection with initial probe into bugging; reptdly testified to grand jury some 10 days ago and recently gave statement to Sen com probing Watergate case; Kalmbach atty J H O'Connor confirms testimony but remains silent on matter; attys of 2 groups that have sued Repub re-election com are stunned by information about destruction of records; Common Cause counsel M Rogovin and W A Dobrovir, atty for 3 consumer groups that sued Nixon Adm in connection with '71 milk price increase, comment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Haldeman and Ehrlichman Testify Before Grand Jury
response.abstract: former White House aides H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman appear at length on May 3 before Fed grand jury investigating Watergate; both men say they did not use 5th Amendment; Haldeman says he did not invoke exec privilege either but Ehrlichman declines to comment on this point; soon after Ehrlichman went before grand jury White House delivered memorandum to J J Wilson, atty for Haldeman and Ehrlichman, outlining Nixon's current position on exec privilege; Wilson had asked for guidelines and memo informs him that Nixon decided use of exec privilege should be 'held to a minimum'; Atty Gen-designate Richardson gives impression to Sens who met with him that he will appt special prosecutor to handle Watergate case; S J Harmony, sec to G G Liddy, says under oath that she typed repts based on wiretaps of telephones in offices of Dem Natl Com, Apr 27 testimony released May 3; says she typed intelligence information on special stationery with code word 'Gemstone' printed at top; says sources for data included in repts were variously described as 'Ruby 1,' 'Ruby 2,' and 'Crystal'; says she typed only 1 copy of repts and was unaware of anyone besides Liddy seeing them; says that when Liddy was dismissed as counsel to re-election com she fed stenographic notebooks containing his dictation through paper shredder at Pres campaign hq; lawyer for J S Magruder confirms that Magruder has said that he expects to be convicted and jailed; meetings between Haldeman, Ehrlichman and Magruder with Asst US Atty Silbert noted; special Gallup Poll finds that 1/2 of voting-age population believes Nixon took part in cover-up and that 4 out of 7 people who heard Nixon's Apr 30 TV speech think that he has not yet told 'whole truth'; finds that 58% of those questioned see 'little difference' between Nixon Adm and others over last 25 yrs; illus of Haldeman, Ehrlichman, and J J Wilson
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Connecticut Budget Reduces Sales Tax
response.abstract: Conn Gen Assembly on May 3 approves $1.2-billion budget and gives state its 1st tax cut in 25 yrs; also approves 1st major tax reform in qr century; Sen passed tax bills on May 2 and approves appropriations pkg on May 3 by vote that follows party lines, 23 Repubs to 13 Dems; C T Alfano, Suffern Dem and Sen minority leader, declares at opening of debate on May 3 'everybody knows' budget has $100-million surplus; asserts budget destroys 'last shreds of credibility' of Meskill adm's fiscal policy; main argument advanced by Dems in both chambers is that Meskill and Assembly Repubs want room left in their fiscal planning for bigger tax cut in '74, when they are up for re-election; Meskill has argued that there is no assurance that he will have surplus next yr; has reminded Dems that he inherited $244-million deficit when he took office in '70, when Dems controlled Legis; among amendments offered by Dems is one that would provide towns with payments amounting to $3 for each inhabitant to ease towns' difficulties in trying to get by without raising property taxes; Sen Lenge, W Hartford Dem, asserts that budget contains state payments to towns that would even now amount to 22.6% of budget
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: INDUSTRIAL PRICES SPURTED IN APRIL
response.abstract: Labor Dept repts on May 3 that Wholesale Price Index shows that increase in industrial prices in Apr more than offset farm and food prices; decline in farm-food sector of index, 1st since Oct '72, attributed partly to consumer meat boycott and Govt's imposition of ceilings on meat prices; much of decline in food-farm index was seasonal; on adjusted basis, index for farm prices and processed foods rose by 0.1 % in Apr; chart of wholesale price index shows fluctuation of all commodities, industrial commodities and food-farm commodities
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LEBANESE JETS AND TANKS. ATTACK PALESTINIAN UNITS AFTER A CEASE‐FIRE FAILS
response.abstract: Lebanese armed forces attack Palestinian guerrillas on May 3 with jet aircraft and tanks as heavy fighting continues in Beirut, Lebanon, for 2d day; Defense Min communique repts scores of engagements in Beirut and in interior as guerrillas ambush police stations, run roadblocks, try to cut major highways and take to high bldgs as snipers; resumption of firing occurs after ceasefire, agreed to on May 2 by Palestinian guerrilla leader Y Arafat and Premier A Hafez, is broken reptdly by ambush in which guerrillas opened fire during changing of guard at Sayyar police barracks killing 3 policemen and wounding 7; Beirut radio announces on May 4 that another cease-fire agreement is reached between Govt and Palestinian guerrillas but there are repts that fighting is continuing; Defense Min sources rept on May 4 that Lebanese troops intercepted about 1,000 guerrillas trying to enter Lebanon from Syria; fighting between Govt troops and members of guerrilla orgn As Saiqa, which is backed by Syrian Govt, is reptd to have begun in southeastern part of Lebanon in Rasheiya and Yanta areas; Hafez says that unless there are 'positive developments' he will decide later in day whether to submit resignation of his Govt, which has been in office for only 9 days; basic issue between guerrillas and Govt has been guerrillas' freedom of action in their fight against Israel; heavy fighting also breaks out in southern Lebanon, particularly in Arkub region, where guerrilla groups have long had bases from which to operate against Israel; fighting described; Govt casualty figures in 2 days of fighting that began on May 2 are put at 15 dead and 58 wounded; Lebanese Pres Franjieh says Lebanon would continue to be host to 300,000 Palestinian refugees but will not accept occupation army, refering to rebel guerrillas who seek to use Lebanon as base for infiltration actions into Israel and terrorist strikes against Israelis abroad; apparent inability of Arafat to enforce cease-fire among various guerrilla orgns suggests that internal divs among Palestinian fighters is undermining discipline; curfew imposed on Beirut on May 2 is lifted for 2 hrs on May 3; illus; maps
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Vesco Warrant Issued
response.abstract: A warrant for the arrest of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who secretly gave $200,000 to President Nixon's re‐election campaign, was issued in Federal court here yesterday. Details on Page 19.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ELLEN JUDGE ORDERS HUNT DATA
response.abstract: Judge Byrne orders that grand jury testimony E H Hunt Jr gave on May 2 in Watergate case be turned over to him immediately; Hunt reptdly testified that he and G G Liddy, convicted in Watergate conspiracy, personally took part in break-in at office D Ellsberg's psychiatrist Dr L J Fielding on night of Sept 3-4, '71; Fed Dist Judge J J Sirica, presiding over Watergate trial, orders that 37 pages of testimony by Hunt be sent to Byrne; Byrne reiterates that 'burden is on the Government' to prove that neither Justice Dept nor White House nor Watergate conspirators had interfered with const rights of defendants Ellsberg and A J Russo and therefore 'tainted' Pentagon case; discloses that number of former high-ranking Govt officials have refused to be int by FBI in ct-ordered inquiry into link between Watergate affair and Pentagon papers trial; Ellsberg's defense attys read in open ct article in Washington Post saying that Pres Nixon had been consulted before rept of break-in at Fielding's office was turned over to Byrne, and that Atty Gen Kleindienst made desision to consult Nixon; article says that because Nixon had to be consulted there was 10-day delay between time Justice Dept admitted to learning of break-in until it was finally reptd to Byrne; attys read another Post article saying that Hunt and Liddy supervised wiretapping of at least 2 NY Times reporters in '71 as part of their investigation of Pentagon papers publication, and that this wiretapping had been authorized by then Atty Gen J N Mitchell; defense continues questioning of former Rand Corp pres H Rowen; Rowen says that set of Pentagon papers that Ellsberg and Russo are accused of Xeroxing were not logged into Rand Corp's top secret control system until Dec 31, '70, long after papers arrived at Rand; information would tend to prove Ellsberg's contention that papers had been given special treatment at Rand and that he had been given access to them; Los Angeles County Dist Atty J P Busch repts he is conducting investigation into break-in at Fielding's office
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Martha Mitchell Testifies in Civil Suit
response.abstract: Mrs J N Mitchell says on May 4, after giving deposition in connection with Dem's $6.4-million civil suit against officials of Repub re-election com, that she trusts and prays that her husband is not guilty of wrongdoing in Watergate case; says that if her husband was involved I didn't know it'; says she 'just couldn't say' if Pres Nixon had prior knowledge of bugging; says that she has never really known anything about Watergate case but that she is 'glad it's all coming out,' later telephone int; she told at least 11 assembled lawyers for Dems and Repubs that White House last yr leaked false stories about her that suggested she was in an insane asylum; accused Mrs Nixon of using news conf to announce that Mrs Mitchell was 'very, very ill'; describes her efforts to get her husband out of '72 campaign because 'Mr President was going to be re-elected anyway'; detailed Calif episode during which she said she was thrown to floor and stuck with hypodermic needle; added name of J S Magruder to list of people she said she has 'suspected' all along; said McCord may have bugged her Watergate apartment and he did X-ray her furniture to make sure apartment was safe; atty H Rothblatt says Mrs Mitchell's testimony was 'interesting' but 'not very helpful to case itself; says that at start of deposition, Mrs Mitchell asked that there be no questions that might violate husband-wife relationship and that request was granted; W McLendon, who is writing book for Mrs Mitchell, refuses to discuss published speulation that bidding for book had reached $1-million; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KISSINGER VIEWS CAMBODIA PARLEY AS POSSIBLE SOON
response.abstract: Nixon State of World Message to Cong stresses '73 as 'yr of Eur'
keywords: AMERICAN NATIONS AND WESTERN HEMISPHERE POSSESSIONS
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Revised Narcotics Measure Is Voted80‐65 in Assembly
response.abstract: NYS Assembly, 80-65, on May 3 passes modified version of Gov Rockefeller's antinarcotics proposal; modified legis calls for mandatory minimum prison sentences, a limited form of plea bargaining and a system of 'mandatory life sentences' that will permit parole, but which would require lifetime supervision of parolee; includes deletion of hashish from list of dangerous drugs and exempts from life sentence housewives who gives friend diet pill containing amphetamines; will allow drug-seller who gives evidence for prosecution to be placed on probation for life rather than serve prison term; NY Civil Liberties Union contends action by Assembly is 'one of the most ignorant, irresponsible and inhumane acts in the history of the state'; Assemblyman Steingut asserts bill is 'a sham' and a 'hoax'; other criticisms of legis noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: City Seeks Mortgage Unit to Curb Slums
response.abstract: NYC plans to submit bill to NYS Legis to create new local FHA-type of agency to insure bank mortgages in major move to prevent transitional neighborhoods from becoming slums; agency would be governed by bd of 7 members, 4 city officials and 3 mayoral appointees
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 in Mackell's Office Got Free Car Use, Avis Says
response.abstract: documents presented to NYS Joint Legis Com on Crime show that Avis Rent-A-Car System Inc permitted at least 4 employes in office of former Queens Dist Atty Mackell to use cars free at time office was prosecuting case whose outcome benefited Avis; one of those identified as receiving free use of Avis cars is Asst Dist Atty F J Ludwig, who became acting head of Queens prosecutor's office after Mackell's resignation; Ludwig, in phone call to com counsel J B McKenna, immediately denies assertion by Avis repr that he failed to pay for rented cars on 4 occasions; J N Monty, former chief rackets investigator for Mackell, takes Fifth Amendment 38 times when asked about his acceptance of free car from Avis and his investigation of criminal matter against former business assoc of Avis; Avis records, presented to com by Avis assoc gen counsel S B Stillman, show that Monty was permitted to drive at least 8 new cars for most of '71; Avis vp R Wulkan on Apr 13 said Avis 'completely and unequivocally denies ever giving free use of a Cadillac' to Monty or to any other Mackell staff member; Asst Dist Atty D J McKeon, another official in Mackell's office, is also named by Avis as one who had recd free use of car; handled Avis's case against Sta-Brite Auto Painting Co from presentation to grand jury until corp pleaded guilty to much-reduced charges; com chmn Sen Marino, after taking testimony from Sta-Brite pres G T Cestara and 2 officials in Mackell's office, accuses Avis of having used Queens prosecutor's office as 'private collection agency'; 4th official in Mackell's office said to have failed to pay for rented car is M Drucker, Mackell's exec sec; Avis presentation showing that at least 4 officials in Mackell's office had been given use of free cars comes after ITT spokesman defends its actions in giving Inst for Advancement of Criminal Justice $188,860; ITT owns 52% of Avis stock; inst was created and headed by Mackell with stated aim of promoting 'communitywide understanding' of criminal justice
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GRAND JURY DATA
response.abstract: Judge Byrne releases testimony of E H Hunt Jr given before grand jury investigating Watergate break-in, concerning plot to break info office of D Ellsberg's psychiatrist Dr L J Fielding; Hunt's testimony says that break-in was conceived, supervised and paid for in White House, and CIA supplied camera and disguises; says operation was personally directed by White House staff members D Young and E Krogh Jr; CIA spokesman repts agency had no advance knowledge of any break-in at Fielding's office or of Watergate incident; says all information on contacts with persons involved in such incidents 'has been fully reported to the Justice Dept' and all inquiries should be directed to dept; Byrne denies defense motion for dismissal based on his own visits with J D Ehrlichman; takes under submission motion to dismiss on ground of Govt misbehavior for suppressing evidence and for burglary; refuses to hear arguments on whether case has been 'tainted'; says he is convinced that 'nothing has compromised my ability to act as a fair and impartial judge in this case'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CAWLEY TO SCREEN ‘VIOLENT’ POLICE
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr D F Cawley, responding to unrest over fatal shooting of 10-yr-old C Glover by Ptl T Shea on Apr 28, on May 4 creates special panel to screen out members of dept who have shown tendency toward chronic use of force in their work; panel will go through records of every policeman, assisted by psychiatric profile of violence-prone; those identified as using force in cases which fellow officers deal with in other ways could face additional training, disciplinary action, reassignment or dismissal; Cawley discloses that Ptl Shea had been in 4 previous incidents involving use of firearms; incidents detailed; PBA pres McKiernan decries dept's action of releasing Shea's record without also saying that ptl has made 200 to 250 arrests and has assisted in 300 to 350 more; says PBA is recommending to policemen that they be extremely careful and cautious before taking any action against suspected criminals; criticizes creation of panel; no repts of further violence are reptd on May 4 in S Jamaica, scene of 3 days of unrest following shooting
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. CONSUL SEIZED BY MEXICAN GROUP
response.abstract: T G Leonhardy, US consul gen in Guadalajara (Mex), kidnapped May 4 by 3 armed men; group called Armed Revolutionary Forces of the People claims responsibility for kidnapping, issues statement demanding release of 30 Mex prisoners in exchange for Leonhardy; note says prisoners, as yet unnamed, must be taken to Mex City and then transported to Havana (Cuba); contains threat of execution of Leonhardy if demands are not met; kidnapping condemned by Mex's Foreign Min E O Rabasa
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Publicity Kit on Nixon's Budget Is Called Illegal by the G.A.O.
response.abstract: GAO, in rept signed by Controller Gen Staats to Sens Humphrey and Muskie, says on May 4 that publicity campaign kit designed to rally support for Nixon in his dispute with Cong over spending violates provs of 1973 appropriations act and may have been prepared in violation of criminal law forbidding use of Govt money for lobbying purposes; kit contains background information on Nixon's budget positions, 'one-liners' or anecdotes to be used in speeches, and suggests arguments for use against 15 specific bills enacted by or pending before Cong; Humphrey and Muskie call on Atty Gen Richardson to begin investigation of 'propaganda campaign' that they say was part of attack on Cong; White House deputy dir of communications K W Clawson defends kits as part of White House 'informational function'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Truce Halts Fighting By Lebanon and Guerrillas
response.abstract: cease-fire is arranged on May 4 between Lebanese Army and Palestinian guerrillas, ending more than 2 days of heavy fighting in and around Beirut; with Egypt, Iraq and Algeria mediating in dispute, cease-fire is accompanied by withdrawal from Lebanese territory of guerrilla reinforcements that crossed border from Syria on May 3; it is 2d truce worked out since fighting began on May 2; official figures for army casualties and unofficial figures for guerrillas and civilians put number of dead at 50 and wounded at 200 in fighting, in which Lebanese armed forces used jet fighters, tanks and artillery against guerrilla positions; Defense Ministry repts 'limited incidents' in southern Lebanon on May 4 between guerrillas and army; Defense Min F Ghosn says 'situation is calm and there are no foreign armies on Lebanese soil'; political situation in Beirut remains tense; heavily armed guerrillas are still in full control of major refugee camps, which are Palestinian strongholds; special reprs from Egyptian Pres Sadat and Iraqi Pres Bakr arrive in effort to help in negotiations between Lebanese Govt and Palestinian guerrilla leadership, headed by Y Arafat; telephone appeals are also made by Sadat and Algerian Pres Boumedienne; Lebanese Pres Franjieh and new Cabinet headed by Premier A Hafez are faced with controlling Palestinian guerrillas and 300,000 refugees whom they claim to represent in Lebanon; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Daley's Ally With Stock in Bank, Indicted Over Chicago's Deposits
response.abstract: Chicago Alderman T E Keane, Mayor Daley's closest pol assoc, is indicted on May 4 on charges of conflict of interest, official misconduct and conspiracy; indictments, returned against Keane and E P Fifielski, another Dem Alderman, are latest in series of criminal charges that have shaken Daley orgn; 9-count indictment charges Keane and Fifielski with voting to deposit city funds, with no interest paid, in Jefferson State Bank, in which they held shares; State's Atty B Carey declares 'this is a simple one,' adding that several separate, more complicated, cases were to be brought before grand jury
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. APPEAL COURT UPHOLDS RELEASE OF BIAGGI MINUTES
response.abstract: US Appeals Ct on May 4 affirms, 2-1, lower ct decision to disclose grand jury testimony of Repr Biaggi on ground that he has waived his right to secrecy; rejects Biaggi's appeal against disclosing testimony with other names deleted; delays decision for 5 days to permit Biaggi, Dem mayoral candidate, to go to US Sup Ct; Biaggi lawyer A H Christy confers with Biaggi but no decision is reached about whether to appeal to Ct; sources say on May 4 that Biaggi had applied to Appeals Ct for rehearing of his case, arguing that, contrary to majority opinion, he had not waived his rights to secrecy; Biaggi's '71 testimony became major issue in mayoral race when NY Times reptd on Apr 18 that he had invoked Fifth Amendment before grand jury, despite his assertion that he had answered all questions put to him; according to Appeals Ct opinion, testimony before grand jury could not be disclosed if Biaggi had not come to ct seeking disclosure; critics contend that Biaggi applied for severely limited rev of his testimony and then asked for total disclosure in hope that his legal motions would be denied while enabling him to claim that he had tried to divulge truth; ct observes that rule against releasing grand jury testimony generally prevails but holds that Biaggi waived protection when he asked for complete disclosure; majority opinion, written by Chief Judge H J Friendly, affirms Fed Judge E L Palmieri's decision to release testimony with other names deleted; Judge W J Jameson concurs and Judge P R Hays dissents; Friendly notes that events leading to proceedings began with NY Times reporter N Gage article; directs US Atty Seymour, in footnote to opinion, to pursue investigation into 'these leaks' about grand jury testimony
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEWS INDEX
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DEANSAYS HE TOOK WATERGATE DATA
response.abstract: J W Dean 3d says on May 4 that before his dismissal as counsel to Pres Nixon, he removed documents dealing with Watergate scandal from his White House office to prevent their 'illegitimate destruction'; repts, in papers filed May 4 with US Dist Ct, Washington, DC, that he placed documents in safe deposit box in bank in Alexandria, Va; Judge Sirica was asked to take custody of 2 keys to box pending judgment whether papers can be examined by others; Dean says they bear 'security classification'; says safe deposit box holds 43-page document and 8 related documents bound in blue plastic cover but does not detail their contents; H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman spend May 4 in preliminary testimony before staff of Sen Watergate com; it is disclosed that officials of Nixon's pol fund-raising unit secretly collected between $1-million and $2-million in cash and then destroyed records in which donors were identified; former White House aide E Krogh Jr confers with Fed prosecutors handling Watergate investigation; legal problem confronting Sirica involves Dean's suggestion that neither Sen com nor govt prosecutors 'may carry the requisite security clearance' to see papers; Dean says that on other hand, he, as terminated White House staff member, should no longer exercise control over documents; illus of Haldeman and Ehrlichman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Segretti Indicted in Mailing Of Bogus Muskie Letter
response.abstract: Fed grand jury, Orlando, Fla, indicts D H Segretti, natl campaign worker for Nixon, on charge of pol espionage in Fla in '72; grand jury accuses Segretti and Tampa, Fla, accountant G H Hearing of arranging for mailing of fictitious lr on stationery of Sen Muskie, who was candidate in Fla Pres primary at time
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘INTERIM’ CHOICE
response.abstract: Haig named by Pres Nixon as Asst to Pres, on 'interim' basis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Labs Test Purity of Drugs Sent by Unidentified Users
response.abstract: NY Times survey finds increasing number of laboratories across US will analyze, without asking embarrassing questions, any illicit 'street' drug that user would like to know more about, and that drug analysis programs have become a sort of consumer protection service for the occasional 'tripper' who fears that drugs he buys from unknown dealer may be faked, adulterated, badly made or downright poisonous; finds laboratories providing service are operated by univs, private concerns, hosps, local police stations, drug treatment centers and, frequently, underground drug-oriented orgns and individuals
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sri Lanka: A Victim of Own Generosity
response.abstract: econ and pol plight of Sri Lanka discussed; Prime Min Bandaranaike openly complains about econ problems that have plagued nation since '70 gen elections; many problems, which have turned once wealthy nation into one facing bankruptcy, are blamed in part on Govt's own policies; econ fabric of Sri Lanka has been frayed by extravagant soc welfare programs that nation cannot afford; these measures have included free educ at univ level and subsidized med care and transportation; econ plight is especially perilous because Govt, to keep up with these programs, imports food at crushing cost; basic foods account for almost half nation's imports; most Govt officials concede that such policy is counterproductive because indus and nonconsumer items are more crucial to nation's development; econ difficulties are compounded by shortage of foreign exchange; Sri Lanka's main exports, tea, rubber and coconuts, have been sold at static world prices while cost of importing rice and wheat has steadily risen; imbalance has caused 'monstrous' deficit in foreign currency and nation is about $1.5-million in debt to other nations; key element in econ crisis is severe unemployment among young and educated; there are 700,000 unemployed workers, including about 70% of current hs graduates; Sri Lanka's underlying pol ferment, which exploded in '71 when revolt by leftist youths almost toppled Govt, has shown signs of resurfacing; 1.5-million mourners streamed into Colombo recently to pay tribute to late Prime Min D Senanayake, who was leader of main opposition party; huge turnout clearly underlines disappointment and anger among many in Sri Lanka; Bandaranaike por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ROCKEFELLER ASKS COLLEGE AID RISE
response.abstract: NYS Gov Rockefeller on May 5 proposes 46% increase in amount of state aid he originally recommended for private colls and univs in '73-74, urging that they receive $26.8-million rather than $18.3-million in additional funds; would expand state assistance to most public community colls
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Secretariat Wins Derby
response.abstract: Secretariat wins Kentucky Derby on May 5 at Churchill Downs; sets Derby record for 1 1/4-miles (1:59 2/5); illus; chart of race
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hanoi Believed Planning Attack in Northern Area
response.abstract: high-ranking US and S Vietnamese officials say N Vietnamese troops are preparing for an eventual offensive in next 6 to 12 mos in 1 northernmost provs of S Vietnam; say only a series of true pol compromises between Communists and Saigon or a successful application of internatl pressure on Hanoi could head off such an assault; consider the compromise and the pressure highly unlikely; say that since truce took effect on Jan 28, Hanoi has brought thousands of tons of materiel into the northern region, are rebldg airfields and improving rds; Hanoi reptdly has equivalent of 7 inf divs in Quang Tri and Thua Thien Provs; officials in Hue says they have been documenting the Communist build-up with aerial photographs and other means; there are no indications that Hanoi has given up its goal of taking over S Vietnam and uniting the 2 Vietnams; so far, there has been little pub reaction from the Saigon Govt; pol analysts say that US and Saigon believe that for the moment they can be more effective with Hanoi in private
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Yorker May Direct Watergate Investigation
response.abstract: Washington, DC, sources say US Appeals Ct, NY, Judge L E Walsh has been approached to be special prosecutor of Watergate case and that NY Judge I R Kaufman has been asked to comment on some proposed candidates and recommend others; say likeliest candidate at this point is L E Walsh, Deputy Atty Gen under Pres Eisenhower; Walsh says he has not been approached in matter; sources say Kaufman has turned job down; Judge J E Lumbard Jr says on May 5 that there is 'nothing to it' when asked about rumors that he might be apptd; others who have been mentioned for post are US Atty for NY H J Stern and Pa atty W T Coleman, who is now said to be out of running; 29 Dem Sens, led by A E Stevenson 3d, send lr to Atty Gendesignate Richardson asking for apptmt of special prosecutor; Stevenson says lr asks for completely independent staff, independent funds and access to all files and records; Walsh illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon's Imprint Is Deep At Regulatory Agencies
response.abstract: NY Times survey cites recent apptmt of Okla state dist Judge West to CAB by Pres Nixon as example of attempt by Adm to turn ind regulatory agencies into bastions of Nixon Republicanism
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lebanon W arns Guerrillas On Kidnapping and Terror
response.abstract: Lebanese Pres Franjieh on May 5 says Lebanon is not prepared to allow Palestinian guerrillas in country to terrorize and kidnap people 'as if they were above the official authority'; crisis between Lebanese Army and Palestinian guerrillas goes into 2d day of cease-fire with only minor skirmishes in southern Lebanon; political front is clouded as mediators from several Arab countries arrive to help reach settlement to conflict in which 60 persons were killed and more than 240 wounded during fighting since May 2 between army and guerrillas; Franjieh reptdly told reprs of Syria, Egypt and Iraq that Lebanon will not give Palestinian refugees and their armed guerrilla leadership any special privileges to organize attacks against Israel from Lebanon; reptdly said that Palestinian refugee camps, where more than 150,000 people live, harbored centers of illegal arms and hq of subversive guerrilla groups; said he is prepared to apply same rules for Palestinian refugees in Lebanon that is in force in other Arab countries, such as Syria and Egypt, where armed Palestinian resistance groups are under direct mil control; said Lebanon is tired of being victim of Israeli retaliatory raids resulting from actions of Palestinian guerrilla and terrorist groups in Lebanon; issue seems to be whether Lebanese security forces would be able to control refugee camps, which have been entirely under control of Palestinian commando groups; Franjieh illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PROSECUTORS ACT
response.abstract: rev of recent events involving disclosure by Fed Dist Judge W M Byrne, presiding over Pentagon papers trial, that he was approached twice by Nixon's former top advisor J Ehrlichman and reptdly offered Govt position, and subsequent motion by defense attys that charges against defendants D Ellsberg and A J Russo be dropped; holds that there has never been such an intrusion into judicial process by exec branch as there is in Pentagon papers trial
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FOES OF FUENTES WIN IN DISTRICT I Union‐Backed Slate Wins 6, of 9 School Board Seats on Lower East Side
response.abstract: mostly white slate, backed by UFT and opposed to Lower East Side School Dist 1 supt L Fuentes, wins 6 of 9 seats in dist school bd election, figures released May 6; repts say Fuentes will be removed from office when new bd takes over on July 1; unofficial results from 8 of 32 city school dists are made available; 7 of 9 seats on Canarsie bd are won by Canarsie residents apparently opposed to busing of Brownsville youths into area; members of opposing slates in Fuentes dist comment on results; several Assemblymen are elected to school bds in Bklyn; Fuentes illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ellsberg Judge's Act Cited In Plan to Ask End of Trial
response.abstract: defense attys in Pentagon papers trial plan to ask US Appeals Ct to dismiss case against D Ellsberg and A J Russo on ground that White House tried to compromise trial judge W M Byrne Jr by arranging 2 meetings between him and White House aide J D Ehrlichman during which Byrne was offered job as head of FBI; say that final decision on when to go to higher ct will be made by defendants; one grounds for going to higher ct is that case is one of selective pol prosecution directed from White House, rather than normal criminal prosecution directed by Atty Gen; other is what defense terms 'long history' of Govt 'misbehavior' in case; writ of mandamus drawn up during past weekend asserts that Byrne did not volunteered information on his meetings with Ehrlichman only after news of meetings was published in newspapers, and that even then disclosure came about after defense solicited statement from Byrne; proposed writ charges 'selective political prosecution' stemming from allegation that E H Hunt Jr, convicted Watergate conspirator, leaked 'top secret' information to now defunct Life magazine and was not prosecuted for it
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Knicks Defeat Lakers
response.abstract: The Knicks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 87‐83, at Madison Square Garden yesterday and gained a 2‐1 lead in the four‐of‐seven‐game National Basketball Association championship series. The fourth game will be played at the Garden tomorrow night. Details on Page 55.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hoover Files Vanish
response.abstract: Official documents authorizing wiretaps on the telephones of reporters and White House aides reportedly disappeared from J. Edgar Hoover's files in 1971 after he threatened to disclose that taps existed. Page 46.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Indians SignAccord to End 68‐Day Seizure of Town
response.abstract: Fed and Indian negotiators announce on May 6 agreement to end 68-day-old occupation of Wounded Knee (SD) by militant Indians and their supporters; agreement, unlike previous one signed in early Apr, includes detailed written procedures for disarmament and evacuation of Wounded Knee; stipulates that Govt armored personnel carriers will begin pulling back from roadblocks and bunkers on May 9; occupiers will then evacuate hamlet; Fed officials say that 35 to 40 Indians will be arrested; reprs from both sides seem optimistic that agreement will end occupation, which began on Feb 27; Amer Indian Movement lawyer R Roubideaux claims seizure 'has been an historic tragic event'; chief Fed negotiator Deputy Asst Atty Gen Hellstern hails agreement as 1 that can be implemented; Interior Dept solicitor Frizzell praises Fed agents for their patience during stalled meetings; Hellstern says that Govt learned a lot during seizure and that such patience 'will not necessarily be pattern followed in future confrontations'; agreement was spurred by lr from L Garment, counsel to Pres Nixon; lr promised that 5 White House reprs would arrive at Wounded Knee to hear Indian grievances; Fed officials, with agreement in hand, approve burial at hamlet of L Lamont, tribe member who died in gunfight 9 days ago; agreement signed by Hellstern, Frizzell, Chief US Marshal W B Colburn and 11 Indians; Amer Indian Movement leader D J Banks refuses to sign agreement, claiming that it is 'outside protection of US Const'; main provisions of agreement given; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CUSHMAN NAMED
response.abstract: sources close to Watergate case rept on May 6 that Gen R E Cushman, who in '71 was Deputy Dir of CIA, authorized use of CIA material and research in burglary of office of D Ellsberg's former psychiatrist Dr L J Fielding; rept that Cushman acted at request of J D Ehrlichman, Nixon's former chief asst for domestic affairs; Cushman was questioned by FBI late last wk and reptdly accepted full responsibility for decision to permit agency to help E H Hunt and G G Liddy prepare for break-in; 2 sources confirm on May 6 that E Krogh, White House staff member, with whom Hunt reptdly had arranged for CIA cooperation, did not have authority to deal directly with CIA on such matters as arranging help for clandestine operation inside US; hold that Krogh enlisted help of CIA through his superior, Ehrlichman; CIA officials refuse to comment on reptd link between Ehrlichman and Cushman, but 1 official does confirm rept in May 6 Washington Post that agency's psychological profile of D Ellsberg had been prepared and provided over protests of some agency officials; Dr B Melloy, in charge of agency's psychological profile according to Hunt's testimony, reptdly told his superiors that providing such study for domestic purposes was error in judgment; illus of Cushman being sworn in as Deputy Dir of CIA in '69 by Nixon
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MEXICO FLIES 30 TO HAVANA TO WIN CONSUL'S RELEASE
response.abstract: Mex Govt releases 30 prisoners and flies them to Havana (Cuba), acceding to demands of kidnappers of US Consul Gen T G Leonhardy; illus of released prisoners; hopes for early release of Leonhardy grow dim amid repts that kidnappers have made 'new demands'; kidnappers refer to 30 released prisoners as 'pol prisoners' but Mex Govt official disputes label, calling them 'common delinquents' in jail for committing robbery and murder; details of Leonhardy kidnapping revd; illus of Mrs Leonhardy; kidnappers believed to be left-wing guerrillas
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Protest Backs Soviet Jews OnEve of Israel's Birthday
response.abstract: Estimated 100,000 people participate in rally-parade on May 6 in NYC to protest treatment of Jews in USSR and to celebrate Israel's 25th anniversary; Israeli Premier Meir sends message; May 7 is Israel Independence Day, which occurs annually on 5th day of Iyar in Hebrew lunar calendar; in Israel, festivities mark celebration of holiday; illus of marchers; illus of Israeli Pres Z Shazar lighting candle in Jerusalem to mark start of Memorial Day
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Diplomat and a Professor Beaten by 5 Youths Here
response.abstract: Liberian Deputy Min W Richards and Rutgers Univ Prof E Dennis, also Liberian, are beaten by 5 white youths in racially-motivated attack on May 6 in Marble Hill, Bronx until off-duty Ptl J Crowe rushes from his apt to rescue them; Liberian Ambassador E Peal receives calls expressing regret for incident from State Dept officials, including D D Newsom, Asst Sec for African Affairs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HANOI BUILDING UP HIGHWAY IN SOUTH
response.abstract: Sr US and S Vietnamese officials rept several thousand N Vietnamese laborers have been sent into NW S Vietnam to build roads and airfields to to move supplies; say these activities greatly enhance Communists' mil capabilities in the region in violation of the truce accord and indicate a major attack is in the offing; say major project is to complete all-weather rd from Khe Sanh lear Laotian border, southward through the Ashau Valley and eastward to outskirts of Da Nang; Khe Sanh is reptdly being developed into a major logistical center by the Communists; N Vietnamese are also reptdly restoring the old US airfields at Dong Ha, A Luoi, Ta Bat and at Kham Duc; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2 ATTEMPTS CITED
response.abstract: sources close to Watergate case rept on May 7 that Pres Nixon, invoking natl security, sought on at least 2 occasions within last 2 wks to prevent release to ct of details of burglary at office of former psychiatrist of D Ellsberg, Dr L J Fielding; Nixon, in 1 case, was said to have reversed himself after receiving contrary recommendation from Asst Atty Gen H E Petersen in charge of Watergate investigation; reptd attempt to postpone release of information came after Justice Dept recd memo on Apr 16 or 17 from E J Silbert, chief prosecutor in Watergate case; in 2d case, information was reptdly provided to Fed Ct investigating Pentagon papers case at insistence of Defense Sec E L Richardson; 2d attempted delay came after former Pres aide E Krogh Jr was told by J D Ehrlichman that Nixon 'doesn't want any more of this to surface for security reasons'; White House on May 3 issued guidelines to Krogh telling him that he was free to testify regarding steps taken about Ellsberg but advised him that he was not authorized to discuss details of specific leaks or any information about specific security concerns; Krogh, in affidavit rleased on May 7, told of receiving rept from FBI indicating that Pentagon papers had been in possession of Soviet Embassy in Washington prior to their pub in June '71, in NY Times; affidavit also refers to Times article on US position in strategic arms limitation talks; White House sources have indicated this kind of information was considered too vital to natl security to be transmitted to Fed Dist Judge W M Byrne Jr, presiding over Pentagon papers case; Byrne's decision to release Silbert memo reptdly angered many officials in Justice Dept and White House
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Chapin May Head Met
response.abstract: Schuyler G. Chapin, acting general manager of the Metropolitan Opera since the death of Goeran Gentele last July, is virtually certain to be named to the post today for a 3‐year term. Page 36.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hunt Says Colson Ordered Forged Datain Diem Death
response.abstract: Watergate grand jury testimony of E H Hunt Jr and affidavit from former White House aide E Krogh Jr are released to public on May 7 at Pentagon papers trial; Hunt, in his testimony, says that C W Colson, Pres Nixon's former counsel, ordered forgery of State Dept cables to implicate Pres Kennedy in assassination of Pres Ngo Dinh Diem of S Vietnam

response.headline: Mrs. Crimmins Wins Upset of Convictions
response.abstract: NYS Appellate Ct on May 7 overturns murder and manslaughter convictions against Mrs A Crimmins in deaths of her 2 children in '65; ct orders her retried on manslaughter charge, holding that prosecution did not prove beyond reasonable doubt that death of her son resulted from criminal act; Crimmins was 1st convicted in '68 of manslaughter, but conviction was set aside in '69 after several jurors admitted having made unauthorized visits to scene of crime; '71 retrial resulted in murder and manslaughter convictions; 4 errors in trial detailed; her atty, H Lyon, will apply for bail pending possible retrial on charges of killing daughter; por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SOVIET IS SEEKING A LOAN IN EUROPE
response.abstract: internatl banking sources, noting USSR effort to borrow $1-billion from group of Eur banks, hold money probably will be used to finance grain purchases from US
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONNALLY VISITOR
response.abstract: White House deputy press sec Warren issues statement May 7 denying that Pres Nixon had prior knowledge of Watergate operation; statement follows published repts in Time (pub) and Newsweek (pub) that former White House counsel J W Dean 3d has told Fed investigators that Pres personally thanked him for his effort 'to keep the lid on' Watergate scandal; Newsweek and Time articles discussed; J B Connally holds surprise meeting with Nixon May 7 amid rumors that he has been offered high Adm positon; Cong members continue to press for outside, independent investigation of Watergate affair; Nixon meets with White House press sec Ziegler and new chief of staff Gen Haig reptdly to discuss 'future White House operations and other administrative details'; illus of Nixon, Ziegler and Haig
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Fragments Found in Italy Linked to Museum Vase
response.abstract: Italian authorities on May 7 say that they have found new evidence demonstrating 'almost conclusively' that vase was dug up in Italy and smuggled out; G Guasco, magistrate in charge of investigation of vase, says that he has obtained set of fragments found in Etruscan tomb in '71 that should prove that they are part of museum's vase; fragments were found wrapped in newspaper near Cerveteri, Italy, following information given by anonymous phone caller; have been examined by number of experts including M Pallottino, Italy's foremost authority on Greek and Etruscan art; Pallottino reptdly has said that fragments definitely belong to vase painted by Euphronios; Guasco, who has declined to describe pieces, says that he cannot understand why museum has not sent him pictures of vase before its restoration; holds pictures could be matched with fragments to prove or disclaim theory of its Italian provenance; says he is certain that pieces are not part of Euphronios cup that R E Hecht Jr, who sold vase to museum, reptdly offered for sale in '72; Met's curator of Greek and Roman art D von Bothmer says that 'on surface' he does not think that fragments are part of museum's Euphronios calyx krater but that he greatly respects Pallottino and would welcome whoever comes from Italy with fragments to check them against vase; Italian Min of Educ is reptdly planning to send panel of archeological experts and police officials to NYC to pursue case; museum's version of vase's purchase revd; Italian police have charged 7 tombaroli, or grave robbers, with theft of objects in Etruscan tomb and have named Hecht suspect of illegal retention, sale and smuggling charges; illus of Etruscan tomb; illus of vase
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ABDUCTED CONSUL IS FREED IN MEXICO
response.abstract: US Consul Gen T G Leonhardy, kidnapped in Mex on May 4 by leftist pol group, is released May 7 after Mex Govt complies with kidnappers' demands by releasing and flying to Cuba 30 prisoners; Leonhardy returns to his home in Guadalajara 'very tired' but in good condition otherwise; kidnap details revd; illus of Leonhardy; decision to release prisoners, many of them pol terrorists, made personally by Mex Pres Echeverria; US State Dept says it informed Mex Govt of its policy toward pol kidnapping, which is a refusal to yield to extortion or blackmail for release of its officials anywhere in world
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: RICHARDSON VOWS NEW PROSECUTOR
response.abstract: Atty Gen-designate Richardson announces May 7 that if he is confirmed by Sen he will appt special prosecutor to conduct investigation of Watergate case; says he has not picked anyone for job but has 'begun the search and will press it as rapidly as possible'; says prosecutor will have 'all the independence, authority and staff support needed to carry out the tasks entrusted to him'; Pres Nixon said in his Apr 30 speech that Richardson would have authority to appt special prosecutor if he believed such action was appropriate; pressures on Richardson to name prosecutor noted; Richardson says prosecutor will be in Justice Dept 'and rept to me--and only to me--(but) he will be aware that his ultimate accountability is to Amer people'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lebanese Battles Resume; New Premier Steps Down
response.abstract: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, May 8 — New fighting erupted here last night between Palestinian guerrillas and the Lebanese Army, and the Government declared a state of emergency, placing the country under martial law. Heavy cannon, rocket and automatic weapon fire was reported for more than an hour near the Shatila and Burj al‐Barajneh refugee camps.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Voluntary Controls On Gasoline Hinted
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, May 7—The Administration expects to announce within a week a voluntary system of allocating scarce gasoline supplies and possibly other petroleum products, official sources disclosed today.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pulitzers Go to Washington Post, Frankel, ‘Championship Season’
response.abstract: Pulitzer Prizes are awarded on May 7; winners include Washington Post for public service in journalism, D S Broder (Washington Post) for commentary, M Frankel (NY Times) for internatl reptg, J Miller for play That Championship season (drama prize), F FitzGerald and Dr R Coles (gen non-fiction), J T Flexner (special biography prize), W A Swanberg (biography prize), E Welty (fiction prize), M Kammen (history prize), M W Kumin (poetry prize), E Carter (music prize), Chicago Tribune for gen local reptg, Omaha Sun Newspapers for special local reptg, R Boyd and C Hoyt (Knight Newspapers) for natl reptg,; R B Linscott (Berkshire Eagle) for editorial writing, Huynh Cong Ut (AP) for spot news photography, B Lanker (Topeka Capital-Journal) for feature photography, R Powers (Chicago Sun-Times) for criticism; no award for editorial cartoons is given; illus of Huynh Cong Ut's prize-winning Vietnam war photo
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ASK COURT ORDER
response.abstract: Sen Watergate com announces May 8 that it will begin public hearings May 17 and will move to compel testimony by ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d by granting him immunity from prosecution; White House says Pres Nixon is no longer advising prosecutors in Watergate case not to grant immunity to present or former Adm members; sends to Sen com guidelines under which present and past Adm aides will be allowed to testify once hearings begin; rules, formulated last wk by Pres counsel L Garment, note that White House counsel will be present at informal ints of White House personnel by com staff, but only to observe and to take notes; rules state that privilege will be invoked by White House counsel, if at all, only in connection with formal hearings before com; ex-Commerce Sec Stans meets with Sen Watergate investigators May 8 and says he 'answered all their questions'; Dean is reptdly prepared to say there was a White House cover-up of scandal and to impute knowledge of effort to Nixon; procedure and possible significance of Sen's granting of immunity discussed; Sen com serves Dean with subpoena May 8 for preliminarty testimony later in wk; Sen Judiciary Com is scheduled to open hearings May 9 on nomination of Atty Gen-designate Richardson; apptmt of special Watergate prosecutor will be an issue; it is disclosed May 8 in Fed ct that accountants for Pres Nixon's re-election com wrote at least 12 checks to themselves and delivered cash to unidentified parties; details of transactions are expected to be disclosed later this wk when pretrial depositions by accountants H M Buchanan and G F Lynch Jr are made public; Ervin illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Governor Signs His Drug Bills And Assails the Critics Again
response.abstract: with panoply of fanfare and some caustic words for his critics, NYS Gov Rockefeller on May 8 signs into law final version of his antinarcotics legis, which will levy harsh prison sentences on narcotics traffickers; he says legis is 'the toughest antidrug program in the nation,' and applauds Legis for adopting bill and standing firm 'against this strange alliance of vested establishment interests, political opportunists and misguided soft-liners who joined forces and tried unsuccessfully to stop this program;' implies that if legis fails it will be as result of elements in state's criminal-justice system who are most critical of it; urges law-enforcement system to use its powers effectively, and police to act aggressively in enforcing drug laws for protection of public; says Dist Attys must prosecute forcefully and judges must act firmly; says he is submitting legis which will authorize him to appt up to 100 additional judges 'as needed' as well as to create necessary additional courtroom facilities; antinarcotics legis outlined; Rockefeller illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SEVERE SHORTAGE OF ORES IS FEARED
response.abstract: US Geological Survey issues document on May 8 that finds that present use of minerals in US will lead to severe shortages in next few decades unless nation stops wasting resources and starts employing better ways of finding and exploiting low-grade ores; 722-pg document, 1st over-all assessment of US mineral use and resources in 21 yrs, covers everything from abrasives to zirconium, including coal, oil, natural gas and all industrially important metals; Interior Sec Morton, in foreword, says question of magnitude of usable resources is of mounting concern; notes that minerals and mineral fuels are 'literally cornerstones of modern life'; survey dir Dr V E McKelvey, in summary statement, says that nation's known deposits of mineral raw materials were seriously depleted and that future supplies must come, in many cases, from low-grade ores or from yet undiscovered resources; notes that increased dependence on low-grade ores also means increasing costs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Developments in 2 Cases
response.abstract: Watergate and immunity: The Senate committee investigating Watergate will hold its first public hearings May 17 and will move to compel testimony by John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, by granting him immunity. President Nixon, the White House said, will no longer advise prosecutors to withhold immunity from current or former members of the Administration.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Proxmire Calls Press ‘Unfair’ to Nixon A Day After Linking Him to Watergate
response.abstract: Sen Proxmire denounces press May 8 for being 'grossly unfair' to Pres Nixon, Sen speech; day before, he told M McMillin, editor and publisher of Madison (Wis) Capital Times, in private telephone call that he believed Nixon was 'involved in Watergate up to his ears'; says press is engaged in campaign of 'McCarthyistic destruction' of Pres that represents 'press at its worst'; singles out Newsweek magazine, in whose current issue former White House counsel J W Dean 3d is said to have told grand jury investigators of alleged White House meetings that seem to imply that Nixon had direct knowledge of and involvement with White House cover-up attempts; says 'crux of whole matter is whether or not Pres had knowledge of Watergate case and this should not rest on apparently unsupported allegations of unidentified investigators ; Proxmire, when questioned about disparity, says he does not believe there is a contradiction and that he thinks there is 'lots of evidence' that Pres is involved but says that there is great deal of difference between expressing private convictions in private telephone call; Sens Scott and Mansfield agree with Proxmire's criticisms; Proxmire illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEWS INDEX
