response.headline: AIDES SAY REPORT TO NIXON ABSOLVING HIS STAFF CAME
response.abstract: sr White House officials rept May 15 that only rept Pres Nixon recd last yr on possible staff involvement in Watergate break‐in was informal oral rept from J D Ehrlichman; sources say that shortly after break‐in Nixon ordered Ehrlichman to set in motion investigation to determine whether any member of White House staff had been involved; say Ehrlichman delegated J W Dean 3d to conduct investigation and Ehrlichman subsequently delivered oral rept to Nixon; say it was on basis of Ehrlichman's assurances that Nixon said in Aug 29 news conf that Dean had conducted ‘complete investigation of all leads’ and that he can assure US that ‘no one in this Adm, presently employed, was involved in this very bizarre incident'; rept that since then Nixon has concluded, without identifying anyone as culprit, that investigation, and Ehrlichman's rept on it, was seriously deficient effort; say there is no question that Nixon ordered investigation and acted on assumption that his orders had been totally complied with; disclosure that Dean, Ehrlichman and H R Haldeman will leave Fed payroll as of May 15 by White House press sec Ziegler at briefing and sharp exch with newsmen noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dwain Tied to Plea to C.LA. To Help Watergate Group
response.abstract: Illus of D Ellsberg, acquitted of charges in Pentagon papers case, undergoing routine security check at Los Angeles Airport before leaving for Washington, DC
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dollar Firm, Gold Off
response.abstract: The dollar firmed against other currencies on leading European money markets yesterday in somewhat quieter dealings. Prices of gold bullion dropped following the sharp advances of Monday and Tuesday. Details, Page 63.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BIAGGI SUMMONED By A NEW PANEL
response.abstract: NYC mayoral candidate M Biaggi expresses outrage at recently announced investigation into '59 shooting incident in which he, as police lt, shot robbery suspect, saying that it has been considered act of heroism for 14 yrs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON DECLARES CONGRESS PERILS U.S. TRUCE EFFORT
response.abstract: Pres Nixon accuses Cong, May 16, of 'action that could severely undermine' the chances of restoring peace to Cambodia and all of Indochina, statement read by his press sec R L Ziegler; argues that recent Sen and HR moves to stop US bombing in Cambodia are especially damaging because they come 'on the very eve of negotiations to achieve compliance' with the truce accord; refers to Kissinger‐Le Duc tho talks in Paris; Sen Repub leaders, using series of technical delaying measures, force Sen Mansfield to hold up action for a wk on a total cut‐off of funds for the bombing; Mansfield says he has no choice; Sen Scott says an opportunity should be given for Kissinger‐Tho to succeed; Repub Sen Saxbe says he will probably vote for fund cut‐off; says US bombing of Cambodia 'shows a callousiness for civilians that we cannot tolerate in this country'; thinks fund cut‐off will pass; Sen E J Gurney opposes further bombing; excerpts from Sec Richardson secret testimony, obtained by NY Times, suggest that Nixon will back off from conflict with Cong if it votes fund cut‐off; adds that if US can go ahead on bombing at present rate during Paris talks, 'we should have a relatively stable situation through the summer, and the whole situation should be reassessed then'; HR Dem Caucus votes 125‐10 for resolution urging legis to prohibit the conduct of war in SE Asia without specific permission of Cong
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATE'S INQUIRY WILL BEGIN TODAY
response.abstract: Sen Watergate com will begin its hearings May 17 in Caucus Room of Old Sen Bldg exactly 11 mos after Watergate scandal 1st arose with arrest of 5 men who had broken into Dem Natl Com hq; 1st witnesses will be R C Odle Jr, dir of adm for Repub re‐election com, B A Kehrli, staff sec to Pres, and Sgt P W Leeper, policeman who, along with 2 colleagues, arrested Watergate burglars; hearings will be televised nationally; Watergate com has divided its investigation into 3 principal areas: effort by J W McCord Jr, his co‐conspirators and any others to wiretap and bug Dem opposition in May and June '72; campaign financing irregularities and broader efforts at espionage and sabotage; major issue within com is question of whether to compel testimony from ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d by granting him immunity from prosecution; Judge Sirica grants Sen immumity to G G Liddy May 16; illus of Caucus Room
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A ONE‐YEAR TRIM IN INCOME TAXES VOTED IN ALBANY
response.abstract: NYS Legis on May 16 overwhelmingly approves bill that would suspend for 1 yr 2.5% income tax surcharge authorized during '71‐72 fiscal crisis; measure passes Assembly by vote of 134‐1 and Sen by 59‐0; bill would suspend surcharge on '73 taxable income and save avg taxpayer about $15; loss of revenue to state is estimated at $80‐million; Sen majority leader W M Anderson says indications from Gov Rockefeller are that he 'would be happy to sign it'; surcharge was added to income tax as temporary, 5‐yr measure; only Assemblyman to vote against suspension of surcharge is A O Eve; Dems call passage of tax cut 'limited victory'; Assembly Speaker P B Duryea hails passage as 'historic event'; Dems in both houses take credit for 'forcing' Repubs to come out with surcharge suspension; Sen M Ohrenstein says that credit for passage belongs to Dem minority; during debate on measure, Assembly majority leader J E Kingston said that income‐tax receipts during Apr were up 12% over '72, assuring sufficient surplus to permit suspension of surcharge; Assemblyman B G Hecht estimates that there would be surplus in excess of $700‐million; Assembly minority leader S Steingut joins call for additional tax‐cutting measures; Assemblyman C E Cook comments; last tax cut in NYS was in '61, when income taxes were cut by 10% for 1 yr to absorb unanticipated fiscal surplus built up in '60‐61
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Southern G.O.P. and Goldwater Critical of Nixon on Watergate
response.abstract: some 25 Repub party leaders strongly criticize Pres Nixon's handling of Watergate scandal on May 16 and warn that dwindling confidence in Govt is damaging both country and party, meeting, Washington, DC; conclude that party might function better by divorcing itself from Adm unless there is some quick action 'to restore confidence and reorganize the White House'; Sen Goldwater says May 16 that Pres has not gone far enough to restore confidence in his Adm; Miss Repub state chmn C Reed, chmn of closed meeting, says it is his judgment that group 'wants this thing absolutely out in the open and compeletely straight, no matter who is involved, including the Pres'; endorses Goldwater's statement, which was issued earlier in day
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Helms Says He Didn't Tell Nixon About Bids to C.I.A.
response.abstract: former CIA Dir Helms is quoted as saying May 16 that he felt White House requests for CIA's assistance in Watergate affair were improper but that he never told Pres Nixon of his concern; Helms testifies May 16 before Sen Appropriations subcom that is investigating CIA's involvement in Watergate case; Sen McClellan says Helms expressed concern over repeated attempts of White House aides to involve CIA in Watergate; Helms confirms repts of other CIA officials but under questioning he defends his earlier denial before Sen Foreign Relations Com of CIA involvement in Watergate affair; Sen M R Young, when asked if Helms had known that White House requests for CIA assistance were part of attempted cover‐up, says he did not and in fact, they were not; says so‐called Mexican laundering operation did not relate in any way to bugging of Dem Natl Com hq; Helms por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Astronauts May Go Aloft To Put Awning on Skylab
response.abstract: Chmn of Sen Aeronautical and Space Sciences Com Sen Moss, in lr to NASA Admr Fletcher, on May 16 urges prompt investigation into problems besetting orbiting Skylab space station
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Overseas Criticism on Watergate Mild
response.abstract: NY Times survey finds that overseas criticism of Nixon Adm has been light and Amer foreign relations so far do not appear to have suffered significant damage in wake of Watergate scandal; survey indicates that despite heavy overseas news coverage of Watergate, there his been no rise in anti‐Americanism and that affair has provoked understanding discussion of Amer system; other results; country‐by‐country break‐down of survey
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Federctl Reserve Moving To Slow Rise of Lending
response.abstract: Fed Reserve Bd takes series of steps May 16 aimed at slowing huge growth in bank lending to business by reducing incentive of banks to add to their funds by issuing large 'ctfs of deposit' in order to relend them, at profit, to borrowers; key measure would require banks to keep on deposit with Reserve 8% of any additional funds they raise issuing large ctfs of deposit in excess of amt of ctfs that they had outstanding this wk; applies to ctfs of deposit of $100,000 or more and, thus, does not affect ordinary personal savers; other actions involving reserve requirements on commercial paper, bank borrowings of Eurodollars and ceilings on interest rates paid on ctfs of deposit outlined
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: POST HEED 74 DAYS
response.abstract: SEC Chmn Cook resigns May 16 and becomes 13th Nixon Adm official to do so since late Feb after Watergate scandal and disclosures of Nixon re‐election campaign activities; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: JOHN L LOEB CITED ON CAMPAIGN GIFT
response.abstract: J L Loeb, Wall St investment banker, accused by Fed Govt of disguising source of $48,000 contribution to Sen H Humphrey's unsuccessful '72 Pres campaign; Loeb, 1st contributor to be accused under new campaign contribution disclosure laws, is charged with 'urging' 8 people to write checks for Humphrey's campaign and then reimbursing them with his own money, in violation of new law that provides 'no persons shall make a contribution in the name of another person'; Loeb, sr partner of Loeb Rhoades & Co, issues statement asserting that at time of donation he was not aware of change in law; says when he found out he immediately asked Humphrey's campaign people to announce that money in question really came from him; says Humphrey people did make such announcement; denies suggestion made by some politicians that he was 'hedging his bets' by making secret donation to Humphrey at same time he was donating to Nixon's campaign; says he did not support Nixon until after McGovern became Dem nominee; Sen Humphrey says he has 'no knowledge of the details' of matter but says he knows Loeb is 'distinguished and respected citizen'; Loeb's long history of donations to different Humphrey pol campaigns recalled
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRICE‐FIXING CASE ON STORES WIDENS
response.abstract: Fed grand jury investigation of alleged price‐fixing by prominent NYC stores has resulted in subpeona of records and minutes of Uptown Retail Guild, former trade assn grouping most of upper Fifth Av and Madison Av stores, as far back as 1935; sources say Fed attys are interested in discussions contained in minutes of guild concerning 'sale' days in which prices would be changed for limited periods; former Bonwit Teller pres M Custin has been subpoenaed, along with G Franklin, former pres of Saks Fifth Av, and H Saul, retired exec of Saks Fifth Av; prominent mfrs have also received subpoenas including Kimberly Knitwear Inc and David Crystal Inc; Seventh Av sources deny knowing of any illegalities in pricing but say that retailer with substantial buying power could put pressure on mfr to insist that all his accts in same trading area adhere to set price level and bring into line anyone who atttempted to shave prices by denying him merchandise
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BROAD ROLE CITED
response.abstract: Justice Dept sources rept on May 16 that H A Kissinger personally provided FBI with names of number of his aides on Natl Security Council whom he wanted wiretapped; say top council official H Sonnenfeldt was among those tapped at Kissinger's request and that Kissinger's role in wiretapping was far more extensive than previously reptd; note it was Kissinger who initially forwarded formal request for taps to FBI Dir J E Hoover after being authorized to do so by Nixon; one dept source says Kissinger's decision to authorize tapping of Sonnenfeldt was designed to clear him; notes Sonnenfeldt prides himself on his 'brilliance and his intellectual capability' and adds that man like that 'can let things slip'; another official notes Kissinger was only trying 'to protect' Sonnenfeldt; Kissinger acknowledged in int in NY Times on May 15 that he saw summaries from several wiretaps in '69 and '70 but said he had not asked that they be installed nor had he specifically approved of them in advance; FBI Acting Dir W D Ruckelshaus also disclosed on May 14 that wiretaps were placed on 13 Govt officials and 4 newsmen from '69 through '71; NY Times repts on May 16 that A Lake and D I Davidson, 2 former members of Natl Security Council, and 1 current staff member W Lord were among those tapped, but it could not be learned whether any of 3 was put under surveillance at Kissinger's request; one high Govt official says he was aware that wiretapping was going on and says to have done less would have been 'highest order of irresponsibility'; another notes some White House officials had been determined to be 'blabbermouths' and were eventually eased out of positions; another source with access to wiretap transcripts says there was not one member of Natl Security Council staff who was disloyal to country; adds they were disloyal to Kissinger and were giving him 'real problems'; other Govt official notes wiretaps produced nothing from standpoint of evidence that could be proven in ct; says there was good reason to feel that they had found something, and it justified whole operation; Sen Finance Com asst chief clerk M M Stern says on May 16 that Sonnenfeldt had been challenged by J D Hemenway for being responsible for at least 2 security violation in late '50s but that investigations cleared him of both accusations; Justice Dept spokesman, commenting on legality of wiretaps, say Pres's authority to install such natl security wiretaps derive from Const and Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of '68; Dr M Halperin says he thinks they are clearly illegal and violated his const rights
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lebanese and Guerrillas Report ‘Identical’ Views
response.abstract: Lebanese Govt and Palestinian guerrillas on May 17 announce that they have reached 'identical viewpoints' on settlement of conflict in which at least 250 persons have been killed since May 2; Lebanese radio repts that com of Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese authorities has been set up to see that measures agreed upon are carried out; measures that are involved were not announced by either side after 2 days of negotiations ended on May 16 between team of 3 Lebanese Army officers and reprs of 3 major guerrilla orgns, Al Fatah, Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and Popular Democratic Front; Attalah Attalah, also known as Abu Zaim, mil commander of Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon, says that 'complete understanding' has been reached in negotiations, in which he took part; diplomatic sources say that guerrillas agreed to refrain from making illegal arrests; issue raised by Lebanese Army was removal from Palestinian refugee camps, which serve as bases for guerrillas, of heavy mortar and rockets; it is not clear what agreement was reached on this point; state of emergency has placed Lebanon under martial law and curfew remains in effect after dark; despite heavy bombing by tanks and air force jets, guerrillas remain entrenched in major refugee camps in Beirut, with no shortage of ammunition and supplies; Lebanese econ has suffered because of crisis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: COUNCIL REPEALS BASE‐RENT PLAN
response.abstract: NYC City Council votes, 34 to 1, to repeal rent control law's controversial maximum base rent formula; landlord spokesmen warn that action could touch off widespread strike by bldg service employes; Lindsay denounces repeal bill, which he says is illegal under state law
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HEARING IS TOLD THAT MAGRUDER HAD FILE MOVED
response.abstract: Nixon campaign official R C Odle Jr, 1st witness to testify before nationally televised Sen Watergate Com hearings May 17, says that deputy dir of orgn J S Magruder ordered file that apprently contained pot intelligence removed from his desk hrs after Watergate burglary for 'security' reasons; says he did not read file but suspected that things 'which have no place in a pol campaign were in it'; says he returned file to Magruder upon his return to Washington 2 days later but so far as is known documents contained in it have never been found by investigators; Odle is questioned closely about Magruder's file, suggesting that com is attempting to develop evidence of high‐level involvement in cover‐up immediately after arrests; com's interest in file appears to stem in part from possibility that Nixon campaign aide moved almost immediately to safeguard and then to destroy or hide crucial documents; there have also been repts that folder held documents on wiretapping operations against Dems and possession of such material by Magruder would be highly incriminating; Odle says J N Mitchell took part in making pol decisions while he was still Atty Gen; testifies that 'decision memos' were sent to Mitchell at Justice Dept and that Mitchell was involved in 'major campaign decisions' as early as '71; B A Kehrli, special asst to Pres, testifies about White House structure using orgn charts; burden of organizational testimony is that many officials at Nixon com had gone there from White House and that White House retained over‐all direction of re‐election effort; final witness May 17 is Sgt P W Leeper, 1 of 3 men who apprehended Watergate burglars; illus of com members Gurney, Baker, Ervin, Talmadge and chief counsel S Dash; illus of R C Odle Jr
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GUIDELINE ISSUED FOR PROSECUTOR
response.abstract: Atty Gen‐designate Richardson issues detailed set of guidelines May 17 for special Watergate prosecutor as yet unnamed; Richardson asserts, in lr to Sen Judiciary Com, that special prosecutor will be apptd by Atty Gen to serve within Justice Dept, and will be given 'full authority for investigating and prosecuting offenses against the US arising out of Watergate break‐in; says prosecutor will also handle 'all offenses arising out of '72 Pres election' as well as 'allegations involving the Pres, members of his staff, or Pres appointees and any other matters assigned to him by the Atty Gen'; concept of 'full' authority used in guidelines still does not meet insistence among some members of Cong that prosecutor be given 'final' authority; Justice W H Erickson, 1 of major candidates for job, counters Richardson's guidelines with set of his own but refuses to say what was in proposal he forwarded to Richardson; his only elaboration is that he made it clear to Richardson that prosecutor would have to be 'independent'; Richardson says prosecutor will have 'greatest degree of independence that is consistent with Atty Gen's statutory accountability for all matters falling within the jurisdiction of Justice Dept; White House press sec Ziegler says 'independence' problem 'is totally and completely in the hands of Mr Richardson' and that Richardson is Tree to grant total independence if he chose'; Sens Kennedy, Tunney and Burdick praise Richardson for agreeing to release guidelines for public inspection; Richardson's brother Dr E P Richardson says his brother was reluctant to take on task of Atty Gen but did so out of sense of service to US
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Palestinians Still See Victory Despite 25 Years of Setbacks
response.abstract: May 18: NY Times survey on Palestinian Arabs notes that 25 yrs after creation of state of Israel, uprooted Palestinian Arabs not only are at war with Israel but are in conflict with Arab Govts and among themselves; notes loss of bases in Jordan during fighting in '70 and '71 between Jordanian King Hussein's army and guerrillas is recognized as severe setback to aspirations of Palestinians, who are believed to number 3 million; says they are determined to prevent repetition of '70 and '71 in Lebanon where cease‐fire between Lebanese Army and guerrillas was consolidated recently; notes Israeli retaliation at guerrilla bases in Jordan, Lebanon and Syria has resulted in curtailed guerrilla raids into Israel from Syria; holds now Lebanon is seeking to place stricter controls on armed guerrilla activities on its territory; notes that of approximately 3 million Palestinians, 1.5 million are registered refugees and 400,000 are displaced persons from '67 war; holds that although sentiment among rank and file is strong, 1 of weakest aspects of Palestinian struggle is lack of unified political leadership enjoying broad support; says Palestine Liberation Orgn, in which all major guerrilla groups and some Palestinian professionals and intellectuals are represented, is recognized by Arab League and its member govts as official voice of 'Palestinian entity'; notes Y Arafat, founding member of Al Fatah, largest guerrilla group, is chmn of Palestine Liberation Orgn; says Arafat shares leadership with other Fatah figures such as S Khalef and with leaders of more radical groups such as Dr G Habash of Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and N Hawatmeh of Popular Dem Front, who is Maoist Marxist; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Launching of Skylab Crew Put. Off Until Next Friday
response.abstract: launching of crew of Skylab, 1st US orbiting laboratory, is again postponed on May 17 until May 25 to enable astronauts to undergo training to effect necessary repair job on overheated spacecraft, which has resulted from failure of solar panels to deploy and from spacecraft's loss of heat shield during launching from Cape Kennedy; NASA says crew will attempt to install a thin mylar awning over sunlit side of vehicle to deflect solar rays that are causing interior temperatures to soar above 100 degrees Fahrenheit; Sklab crew member Dr Kerwin reptdly is undergoing training with mock‐up of vehicle at Marshall Space Flight Center; scientists are confident mission can be continued without malfunctioning solar panels; say electricity can be drawn from Apollo spacecraft but that some experiments may have to be curtailed; alternate plans to salvage mission discussed; drawing of Skylab space station
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Low‐Key Beginning Before Rapt Audience
response.abstract: Sen Select Com on Pres Campaign Activities, investigating Watergate bugging case, begins hearings on May 17 in Room 318 of Old Sen Office Bldg; constant lines of 150 or more persons clog foyer of Sen bldg as public seeks access to hearings; among spectators is D Ellsberg who says he came 'to pay my respects to the independent legislative branch'; Sen H H Baker Jr, member of 7‐man panel that is presiding over hearings, says in opening statement that it is Amer people who must be final judge of Watergate; Pres press sec R Ziegler repts that Nixon is not watching televised hearings, 'He doesn't watch much television'; illus of students and others crowed into hearing room to hear opening session
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A‐Blast in Colorado Does Less Damage Than Was Expected
response.abstract: Project Rio Blanco, detonation of 3 nuclear devices equal to 90,000 tons of TNT, in northwest Colo, set off May 17 with less resulting damage than expected; project sponsored by AEC and CER Geonuclear Corp to stimulate gas production; local effects and reaction described; are minor; AEC aide J Toman says blast went off as planned; AEC Chmn Ray and Gov Love watch detonation from helicopters; Ray says experiment proceeded 'perfectly'; some local residents picket in protest; environmentalists arguments against blast recalled; local poem on it quoted; schematic diagram of blast; map of site
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ferry Planned to Connect Brooklyn and Manhattan
response.abstract: South St Seaport Museum officials on May 17 announce that museum plans to set up passenger ferry service between Manhattan and Bklyn at peak travel hrs, 'hopefully by next spring'; say ferry would operate virtually in shadow of Bklyn Bridge; last ferry service on this 600‐yd route was discontinued in '26; officials contend that small ferry could be economically viable because of traffic snarls on bridge and overcrowding in subways at rush hrs; drawing shows proposed ferry route
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Wife Says Mitchell
response.abstract: Mrs Mitchell says May 18 that her husband ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell has been protecting Pres Nixon in Watergate scandal, news conf; suggests that Nixon might be impeached if he does not resign; says White House must bear 'all the blame' for Watergate; says they tried to make her husband 'fall guy' but he is 'good guy'; says her husband told her May 18 that 'if anything happens to the Pres, the country will fall apart' says she replied that it would be a 'darn better idea for Mr Nixon to resign than to be impeached'; Mrs Mitchell's comments come after Watergate conspirator McCord told Sen Watergate com that he believed he was acting on orders from Mr Mitchell in Dem Natl Com hq break‐in
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘HAS A LOT TO DO’
response.abstract: White House press sec Ziegler says May 18, in response to questions, that Pres Nixon has no intention of resigning; says Nixon 'was elected to lead this country as Pres in '72, and that he intends to do'; Ziegler repeats denial made by his deputy G L Warren 10 days ago that 'Pres did not participate in any way, or have any knowledge regarding cover‐up and at no time authorized anyone to represent him in offering exec clemency'; says Watergate conspirator J W McCord Jr's allegations at Sen Watergate com hearings are 'based on total hearsay'; says Nixon is not watching any of Sen proceedings on TV but is seeing daily summary of them prepared under direction of Gen A M Haig Jr, acting White House chief of staff; says White House has bought copy of running transcript from Ward & Paul, stenographic reptg co; says Nixon met with Cabinet May 18 and discussed such topics as foreign policy, energy and trade and that there was 'some reference to the situation and setting we are in' but that there was no specific discussion of Sen hearings; says, in reply to question, that Nixon never questioned 'legitimacy' of '72 Pres election or fact that it constituted 'total, absolute expression of the Amer people'; says Nixon has no plans to make statement to Sen com, either in person, by submitting written statement or through counsel; comments, in reply to question, that any statement made by ex‐White House counsel Dean 'must be seen in the light of the fact' that he is seeking immunity from prosecution in scandal and is seen suggesting that Dean is willing to exaggerate or invent in order to convince prosecutors that he has so much information that he must be given immunity if they hope to prosecute 'higher‐ups'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Effort to Get Tax Data Laid to Caulfield
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, May 18—John J. Caulfield, a former White House aide whose name figured prominently in today's Senate Watergate testimony, tried three years ago to obtain Internal Revenue Service intelligence for the White House on one of President Nixon's closest friends, according to sources directly acquainted with the matter.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ALBANYAPPROVES REVISED OM LAW
response.abstract: NYS Legis on May 18 passes revision of off‐track betting law that establishes state racing and wagering bd, eases financial problems of race tracks, permits new off‐track betting operations in various localities and allows racing on Sunday; new 3‐man racing and wagering bd, to be named by Gov, will supervise race tracks, OTB and state lottery; new off‐track betting operations will be created in 6 regional systems connected to statewide betting pool; other provisions of bill would extend racing to end of yr instead of present Dec 15 deadline, have OTB pay more to tracks, about $6.4‐million, but its share in 'exotic' betting would increase, cut state race track admission taxes from 15% to 4% and increase aid to horse breeders; NYRA would be granted tax relief amounting to 1% for rest of yr; state will also cut revenue and expense take‐out from betting pool from 17% to 14%; opposition to bill noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: High Drama in Quiet Testimony
response.abstract: article discusses J W McCord Jr's appearance before Sen Watergate com; notes McCord's statements regarding exec clemency and his allegation that White House was involved in 'game‐plan' designed to cover up involvement of officials in Nixon Adm and Nixon's re‐election com; notes Sens emphasis on fact that much of what McCord was asserting is hearsay; says Sen Talmadge seems anxious to discredit McCord's testimony while some of com's Dem members appear eager to reinforce McCord's believability
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stock Prices Slump
response.abstract: The Watergate hearings and fears of a crisis of confidence affecting the Nixon Administration sent stoat prices plummeting yesterday. The Dow‐Jones industrial average tumbled 16.55 points to 895.17. This marked the first time in more than 15 months that the Dow had finished under 900. Details, Page 49.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON VETOES BILL ON CONFIRMATIONS
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, accusing Cong of 'backdoor' assault on Pres authority, vetoes May 18 bill that would require Sen confirmation of Dir and Deputy Dir of Mgt and Budget Office; veto is 1st strong indication that Pres will continue his const struggle with Cong despite shake‐up his Adm has undergone in Watergate case
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AIDE IS IDENTIFIED
response.abstract: Watergate conspirator J W McCord Jr testifies before Sen Watergate Com May 18 that former White House official then in Treas Dept J J Caulfield, who said that he was acting with Pres Nixon's knowledge, offered him exec clemency, financial aid and eventually a job in return for his silence in Watergate scandal; White House denies that Pres knew of any such efforts; McCord says Caulfield met with him in Jan and pleaded for his silence; says Caulfield told him that he was bringing 'message of exec clemency' to McCord 'from very highest levels of the White House'; says Caulfield stated that 'Nixon was in Key Biscayne, Fla, that weekend, had been told of the forthcoming meeting with me and would be immediately told of the results of the meeting'; says Caulfield further stated that 'I may have a message for you at our next meeting from the Pres himself; says that while he was at Nixon's re‐election com he recd 'almost daily' confidential memorandums from Internal Security Div of Justice Dept concerning activities of orgns that dept believed were planning demonstrations against Repubs; McCord says that at another meeting with Caulfield he was told that Pres' 'ability to govern is at stake'; says pressure to keep silent and plead guilty began in late Sept or early Oct and continued through 'the night before my conviction' Jan 19; says pressure also came from Watergate conspirator E H Hunt Jr, atty G Alch and Hunt's atty W O Bittman; Alch refuses to comment on charge and Bittman denies any improper activity; Sen Ervin says that McCord's statement 'would not be accepted in ct of law to connect Pres with what Caulfield was doing' because it was hearsay; McCord testifies that after his arrest June 17 he recd $46,000 in cash from Mrs E H Hunt Jr, $25,000 of which was used for legal fees; says he thought funds had come from Nixon campaign com; McCord repeats charges made during closed‐door appearances in various proceedings that J N Mitchell had approved conspiracy in advance; says co‐conspirator G G Liddy told him that Watergate wiretapping was approved by ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell, J W Dean 3d and J S Magruder in early '72; Caulfield, who was immediately subpoenaed by Sen com, reads statement May 18 in which he confirms that he met with McCord 3 times in Jan and conveyed to him 'certain messages from a high‐White House official'; asserts that McCord's version of meetings 'does not fully reflect my best recollection of the events'; illus of Ervin, McCord, Sen Gurney and hearing room
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Archibald Cox Appointed Prosecutor for Watergate
response.abstract: Atty Gen‐designate Richardson names Prof A Cox, Solicitor Gen in Kennedy and Johnson Adms, as special Watergate prosecutor; says he did not consult White House prior to naming Cox; says he will go before Sen Judiciary Com May 21 with Cox and that apptmt will be subject to Sen confirmation although there is no legal necessity for it; Richardson says he plans to modify guidelines, made public May 17, in line with recommendations he has recd from Sen, news conf; says he will have no control over investigation for 'all practical day‐to‐day purposes'; says he will make no attempt to keep in touch with special prosecutor and that Cox will determine to what extent he will keep Richardson informed; Cox career sketch; Sen Kennedy lauds choice of Cox; Asst Atty Gen Petersen told friends that he feels badly about idea of outside prosecutor as he believes it reflects on Justice Dept and him personally; Richardson illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Secretariat Is Winner
response.abstract: Secretariat wins Preakness on May 19 at Pimlico; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GOVERNOR URGES DELAY ON CHARTER
response.abstract: Rockefeller request that Legis postpone until '75 any public referendum on changing NYC Charter seen effort to avoid controversial issue in 74, when he may be running for re‐election
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CAULFIELD IS SAID TO CONNECT DEAN TO CLEMENCY BID
response.abstract: investigators say that former White House official J Caulfield has told Sen investigators that when he offered exec clemency to J W McCord Jr in return for McCord's silence about Watergate conspiracy, he was operating on instructions from then‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d; investigators who particpated in int with Caulfield May 17 say May 19 that when they asked Caulfield whether he had invoked Pres Nixon's name when he met with McCord, Caulfield replied 'I might have, but I don't recall that I did'; McCord has testified that Caulfield said that Pres was aware of their clandestine meetings and that offer of clemency had come 'from very highest levels of the White House'; recent Gallup Poll indicates that concern over corruption in Govt increased from 1% in mid ‐Feb to 16%; questions Sens hope to ask McCord in future hearing noted; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Brezhnev and Brandt Sign 10‐Year Pact
response.abstract: D Binder comment on visit by Soviet Communist party leader Brezhnev to W Ger discusses recent resignation of Opposition party leader Barzel

response.headline: Nixon Demands Hanoi Tell Fate of Missing Americans
response.abstract: Pres Nixon arrives, Norfolk, Va, on May 19; leaves for Camp David, Md

response.headline: Mrs. Johnson to Pursue A Selective Public Life
response.abstract: Mrs L B Johnson discusses her plans for the future; illus

response.headline: MITCHELL REJECTS ROLE OF ‘FALL GUY’
response.abstract: ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell says someone is trying to make him 'fall guy' in Watergate scandal but that the effort will fail because 'I never did anything mentally or morally wrong,' telephone call initiated by his wife; says he has 'clear conscience'; says only thing he did was 'to try to get the Pres re‐elected'; Mrs Mitchell repeats her contention that White House is trying to make her husband 'fall guy' in scandal and predicts that there will be 'a resignation or he'll (Pres Nixon) be impeached'; Mitchell says he and his wife watched televised sessions of Sen Watergate hearings; criticizes Sens for failing to cross‐examine more closely statements made by Watergate conspirator McCord; denies McCord's allegations that McCord met several times with Mitchell; says he saw McCord once and passed him 'in the hall' several times; says he will testify before com
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Conservatives Expecting Sandman to Win in Jersey
response.abstract: 3d article in series of profiles on candidates for Gov of NJ discusses campaign of Repr C W Sandman Jr; Sandman has raised about $225,000 for his campaign; has played down issue of corruption in Cahill Adm; his chief campaign strategist is F C White, who engineered NYS Sen Buckley's successful campaign 3 yrs ago; Sandman por; illus of Cahill campaigning
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Extensive Fraud Charged In Europe Farm Subsidies
response.abstract: Eur officials charge that farmers in EEC member nations are receiving financial support and have collected export subsidies on nonexistent exports; farm frauds reptdly are widespread and were brought to light only after GB entered EEC on Jan 1 and complained about unaccounted funds; officials feel that frauds are result of inadequate controls by community; examples cited; EEC, in order to control frauds, would have to have power to examine records of natl customs authorities and natl farm orgns; natl govts, however, are reluctant to permit Commomn Mkt authorities to inspect their records; Eur Parliament com on budgets notes that 'expenditure of guarantee section' of Agr Fund is not subject to adequate external control; claims that Audit Bd is unable to give official bodies binding information on financial mgt of Agr Fund; Agr Fund section of EEC contains 80% of community's budget that is nearly $5‐billion a yr; funds are received from duties and levies on goods entering EEC and from taxpayers in member nations; experts believe that as more activities are financed by community, Agr Fund budget will increase will become subject to increased irregularities; hold such problems are inevitable unless control procedures are tightened; Brit MP Pounder, commenting on charges, maintains there is an 'urgent need for massive shakeup'; says frauds are an 'appaling indictment' of present methods of appropriating and administering Mkt funds; Pounder, deputy chmn of Budget com H Aigner and Brit finance specialist E Reister believe that $130‐million, which cannot be accounted for in EEC, represents minimum losses from farm finance fund every yr; Eur Budget Comr C Cheysson says dimensions of frauds are greatly exagerated and places 'true' figure at less than $10‐million a yr; Eur Parliament pressure reptdly could lead to strengthening of central insts, EEC exec comm would assert its authority over spending of Community funds and Eur Parliament would assert its authority over exec comm; possible reasons for farm frauds cited
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Authority Over Land Use is Termed a Public fight
response.abstract: Fed Task Force on Land Use and Urban Growth of the Citizens Advisory Com on Environmental Quality, headed by L S Rockefeller, concludes 6‐mo study; says May 19 that development rights on private property must be regarded as community matter; urges broad array of controls and measures, particularly systematic development of 'open space,' and urges enactment of pending natl land‐use legis; study was sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund; members of task force listed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ervin Crititizes Delaying Trial Until '73
response.abstract: Common Cause chmn J W Gardner opposes Pres Nixon's proposal for study comm to seek reforms, saying it would be a 'mortuary for action proposals', int, May 20, CBS Face the Nation program; calls for resignation of Repr W L Hays as chmn of Dem Cong Campaign Com; points out that Hays is also chmn of HR Adm Com which has jurisdiction over campaign reform; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Reid's Tour Called Opening of Gubernatorial Bid
response.abstract: Repr Reid, who switched from Repub to Dem parties last yr, begins barnstorming tour of Dem functions in what is viewed as initial stage of a drive for Dem Gubernatorial nomination in '74; assails Rockefeller adm for what he calls state's 'fiscal quagmire', condemns as 'slavish allegiance Rockefeller's support of Nixon and calls for new leadership in Albany; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Building to Resume at St. John the Divine
response.abstract: Cathedral Ch of St John the Divine on May 20 celebrates its 100th anniv and installation of Very Rev J P Morton as its new dean; Morton discloses that construction at cathedral will resume, but that ch will continue its focus on needs of people; there has been no major construction on ch, world's largest Gothic cathedral, for more than 30 yrs and there are still no plans to complete unfinished edifice; celebration following installation of Morton described; ch history traced; illus
keywords: ST JOHN THE DIVINE, CATHEDRAL CHURCH OF (MANHATTAN)
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 17 OF CAMDEN 28 FOUND NOT GUILTY
response.abstract: jury of 5 men and 7 women on May 20 finds 17 members of Camden 28 not guilty of breaking into Camden Fed bldg in 71 and destroying draft files even though defendants admitted having done so; verdict constitutes 1st legal victory for antiwar movement in 5 yrs of such incidents; defense lawyer C Broege Jr says motions will be filed promptly to dismiss charges against remaining members of group whose cases had been severed from trial and prosecutor J Barry says he will recommend dismissal; juror A Bertino notes Judge C S Fisher's presentation of case as one in which Govt overstepped propriety in use of R Hardy as agent provocateur to actualize crime had influenced jury; trial lasting 3 1/2 months involved 45 witnesses, primarily FBI agents for Govt and informer R W Hardy; rev of case; list of defendants
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Charge Naming the I.T.T. Is Reported Cut in S.E.C.
response.abstract: proposed charge of fraud against ITT reptdly was deleted from SEC draft complaint in '72 even though it was recommended by SEC's top staff officials; W J Casey, then SEC chmn, reptdly took lead in advocating decision but it reptdly was unanimously made by whole comm; charge detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WHITE HOUSE UNIT REPORTEDLY SPIED ON RADICALS IN 70
response.abstract: source near Watergate investigation says May 20 that White House established secret intelligence unit in '70 to collect and evaluate information about radical and antiwar groups; unit, known as Intelligence Evaluation Com, is now clandestinely operated out of Justice Dept's Internal Security Div; source says unit reptd directly to ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d and J Caulfield; say intelligence unit was set up in response to order from ex‐White House chief of staff J D Ehrlichman; say E Krogh Jr, Ehrlichman aide, is believed to have been connected with unit at varying times
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.,S.Companies and Soviet Discuss a Vast Gas Line
response.abstract: Occidental Oil Corp chmn Dr A Hammer says May 20 corp is negotiating massive gas pipeline deal with USSR that will be bigger than multi‐billion dollar chem fertilizer deal recently concluded, int; says pipeline will be joint Occidental‐El Paso Natural Gas Co project and will involve construction of 2,000‐mi line from western Siberia to Murmansk; will visit Moscow shortly for negotiations; says deal will require pol decision by Us and Soviets and be subject to US energy importation policies; repts discussing pol implication during recent meeting with USSR Chmn Brezhnev; says pipeline gas will be from Yakutsk fields; explains Occidental‐El Paso arrangements are part of larger US‐Soviet pipeline project involving Texas Eastern Transmission Corp and Tenneco Inc; illus; forthcoming visit by USSR technicians to discuss plans for constructing waste disposal plant converting garbage into oil noted
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Justice Officials Find Corruption Rife Among Immigration Aides in Southwest
response.abstract: Fed agents, investigating alleged corruption among immigration aides in Southwest US, say that members of Border Patrol, enforcement arm of Immigration and Naturalization Service, reptdly supply illegal Mex labor to big US ranch owners in return for hunting privileges, cash payments and other emoluments
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIEU ANNOUNCES 8‐YEAR PROGRAM OF WAR RECOVERY
response.abstract: Pres Nguyen Van Thieu announces new 5‐yr plan for reconstruction and econ development of S Vietnam, radio‐TV speech, May 20; also announces that responsibility for the econ will be shifted to a 'reconstruction and development leadership council' under his direction and that the independent Pub Service Dept, which directs the civil service, will also be under his personal control; some Thieu supporters are disappointed because the 8‐yr plan is couched in vague terms and because the adm reforms stop short of the major Govt overhaul that had been expected; details on 3 phases of econ plan; Thieu, in speech, seems to play down difficulties of dealing with the communists and the likelihood of renewed hostilities; stresses continued maintenance of a strong mil force for territorial security; some foreign economists who have had access to details of econ plan criticize it for its unrealistic estimates of the amount of foreign aid required and the capacity of the econ to grow
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 Candidates for Mayor Favor Rent‐Law Change
response.abstract: NYC Dem mayoral candidates Controller Beame, Assemblyman Blumenthal and Repr Biaggi favor changing NYC rent‐control program to provide stronger assurances that rent increases are used to improve housing; Repr Badillo prefers restricting rent increases and helping landlords meet maintentance costs through city loans and tax abatement; Badillo, Blumenthal and Beame oppose vacancy decontrol; Biaggi would seek 'modification' of vacancy decontrol; all candidates criticize city's maximum base rent formula on grounds that it does not insure that increases are used to improve housing; Badillo says rent rises are not way to pay for maintenance and endorses stricter rent control with low‐interest city loans and 100% tax abatement to finance upgrading
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THOROUGH INQUIRY IS PLEDGED BY COX
response.abstract: special Watergate prosecutor A Cox says on May 21 that he will pursue his investigation into Oval Office of White House if trail leads him there, testimony, Sen Judiciary Com hearing on E L Richardson's confirmation as Atty Gen; Sec Richardson says, in response to question on what he would do if Pres asked him for progress rept, that he would refer it to special prosecutor and let him decide; Cox, when asked same question, says he feels he would have absolute right, if 'I felt it were against the interests of the investigation, to refuse'; Sen Byrd announces that he will 'reluctantly' vote for Richardson's confirmation; calls apptmt of Richardson 'regrettable and unfortunate' and says he wishes Nixon had 'gone outside the Adm and brought in a fresh name and a fresh face'; Cox says he will work within guidelines laid down by Richardson; Sen Tunney questions Richardson about his personal friendship with C W Colson, former White House aide who has testified before Watergate grand jury
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Gold Up $6.50 to Record As Dollar Falls in Europe
response.abstract: Foreign exch dealers link May 21 rise in gold price to record closing of $112 an ounce in London and Zurich to renewed worries over US in light of unfolding Watergate scandal
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 4 PANTHERS ADMIT GUILT IN SLAYING
response.abstract: The second trial of four Black Panthers charged with the 1971 murder of a member of a rival faction of the party ended abruptly in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday when the defendants pleaded guilty to the reduced charge of attempted manslaughter in the second degree.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: C.I.A. MEMO SAID TO QUOTE: HALDEMAN ON NIXON ‘WISH’TO HALT F.B.I. FUND STUDY
response.abstract: Sen Symington repts May 21 that ex‐White House aide H R Haldeman reptdly told CIA Deputy Dir Gen Walters nearly 1 yr ago that 'it is the Pres' wish' that CIA attempt to halt investigation into at least 1 aspect of Watergate case; Symington says statement regarding Pres was contained in 'memorandum of conversation' that Walters said he prepared after White House meeting with Haldeman and ex‐White House aide J D Ehrlichman 6 days after Dem Natl Com hq break‐in; another of Walters's memorandums, written last yr but disclosed May 21 by another Cong source, quotes then‐FBI Acting Dir Gray as saying that Pres, during a telephone conversation, had inquired about 'the case,' an apparent reference to Watergate inquiry; memo quotes Gray as telling Pres that Watergate case could not be covered up and that he thought Nixon should get rid of those involved; Sen Symington discloses that Sen Armed Services Com has acquired 2 sets of documents purporting to deal with Adm plans in summer of '70 to permit burglary and other violations of law in collection of intelligence information about US citizens; says plans were never carried out; illus of Sens Symington, Muskie and Mansfield
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Warning Against Blaming C.I.A. Is Laid to McCord
response.abstract: Source says on May 21 that J W McCord Jr, convicted Watergate burglar and conspirator, before Watergate trial began in Jan, made telephone calls to Israeli Embassy, which he knew from his days as CIA official to be wiretapped by FBI; say McCord later demanded that White House officials prevail on Fed prosecutors to concede that he had been overheard on illegal wiretap and dismiss charges against him; during 1st wks of trial Fed prosecutors reptd that search of all relevant wiretap logs proved negative; intelligence officials confirm on May 21 existence of wiretaps on Israeli Embassy; Govt source says top‐secret FBI wiretap program was known by code name 'Scope' when it was initiated during Johnson Adm; recalls reading transcript of conversation involving Israeli Premier Meir and former Israeli‐US Amb I Rabin during Middle East crisis of '70; says Meir and Rabin were discussing US Sec Rogers; says copies of 'Scope' material were routinely distributed by FBI to offices of Pres Nixon's natl security adviser H A Kissinger, and to CIA and Natl Security Agency; US has never acknowledged wiretapping Israeli Embassy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BREZHNEV URGES PEACE AND TRUST AS BONN TRIP ENDS
response.abstract: Chancellor Brandt and Soviet Communist party leader Brezhnev on May 21 end 4 days of talks with 'joint declaration' of econ and cultural cooperation and 'moving' TV speech by Brezhnev to W Ger people calling for 'new continent' of Eur, continent of peace, trust and cooperation; declaration alludes to econ cooperation agreement that 2 states signed on May 19; Soviets, in essence, invited from W Gers more industrial investment and promised delivery of raw materials in return for advanced tech and industrial plants from the West; in declaration, no mention is made of any right for W Ger to speak for W Berlin when W Ger and E Ger enter UN; declaration calls for further contacts and exchs in fields of culture, sports, educ and tourism and for more contacts between citizens of both countries and for 'settlement of humanitarian questions,' probably allusion to tensions between E Ger and W Ger as well as between USSR and W Ger
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: COURT BACKS BAN ON SCHOOL MERGER OF A CITY, SUBURBS
response.abstract: US Sup Ct on May 21 affirms, 4‐4, lower ct decision which struck down as unconst a sweeping school desegregation plan for Richmond, Va, that would have merged white suburbs and heavily black city areas into single system; tie vote, with Justice Powell having disqualified himself, automatically affirms decision of next highest ct; attys who had pressed for approval of plan stress that split decision does not set precedent that would bind Ct when it is faced with similar plans for other cities; vote raises doubt, however, that liberal Justices could muster majority in support of city‐suburban integration plans in future; decision represents victory for Nixon Adm
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Europe Is Cool to U.S. Plan for New Ties
response.abstract: Eur officials, 1 mo after Kissinger proposed new US‐W Eur partnership through 'new Atlantic Charter,' are reacting with mixture of public politeness, private irritation and some open and serious reservations; French see charter idea device to insure Amer domination of Eur; officials in Bonn, London and other capitals have shied away from it in skepticism; Eurs seen ready to welcome Nixon on his fall tour but are not ready for common declaration to serve as pol framework for complex trans‐Atlantic negotiations ahead; Kissinger, while in London recently, reptdly said he was not irrevocably wedded to such phrasing as 'new Atlantic Charter' but said Nixon Adm did want perhaps a statement of gen principles Nixon could sign during his fall tour; Eur officials have resented Kissinger remarks that while US has 'global interests and responsibilities,' Eur allies have 'regional interests'; Kissinger has since said phrase was 'descriptive and not prescriptive'; Eurs reluctant to agree to any document suggesting they must pay more for defense and make concessions on trade and monetary issues as price for continued Amer troops and nuclear weapons; Eurs now uncertain of value of any summit meeting between Nixon and Eur leaders
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 38 Hurt in Queens L.I.R.R. Derailment
response.abstract: 38 persons are injured and all LIRR traffic into Penn Station, NYC, is stopped for 1 1/2 hrs on May 21 as LIRR train derails near Woodside, Queens; delays continue into evening rush hr; rr spokesmen and passengers say rear wheels of 7th car of 8‐car train came loose, causing 8th car to derail at 35‐40 MPH; retaining wall kept car from falling into path of oncoming trains; illus; map of derailment site
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stocks and Bonds Fall
response.abstract: Stock and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as Wall Street continued to reel under the combined impact of the Watergate scandal, tightening credit conditions and inflationary fears. The Dow‐Jones industrial average dropped 8.66 points to 886,51. Volume on the New York Stock Exchenge was a brisk 20.69 mil,lion shares. Details, Page 53.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘People Movers’ on Aerial Loop Proposed for Lower Manhattan
response.abstract: rept prepared for MTA and NYC Transportation Adm recommends elevated loop around Lower Manhattan and conversion of 48th and 49th Sts for use by buses and pedestrians only; proposes 2 demonstration projects to assess workability of advanced technologies: set of 2 types of moving sidewalks, traveling below ground at 2 to 3 times avg walking speed, and construction of 'continuous capacity vehicle system' along converted track area from Grand Central Terminal; rept, prepared by Kaiser Engineers Corp, suggests such a system might eventually be installed to replace bus systems on 48th and 49th Sts; elevated loop system would circle area bounded by Chambers St and Bklyn Bridge and would have rubber tires to minimize noise and vibration; would be 3.07‐mi double‐track loop with 10 stations, making complete run in 11 mins; City Planning Comm chmn Zuccotti says steps have already been taken to obtain Fed grant from Urban Mass Transportation Adm to take planning of downtown people‐mover 'to the next stage'; estimates of cost of aerial loop are put at between $81‐and $93‐million; cost of complete downtown system is between $185‐and $255‐million, depending on various specifics; estimates of cost of conversion of 48th and 49th Sts, involving large‐scale widening of sidewalks and construction of bus‐boarding stations, are put at $43‐million
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Krogh Meeting Is at Issue
response.abstract: Sen Judiciary Com on May 22, in unexpected move, apparently in response to actions by Dr D Ellsberg, reopens its hearings on confirmation of E L Richardson as Atty Gen and questions him closely about his contacts with White House and figures close to Watergate scandal; Richardson illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TESTIMONY HEARD
response.abstract: former White House official J Caulfield tells Sen Watergate com May 22 that deposed White House counsel J W Dean 3d ordered him to offer exec clemency to J W McCord Jr; testifies that he had 'no knowledge' that Pres Nixon had approved offer, regarded by McCord as effort to keep him from talking about Watergate scandal; Caulfied says Dean cited authority for offer 'from way up at the top' and that he had thought such a phrase would cover 'at least' J D Ehrlichman; Pres Nixon, in statement issued at White House, denies authorizing exec clemency for any of Watergate defendants and says that he was unaware of 'any such offer'; McCord has testified that Caulfied had said at their initial meeting that Pres was aware of their session, that he would be informed of results and that message from Nixon might come later; Caulfield says May 22 that 'at no time in our 1st meeting do I recall saying anything about the Pres'; does not foreclose possibility that Nixon knew of other 2 sessions; testifies that in Mar '69 Ehrlichman sought unsuccessfully to persuade him 'to set up a private security entity...for purposes of providing investigative support for White House'; says NYC detective A T Ulasewicz was paid through Pres Nixon's personal atty H W Kalmbach to perform 'a variety of investigative functions for the White House'; says that when he told Dean that McCord was being stubborn about accepting clemency offer, Dean said 'Well, what the hell does he know, anyway?'; Caulfied says Dean 1st approached him in Jan '73 about making clemency offer to McCord; says Dean asked him to go to public telephone for discussion of clemency offer; says when he got to pay phone and called Dean, Pres' lawyer reptdly said that 3‐part message should be given to McCord and that although it seemed cryptic, the conspirator should understand it; message reptdly began 'a yr is a long time' and continued 'your wife and family will be taken care of; you will be rehabilitated with employment when this is all over'; says he immediately perceived that he had been 'asked to do a very dangerous thing' and suggested to Dean that task be carried out by Ulasewicz in effort to mask its source; Caulfield confirms McCord's attempt to abort prosecution by establishing that he had been wiretapped by Govt and that case against him had thus been 'tainted'; McCord is allged to have accomplished this by placing calls to 2 foreign embassies in Washington that he thought were wiretapped; it is suggested for 1st time that G Alch, 1 of McCord's attys, was in touch with White House about case; illus of Caulfield
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Heath and Pompidou Shun Idea of an Atlantic Summit
response.abstract: Brit Prime Min Heath and French Pres Pompidou reptdly discussed cooperation between both nations in aerospace tech at 2‐day meeting in Paris
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATE OVERRIDES NIXON VETO, 62.22
response.abstract: US Sen, 62‐22, on May 22 overrides Pres Nixon's veto of a bill requiring Sen confirmation of Mgt and Budget Dir and Deputy Dir; HR is scheduled to vote on May 23 on whether to override measure; HR Speaker C Albert has acknowledged that bill would be 'very difficult' to override; HR passed bill May 1
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT'S VIEW
response.abstract: Pres Nixon concedes in May 22 statement that there were 'wide‐ranging efforts' in White House to conceal some aspects of Watergate case, but says those actions stemmed from his legitimate interest in protecting natl security; declares in supplementary statement that he has no intention of resigning; reiterates his own innocence in burglary of Dem Natl Com and its cover‐up but says that he asked his associates not to let investigation of case disclose covert intelligence operations conducted in interest of natl security; suggests that his closest associates H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman, who resigned Apr 30, may well have carried his instructions on protecting natl security to illegal attempts to cover up episode; says right to claim exec privilege will not be claimed in regard to 'any testimony concerning possible criminal conduct or discussions of possible criminal conduct'; Nixon says 'it is clear that unethical, as well as illegal, activities took place in the course of that campaign. None of these took place with my specific approval or knowledge. To the extent that I may in any way have contributed to the climate in which they took place, I did not intend to; to the extent that I failed to prevent them, I should have been more vigilant'; White House press sec Ziegler says Nixon will appear before press in 'very near future' to answer further to Watergate charges; White House counsel L Garment says 1 reason for releasing detailed statement is to meet 'the legitimate concerns' of pol leaders of both parties that Pres should be less seclusive and secretive
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: From Nixon's Statement
response.abstract: It is clear that unethical, as well as illegal, activities took place in the course of that campaign. None of these took place with my specific approval or knowledge. To the extent that I may in any way have contributed the climate in which they took place, I did not intend to; to the extent that I failed to prevent them, I should have been more vigilant.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 3 Prosecutors Nearly Quit
response.abstract: Justice Dept sources say that 3 Fed prosecutors in Watergate case Asst US Attys E J Silbert, S Glanzer and D E Campbell were on verge of resigning from case on May 22 but delayed their decision until May 23 meeting, their 1st, with special Watergate prosecutor A Cox; sources say Attys believe they have, in effect, solved complex case and resent fact that neither Atty Gen‐designate Richardson nor Cox has had any dealings with them since scandal erupted in Apr; attys had called news conf but their immediate superior US Atty H H Titus Jr showed up instead and announced that Cox had telephoned to invite prosecuting team to meet with him May 23; in anticipation of their resignation, prosecutors dismissed 23 grand jurors and canceled all witness ints; sources say that prosecutors have told high Justice Dept officials that they expect to complete their investigation within 2 mos and now believe that they can indict most of major targets or their inquiry solely on testimony of White House and campaign com officials who were not directly implicated in crimes; source close to Cox says that Cox fully intended to give the 3 prosecutors chance to outline their theory of case and to rept on their progress during May 23 meeting; Cox has chosen Harvard Law School colleague, Prof P B Heymann, to serve as informal deputy, at least during early stages of inquiry
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Consumer Prices Up 0.7% in April, But Climb Slowed
response.abstract: Labor Dept repts on May 22 that increase in food prices was principal reason for 0.7% rise in consumer price index, Apr; food price rise in Apr was less than during any prior mo in '73; index for food prices rose 1.5%, or 1.4% seasonally adjusted; increase in food prices since Apr '72 was 11.5%, while prices of food purchased in food shops rose 13.3%; Council of Econ Advisers Chmn Stein says rise in food was lowest monthly increase in '73, indicating 1st step in transition toward much 'smaller food price' increases later in '73; AFL‐CIO pres Meany scoffs at Stein's remarks
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Gross, Cahill Leader in’ 69, Cited by U.S. in Tax Fraud
response.abstract: Fed grand jury indictment of N G Gross, NJ Repub party leader, on May 22 on charges of masterminding income tax conspiracy fraud involving financing of Gov Cahill's '69 election campaign means that 3 most influential members of Cahill's original pol inner circle have either been convicted or indicted on criminal charges involving various forms of pol corruption; former State Sec Sherwin was convicted on charges that he attempted to fix state hwy contract in exch for $10,000 kickback to Repub fund raisers closely identified with Cahill; former State Treas McCrane was indicted last mo on charges of bribery and misconduct in office; cumulative impact of spreading charges of corruption against Cahill's associates is seen highly damaging to Cahill's campaign to win renomination in Repub gubernatorial primary
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Halts Nixon Library Plan
response.abstract: RM Nixon Foundation, with a majority of its exec bd of trustees directly implicated in Watergate investigation, has put aside for time being its plans to build a library and museum as a monument to Pres; foundation pres L K Firestone says library may be deferred until Nixon is out of office; says it is possible that Watergate affair could hurt ability of corp to raise the $8‐million to $10‐million needed to build library and museum; 4 members of foundation's 7‐member exec bd who are involved in Watergate disclosures are H R Haldeman, J D Ehrlichman, J N Mitchell and H W Kalmbach; 3 other exec trustees in foundation are R H Finch, P R Hitt and L Garment; Firestone takes position that involvement of 4 exec trustees in Watergate is not critical to foundation's operations 'at this time' because he and 3 other permanent officers carry on orgn's day‐to‐day business
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: G.O.P CHIEFS GIVE NIXON AN OVATION
response.abstract: Pres Nixon receives standing ovation from 22 Repub Sens and Reprs on May 23 after he invokes name of natl security in connection with Watergate case; Sen Minority Leader Scott conveys Nixon's remarks to reporters as Repub leaders echo Nixon's latest defense—that White House efforts to conceal some aspects of case stemmed from Nixon's legitimate concerns about security leaks and exposing covert intelligence operations; Gallup Poll shows that Nixon's popularity has dropped to lowest point since he has been Pres; poll, taken shortly after Nixon's Apr 30 address on Watergate, shows that 45% of those questioned said they approved of way Nixon is handling his job; graph of Nixon's popularity as measured by Gallup Poll since '69; Vice Pres Agnew says Nixon has been forced to 'weather an incredible storm of personal abuse and innuendo' from persons who were not aware that natl security was at stake, speech, Orlando, Fla
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Levity Finds a Way Into Senate Inquiry

response.headline: A Cambodian Landscape: Bomb Pits, Rubble, Ashes
response.abstract: Article describes destruction in Cambodia since escalation of US bombing began in Feb; scores of villages have been destroyed; great numbers of livestock have been killed and harvested crops and orchards destroyed; Amers are dependent for their information on Cambodian mil officials who show, in their requests for air strikes, almost no concern about civilian lives or caused by US bombing, for information is difficult to gather; Nixon Adm has divulged almost nothing about bombing of 'Freedom Deal,' name Amers have given to area E of Mekong River that has never been ventured into by Cambodian Govt troops; Amers have been bombing heavily there since war begin in Cambodia in '70; it is essentially a 'free‐fire zone'; civilians from area rept bombing has wiped out entire groups of villages and sizable numbers of people who were living there under Communist adm; uprooted villagers are bitter at US for bombing and also at Cambodian Govt which calls for Amer planes; illus of destroyed homes
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ABROAD PROGRAM
response.abstract: May 24: sources say on May 23 that White House urged FBI in '70 to mount massive counterinsurgency program, involving spying, wiretapping and burglaries, against Arab saboteurs; Pres Nixon briefly described program in his statement on May 23 and noted then that it was never put into effect because of opposition by former FBI Dir J E Hoover; program was outlined in secret rept on domestic intelligence prepared in July '70, and approved by Nixon, his top White House aides and chief officers of CIA, Defense Intelligence Agency and Natl Security Agency; sources say concern was expressed in rept about possibility of Arab sabotage before Middle East talks at UN in late summer of '70; says talks, initiated by UN special repr for Middle East Dr G V Jarring were scheduled to begin on Aug 26, '70; say Palestinian radicals were opposed to such negotiations; note US received intelligence indicating that Arab money was flowing to students in US who were serving as intelligence agents; source says White House officials were so frustrated by inability of FBI to penetrate Arab operations that L Garment, then adviser to Nixon, was urged to contact Jewish intelligence community and ask it about threat; peace efforts, which were unproductive, took place without incident
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ALCH ON THE STAND
response.abstract: G Alch, onetime atty for J W McCord Jr, attempts in Sen testimony on May 23 to undermine his former client's credibility and to suggest that McCord participated in anti‐Adm vendetta; denies involvement in efforts to keep McCord quiet and implies that McCord was converted to effort aimed at 'getting' Pres Nixon; quotes McCord's current atty B Fensterwald as having said 2 mos ago 'We're going after the Pres of the US'; says he replied he was not interested in any vendettas against Pres but only in best interests of his client; UPI repts that Fensterwald denies he had told Alch that he was out to 'get' the Pres; McCord and Fensterwald have asked to testify when Alch is through; Alch directly disputes McCord's accusations involving him, including charge by McCord that Alch took part in offers of exec clemency; over‐all thrust of Alch's statement goes further in suggesting that something has happened to McCord since Alch represented him and implies that McCord is now up to something; Alch says his former client turned down number of opportunities to tell his story earlier, including chance to testify at his trial; says McCord never said that he thought Watergate operation was legal because it was authorized by high govt officials—assertion McCord made to Sen com; says it was only near end of trial in Jan that McCord informed Alch that he had hearsay evidence that former Atty Gen Mitchell approved wiretapping; says that during trial he had characterized his client as 'becoming a bit paranoid' over feelings that co‐conspirators were trying to make him 'patsy' or 'fall guy'; says that earlier this mo, when he asked Fensterwald to explain 1 of McCord's 'false allegations' Fensterwald blamed it on his client's 'faulty recollection'; Alch says Fensterwald was 'most displeased with reaction of the Repub members of this...com' when McCord 1st appeared at closed session in Mar; Fensterwald is also quoted as saying that he would submit memorandums on points in McCord's closed‐door testimony but that he did not want 'Repubs to see them'; McCord reiterates some of his charges against Alch following hearing; principal ones were that Alch helped transmit offers of exec clemency and that Alch had proposed defense that would blame Watergate operation on CIA; Alch confirms some of circumstances surrounding allegations of his former client but testifies that many of these 'have been twisted out of context into untruths'; illus of Alch
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Barker Asserts He Sought Proof of Cuba Aid to Party
response.abstract: Watergate conspirator B L Barker testifies on May 24 at Sen Watergate hearings that he broke into Dem Natl Com hq to search for proof of financial support of party by Cuban Govt but was unsuccessful; says his role in Watergate affair was ‘to obey orders, not to think'; says he and his ‘team’ hoped their participation in break‐in would speed ‘liberation of Cuba'; says, in response to question by Sen Baker, that ‘fact that the Castro Govt was aiding the Dem party had been rumored’ in Miami but that he had no hard evidence that this was true; says his prime motivation for taking part in break‐in was belief that he could later get help from co‐conspirator Hunt and ‘others in high places’ for overthrow of Castro; says he ‘personally was convinced at the time‐‐and I am today, too‐‐that what I did at the time was correct'; insists he was not under pressure to plead guilty and keep silent about Watergate scandal and that he had never been offered exec clemency in return for guilty plea; says that after his arrest he recd from Hunt's wife payments of about $45,000 or $46,000 for bail, expenses and lawyers’ fees, but says this was part of aid he expected to receive ‘if you are caught by the enemy'; A C Baldwin 3d follows Barker as witness; illus of Sen Ervin and Barker
