response.headline: NATION REGISTERS ITS FIRST SURPLUS IN TRADE SINCE '71
response.abstract: Sec Dent announces on May 24 that US foreign trade balance for Apr registered $196‐million surplus, first surplus since Sept ‘71; says exports rose by $107.5‐million, or 2%, to record $5.49‐billion while imports declined $141.4‐million, or 2.6%, to $5.29‐billion; warns it is too early to predict extent of improvement in trade balance for ‘73 as whole but says continued improvement in trade position is thought to be significant since exports are showing considerable strength and imports are turning sluggish; holds trends indicate that currency shifts of past 2 yrs are having stimulating effect on sales of US‐made goods, which are also benefiting from econ boom abroad and are dampening purchases of foreign goods; announcement by Dent comes 1 full day before scheduled release of figures, assuring Adm of possibility of 2 days of impact on stock mkt before weekend; gen view of officials and private economists is that main explanation for big improvement in trade balance is 2‐step devaluation of dollar against most of major currencies; officials say they would not be surprised if trade balance turns back to deficit in some future mos

response.headline: VOTE ON CHARTER DELAYED TILL 75

response.headline: Skylab Astronauts Set to Lift Off Today
response.abstract: 3 US astronauts complete preparations on May 24 and will be launched from Cape Kennedy on May 25 to repair over‐heated Skylab space station in effort to salvage $2.5‐billion project aimed at learning how men react to long‐duration space flights; launching is scheduled for 9 AM, and technicians are feverishly employed in stowing repair equipment aboard Apollo spacecraft; engineers are trying to find room for additional 400 pounds of gear, including new photographic film and med supplies to replace those believed to have been damaged by high temperatures, as well as new thermal shields and tools for their deployment; improvised thermal shields described; tentative flight plan calls for astronauts to fly around Skylab in Apollo command ship to inspect damage before affixing awning; launching of crew was delayed after Skylab lost thermal and micrometeroid shield during launching from Cape Kennedy and after solar panel failed to deploy; Skylab crew illus with NASA officials at Houston Space Center inspecting gear to be used in repair of spacecraft

response.headline: GRAIN DEALS’ SIZE HINTED BY SOVIET
response.abstract: official Soviet publication Foreign Trade hints for 1st time at magnitude of USSR grain imports in '72 after serious crop failure; grain purchases are believed to have insured adequate supply for staple Soviet diet; article in journal suggests that as much as 15‐million tons of grain were imported by USSR, which is about half what supplier nations had reptd for '72‐73 period; US Agr Under Sec C G Brunthaver's meeting with USSR Foreign Trade Deputy Min M R Kuzmin suggests possibility of additional grain purchases from US; Brunthaver's visit to USSR seen as preparation of an agr agreement that would be signed when Brezhnev visits US; declines to meet with Amer newsmen; disclosure of Soviet purchase seen pointing out reluctance by USSR authorities to publicize growing dependence of country on grains, capital and advanced tech; Soviet leaders evidently do not want to concede that after more than 50 yrs of planned econ development under Communist system, they find it necessary to turn for assistance to capitalist system

response.headline: THREE ASTRONAUTS REACH SKYLAB, BUT FAIL TO DEPLOY POWER WING; THEY REDOCK AFTER DIFFICULTIES
response.abstract: 3 US astronauts on May 26 are launched from Cape Kennedy for orbital rendezvous with malfunctioning Skylab space station; fail to dislodge jammed solar power wing and, after 9 attempts, finally succeed in docking with Skylab; transmit TV pictures of malfunctioning vehicle; link‐up is achieved after 3 hrs, during which crew effects changes in wiring of Skylab's docking hatch; achieves 'hard dock' by using jumper cable to bypass series of control switches and route power directly to motor that operates docking latches; Comdr Weitz fails to dislodge solar power wing using 10‐ft‐long shepherd's crook and pruning shears; radioes: 'I hate to say it, but we ain't going to do it with the tools we got'; Capt Conrad says wing appears to be 'hooked in there like its nailed in'; repts: 'Solar wing 2 was gone, completely off the bird. Wing 1 is partially deployed, a bulge of meteoroid shield holding it'; repts also that gold foil covering much of Skylab's hull, exposed because of missing thermal shield, has turned considerably black in sun; temperatures within space station have remained excessive as result of loss of thermal micrometeoroid shield during launching from Cape Kennedy and because of failure of solar power wing; crew will transfer from Apollo spacecraft to Skylab wearing face masks in event that laboratory contains noxous gases from deterioration of overheated plastic materials; hope to deploy mylar awning over space station through airlock in side of vehicle; launching of astronauts from Cape Kennedy described; scientists illus at Kennedy Space Center; Saturn 1B illus leaving launching pad; TV picture of Skylab as seen from Apollo spacecraft
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Friend of Nixon Is Identified as Backer In Purchase of Western White House
response.abstract: White House issues statement on May 25 which says that bulk of Pres Nixon's estate at San Clemente, Calif, was controlled by unnamed investment co formed by R H Abplanalp, multi‐millionaire businessman who is dose friend of Nixon; says co was formed by Abplanalp 'for the purpose of acquiring and holding' all but 5.9 acres and house on 26‐acre property and that it paid $1,249,000; Orange County, Calif, property records show no evidence that property has been legally divided; wall, paid for by Fed Govt, has been built around entire 26 acres and Nixons are only ones residing there; statement says Abplanalp aided Nixons in '69 when they bought the $1.4‐million H Cotton estate with $100,000 down payment and they were not able to find financing as expected; says at 1 point, Nixons owed Abplanalp $625,000 in personal notes; says on Dec 15 '70 Abplanalp created co and acquired and held entire property except for 5.9‐acre tract on which mansion is located; Pres and Mrs Nixon own this tract and house, subject to mortgage; background which prompted statement noted; statement raises questions about name of investment co Abplanalp organized and that White House now says owns land around Pres home in San Clemente and about whose money financed the $1,249,000 capital that statement implies is in investment co; there is question about where documents are that illustrate transactions described by White House and about who paid for improvements; illus of main house and aerial view of estate

response.headline: Prosecution Is Said to Link Haldeman and Ehrlichman To Ellsberg Case Break‐In
response.abstract: Sources close to Watergate investigation disclose on May 26 that Fed prosecutors now have evidence directly linking H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman to illegal activities against Dr D Ellsberg in '71; say that prosecutors have concluded that those activities were major factor behind decision at White House to cover up Watergate bugging yr later; theory is outlined to special Watergate prosecutor A Cox in his meeting with Fed prosecutors this wk; spokesman for Haldeman and Ehrlichman denies that 2 men participated in or covered up any criminal activities while in White House; prosecutors are known to believe that Pres Nixon's May 22 statement on Watergate cover‐up was designed, in words of 1 official, 'to provide an unbrella of natl security for Haldeman and Ehrlichman'; sources say that prosecutors' thesis is that White House participated in covering up bugging of Dems not only for pol reasons but to insure that E H Hunt Jr and G G Liddy kept silent about their role on in activities against Ellsberg

response.headline: REGIME IN GREECE SAID TO PLAN VOTE ON KING'S FUTURE
response.abstract: Athens newspapers Eleftheros Kosmos and Acropolis rept on May 27 that Greek regime has decided to hold nationwide referendum soon to allow Greeks to determine future of exiled King Constantine; deplore Constantine's refusal to condemn recent mutiny in Greek Navy and say his silence implies plot had royal blessing; Constantine reptdly has made no public statement on internal Greek matters since '68; observers in Athens assume that newspapers must have approval of Govt, since Greek newspapers print such articles with impunity; Constantine is said by close friends to favor referendum on Greek monarchy provided Govt gives foolproof safeguards for electoral fairness, lifts martial law and allows Constantine to return to conduct his own electoral campaign 'on an equal footing with his opponents'; Eleftheros Kosmos carries front page ed by publisher S Constantopoulos noting King's return to his throne or to Greece is ruled out and that people will be called upon to express their will by referendum; says King knows of this turn of events; says voters will also be asked if they favor monarchy, whether they want Constantine back at once, or if he should remain abroad for 10 yrs more while country is governed by elected substitute; also says people will be asked if Constantine's 6‐yr‐old son Paul should become king if they do not want Constantine, or should crown of Greece be offered to another dynasty; Acropolis says decision to liquidate royal question has been taken; notes move would be drastic, involving nationwide referendum; indicates this would happen sooner if judicial inquiry into naval mutiny finds that event had King's blessing; no evidence is reptd to have been produced yet to link King with abortive navy coup
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ulster Families Are Prisoners of Violence
response.abstract: R Eder article on Cath and Prot families in Belfast, N Ireland, caught in continuing violence between Brit troops and extremists; illus of Brit soldier
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Memorial Day
response.abstract: Securities exchanges and commodities markets will be closed, as will most banks and other financial institutions. Government offices, libraries and most businesses will be closed, but many department stores will be open.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 1,000 American Workers in Vietnam, Their Jobs Ended, Refuse to Go Home
response.abstract: About 1,000 Amer civilian technicians and construction workers live in Vietnam illegally; their jobs with US defense contractors were closed out recently as part of Vietnamization program, but the 1,000 do not want to go home; 7 of the men have been put in jail; Saigon police are reluctant to arrest more because those in prison have refused offers of freedom in exch for promises to leave Vietnam; US Embassy officer says they are the 'tail end of the great bonanza that began in '65 and now they don't know what to do with themselves'; their presence in Vietnam is illegal because, under the terms of their employment, 30 days after they lose their jobs they must find others with Amer defense contractors, register as ordinary Vietnamese civilians or leave the country; few have adopted alternative of becoming Vietnamese citizens because it would mean giving up benefits of high Amer wages, privileges that include profitable resale of US goods on the black mkt and exemption from Vietnamese taxes; US officials are concerned not only about the over‐all number of those staying on but about the possible trouble they can easily get into, once unemployed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ALBANY CREATES 7‐MEMBER BOARD
response.abstract: NYS Sen, 44‐14, and Assembly, 138‐0, on May 28 approve Assemblyman R R Gunning bill that will establish 7‐member NYC Bd of Educ to replace interim bd created by '69 school decentralization law; new bd members will begin 4‐yr terms on July 1, '74; 5 will be apptd by Boro Presidents and 2 by Mayor; Sen meeting illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SKYLAB COOLING; ASTRONAUTS ABLE TO INSPECT CABIN
response.abstract: temperatures aboard over‐heated Skylab space station are falling on May 27 after astronauts deploy mylar awning to replace thermal and micrometeoroid shield lost by vehicle during launching from Cape Kennedy; have fallen from 125 degrees Fahrenheit to 94 degrees; open grid flooring separating 2 levels of space station registers temperature of 105 degrees, and some of food lockers 110 and 116 degrees; engineers voice hope that temperatures will fall to normal within day; Skylab crew will attempt to repair jammed solar power wing toward end of mission when Dr Kerwin is scheduled to make 'space walk' to retrieve film from solar telescope unit; return to Apollo module for meals and sleep because of excessive heat; illus in TV pictures transmitted from space station
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BEAME IS LEADING, CANDIDATES AGREE
response.abstract: Dem mayoral candidates' campaign officials agree on May 27 that Controller Beame is in lead as campaign enters final wk; some cite polls, formal or informal, to buttress belief; workers for candidates Blumenthal, Biaggi and Badillo insist that Beame's support is 'soft' or 'weak,' that it is shaded by high percentage of voters still undecided and that it is slipping; Beame campaign dir S Terry contends 'we've got 50% of vote'; Blumenthal campaign mgr M Delguidice repts that his figures show Beame with 31% of vote and Blumenthal with 21%; Badillo press sec J Vlasto notes that campaign contributions have been pouring in since NY Times and NY Post endorsed Badillo; Biaggi pres sec M Matz contends that 'undecideds' are coming to Biaggi
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Report Brands Watergate A Low in Election Tactics
response.abstract: Fair Campaign Practices Com on May 27, in rept on '72 campaign, calls Watergate affair low point in campaign tactics since com began monitoring pol campaign activities nearly 20 yrs ago; says scandal is not simply more of same tactics which have made pol a dirty word; says 'it is a conscious conspiracy to violate laws, to manipulate voters, and to make a mockery of dem system of self‐govt'; J D Ehrlichman says that there was 'no functional relationship' between special White House unit that sought to plug natl security leaks and men involved in Watergate break‐in, ABC int; says he did not believe that there was 'anything worth going after' in Dem's Watergate offices; says he is prepared to testify before Sen Watergate com; Sen Symington says he hopes Nixon Adm's concern over natl security will not prevent it from 'giving the public all the information they have a right to know' about Watergate and other pol espionage, int, CBS program Face the Nation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Levitt Says City Overpaid $6.3‐Million on Textbooks
response.abstract: Audit by NYS Controller Levitt reveals that NYC school system may have been overcharged as much as $6.3‐million on its textbook purchases during 5‐yr period from '67‐68 through '71‐72; rept says many school dists throughout country paid lower prices for same textbooks in same yr; rept criticizes Educ Bd's purchasing practices as major reason for overcharging; Educ Bd member M Bergtraum says bd asked city's Corp Counsel to investigate Levitt's charge and will file suit immediately to recover overcharges; illus of Levitt
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ANTI‐WALLACE AID LAID TO KALMBACH
response.abstract: Informed sources disclose on May 28 that J W Dean 3d has told Watergate investigators that H W Kalmbach, Pres Nixon's former personal atty, approved spending of $200,000 to $400,000 in leftover '68 Repub campaign contributions to help defeat Gov Wallace in closely contested Dem primary in Ala in '70; Wallace, then a former Ala Gov who was widely viewed by pol strategists as pol threat to Nixon in '72 Pres election, won runoff for Dem gubernatorial nomination by 3 percentage points in June '70; defeated Gov A P Brewer, who ran ahead of Wallace in 1st primary but failed to gain majority vote; 2 Washington attys familiar with election law say that such contributions would not have violated Fed law but caution that careful check of state campaign financing law would be required before final opinion could be rendered; both Vice Pres Agnew and W M Blount, former Postmaster Gen in Nixon Adm, endorsed Brewer in bitter primary elections, which attracted natl attention; Wallace repeatedly charged that Blount was raising money for Brewer but no evidence was provided at time
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: South Africa's Course In Racism Less Certain
response.abstract: NY Times survey details S Africa's current moves to relieve pressures of apartheid, while preserving what it calls white 'identity' in predominantly black country; Govt has proclaimed that 16‐million blacks will become citizens of 9 African homelands and 650,000 Indians and 2‐million people of mixed race will achieve 'parallel development' although not in geographic homelands; Govt recently introduced bill that would give blacks qualifed legal right to strike‐right that had been withdrawn 31 yrs ago; has staged interracial sports competition; its wage board is urging review of minimum wages in more than 30 industrial categories; Afrikaner people themselves, descendants of Dutch, French Huguenot and Ger settlers who came to cape in 1600's, are becoming increasingly urbanized, prosperous and sophisticated; businessmen are demanding increasing frequency of 'rational' black labor policy that will permit them to increase productivity by greater training and use of blacks in skilled and semiskilled jobs; this will demand that urban blacks be given greater security and permanence of residence in white areas, bringing into direct conflict theory of separate development; Nationalist party's official newspaper has called petty apartheid humiliating, unjust and and held it increases racial tensions without protecting any fundamental white interests, such as pol power; main expression of black power has been wave of illegal black strikes; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Rain and High Death Toll Mar the Holiday
response.abstract: rain driven in some places by high winds washes out parades and other Memorial Day events in NYC Met Area; Natl Weather Service puts into effect tornado watch covering NYC, Westchester and Rockland Counties and northern NJ; over 30 traffic fatalities in tristate area, including at least 3 in NYC, are among natl total that reached 400 before surge of homeward bound traffic began; illus of Defense Secdesignate Schlesinger presenting wreath at Arlington Natl Cemetery and Boy Scouts in Bklyn forming color guard
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SESSION IN ALBANY ENDS WITH PASSING OF WELFARE BILL
response.abstract: NYS Legit on May 28 approves measure sought by Gov Rockefeller that prepares way for state take‐over of adm of NYC welfare system; measure creates special div within Rockefeller's office to prepare for central welfare computerization; approval of measure in closing hrs of session was accompanied by assertions from 'suspicious' city Dems that they had received assurances from Repubs that Rockefeller's new welfare div would not overrun city; bill creates special div with $1‐million budget and an adm bd of 5 appointees; div's powers and duties include submission of proposal in '74 for public corp to administer welfare
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DEAN SAID TO GET OFFER TO REDUCE POSSIBLE CHARGES
response.abstract: Sources close to Watergate case say on May 28 that Watergate prosecutors have sent J W Dean 3d a lr formally offering to permit him to plead guilty to 1 count, obstruction of justice, in return for his cooperation; 1 source says prosecutors apparently decided to send lr after recent TV appearance by Dean in which Dean declared he wanted to tell truth; Dean has recd partial immunity from Sen Watergate com and is known also to be seeking immunity from Fed prosecutors in return for his testimony; some sources say Dean will continue to seek full immunity from prosecution before cooperating; special Watergate prosecutor A Cox is reptd to be ready to name top‐level staff lawyers for his investigation of scandal; Cox's 2 temporary assts, P E Heymann and J Vorenberg, are to be officially sworn in; Sen Ervin says that com will not hear from former White House officials until about mid‐June when it expects to complete qustioning of staff members of Pres Nixon's re‐election com, telephone int; Sen Muskie accuses Pres Nixon of 'obsessive secrecy' and 'systematic deception,' speech, Hyde Park, NY; Washington Post repts on May 28 that Fed prosecutors in Watergate case have told Justice Dept that there is justification for asking Nixon to answer questions about his role, but that there is no legal basis for doing so
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mayoral Candidates Seek To Thwart Voter Apathy
response.abstract: 4 Dem mayoral candidates, although short of money, plan extensive TV ad in final wk of primary campaign to combat what their strategists believe is extraordinary voter appathy; for Repr Badillo, TV commercials will be 1st of his campaign; Badillo aides, contending that they have had influx of money into campaign as result of endorsements by NY Times and NY Post, say that will spend up to $70,000, largely on TV; Controller Beame and Repr Biaggi will resume radio and TV ads after interruption of several wks; each plans to spend about $30,000; Assemblyman Blumenthal has had extensive TV campaign because he is least known of candidates; Blumenthal campaign mgr M DelGiudice notes that total of $115,000 had been spent on media in last mo and $40,000 would be spent in last wk; asserts there is 'sense of apathy' about election, echoing other campaign mgrs; among reasons cited for apathy are preoccupation with Watergate scandal, absence of any major issue dividing candidates, shortage of campaign money, lack of colorful candidate with strong following, and failure of 1 liberal candidate to emerge in essentially liberal Dem city
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GREECE WILL TRY 35 FOR REBELLION
response.abstract: Greek regime declares on May 28 that 35 navy officers will be tried, probably on treason charges, in last wk's mutiny aboard Greek destroyer; says episode was not merely mutiny but full‐fledged attempt to overturn leadership by blackmail; Defense Min notes naval officers planned to hijack Greek fleet, occupy some unguarded Aegean islands, blockade main ports, and, after inviting army and air force to join them, ask Govt to surrender; holds plot failed and would‐be mutineers were rounded up on night of May 22 before they had time to move ships; notes only Greek destroyer Velos, which was taking part in a NATO exercise, headed for Italy, where 31 men were promised pol asylum; does not say how many ships were involved in reptd plot, but reliable informants say that 25 had been involved; min notes 32 of 35 navy officers implicated in plot were of sr rank and that men face possible death penalty on treason charges; indicates more officers had been in plot than was originally believed; says plan of insurgents was to move largest possible number of ships, which would have made rendezvous at harbor of Hermoupolis, on Syros Island; notes insurgents were to issue proclamation outlining pol targets and demanding Govt's resignation and would proceed to show force by sending small landing parties to various islands of Cyclades to bolster morale of population until demands were met; says group planned to blockade ports of Piraeus and Salonika and that fleet planned to leave for Italy if plot failed; identifies Capt G Konofaos, and retired Vice Adms C Engolfopoulos and I Mincos as alleged coup leaders; asserts that mil underground group known as Greek Antidictatorial Youth was to have engaged in sabotage and pol assassinations while navy was to stage coup; says security police disrupted this group, seizing its arms and arresting all its leaders and members
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Baseball to Washington
response.abstract: The San Diego Padres of tine National League have been sold to a Washington syndicate for $12‐million, heralding the return of major league baseball to the capital. The transaction, confirmed yesterday, is subject to approval by the club owners. Details, Page 43.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Middle‐Class Whites Still Leaving City
response.abstract: NY Times survey finds enrollment of whites of Eur descent (all whites except Puerto Ricans) continues to drop substantially in NYC public and nonpublic schools; white enrollment in city schools was 100,000 less in '71 than '66; whites have been minority in public schools since '66 and their share of total enrollment in all types of schools has dropped from 59% in '66 to 52% in '72; decline in white enrollment has outpaced decline in white births, indicating that whites continue to leave city in large numbers; tables; charts show public school enrollment by race in each city school dist, '71‐72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Crew of Skylab Confident Of a Full 28‐Day Mission
response.abstract: Skylab astronauts, in TV news conf on May 28, rept that their orbiting space station is in 'excellent shape' and that they fully expect to complete planned 28‐day mission despite high onboard temperatures and limited electricity; conduct 1st med tests by taking and processing blood samples and checking condition of their hearts and circulatory systems; Dr Kerwin notes, contrary to expectations, that it is possible to sense difference between 'up' and 'down' in zero‐gravity environment, observing that all it takes is a 'conversation' with the brain; concludes that it must therefore be possible for eyes and brain to override body's vestibular system, which is centered in inner ear and provides sense of balance; astronauts are saving fecal and urine samples for return to earth; rept special scale for weighing waste materials is not functioning properly; Comdr Weitz conducts experiment in pressure chamber to test effect of pooling of blood in legs, and pedals stationary egrometer to determine his capacity for strenuous work in zero‐gravity environment; temperatures inside space station continue to fall slowly, reaching 86 degrees Fahrenheit; flight controllers estimate atmospheric temperature in Skylab will stabilize at 75 degrees Fahrenheit
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Abbott Labs and 5 Indicted in Fluids Sale
response.abstract: Abbott Laboratories Inc and 5 of its present or former officers on May 29 are indicted by Fed grand jury in case involving sale of allegedly contaminated intravenous fluids in 70 and '71; deaths of 50 persons and illnesses of 12 others were found by Fed health authorities to be traceable to contaminated fluids from improperly sealed containers; Abbott has been charged with violations of law in connection with production of intravenous fluids in '64 and '69, but was not previously subject to criminal prosecution; co says it is 'most disappointed' with Justice Dept's decision to go ahead with criminal prosecution in latest case; also protests that none of its accused officials had been given opportunity to defend their actions during course of the investigation conducted by FDA; notes that allegedly contaminated fluids were recalled in '71 and that case is not related to current or future operations of the business; all of the contaminated vaccine was made in co's plant in Rocky Mount, NC, which was closed by FDA; indictment covers 30 different batches of several different types of solutions; co and each individual defendant were named in each of 60 counts of indictment, count of 'adulteration' and count of 'misbranding' for each of 30 batches; maximum penalty upon conviction is fine of $1,000 for each count; maximum penalty upon conviction of each official is 1 yr in jail and fine of $1,000 for each count; defendants are H M Gross, C J Endicott, R T O'Donnell, R H Otto and H W Howell; O'Donnell is no longer with co
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Current Figures Shown
response.abstract: TRENTON, May 29 — A new list of contributors to Governor Cahill's re‐election campaign made public today includes the name of E. Lawrence Bellante, the head of an engineering concern that was indicted today on charges of Federal tax fraud involving concealed donations to the Governor's 1969 election campaign.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KEY SENATE TEST WON BY WAR FOES
response.abstract: Supporters in US Sen of Nixon Adm seen prepared to filibuster against move to cut off funds for bombing in Cambodia until after H A Kissinger and Le Duc Tho meet June 5 in Paris in what is expected to be their last session of current round of truce observance talks
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kissinger Expects Talks To Strengthen Cease‐Fire
response.abstract: Kissinger says, May 29, he expects to conclude 'new understandings' with Hanoi next wk to strengthen truce accord, news conf, May 29, 1st on his talks with Le Duc Tho; says that when talks resume June 5 'we expect we will conclude them satisfactorily'; speaks mostly in generalities because of agreement with Hanoi not to make public details of the tentative agreement; stresses that current talks concern method of implementation of the accord, not renegotiation of it
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 30 Felled as Scores Flee Penn Central Tunnel Fire
response.abstract: Tens of thousands of home‐bound Penn Central commuters are stranded or delayed on May 29 after fire breaks out in engine of train stalled in Manhattan tunnel, prompting power shutdown that halts all service into and out of Grand Central Terminal; firemen fight blaze amid dense smoke for nearly 6 hrs but are unable to extinguish flames; fire is finally doused after engine is towed out of tunnel; at least 27 firemen and 3 rr employes are injured; about a dozen passengers are treated for smoke inhalation; NYC Fire Comr R Lowery says there was delay in notification of his dept about fire; train crew has been subpoenaed for hearing; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ECONOMIC GAUGES DECLINED IN APRIL
response.abstract: Sec Shultz says May 29 Nixon Adm weighs increase in Fed gasoline tax to curb gasoline consumption and act as brake on econ
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: JUSTICES BROADEN POWER OF POLICE TO HUNT EVIDENCE; Use of Fingernail Scrapings and a Car Search Are Upheld in Two Rulings; VOTES ARE 7‐2 AND 6.3; Court Also Backs Refusal of TV and Radio Stations to Accept Political Ads
response.abstract: Murphy, Daniel (Mrs): US Sup Ct on May 29 decides that it is const to take samples from under fingernails of murder suspect without warrant when he was not under arrest, had gone to police station voluntarily and had not consented to search; case involves D Murphy, who was suspected of having strangled his wife; he was convicted of 2d degree murder after scrapings from his fingernails, taken over his protest, were shown to contain traces of skin, blood and fabric of his wife's nightgown
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Princess Anne Is Engaged to an Army Lieutenant
response.abstract: Buckingham Palace on May 29 announces engagement of Princess Anne and Lt M Phillips; Anne and Phillips are expected to many in Nov; wedding is expected to take place at Westminster Abbey or at St George's Chapel, Windsor; Anne will remain 4th in line to throne, after her brother Prince Charles, heir to throne, and her younger brothers Prince Andrew and Prince Edward; palace spokesman says that Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip are 'delighted' with engagement; Phillips, member of Queens Dragoon Guards, is son of Mrs and Mrs P Phillips; Anne and Phillips met at horse events at Olympics in Mexico in '68; illus of Anne and Phillips on horseback
keywords: ANNE ELIZABETH ALICE LOUISE, PRINCESS OF EDINBURGH
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TRAFFIC IS BANNED IN 3 MAJOR PARKS PART OF EACH DAY
response.abstract: NYC Mayor Lindsay on May 29 announces that Central, Prospect and Forest Pks will be closed to motor vehicles from 10 AM to 4 PM Monday through Friday, beginning on June 5 and continuing through Sept; says excluding traffic during nonrush hrs will improve environment of pks, where 'public has been in danger of being gassed to death'; hopes that ban will discourage motorists from northern Manhattan from driving into midtown; says Police, Parks and Traffic Depts will monitor effects of closings, looking into possibility of extending hrs; Traffic Comr Ward says surveys indicate that parallel routes will not be overtaxed by rerouted off‐hour park traffic; taxi indus spokesman A Gore is 'appalled' by ban; NY Auto Club official P C Petrillo says club is taking 'wait‐and‐see' attitude
keywords: PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS AND OTHER RECREATION AREAS
PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS AND OTHER RECREATION AREAS

response.headline: Bradley Beats Yorty In Los Angeles Race
response.abstract: Los Angeles Councilman Bradley on May 29 is elected city's 1st black Mayor, scoring surprisingly solid victory over 3‐term Mayor Yorty; with 2,427 of 3,169 pcts reptg, Bradley has 324,101 votes and Yorty 260,332; Yorty, trying for unprecedented 4th term, tried to overcome apparent deficit with last‐min appeal to racial fears, a tactic he successfully employed in '69; Bradley wins nearly half of white vote and also receives more than 90% of black vote; blacks comprise about 18% of city's population; Bradley is running ahead in Mex‐Amer dists, which he lost to Yorty in their bitter battle 4 yrs ago; 65% of city's 1.2‐million voters cast ballots; Yorty fails to achieve expected margins in suburban areas; Bradley illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 1969 Race Involved
response.abstract: NEWARK, May 29 — A Federal grand jury investigating alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign today indicted two corporations on charges of filing false income tax returns.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 8 P.O.W’S CHARGED WITH MISCONDUCT
response.abstract: Col T W Guy, who was sr Amer officer in POW camp near Hanoi, charges 5 Army and 3 USMC enlisted men with misconduct while they were all held as POWs; cts‐martial charges are first formal action taken against any of the 566 POWs released earlier in yr; there is concern within both civilian and mil circles in Defense Dept that charges could end the officially promoted atmosphere of 'forgive and honor' that thus far has surrounded the POWs and lead to a period of recriminations; there are indications that some high‐ranking officials and his fellow officers sought to discourage Guy from bringing the charges; there is also doubt that his charges, reptdly based largely on hearsay and circumstantial evidence, would ever lead to trials; marines indentified as Sgt A L Kavanaugh, S/Sgt A E Riate and Pvt F L Elbert; army men are Sp/4 M P Branch, S/Sgt R P Chenoweth, S/Sgt JA Daly Jr, S/Sgt K D Rayford Jr and S/Sgt J A Young; Daly calls charges 'stupid,' TV int; Guy illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hoffa Prosecutor Named To Aid Cox on Watergate
response.abstract: J F Neal has joined staff of special Fed prosecutor in Watergate case; informed sources say Neal has been assigned to master all information that Govt investigators have gathered up to now and to rept to special prosecutor A Cox; official Justice Dept statement says Neal will 'be working with team of E J Silbert, D E Campbell and S Glanzer of US Atty's office'; there is speculation that 1 of Neal's functions will be to rev work of these 3 men and to advise Cox on whether they should be retained; Neal career sketch and illus; White House says on May 29 that Pres Nixon will not testify, either orally or in writing, to either grand jury or Sen Watergate com; CBS News repts that R C McCandless, atty for J W Dean 3d, said that his client will turn down offer from Watergate prosecutors that he plead guilty to only 1 felony count—that of obstruction of justice—in return for his testimony about Watergate case; quotes McCandless as saying that 'the only deal will be for total immunity from prosecution'; Judge Sirica issues order granting ltd immunity from prosecution to R M Sheppard, deliveryman who allegedly was hired to haul away 8 cartons of documents from White House immediately after Watergate break‐in
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CANER RECALL TRUCE OBSERVERS WITHIN 60 DAYS
response.abstract: Canadian Govt announces, May 29, it has decided to bring its cease‐fire observers home within 60 days; says they are not being permitted to do their job properly; Canada's decision grows out of series of frustrations that began before the cease‐fire was signed on Jan 27; Sec Sharp tells Commons that Canada does not criticize the truce accord but only the fact that the parties are not applying it; says, at news conf, that he discussed Canada's decision in a phone talk with H A Kissinger and there was 'no strong pressure' exerted on Canada to stay on the control comm; says he has heard, secondhand, of one country that may be willing to take Canada's place on the comm, but declines to identify it
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stock Prices Plunge
response.abstract: The stock market declined sharply again yesterday. The Dow‐Jones industrial average plurfged 16.70 points, its third largest drop this year, and closed at 908.87. The selling apparently came in response to renewed pressure on the dollar in European currency markets. At the same time, the price of gold rose to new highs in London and Zurich. Details, Page 59.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: COLLEGE CONTROLS SET IN ARGENTINA
response.abstract: new Peronist Govt of Pres Campora takes control of natl univs in Argentina, appoints special trustees who will have ultimate power in all adm and ideological questions on campuses; Govt also endorses left‐leaning educ programs for 19 natl univs in which two‐thirds of country's college students are enrolled; moves bring no protests, in sharp contrast to student riots in '66 when mil regime took control of country; during former dictator J Peron's regime many professors quit univs in protest against ideological pressure from Govt; Pres Campora emphasizes that natl univs must become institutions able to grapple with country's pressing social and econ problems
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Survey Urges an Overhaul of Court Procedure Here
response.abstract: Repts on NYC juries, part of series prepared for presiding justices of NYC Appellate Div and released at May 30 news conf, call for letting 18‐yr‐olds serve and on ending women's right to be excused on request; note preliminary findings that juries do not conform to adult population as whole, repting 87.8% of all jurors are men and about half are between 41 and 60 yrs old; urge judges select jurors and weigh proposal to have 6‐member rather than 12‐member juries in felony trials; proposal for juror's manual to explain reasons for mury duty and ct procedures for jury selection is already being implemented; C K Simon headed subcom that prepared repts
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Saigon's Economy, in Trouble, Awaits Added Help From U.S.
response.abstract: article on deteriorating S Vietnamese econ situation; heart of problem is sharp reduction in US mil spending, gradual decline in US econ aid and a continued high level of imports
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: EHRLICHMAN SAYS NIXON SOON KNEW OF MEXICO INQUIRY
response.abstract: J D Ehrlichman, former chief domestic adviser to Pres Nixon, tells Sen subcom that Pres Nixon knew 6 days after Watergate break‐in that Fed agents were investigating 'Mex aspects' of case; several Sens say they feel Ehrlichman was referring to transfer of $89,000 through Mex City bank that ended up in hands of Watergate burglars, money which came from Pres's re‐elect com; Ehrlichman says Nixon was worried that investigation of Watergate break‐in might expose covert intelligence operations being conducted by CIA in Mex; says that is why Nixon had him and H R Haldeman, former White House chief of staff, meet with CIA officials and ask them to tell FBI to call off investigation in Mex if Nixon's fear was true; says Gen V Walters, then deputy to former CIA dir R Helms, reptd that no CIA operation in Mex would be imperiled by FBI investigation, but that Nixon did not believe Walters; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SPEED ON INQUIRY URGED BY AGNEW
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, May 30—Vice President Agnew said today that the facts in the Watergate conspiracy case should be “dredged” into the open quickly so that the nation, and the Republican party, could “get it over with.”
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Victor Over Yorty Sees Further Gains
response.abstract: Los Angeles Mayor‐elect Bradley holds on May 30 that his victory could help open 'new thrust' of black leadership into electoral pol, news conf; contends outcome proves that voters will listen to candidate and make judgments on merit rather than race or creed; with all but 1 pct reptg, Bradley has 431,222 votes and Yorty 334,297; Yorty's defeat probably marks end of his long, tempestuous and often frustrating career; Bradley had openly expressed dislike for Yorty and his campaign tactics; ran particularly strong in liberal Jewish dists on west side; some pol observers caution about 'misreading' natl implications into result; note Bradley is unusual politician and Los Angeles unusual city; campaign revd; Bradley hired D Garth to handle media campaign, which sought to portray Bradley as reasonable and responsible black; displayed considerable poise and self‐confidence during campaign; stressed his role as policeman; took strong stand in support of environmental protection; Bradley and Yorty illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MAFIOSO INDICTED AS TOP LOAN SHARK
response.abstract: A Salerno, reptdly among most powerful Mafia figures in NYC met area, on May 30 is indicted on charges involving multimillion‐dollar loan‐shark ring;Dist Atty Hogan's office tells NYS Sup Ct Justice J B Grumet that Salerno 'controls organized loan‐sharking and gambling in NY and Fla'; indictment describes loan‐shark operation that had $80‐million in outstanding loans 'on the st' in 1 day and lent money at interest rate of 3% a wk or 156% yrly; Hogan says such loan shark operations not only harm victims, but are threat to soc because tremendous power and 'huge profits' of operation finance much of the criminal activities of underworld and give wedge into legitimate business; Salerno is charged with 11 counts of criminal usury, 1 count of conspiracy and another of criminal solicitation for allegedly telling associate to break delinquent borrower's leg; pleads not guilty and is held in $35,000 bond, which he posted; investigation, conducted by Asst Dist Atty Fine with help of Chief Asst Dist Atty A J Scotti and prosecutor A Campriello, began in '70 when police impounded abandoned, stolen car and found stacks of small‐time loan‐shark records in back seat; probe led to Salerno's arrest; if convicted, he could receive 46 yrs in prison; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Break‐In by F.B.I. Alleged Before 1969 Inauguration
response.abstract: 2 former Army intlligence operatives say on May 30 that FBI agents broke into offices of radical newspaper Washington Free Press, Washingon, DC, without search warrant shortly before Pres Nixon's inauguration in '69 in attempt to find evidence of overseas Communist influence

response.headline: BONN AND PRAGUE REACH AN ACCORD
response.abstract: Negotiations are completed between W Ger and Czech on May 30 on treaty to establish normal relations, ending 35 yrs of hostility; joint communique says accord will be initialed in Bonn in June; formal signing is expected to take place shortly afterward in Prague; W Ger Foreign Min repts that issue revolving around Munich Pact has been settled in manner satisfactory to both sides but does not elaborate; treaty is expected to lead to establishment of full diplomatic relations

response.headline: HALDEMAN DENIES ROLE IN COVER‐UP; CONFLICT WIDENS
response.abstract: June 1-15: ex-White House aide H R Haldeman denies 'categorically' on May 31 before Sen Appropriations Subcom on Intelligence Operations that he participated in Watergate cover-up; disputes earlier testimony by CIA Deputy Dir Walters that he had instructed Walters to try to get FBI to stop investigating certain aspects of Watergate affair; Sen Pastore, after hearing Haldeman's testimony, complains of 'glaring inconsistencies' between testimony of Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman on 1 hand and that of Gens Walters and Cushman on other; 2 basic points of conflict are over what was said at a June 23 White House meeting that was called on Pres Nixon's orders and over source of instructions to Walters to provide assistance to Watergate conspirator E H Hunt Jr; Haldeman says 'I can categorically state...that at no time nor in any way did I suggest, direct or participate in any cover-up of the Watergate Investigation,' statement to newsmen following testimony before subcom; says he never asked CIA to participate in any Watergate cover-up and never suggested that CIA take any responsibility for break-in; Sens Pastore and McClellan point out direct conflict between statements of Haldeman and those of Walters; Walters has testified that he was ordered by Haldeman to try to get FBI to stop investigating Mexican aspects of Watergate case; Haldeman says Walters was asked to meet with then-FBI Acting Dir Gray to insure that any unrelated covert operations of CIA or any unrelated natl security activities had been previously undertaken by some of Watergate principals not be compromised in process of Watergate investigation and attendant publicity and pol furor; says this was done with 'no intent or desire to impede or cover up any aspect of Watergate investigation itself; McClellan says he cannot understand why, if their stories were accurate, Haldeman and Ehrlichman did not simply ask then-CIA Dir Helms whether CIA operations would be endangered; also questions why, if purpose of meeting was 'to get the 2 agencies together, Gray was not invited to be present so they could have them all there'; Sen Hruska says Haldeman told subcom that Gray was not invited because there could have been 'high-level discussions' about secret CIA affairs that Gray should not have known about'; Haldeman suggests that ex-White House counsel Dean 1st suggested possibility of CIA involvement in Watergate burglary and that it was because of Dean's suggestion that meeting was called with Helms and Walters; illus of Cushman, Haldeman and Haldeman's atty F Strickler
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon and Pompidou Fail To Resolve Major Issues
response.abstract: Nixon and Pompidou conf for nearly 5 hrs in Reykjavik, Iceland, May 31, but fail to narrow significantly questions that divide France and US on US-W Eur relations; Kissinger, for US, and D Baudoin, for France, reveal divergencies during their news briefings on conf; divergencies also revealed in Nixon and Pompidou toasts at state dinner; revolve around French desire for discussion of specifics and US desire to put talks in broad context; Kissinger says a summit conf is possible during Nixon's Eur tour in Oct, but French officials see no possibility for early meeting; Kissinger goes to some lengths to allay Eur fears of Amer domination; says US is not going to hand Eurs and Amer blueprint
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Banker Here Pleads No Contest To Charge He Hid Political Aid
response.abstract: J L Loeb, sr partner of Loeb Rhoades & Co, on Apr 30 pleads no contest in Fed ct to 3 charges of having disguised campaign contributions to Sen H H Humphrey's '72 Pres campaign totaling $48,000; tells Fed Judge J M Cannella that he felt it would be 'unfair' to subject his family and friends to ordeal of trial; will be sentenced on June 7 and could receive $1,000 fine and 1 yr's imprisonment on each count; Loeb's atty W D Scott says Loeb was asked by Sen Humphrey to help provide urgently needed funds to aid Humphrey's Calif primary campaign; says Loeb agreed and spoke to Humphrey's counsel J Chestnut with respect to mechanics of contributions; says Loeb asked aide A Griffiths to find some employes at Loeb Rhoades & Co who supported Humphrey and would contribute to his campaign; 9 employes agreed and were told that Loeb would reimburse them; Humphrey aide B Solomonson personally picked up checks from Loeb on May 12, '72; facts about contributions began to emerge in '72 after Humphrey Com filed preliminary repts on May 24, '72 of receipts and expenses; reporters' curiosities were aroused when they found that 9 loeb contributors' addresses were listed as addresses of their banks because com evidently did not have their home addresses; Scott said that Loeb was 'unaware' of law's requirements and had 'responded to the call of an old friend'; Asst US Atty J J Tigue Jr says that Govt's position is that it has 'indiputable' proof that Loeb knew exactly what law was regarding disclosure of campaign contributions; says this had been determined through int with Loeb and through documentary evidence
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Bar Group Backs Hogan, Rules Out vanden Heuvel
response.abstract: NYC Bar Assn gives Manhattan Dem Dist Atty aspirant W J vanden Heuvel lowest rating, 'not approved,' while bestowing rarely-used highest rating on incumbent Hogan, 'approved as highly qualified and preferred'; gives no explanation; vanden Heuvel por; exec sec P De Witt makes announcement after assn exec com holds 7-hr meeting considering earlier ratings by judiciary com; repts exec com member A J Scotti disqualified himself because he is Hogan aide; vanden Heuvel, at earlier news conf, presents 2 crime victims to dramatize charge that crime victims are often victimized by justice system; Hogan issues statements demanding immediate destruction of dangerous drugs seized by authorities and proposing to limit immunity granted public officials in ct cases
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Farm Prices Climb
response.abstract: The Administration's hopes of reducing inflation received a setback yesterday as the Department of Agriculture reported that farm prices, after dipping in April, re sumed their sharp rise in May. Prices received by farm ers in the month to May 15 were up 33 per cent from a year earlier. Details, Page 47.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pact on Public TV Control Reached, Ending Dispute
response.abstract: Public Broadcasting Corp (PBC) and Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) on May 31 approve agreement to end their long battle over control of public TV and program decision-making; PBS wins one of its key goals, assurance that its programs not financed by PBC will have access to network linking nation's public TV stations; PBC chmn Dr J Killian Jr hails agreement as ushering in 'new era in public TV'; terms of agreement are unanimously approved by PBC dirs bd, meeting in Boston, and PBS govs bd, meeting in Dallas; agreement ends over 6 mos of intense negotiations between 2 groups; Ford Foundation TV consultant F Friendly says agreement is 'big and vital step forward'; says foundation is now in position to receive official grant requests; agreement reaffirms that 'public affairs programs are essential responsibility of public broadcasting'; pledges PBS and PBC will work jointly for longe-range financing of public broadcasting that will 'remove it from pol hazards of annual authorization and appropriations'; agreeement detailed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: COAST FINANCIER ACCUSED BY S.E.C, OF MASSIVE FRAUD
response.abstract: SEC on May 31 charges C A Smith, long-time confidant of Pres Nixon, with massive fraudulent manipulation designed to misappropriate assets of Westgate-Calif Corp, complaint filed in San Diego Fed Dist Ct; asks Smith, along with assocs P A Toft and M J Coen, Westgate-Calif and 4 subsidiaries be enjoined from continuing alleged schemes; asks ct to appt receiver to take over Westgate, to make full investigation and acctg into its financial affairs; alleges Smith, as chmn and chief exec officer of Westgate as well as of US Natl Bank, arranged sale of co's assets to various defendants or their nominees 'at bargain prices' and that purchases were made with loans from bank approved by Smith; alleges bank in turn accepted purchased assets as collateral on loans; charges defendants, to camouflage their fraudulent appropriation of Westgate and US Natl Bank assets, created ostensible profits for these entities and published misleading statements concerning their activities; other charges detailed; Currency Controller announces bank and Smith consented to cease and desist order requiring orderly collection of loans presently held by banks; adds Smith has agreed to indemnify bank against losses in connection with loans
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ACCORD REACHED IN PATH DISPUTE
response.abstract: PATH line and representatives of 214 Ry Carmen on May 31 reach tentative accord on terms for settling 61-day-old strike; trains to resume operation on June 3 if pact is approved by Carmen and Port Authority of NY and NJ; details of agreement are not disclosed; strike issues revd

response.headline: U.S. Reported Optimistic On a Cambodian Truce
response.abstract: S Vietnamese officials rept that US and N Vietnam, during latest round of Paris peace talks, agreed to sequence of steps to be taken in new effort to carry out cease-fire in S Vietnam fully; rept that US and N Vietnam have decided to issue communique after resumption of talks next wk, with or without concurrence of partners; US officials concede that new agreement does not go beyond original Paris accord signed in Jan, acknowledge that negotiators do not appear to have devised means of insuring that it will be any more effective; N Vietnamese reptdly have agreed to reduce support for Cambodian rebels and urge new cooperation on Vietcong in exch for resumption of US minesweeping in North and revival of talks with US on postwar econ aid; US reptdly will halt reconnaissance flights over N Vietnam; other reptd measures discussed in new accord detailed

response.headline: Recordings Indicate Penn Central Delay In Calling Firemen
response.abstract: Conversation taped by Fire Dept between dept dispatcher and Penn Central supervisor on May 29 reveals, May 31, that some rr officials were aware of fire in train stalled in NYC tunnel but delayed notifying dept for at least 75 mins; Penn Central employe told dept dispatcher that he had been trying to get through to rr dispatchers but they claimed rr did not need Fire Dept aid; Fire Comr Lowery says this conversation, initiated by Fire Dept dispatcher, was 1st contact between fire officials and rr; says his dept has held practice drills to train Penn Central employes in methods of dealing with tunnel fires, but such training was ignored by train crew in May 29 incident; casualties revd; excerpts from taped conversation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Freighter Rams Tanker in Narrows, Setting Off Explosions and Fire
response.abstract: Esso Brussels (Tanker) and Sea Witch (Containership): Amer Export containership Sea Witch rams tanker Esso Brussels on June 2 near Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, Bklyn, triggering series of explosions, fires and causing deaths of at least 5 persons and injuries to 34; seaman B Lopez repts he observed smoke and flames that extended 75 ft above upper roadway as he approached SI tower of bridge in his car; adds taut anchor chain extended from tanker which appeared to have been rammed in starboard side, spilling oil over 150-ft area; firemen rept continuous explosions occurred on vessels which remained locked together, drifting toward bridge; undergirding of bridge is scorched by flames, leading to speculation that steel superstructure may have been weakened by heat; police sgt repts rescue of 14 survivors by fireboats, USCG vessels and tugboat G MacAllister; notes that between 50 and 100 men remain unaccounted for; says loud explosions, fire and bright search lights trained on area attracted large crowds of spectators, and that motorists who abandoned cars on bridge after sighting fire were responsible for massive traffic jam; illus of burning ships as seen from Bklyn

response.headline: ‘Ex‐Security Agent’ Is Called Swindler
response.abstract: San Francisco clothing mfr, Paul Maris Co, charges that its former pres misrepresented himself under alias of P Maris as mil security expert when he was confessed stock swindler; co, which has filed complaints against Maris, believes his real name to be G M Zelmanowitz; co atty W Trautman says conversations with Justice Dept officials left 'no doubt' that ousted pres was being guarded by Fed marshals to prevent Mafia reprisals because he had testified for Govt in '70 trial of A De Carlo, reputed Mafia leader

response.headline: NIXON, POMPIDOU CONCLUDE TALKS; SOME GAINS SEEN
response.abstract: Nixon and Pompidou end talks in Iceland June 1 with no concrete agreements; Nixon had hoped to persuade French to accept idea of new declaration of Atlantic principles, perhaps even formal 'charter,' as outlined by Kissinger Apr 23, but this is deferred pending detailed talks on certain concrete issues by subordinates; French also poured cold water on Nixon's hopes for a Eur summit meeting during his trip this fall; Amers, on other hand, may have moved French closer to more active participation in Atlantic diplomacy

response.headline: Bill Easing Divorce Law Passed in Rush in Albany
response.abstract: NYS Legis passes bill abolishing 90-day period of conciliation which is mandatory under state's 6-yr-old liberalized divorce law; spokesman for Gov Rockefeller says he does not know if Gov will sign or veto bill; measure, sponsored by State Sen R M Goodman and Assemblyman T J Murphy, would dissolve network of State Conciliation Bureaus and make it easier to obtain a divorce; critics say bureaus have had little success in reconciling broken marriages; C Tobin, sec of NYS Catholic Com and legis lobbyist for RC Ch, denounces passage of bill, saying 'it's almost incomprehensible' that legis will not appropriate $1-million to run bureaus 'to save families' when hundreds of millions are spent 'to pick up pieces in family dissolution' through welfare and other programs

response.headline: VALUE OF DOLLAR SLUMPS AS GOLD SOARS IN EUROPE
response.abstract: Arab oil producers reptdly are selling dollars on Eur money mkts to bolster their negotiating position at forthcoming talks with Western cos in Geneva on oil prices; danger Arabs will keep dumping dollars to force price increases noted

response.headline: Vanden Heuvel's Rating by Bar Is Laid to His ‘Lack of Candor’
response.abstract: Bar Assn rating of vanden Heuvel as not approved reptdly based on his 'lack of candor' with assn and 'lack of experience' in criminal cts; vanden Heuvel reptdly wrote on assn questionnaire that he was partner in Sen Javits law firm from '59 to '62, whereas firm partner C R Bergoffen says he was only an associate; vanden Heuvel calls NY Times to assert he was partner, then says he had been offered partnership but left to run for Cong in '60; M N Nessen, his atty before assn, declines comment; assn also reptdly questioned vanden Heuvel's filing of brief as atty for St George's Episc School and other insts in case of S L Birnbaum, millionaire accountant who was donator and who was convicted of bribing tax agent in '63; details on that case; Mayor Lindsay statement gives high praise to Hogan

response.headline: ‘Unused’ Spy Plan Under F.B.I. Study
response.abstract: FBI is looking into possibility that elements of Nixon Adm's master plan for domestic intelligence gathering were put into operation despite Pres Nixon's assurance that proposal 'never went into effect'; Nixon acknowledged existence of so-called '1970 intelligence plan' in long statement last wk on several aspects of Watergate case; disclosed at 1 point that 'unused' intelligence program included provisions for 'surreptitious entry' by Fed agents in course of natl security investigations; FBI is now examining copy of secret intelligence program as are investigators for Sen Watergate com; Sens recd their copy of document from J W Dean 3 who removed it from White House shortly before his Apr 30 dismissal as Nixon's counsel; Sen Ervin says on May 31 that he has seen plan and that its contents would be 'great shock to the Amer people' if it were released
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MONARCHY ENDED AS GREEK REGIME SETS UP REPUBLIC
response.abstract: Premier Papadopoulos announces abolition of monarchy on June 1 and proclaims Greece a 'presidential parliamentary repub,' radio speech; says Greece will have chance to approve changes in referendum some time before July 29 and promises that gen elections will be held by end of yr; calls monarchy 'an outdated left-over of past ages' and charges King Constantine 'brought it all on himself; says Constantine indulged abroad in activities 'that betrayed an unpardonable immaturity for a person of his age'; holds Constantine collaborated with reactionaries of all descriptions despite repeated warnings from Govt; charges Constantine behaved both openly and behind scenes as faction leader of adventurers, bankrupts, fellow travelers, saboteurs and murderers; says he organized, through coordinated pol, conspiratorical and seditious activities, new coup against revolution, 'against the peace of the people', in abortive mutiny by members of Greek Navy; Papadopoulos is apptd Provisional Pres of the Repub and will continue to carry out his duties as Premier; illus; police in Athens are put on special alert, but city remains calm; Cabinet, in issuing decree, says actions were taken because of 'manifest opposition of great majority of people in maintenance in Greece of the regime of crown democracy'; notes emblem of crown will be replaced by symbol of '67 revolution; all pictures of Constantine and Queen Anne-Marie are removed from walls of Govt bldgs; Defense Min issues detailed statement linking doomed naval coup to King and to former Premier C Caramanlis; says 'insurgents' made contact with Caramanlis in Mar, told him of plot and proposed he take over as premier; holds Caramanlis agreed if insurgents were serious; charges King agreed and in Apr word was passed to naval officers of Caramanlis-Constantine pact but that Capt G Konofaos began having serious doubts about chances of success between May 5 and 10; repts that Rear Adm A Rozakis was asked on May 17 by leaders of plot to carry his doubts about it to Constantine and find out whether plotters should proceed; adds that Constantine 'decided' it should be carried out as planned; Gen O Anghelis charges Constantine attemped 'for second time to throw nation's armed forces into a fraticidal civil war,' radio broadcast; 1 result of abolition of monarchy will be to deprive Constantine of allowance of $15,000 a mo he has received during his time in exile; Constantine illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: EX‐MACKELL AIDE INDICTED IN BRIBE
response.abstract: J N Monty, chief rackets investigator in Queens for last 6 1/2 yrs, has been indicted on charges of extortion, bribery and conspiracy for allegedly taking more than $4,500 in cash and services from Avis Rent-a-Car System; Monty in return, according to indictment announced on June 1, did variety of favors for Avis, such as threatening customer with criminal prosecution unless he paid bill, acting as 'collection agency' and making illegal checks to determine whether prospective employes had arrest records; indictment against Monty was voted May 31 by special grand jury empaneled by NYS anticorruption prosecutor Nadjari; charge that Monty had accepted free cars from Avis while directing criminal investigation that benefited Avis was made initially by State Sen R J Marino, Sen Crime Com chmn; com developed evidence that 3 other employes in former Dist Atty Mackell's office, in addition to Monty, had been granted free use of cars by Avis; one was D J McKeon, Asst Dist Atty who presented case benefiting Avis to Queens grand jury; Asst Deputy Atty Gen S Sawyer, at brief news conf announcing Monty's indictment, is extremely cautious about discussing possible future directions of Avis case; is in charge of investigations for Queens; Monty illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Brezhnev Pledge On Jews Reported Given to Kissinger
response.abstract: Jewish orgn officials and diplomatic sources rept on June 1 that Brezhnev told Nixon adviser H A Kissinger in May that USSR would permit Jews to emigrate at current rate of 36,000 to 40,000 a yr and that educ tax on emigration would remain suspended; says Brezhnev accepted from Kissinger list of about 1,000 'hardship' cases, including 42 Jews imprisoned on charges relating to their efforts to go to Israel, and said he would look into their cases; list of hardship cases was compiled by Amer Jewish groups and given to Kissinger in unpublicized meeting before Kissinger went to Moscow in early May; leaders of Jewish orgns who were informed of talks attach importance to Brezhnev's acceptance of list of hardship cases
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Budget Deficit Cut Again By EDWIN L. DALE Jr.
response.abstract: Fed Govt adds $3-billion more on June 1 to its estimate of tax collections in forthcoming fiscal yr, and correspondingly reduces its estimate of budget deficit to $2.7-billion, reason being inflationary boom, which increases incomes and profits and hence tax receipts

response.headline: Factory Hours Off in May
response.abstract: Chmn Stein, commenting on June 1 on small increase in number of available jobs in May, says this constitutes another piece of evidence that growth in econ has at least subsided from unsustainable and highly inflationary rate of previous mos

response.headline: Effect of Senate's Inquiry On Future Trials Studied
response.abstract: staff of Sen com probing Watergate scandal studies possible effects of full-scale com hearings on criminal trials growing out of case in wake of chief counsel S Dash informal May 30 meeting with special prosecutor A Cox, during which matter was discussed; Cox, Dash and Cox's aide J Vorenberg, who attended meeting, deny Washington Post June 1 rept that Cox asked for halt to Sen hearings to bar interference with criminal prosecution; Cox says talks were preliminary exploration of relationships between com and his probe; says they discussed immunity for witnesses; com staff members comment; Cox illus

response.headline: Saigon Soldiers Openly Abuse Civilians
response.abstract: S Vietnamese army's arrogance toward civilians seems to be becoming increasingly blatant with departure of last US mil advisers from field; US Embassy is particularly concerned about misbehavior, which for yrs has alienated popular support for Saigon govt; abuse of civilians has continued to flourish despite gen improvement in army's combat ability; conduct seems to vary greatly from 1 region to another; worst area is that from Bong Son up along Route 1 into Quang Ngai Prov, territory garrisoned by 2d and 22d Divs, 2 of least disciplined and least distinguished units; map; habit of extorting money from civilians is matter of economics, since pay is low; corruption and abuse of civilians exists in Binh Dinh on large scale, where refugees have not recd rice and tin roofing allowances
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: IB.M.'s Methods
response.abstract: Article discusses IBM's methods of maintaining dominance in computer mkt by tracing history of System 360 computers as revealed in memos used by Control Data Corp in its antitrust suit against IBM; Control Data contended in its case, which was settled out of ct, that IBM deliberately announced 360 line more than a yr ahead of schedule, well before all tech testing was completed, because it did not want customers to select new computers already announced by competitors; memos cited to support Control Data's charges may be used by Justice Dept in its own antitrust suit against IBM; dept hopes to prove under Sherman Act that IBM actually 'monopolizes' computer indus, with 65% share of $8.9-billion worth of computers manufactured by Amer concerns in '72, and that it actively seeks its dominant position; under recent interpretations of act cos that achieve dominance as result of 'superior product, business acumen or historic accident' are not considered to have violated antitrust law; unless it proves that IBM deliberately set out to stifle competition, dept apparently can prevail only by convincing Supreme Ct to broaden Sherman Act's coverage; illus of IBM/360 model
keywords: DATA PROCESSING (INFORMATION PROCESSING) EQUIPMENT AND SYSTEMS
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kodak and the Lilliputians
response.abstract: Article on 3 private antitrust suits filed by GAF Corp, Berkey Photo and Bell & Howell against Eastman Kodak; suits ask triple damages from Kodak and various divestitures to moderate co's influence in sale of photographic equipment, supplies and services; Kodak dominates or significantly influences most aspects of domestic amateur, commercial and indus photography; illus; graph of co earnings
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KROGH DISPUTED
response.abstract: Justice Dept sources rept on June 2 that former White House aide E Krogh Jr in sworn statement said that contrary to assertions FBI had knowledge in late June,'71, that Soviet Govt did not possess Pentagon papers before they were published by N Y Times; rept that although bulk of Pentagon papers were mysteriously delivered to Soviet Embassy in Washington, they did not arrive until after Times printed its 1st 3 installments and had been placed under temporary ct order to halt further publication; Krogh, in affidavit submitted in May at Los Angeles trial of D Ellsberg, saids that he approved burglary at office of Ellsberg's former psychiatrist Dr L J Fielding as part of White House investigation into unauthorized disclosure of documents; testifies that among other factors that led him to authorize illegal break-in was rept from FBI that Pentagon papers were in possession of Soviet Embassy in Washington prior to their publication by Times; said that authorization to engage in covert activity to obtain 'psychology history' of Ellsberg was recd from former Pres adviser J D Ehrlichman and that plans for acquiring information were developed by G G Liddy and E H Hunt Jr; Krogh illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.abstract: “Hard footsteps follow you home at night. A knife at your throat, a jab in your stomach, your purse or wal let gone and it's over. You're another statistic in the war we could lose— the against the criminal.”

response.headline: Florida's Accessible Billionaire
response.abstract: Article on success of Fla real estate developer J D MacArthur, who has built real estate fortune in Fla during last 18 yrs; discusses his encounter with conservationists, who he claims are 'forcing him' out of Fla; MacArthur's Fla cos are Royal Amer Industries and Southern Realty and Utility Co; illus

response.headline: A ‘Money Machine’ Attracts Investors
response.abstract: Real estate leaders see growing popularity of condominiums as boon to their business; builders of condominiums have financial advantages over builders of rental bldgs; since condominium units are sold individually, the sum of their prices is significantly larger than the price of a rental bldg sold to an investor; condominium developers are also able to get construction loans as high as 80% of sellout price; much of available money is in real estate investment trusts which are willing to lend condominium builders all of development costs, with builder usually keeping all the profits; some builders still prefer rental properties because they provide steady long-term income and depreciation deduction for tax purposes but market considerations are important and rising construction costs have pushed rents and house prices beyond means of many; condominium serves as workable compromise
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Jersey
response.abstract: charges of corruption that have turned NJ Repub gubernatorial primary into 'nightmare' for Gov Cahill and his opponent US Repr C W Sandman Jr show no signs of easing; during wk of May 28 more Fed indictments against heavy contributors to Cahill's '69 campaign were issued as well as embarrassing disclosure by Cahill that E L Bellante, whose Penna firm was recently awarded fat contract by NJ Sports and Exposition Authority and was 1 of cos indicted for income tax fraud, was major contributor again this yr; Sandman admits that he recd financial help from H Orman, reputed 'kingpin' of organized crime in Atlantic City; also discloses that another contributor M J Stavola was convicted briber who also was implicated in income tax conspiracy involving Cahill's '69 election campaign; Cahill, who less than 6 mos ago was favored to win renomination and re-election, is now faced with prospect that Sandman will win nomination and that B T Byrne, favorite in Dem gubernatorial primary, will be able to defeat either Cahill or Sandman in Nov election; Cahill supporters are counting heavily on fact that primary defeat for incumbent Gov is still relatively rare event, but spread of original scandal involving former Sec of State and close Cahill pol adviser P J Sherwin, who was convicted on charges of attempting to fix state hwy contract in return for pol campaign kickback, to former State Treas J M McCrane Jr and Repub leader N G Gross may very well have undermined Cahill's chances of victory; McCrane and Gross have been charged with masterminding income tax fraud in which heavy contributors to Cahill's '69 campaign allegedly wrote money off on their income tax returns as business expenses; Cahill cartoon
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.
