response.headline: Delay in Paris Agreement Laid to Saigon Objections
response.abstract: Kissinger and Le Duc Tho decide to break off their talks in Paris on June 10 for few days when 'it became clear' that they could not quickly resolve last-min reservations raised by S Vietnam to proposed document on strengthening Vietnam cease-fire agreement; talks are due to resume this wk after Kissinger returns to Paris; Kissinger speaks by phone with Pres Nixon; officials are reluctant to criticize Pres Thieu publicly because of delicate US relationship with S Vietnamese Govt but privately they indicate that his last-min reservations are not well-founded; Adm official says new document being worked out now is not new agreement but series of procedures to put into effect more satisfactorily what has already been agreed upon
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Home Costs Rise 91.7% in 20 Years, Outstripped Only by Service Industry By BILL KOVACH
response.abstract: Survey by BLS shows home costs have nearly doubled during yrs between 1952 and 1972 in almost all areas of US; cost of home ownership during that period is up 91.7%; nati housing market, under combined pressures of inflated material costs, scarce land, increased number of home seekers and lack of natl planning, is becoming critical problem for nation; situation reviewed for New York, Miami, Chicago, Raleigh, NC, and Los Angeles; Natl Assn of Home Builders repts that in decade 1960-70, total inventory of houses increased by 10.3-million but during same yrs, masses of children born in early postwar yrs were entering house-hunting phase and most recent estimate by assn is that only 1% of existing housing stock is vacant and available for sale; M Sumichrast, chief economist of home bldrs assn, says land is most important factor; environmental pressures have increased cost of land and land development; radical changes in Govt policy under Nixon Adm have aggravated situation; wage-price controls disrupt market and moratorium on subsidized housing has cut deeply into production of housing for poor; since 1970 number of subsidized housing units has dropped from 433,300 to fewer than 300,000 in 1972 and decline is continuing
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Rising Bangladesh Unrest Marked by 2,000 Killings
response.abstract: Pol murders, communal unrest and armed terrorism are afflicting Bangladesh; militant labor and youth wings of governing Awami League have begun 'purification drive' against what they call corrupt and pro-Pakistani elements; opposition parties say that drive is aimed solely at crushing anti-Govt forces; have taken radical, anti-Indian stand; assert that Bangladesh is in convulsive mood, propelled by discontent and econ distress; 2 key radical figures have emerged to oppose Awami League; 1 is 91-yr-old M Bhashani, who furiously attacks India as 'our greatest enemy'; Bhashani represents anti-Hinduism that simmers in Bangladesh; 2d, and possibly more threatening anti-Govt figure, is Maj M A Jalil, guerrilla comdr who broke away from Awami League and helped organize opposition Natl Soc party; Jalil predicts that Bengalis will revolt because they are not being fed, there are no jobs and corruption is everywhere; pol killings reptdly have reached 2,000 since Dec '71 when Bangladesh achieved independence; 1,500 victims were Awami League workers; volatile mood of Bangladesh is underlined by paramilitary groups that have emerged within Awami League; another evolving force within Govt is Awami Jubo or Youth League, whose pres is Sheik F H Moni, nephew and close advisor of Prime Min Sheidk Mujibur Rahman; Sheik Moni says his group will mobilize 100,000 members to press Govt policies
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GOVERNOR CITES RELIEF‐ROLL DROP
response.abstract: Article discussing NYS Gov Rockefeller's rept on a 'significant' downward trend in number of welfare recipients notes NYS rept parallels downward trend reptd in recent mos by welfare officials in NYC, which contains about 70% of statewide caseload; NYC HRA Admr Sugarman reptd that city welfare rolls in Apr totaled 1,208,475 persons, decline of 61,493 in 10 mos; while NYC officials have claimed credit for beginning reform of welfare mgt several yrs ago, Rockefeller apparently feels that decline would not have occurred without his prodding through such means as NYS Welfare Inspector Gen Berlinger's office
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Coast Bugging Is Linked To Aide in House Inquiry
response.abstract: FBI and San Diego County Dist Atty are investigating charges that M A Jarvis, top asst to Repr S Steiger, planted illegal listening device in wall of San Diego hotel as part of investigation being conducted by House Select Com on Crime, of which Steiger is member; investigation of Steiger and Jarvis comes at time when Govt's use of electronic surveillance is of paramount concern to cts, Cong and public; Jarvis confirms repts that he placed microphone in wall in attempt to record information about Emprise Corp, nation's largest sports-concession co, which has been accused by Steiger of having close ties to organized crime; Steiger says on June 10 that he may have known about plan to plant microphone before it was installed, and that he was certain he was told about it afterward; insists that action was legitimate and warranted because of nature of investigation; Jarvis had attempted to record conversation in July, '71, between atty R P Leacy, who worked for late former Emprise pres L M Jacobs and H F Nunn, who was associated with Emprise in '60's in operation of Ariz race track; Nunn had conspired with Jarvis in eavesdropping and led Leacy into conversation about Emprise's alleged dealings with organized crime figures; Jarvis says, however, that no conversation was picked up in 2 hrs of taping; central issue is how deeply Repr Steiger was involved in planning bugging operation; Steiger illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Secretariat Enjoys Lazy Belmont Day Away From Cheers
response.abstract: Secretariat's future discussed; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ALL 47 CEMETERIES ARE STRUCK HERE
response.abstract: members of Cemetery Workers and Green Attendants Union Local 365 on June 10 extend their 2-mo-old strike from 3 to 47 NYC met area cemeteries; strike is having great impact on Jewish cemeteries because Orthodox Jewish faith requires burial within 24 hrs of death; many families and friends of Jewish deceased are digging graves and burying dead; are also driving hearses because drivers refuse to cross strikers' picket lines; NYC Health Comr J A Cimino says that dead bodies have not created health problem yet because most of cemeteries have several-mo cold storage capacity; compulsory arbitration bill applicable only to this labor dispute, after health emergency has been certified, was recently passed by NYS Legis and is awaiting Gov Rockefeller's signature; under bill, Gov is empowered to have State Mediation Bd make final mediation effort and if no settlement is reached after 48 hrs compulsory arbitration would be invoked; rev of '70 strike involving same union; contract demands being made by memebers of Local 365 discussed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Hard‐Earned Age of Affluence Is Dawning in Japan
response.abstract: Article on age of affluence which is becoming apparent for most of 104 million Japanese; attributes affluence to various factors, including 15-20% annual increase in wages, relatively evenly distributed income with its corresponding mass purchasing power, effect of enforced savings and other forms of income furnished by employers, fact that Japanese tend to save off the top of income rather than save what remains at end of mo, and relatively low taxes on middle-class incomes; notes avg Japanese family has acquired many of the appurtenances of the affluent life; illus; table showing breakdown of avg monthly paycheck
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: William Inge, Playwright, Is Dead
response.abstract: HOLLYWOOD HILLS, Calif., June 10—William Inge, whose steady production of prize‐win ning plays illuminated Broad way in the nineteen‐fifties, was found dead in the garage of his home early today, apparently suicide. He was 60 years old.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GRAY IS REPORTED WILLING TO WAIVE TRIAL IMMUNITY
response.abstract: Former FBI acting dir L P Gray agrees to testify without immunity in any Watergate criminal trials about his dealings with Pres Nixon and other top Adm officials after Watergate break-in; Gray reptdly decided to testify without immunity in hope he would not be indicted as result of any high-level attempts to cover up Watergate affair; Govt source confirms Gray has been cooperating for last mo, but refuses to say whether criminal charges will be filed against him; Gray is considered key witness for Fed prosecutors, as is H W Kalmbach, formerly Pres Nixon's personal atty, and J S Magruder, former Repub re-elect campaign official; both Fed prosecutors and officials close to special Watergate prosecutor A Cox are known to believe that naivete and eagerness to please led Gray to become 'a victim' of sr White House aides, and as such, less culpable than those aides who actually directed cover-up
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NEW HANOI TALKS ON AID EXPECTED
response.abstract: high-ranking US official says on June 11 that US plans to resume negotiations with N Vietnam on extending econ aid to Hanoi once agreement is reached in Paris on ways to strengthen Vietnam cease-fire accord; repts that in conversations with N Vietnamese, Amers have pledged to resume activities called for by Jan cease-fire agreement but suspended when US charged Hanoi with violating cease-fire; asserts these included sweeping of mines from N Vietnamese waters and talks on possible Amer econ aid to Hanoi; says that before talks were suspended late in April, both sides had agreed on principles and procedures to govern funneling of econ aid to Hanoi; this preliminary agreement was achieved but not announced on Mar 25 by AID Deputy Dir M J Williams and Finance Min Dang Viet Chau, who headed delegations to joint econ comm which began meeting in Paris on Mar 15; first indication that preliminary agreement had been reached was provided by censored Sen staff study issued by Foreign Relations subcom on June 11; because of widespread Cong opposition to any econ aid to N Vietnam, Adm has been reluctant to rept in much detail on discussions already held with N Vietnamese officials; R Ziegler, White House pres sec, expresses optimism that cease-fire accord talks will be concluded successfully; another White House official says he expects that S Vietnam's reservations, mainly relating to interpretations of wording, will be resolved
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sex Stereotyping Persists in Schools
response.abstract: article finds that despite nearly 5 yrs of challenges, Amer schools are still moving too slowly to eliminate sex stereotypes in classrooms; prevailing attitude among school admrs, both male and female, reptdly is that sexism in schools is not a problem; some school bds, despite increased sensibility to issue, admit that action on sex sterotyping is still being pre-empted by racial issues; admrs rept that emphasis in last few yrs has been on increasing 'ethnic portion' of books and school programs; greatest progress is seen in area of textbooks, where many publishers are reptdly taking positive steps to balance output; teachers and admrs comment; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Brown &
response.abstract: British-owned Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp on June 11 announces offer to pay $23 per share for all of common stock of Gimbel Brothers Inc; announcement came 1 wk after Loew's Corp had made tender offer of $16 per share to increase its Gimbel holdings to 51%; Loew's says June 11 that it will accept Brown & Williamson offer; Brown & Williamson, unit of British American Tobacco Co Ltd, is 3d largest tobacco processor in US, with estimated sales last yr of about $1-billion; B A Gimbel, chmn and chief exec of Gimbel Brothers, says he welcomes opportunity for shareholders to sell their shares at higher price and that Gimbel bd will recommend acceptance of tender offer to shareholders; Brown & Williamson's offer will expire July 23 but it will begin accepting and paying for shares as soon as 51% of outstanding stock has been tendered; pors of J E Edens, head of Brown & Williamson, and B A Gimbel
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: $30,000 Watergate Funds Linked to Philippine Donor
response.abstract: Finance Com to Re-elect the Pres received $30,000 from unnamed 'Philippine natl,' used it in 'urgent White House project' then, believing money was donated illegally, returned it, according to rept made public by Gen Accounting Office; urgent White House project mentioned in GAO rept was payment for Watergate burglars and their lawyers, according to statements made earlier to GAO by Pres Nixon's former personal lawyer, H W Kalmbach; Washington Star-News repts that Philippine contribution came from R Nolan, prominent sugar planter and former sugar quota admr for Philippines; Philippine contribution represents 3d foreign money operation involved in Watergate investigation; 1st involves $89,000 in cash that went through Mex banks to conceal its source and was later traced to Watergate burglars; Houston, Tex, grand jury is investigating this aspect; Kalmbach told GAO he raised total of $210,000 for Watergate defendants and their lawyers; he has agreed to testify for prosecution against Pres Nixon's 2 former top assts, H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 63% CUT IN CAR USE SUGGESTED BY U.S. FOR NORTH JERSEY
response.abstract: TRENTON, June 11—The Fed eral Government has drafted an air‐pollution‐control plan for New Jersey that recommends a cut of 63 per cent hi vehicular travel in the state's northern metropolitan regions to cope with a smog crisis second only to that in Los Angeles.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cemetery Strike Mediation Bill Signed
response.abstract: NY Gov Rockefeller on June 11 signs bill authorizing him to invoke mediation and binding arbitration in cemetery strike if there is threat to health and welfare of NY residents; bill was signed following discussion by special inquiry bd apptd by State Industrial Comr L L Levine; bill specifies that Rockefeller may order mediation and arbitration after Industrial Comr certifies that bargaining impasse exists and State Health Comr Dr H S Ingraham certifies that dispute has resulted in 'actural threat to health and welfare of state residents'; also specifies that Industrial Comr shall order final and binding arbitration if efforts to effect voluntary settlement through mediation fail; comrs are assessing situation daily; several religious leaders announce formation of voluntary burial groups
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: RECORD 95° HEAT FORCES 8% CUT IN CITY'S POWER
response.abstract: NYC Admr Musicus, commenting on impact of Consol Edison NYC met area voltage cut along eastern seaboard, hopes spreading phenomenon of voltage cuts will spur awareness of need to formulate natl energy policies
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Libyan Chief, Citing U.S Aid to Israel, Seizes Oil Concern
response.abstract: Libyan leader Col Qaddafi on June 11 announces nationalization of Bunker Hunt Oil Co, speech to rally; describes Amer oil cos as instrument of US policy in Middle East, asserting time is ripe for Arabs to strike at US interests; clearly aims action at US pro-Israel policy; details on struggle between Govt on Bunker Hunt since '71; spokesman for Bunker Hunt in Dallas, Texas, says that co has no choice but to 'pursue all available legal remedies'; Qaddafi announcement seen as signal of Libya's determination to take control of other foreign cos as well as Qadaffi's decision to use oil as pol weapon; Qaddafi move is expected to be hailed throughout Arab world as major move to exploit pol value of oil resources
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Court Tells States They Cannot Permit Air Quality to Drop
response.abstract: US Sup Ct, 4-4, on June 11 rules states cannot permit air quality to deteriorate from present levels; ct automatically confirms latest ruling of lower ct; ruling effectively bars EPA from approving any state air pollution plan that would allow lower standards of purity in any area than presently exists; Sierra Club pres L Moss, whose orgn was 1 of 4 involved in case, lauds ruling; Natl Coal Assn pres C E Bagge urges Cong to rewrite '70 Clean Air Act; says ruling will bar construction of any new fossil fuel power plants in most of US and foreclose prospect of producing either synthetic natural gas or oil from coal; Govt brief contended upholding inferior ct ruling would discourage econ expansion into areas with clean air and make population shifts into unoccupied areas more difficult; other environmental groups in suit listed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AGNEW CRITICIZES SENATE HEARINGS
response.abstract: Vice Pres Agnew declares on June 11 that televised Sen Watergate hearings 'can hardly hope to find the truth and can hardly fail to muddy the waters of justice beyond redemption,' speech, 67th annual conf of Natl Assn of Attys Gen, St Louis; complains that televising of investigative hearings give them a 'Perry Masonish impact' that he says could ruin reputations of innocent people because of absence of courtroom safeguards against unsubstantiated testimony; Sen Ervin issues statement proclaiming com's intention to proceed 'to ascertain the truth fairly and fully in respect to this tragic episode in our nation's history'; illus of Agnew
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pupil Busing Is Ordered by Court Between Detroit and Its Suburbs
response.abstract: Fed Appeals Ct, Cincinnati, rules 6-3 on June 12 that black children from Detroit must ride buses to suburbs and white children must ride them into Detroit to achieve racial balance in schools; decision appears to set stage for final determination by US Sup Ct on how far state and local govts are required to go in breaking down racial barriers in educ; in approving principle of met area busing, appeals ct sets itself in opposition to other ct which invalidated similar plan for Richmond, Va; Mich atty plans to appeal ruling; decision sends case back to Detroit dist ct for development of specific busing plan; NAACP hails ruling
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S.‐HANOI DRAFT IS SAID TO DEMAND ANEW CEASE‐FIRE
response.abstract: Essential points of draft document being worked out at Paris peace talks to strengthen original Vietnam cease-fire agreement reptdly contains clause that all foreign countries will stop mil activities in Cambodia and Laos and withdraw all their troops and mil equipment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hydrants in City Opened Illegally on 93° Day
response.abstract: water pressure drops on June 12 below critical levels depriving firefighters, hosps and homes of adequate supplies as result of illegal hydrant openings by city youths seeking relief from 93-degree temps; Mayor Lindsay warns of pressure crisis and calls for public aid in curtailing 'malicious misbehavior' by youths; says water wastage is gambling with lives of every citizen; officials says 1,000 of cities 105,000 fire hydrants are spilling 2,000 gals a minute into sts, wasting estimated .55-billion gals; heat wave and water crisis are expected to ease on June 13 as cool front enters met area; impact of water problems on met area communities and cities discussed; illus

response.headline: IMMUNITY DENIED
response.abstract: J W Dean 3d loses his 2-mo struggle for immunity from prosecution on June 12 and for 1st time goes before Watergate grand jury on orders of Judge Sirica of US Dist Ct; Dean cites 5th Amendment and refuses to answer questions; Sirica grants Dean and J S Magruder immunity for their pending testimony before Sen Watergate com; blocks move by special prosecutor A Cox to bar TV and radio coverage of Dean and Magruder when they testify before com; says ct is powerless to interfere; Cox says he will not appeal ruling; types of immunity discussed; Sirica illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: INQUIRY ON FUNDS
response.abstract: former Commerce Sec Stans on June 12 denies any involvement in Watergate scandal or cover-up and pleads ignorance about many of activities of Nixon re-election campaign, testimony, Sen Watergate com; denies knowledge of '71 memorandum suggesting that he was using Govt funds for pol purposes; Sen com made public memo in which Commerce Dept aide to Stans was quoted as saying Stans had 'a discretionary fund' that would total about $1-million; memo said money was being used by Stans at dept for promoting Nixon s re-election and suggests that other Cabinet officials might want to try developing same kind of fund; Stans says he is is unaware of request by Nixon's personal atty H W Kalmbach for 'all the cash I can get' shortly after Watergate arrests; says Kalmbach told him that request had nothing to do with campaign but that he was asking for it on 'high authority'; says he managed to find $75,000 in '2 parcels outside the com'; says 1 parcel originally came from Kalmbach himself when Stans took over as finance chmn; says Kalmbach, who served as principal fund raiser for Nixon before Stans took over, had left behind $45,000 in cash in safe deposit box for 'unusual expenses'; says he learned about 6 wks ago from Kalmbach that request for money had come from J W Dean 3d and that Dean had given assurances that its purpose was legal; Kalmbach was said to have gone to J D Ehrlichman to make sure of Dean's statement; Stans says Kalmbach told him that he went to Ehrlichman and that Ehrlichman confirmed that purpose was legal; says he was ignorant of sizable amount of campaign cash drawn during 1st 5 mos of '72 and used in Watergate plot by G G Liddy; testifies that he had no idea how $114,000 in campaign checks were passed through bank acct of B L Barker but says transaction must have been handled by Liddy; Stans is questioned primarily about financial aspects of bugging and subsequent cover-up efforts; says that there were 'no intentional violations' of campaign finance laws but concedes that because of 'complexity' of statute and 'vast amount of work that had to be done, there may have been some unintended technical violations'; says Com for Re-Election of Pres, headed by J N Mitchell, handled 'entire gamut of the pol effort'; objection by Stans' attys to Stans' appearance before com is overruled; illus of Stans, attys D G Sanders, R W Barker and W J Bonner
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U. S. SUES TEXACO ON GASOLINE DEAL
response.abstract: Justice Dept on June 12 files suit in Fed Dist Ct, NYC, to nullify Texaco Inc agreement to sell 14,000 bbls of crude oil to Coastal States Gas Producing Co; alleges Texaco has made further agreement to purchase substantial amt of refined products from Coastal; cites option Texaco has on Coastal State's Corpus Christi, Tex, refinery; charges agreement would substantially lessen competition and may foreclose ind marketeers from supplies and price competition; seeks to nullify agreement, enjoin Texaco from acquiring assets or stock of any person or co engaged in refining and direct action be taken to restore Coastal States as major supplier of independent marketeers; Coastal States repr says suit will be contested; SEC suspension of trading in Coastal States stock, because of rumors about co reserves and ability to deliver supplies, ends on June 14
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON FREEZES PRICES FOR UP TO 60 DAYS, THEN WILL ESTABLISH PHASE 4 CONTROLS; FARM PRICES, WAGES, RENTS UNAFFECTED
response.abstract: Pres Nixon orders on June 13 freeze on all retail prices, including food prices, for as much as 60 days, nationwide TV address; says he will not freeze prices of raw agr products, but retail costs of those same products will be frozen at supermkts; says during 60-day period of freeze, which in effect will give him time to draft a Phase 4 econ policy, he will search for new mechanisms to control food prices at retail level
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PATH RAISES FARE TO 50C, UP 66.6%
response.abstract: PATH line on June 13 announces fare increase from 30c to 50c, effective July 29; rr spokesman, when Ry Carmen's strike against line was settled on June 3, had claimed that there were no immediate plans for increase; settlement for carmen amounted to 6.9% wage increase, while increase in cost to riders will be 66.6%; Port Authority of NY and NJ spokesman says effect of Pres Nixon's June 13 announcement of new price freeze on PATH increase will have to be studied; spokesman notes increase is 1st in 12 yrs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON'S NOMINEE FOR F.P.C.BLOCKED
response.abstract: Sen, reflecting consumer unhappinness with energy crisis, votes, 49-44, on June 13 to recommit nomination of R H Morris to be FPC member to Sen Commerce Com, ostensibly for further hearings; Morris por; controversy over nomination discussed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Accord on Vietnam Calls for Halt Tomorrow on All Cease‐Fire Violations
response.abstract: US, N Vietnam, S Vietnam and Vietcong join on June 13 in calling for end of all cease-fire violations beginning 4 AM June 15 Greenwich mean time, joint communique containing 14 provisions to improve observance of original Vietnam cease-fire agreement signed Jan 27; Kissinger emphasizes that June 13 agreement is not new one but 'amplification and consolidation' of basic accord, news conf; stresses that goodwill continues to be needed for observance of cease-fire; 14 points were worked out by Kissinger and Le Duc Tho and signed by them and 2 S Vietnamese adversaries; S Vietnam signs only after US overrules some of its suggestions, including Thieu's demand for definite timetable for elections and his reptd demand for reference to N Vietnamese troops in S Vietnam; wording of communique is reworked to call for demarcation of 'areas of control' as soon as possible, in deference to Thieu's objection to use of word 'territory'; communique is initialed by Kissinger and Tho on June 13 in villa at Gif-sur-Yvette and later signed again by Kissinger and Tho in former Hotel Majestic, Paris, with Deputy Premier Nguyen Luu Vien signing for S Vietnam and Min of State Nguyen Van Hieu for Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Govt, in 1st of 2 signing ceremonies; 2d ceremony was concluded 3 hrs later at same site with only Kissinger and Tho signing document; 14 points of communique listed; include US agreement to cease 'immediately, completely and indefinitely' its reconnaissance flights over N Vietnam and to resume minesweeping within 5 days of signing and complete it within 30 days; at news conf preceding Kissinger's, Nguyen Xuan Phuong, deputy head of Saigon delegation, asserts that not only must infiltrations cease but troops that are not Vietnamese must leave S Vietnam to settle its pol problems itself and exercise its right to self-determination
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Business and Labor Say Freeze Fails To Meet Problems
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, ordering 60-day price freeze on June 13, says raw agr products will not be frozen
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Commissioner of Police Finds What Standing Is
response.abstract: NYC Police Comr Cawley on June 13 receives ticket for illegally parking his car before int at NY Times

response.headline: BOMBING CUTOFF WILL BE PRESSED
response.abstract: Sen Mansfield (Mont) asserts on June 13 that he will still seek approval of provision attached to State Dept authorization bill that would cut off all past, present and future funds for Amer bombing or other combat activities in all of Indochina unless Cong authorizes such activities despite Hanoi-Washington, DC, decision to tighten Vietnam cease-fire
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A Frail ‘Fresh Hope’
response.abstract: analysis of Vietnam communique signed in Paris on June 13 holds agreement merely speculates that all sides are willing to reaffirm on paper their Jan commitment to cease-fire and pol conciliation in Indochina; asserts essential problems that have haunted Vietnam for so many yrs remain unresolved by latest agreement; adds latest communique has aroused little enthusiasm in Washington, DC, because of legacy of distrust in Vietnam; holds few people in US Govt expect Vietnamese to carry out spirit or lr of agreement and there are many who believe that US, having in effect negotiated 2 cease-fire agreements, should now bow out of area
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 150 Policemen Screened In Hunt for the Unstable
response.abstract: Police Comr D F Cawley on June 13 announces new program to weed out policemen who are apt to use unnecessary violence in performance of duties; submits list of 150 policemen considered by their superiors to be violence-prone for investigation; program follows murder indictment of Officer T J Shea in shooting of 10-yr-old C Glover; Shea had previously been involved in 2 other cases in which he was reptd to have hit a 14-yr-old boy with his revolver and to have shot a 23-yr-old man; special task force set up by Comr has been sifting through personnel files and will decide if officers should take battery of psychological tests; additional list has been compiled of 25 ptl whose records show previous incidents of unnecessary force; 22 of these will take tests and have all been temporarily transferred to adm work from duties involving contact with public; Comr Cawley discusses program; por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Lefkowitz Studies Reports Of Illegal G.O.P. Activities
response.abstract: NYS Atty Gen Lefkowitz is investigating possibility of illegal campaign activities in connection with Repub efforts to retain majority control of state's Assembly; investigation reptdly focuses on whether Repub campaign, under over-all direction of Assembly Speaker Duryea, quietly promoted 3d-party candidates through fictitious 'liberal' com to siphon votes from Dem candidates and achieve Repub victories in marginal dists; particular concern allegedly centers on orgn known as Action Com for the Liberal Party, which sent out anti-Dem literature in '72 having signature of H J Relkin, who was minor member of Assembly's Repub staff and who has been identified as nephew of Ct of Appeals Judge Breitel; impetus for investigation reptdly came from complaint by aides of former Assemblyman Harwood, Dem who lost tight race in which Liberal party line was margin of difference; state Liberal party officials denounce action com as a fraud; say investigators questioned party officials about Assembly races in NYC and Buffalo areas; Duryea issues statement denying knowledge of Relkin's activities; says he expects thorough investigation by Atty Gen 'will determine no wrongdoing on the part of the Republican Assembly Com'; Rockefeller aides say Gov will make no comment pending outcome of inquiry; Harwood, presently Nassau County Dem Chmn, says he suspects lr allegedly sent by Relkin, in which he was lambasted as being against aid to educ and other 'good government' programs, had 'at least some input' from Repubs; Repub Assembly campaign com's role reptdly is under inquiry for possibility that party funds were channeled from com to so-called Action Com; investigation is seen 1 of particular delicacy since entire Repub team has been approaching '73 election yr in what is considered to be a strong majority position
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Anker to Be Named Schools’ Chancellor
response.abstract: Bd of Educ on June 14 plans to announce apptmt of I Anker to 2-yr term as Chancellor and is expected to name Dr E J Gaines and A Mathew Jr to new exec dirs posts; Chancellor's salary is $53,000 per yr and dirs are expected to earn at least $40,000; backgrounds of Gaines and Mathew noted; Anker illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Stans Attacked by Ervin and Talmadge For Denying Knowledge of Fund Deals
response.abstract: Sen Watergate com gives M H Stans, Pres Nixon's finance chmn, extended pounding on June 13 over his professed ignorance of key financial transactions and for his actions as fund-raiser for last yr's campaign; interrogation fails to shake Stans's testimony but leads to com's 1st partisan clash in public; Sen Gurney charges that Sen Ervin harrassed Stans; com's examination of Stans deals directly for 1st time with series of major questions; 1, taken up by Sen Talmadge, is whether Stans, as 1 of nation's foremost accountants, would have allowed hundreds of thousands of dollars in Nixon campaign funds to be spent loosely; another, raised by Ervin, is whether Stans acted properly in striving to conceal identities of contributors to Pres' campaign and whether he engaged in 'laundering' some of those funds; Stans, when asked whether he had ever asked 'why staff members such as Mr Liddy and Mr Porter (and) Mr Magruder were drawing off large sums of money (in cash from re-election com safes), says he did not know about Magruder money at time it was taken, that he thought Liddy payments had been 'relatively small' and that he had been unaware of some of Porter payments; Stans says Liddy was not accountable to him but to campaign treas H W Sloan Jr; Stans says his reason for destroying records of summary sheets he recd from Sloan was 'to protect the privacy, the confidentiality of the contributors on behalf of the contributors'; Ervin traces Nixon unit's efforts to turn $114,000 in checks into cash, process that took checks through Miami bank acct of Watergate conspirator B L Barker; says it was Liddy who recommended that checks be turned into cash; illus of Stans, Ervin and Gurney
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TESTIFIES 5 HOURS
response.abstract: J S Magruder, former deputy dir of Pres Nixon's '72 re‐election campaign, tells Sen Watergate com on June 14 how he and other high‐ranking officials plotted bugging of Dems and then tried to cover it up; confesses his own guilt and implicates ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell, J W Dean 3d and H R Haldeman; says Mitchell and Dean were among those who planned Watergate bugging as part of broader espionage campaign; says he told Haldeman full story last Jan; testifies that cover‐up effort was decided on almost immediately after June 17 arrests of 5 men inside Dem Natl Com hq and that among those who knew that he would lie to authorities about case were Mitchell, Dean and Haldeman; says he does not know whether J D Ehrlichman was aware of break‐in or cover‐up, that campaign finance dir M H Stans learned shortly after burglary that it had been paid for with campaign funds, and that C W Colson had actively encouraged espionage activities, although not specifically Watergate operation; says he believes Pres Nixon had no knowledge of spying operation; says he feared Nixon's re‐election 'would be probably negated' if story was revealed; says 'I think I blanched, to say the least' when he heard that J W McCord had been arrested at Watergate; says as early as Sept '71 there were discussions with Dean on pol intelligence operations and that talk began in earnest in Dec when G G Liddy arrived at Com to Re‐Elect Pres; says Liddy, on Jan 27 '72, presented his plan to Mitchell, Dean and Magruder at meeting in then‐Atty Gen's office; says projects included 'wiretapping, electronic surveillance and photography (of documents); and cost was estimated at $1‐million; says 'gen nature of 1st Liddy plan was relayed to G Strachan; testifies that he, Mitchell and Dean met again on Feb 4 '72 and that Liddy presented them with $500,000 plan, trimmed of everything but wiretapping and photography; says sometime after meeting, Colson called him and told him to get budget approved for Liddy's plans, because they needed information; says on Mar 30 72 he discussed Liddy's 3d plan with Mitchell and F LaRue; says Liddy had cut cost to $250,000 and Mitchell approved; says logs of wiretapped conversations and photographs of documents in Dem files reached Magruder in 2 packages, 1st 1 a wk or so after tap was installed in May; says Mitchell was shown illictly gathered information at meeting and he 'revd the documents' and indicated that they were not satisfactory as there was no information relating to any of subjects he hoped to receive; Repub state Chmn R Rosenbaum indicates, however, that Dem charges might be harmful to party; H J Relkin, whose signature appeared on anti‐Dem literature sent out by Liberals during several '72 Assembly contests, denies wrongdoing; maintains he was justified in sending out campaign literature attacking Dems; question seen centering on whether Liberals were aided by Repubs in alleged illicit activity; J Olshin, exec sec of Liberal party in Nassau County, admits there has at times been close relationship between Liberals and Repubs; cites instances in recent elections in which Repub workers had solicited signatures for petitions of Liberal candidates; J S Shaw, dissident Queens, NYC, Liberal leader, says he will hold news conf to produce liberal, whom he maintains worked in past Assembly campaign by telephoning voters from office of Repub candidate; Duryea denies knowledge of Relkin's activities or how he came to be hired by Repub Assembly; Atty Gen Lefkowitz, asked to identify 11 Assembly races in which Relkin lrs reptdly were distributed, has referred all inquiries to Liberal party, which he maintains, has such information; response.headline: Magruder on Watergate: Ends Justify the Means

response.headline: New Vietnam T ruce Is On And the Fighting Is Down
response.abstract: Scattered fighting continues throughout S Vietnam on June 16 after 2d cease-fire goes into effect on June 15, but repts from field indicate that battles are fewer and on smaller scale than those that accompanied original cease-fire in Jan; S Vietnamese mil spokesman charges that Communists committed 84 violations of truce beginning at noon June 15 to 6 AM on June 16, though spokesman repts there were no major Communist attacks; newsmen visiting battlefronts rept that Govt forces replied with sporadic artillery fire and air strikes; by contrast, when Paris peace agreement was signed last Jan, there were almost 400 reptd Communist violations in 1st 24-hrs; other indications that provisions of new Paris communique signed on June 13 might not be carried out on schedule; Saigon Govt spokesman Lt Col Le Trung Hien announces that S Vietnamese field commanders will not meet with Communist field commanders at noon June 16 as specified in commmunique; communique says that opposing commanders must meet within 24-hrs after cease-fire begins; Hien asserts that govt officers will not do so until Joint Mil Comm reaches unanimous decision on subject; it is also disclosed that S Vietnamese Govt authorities have asked for postponement of 15 days in their pol talks with Provisional Revolutionary Govt of Vietcong; Foreign Ministry spokesman asserts that there are 'tech reasons' for delay in talks; meetings are supposed to lead to creation of Natl Council of Natl Reconciliation and Concord within 45 days of new accord; S Vietnamese people apparently greet new cease-fire phase with less overt interest than they showed 5 mos ago; Saigon command repts there have been 16,839 violations of cease-fire by Communists since Jan 28 and 23,589 Communist soldiers and 6,056 Govt soldier have been killed; also repts that 28,991 Govt soldiers have been wounded and more than 5,000 civilians have killed, wounded or abducted in fighting that followed original cease-fire accord; Communists on June 15 broadcast periodic orders to their soldiers to stop fighting, and Govt announces that its field commanders have been instructed by radio and phone to observe new truce; repts from field indicate that many S Vietnamese Govt soldiers have not yet received such orders by noon, when truce was to begin; Saigon command asserts that there is slight upsurge in Communist attacks in hrs preceding cease-fire, with 96 violations reptd between 6 AM and noon June 15; experienced Amer official asserts that relative lack of fighting comes from apparent belief that Communists genuinely want to achieve cease-fire and that failure of Communists in Oct and after Jan to hold territory they had seized convinced them that new round of 'land-grabbing' is not worth cost
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Minisubmarine, 4 A board, Is Trapped 360 Feet Down
response.abstract: Johnson‐Sea‐Link (Research Submarine): Navy spokesman Lt Comdr W Smith repts on June 18 that 1st attempts to rescue 4 men trapped in 21‐ft research submarine Johnson‐Sea‐link, 360‐ft under Atlantic off Key West, Fla, failed when divers from rescue ship Tringa discover submarine wedged into wreckage of scuttled destroyer; Lt Comdr R H Brisbing repts from radio conversations with trapped 4 that carbon dioxide levels are rising and temperatures have dropped to 40 degrees; vessel's designer E A Link, whose son is among crew, estimates life support resources aboard submarine show oxygen only sufficient through noon, June 19; Johnson‐Sea Link submarine, owned by Smithsonian Inst and Harbor Branch Foundation Lab at Fort Pierce, was participating in oceanographic research with Smithsonian and Seadiver Corp on fish surrounding sunken destroyer F T Berry and was accompanied by support ship Seadiver; vessel's 2‐part construction consists of forward glass bubble containing submarine's controls and housing 2 crewmen, and aft section with tube through which scuba divers pass; Dr G M Griffin, who was scheduled to take command on June 18, says crew may be instructed to break free of craft and try to surface if all other rescue attempts fail, although method is highly dangerous; crew consists of pilot A Menzies, ichthyologist Dr R Meek and divers E C Link and A Stover; illus of vessel

response.headline: Lefkowitz Gives His Data On Vote Scheme to Hogan
response.abstract: NYS Atty Gen L J Lefkowitz announces on June 18 that his investigation of suspected Repub-aided scheme to siphon votes from Dem candidates for Assembly has been turned over to Manhattan Dist Atty Hogan for possible criminal prosecution; issues brief statement saying only that evidence, including testimony and exhibits, has been sent to Hogan; adds that Albany County Dist Atty A W Proskin has recd information relating to state law that candidates must file campaign statements with State Sec in Albany; inquiry has focused in part on office of Assembly Speaker P B Duryea; announcement makes no reference to individuals or to Repub figures whose campaign statements have been scrutinized; refers to complaint about purported Liberal literature used in '72 Assembly campaign; Nassau County Repub Com acknowledges providing to Liberal party postage mailing labels used to send out some of anti-Dem campaign literature under investigation by Lefkowitz; both Repub and Liberal officials in Nassau disclaim any knowledge of how labels apparently came to be used by H J Relkin, former Queens Liberal who sent out literature and who holds patronage job on Assembly Repub staff; basic question in inquiry is whether Repub Assembly campaign funds were improperly channeled to help Liberal party in certain marginal dists in '72 to cut Dem vote and preserve Repub majority in Assembly; Duryea spokesman denies rept that Assembly Repubs' communication dir J C Threatte delivered copies of suspect literature to Queens printer, who has contended to state investigators that he had printed 'Liberal' literature and was paid with check from Repub campaign fund; literature, printed over Relkin's signature, has been denounced by Liberal party officials as unauthorized; Relkin insists that it is legitimate; Duryea meets on June 18 with Assemblyman J E Kingston, Repub majority leader who was chmn of Repub Assembly campaign in '72; Kingston has said that he had very little to do with campaign com's activities and knows nothing about Lefkowitz inquiry; in related development, officials of NY Com to Re-elect the Pres cast doubt on Repub Assemblyman A A DelliBovi's suggestion that Pres Nixon campaign was responsible for Repub literature on Long Island linked to material under investigation by Lefkowitz; DelliBovi has said that he believes campaign leaflets that mentioned DelliBovi's name as local candidate had come from natl com; F G Perrotta, former head of NYC com to re-elect Nixon, says that he cannot recall such literature and that as rule no such Pres campaign material incorporated names of local candidates; 4th verified instance of campaign mailing sent out by Relkin is disclosed on June 18 by Assemblyman V F Nicolosi, freshman Queens Dem who declares that his '72 campaign was evidently 'ripe' for mailing; lr, signed by Relkin, urged voters to support Nicolosi's Liberal party opponent K A Newman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Another General Chosen As Brazil's Next Leader
response.abstract: Gen E Geisel chosen next Pres of Brazil by country's mil leaders on June 18; his illus; when he takes office on March 15, '74, he will be 4th mil chief of state since '64 revolution that toppled J Goulart, last elected civilian Pres; formal election of Geisel, now head of state oil monopoly, will be held Jan 15 by Electoral Coll comprised of Cong members and delegates from state legis, in which Govt party has overwhelming majority; Geisel is expected to concentrate on continuing Brazil's econ progress under mil-backed Govt, in which gross natl product has jumped over 10% annually for last 4 yrs and inflation has been brought down considerably; some also feel Geisel will loosen Govt's controls on Cong and pol parties
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: $1 Votes Decided Connecticut Issue
response.abstract: Rocky Hill, Conn, Mayor Moser charges that voter approval of proposed $2.25-million indus park was bought for $1 per vote by plan proponents, who bribed voters, including some 1,000 elderly veterans who live in local hosp; map; Conn State Sec Schaffer repts election law does not specifically bar vote-buying in referendums, as opposed to regular elections
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON, BREZHNEV GIVE PEACE VOWS AS SUMMIT BEGINS; 3¾‐HOUR MEETING; Soviet Aide Describes? Session as ‘Good, Businesslike’
response.abstract: Nixon, in speech welcoming L I Brezhnev to White House on June 18, and in toast at a state dinner, pledges jointly with Brezhnev to strive for world peace
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Leaders'
response.abstract: Brezhnev, at White House welcoming for him on June 18, puts his arm around Nixon and says exuberantly in Russian: 'We're moving forward!'; remark symbolizes change in direction and mood of Soviet-Amer relations; stress on cooperation today contrasted with tension and distrust that characterized relations at time of Khrushchev's '59 visit to US; change in emphasis and related factors traced
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SUBMARINE LIFTED, 2 TRAPPED INSIDE 30 HOURS RESCUED
response.abstract: research vessel A B Wood secures grappling hook to Johnson-Sea-Link submarine, imprisoned for over 30 hrs in sunken destroyer Berry's innards of tangled cables and debris, lifting at least 2 members of oceanographic crew to safety; remote-control TV cameras assist in operations supervised by E A Link, who maintained radio contact with submarine throughout operation; winch hoists vessel to surface where rescue workers open forward acrylic bubble which enhanced survival chances for A Menzies and R Meek by not conducting frigid ocean temperatures; Navy Comdr J Neville expresses uncertainty about fate of divers E C Link and A Stover, unconscious in aluminum aft compartment for nearly 12 hrs before craft is brought to surface, noting no vital signs are evident; divers raised pressure as temperature dropped because Baralyme, used in absorbing carbon dioxide, does not function in cool temperatures; cycle eventually failed, stifling area with carbon dioxode and causing occupants to lose consciousness; submarine is lifted aboard mother ship Sea Diver with rear compartment still sealed; attempts are made to lower inside temperature and fix air pressure at sea level; cheers from crews of rescue vessels accompany oceanographers' emergence from submarine; illus of submarine aboard mother ship; project was reptdly designed to enable oceanograohers to observe how subtropical fish had converted wreck of 2,425-ton destroyer into 390-ft artificial reef
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mansfield Acted to Aid Summit Talks
response.abstract: Sen Watergate com on June 18 cancels its hearings this wk so that they will not detract from talks in Washington, DC, between Pres Nixon and Soviet leader Brezhnev; Sen Ervin says decision to postpone hearings did not come at request of White House but at suggeston of Sen leadership; Sens Mansfield and Scott write joint lr to Sen Ervin on June 18 saying that wk's delay in hearings might permit Nixon and Brezhnev to achieve results which hopefully would help mankind; Sen Weicker is only member of Sen Watergate com to vote against postponement; Mansfield says he initiated postponement of hearings on his own; Sen Baker says delay in J W Dean 3d's testimony has nothing to do with any information Dean has recently supplied, int; com's chief counsel S Dash says he has been informed by White House counsel L Garment that White House will waive all claims to exec privilege and atty-client relationships in connection with Dean's testimony; Sen Ervin declares that foreign intelligence information contained in documents that Dean gave com will be withheld from public testimony but that material dealing with domestic security operations will be offered in evidence in public; illus of Dean and his atty C N Shaffer
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: $1 0 3‐Billion City Budget Is Agreed To by Leaders
response.abstract: NYC '73-74 budget, adopted informally on June 18 by Lindsay adm, calls for restoration of full transit subsidies for schoolchildren

response.headline: Dean Said to Keep $14,000 Fund
response.abstract: sources close to Watergate case say on June 18 that J W Dean 3d has told Fed investigators that he kept $14,000 in Repub campaign funds and at 1 time 'borrowed' $4,000 to finance his wedding and honeymoon; sources say Dean subsequently returned $4,000, which he said he secured with his personal IOU, and placed all cash in special trust fund set up after his break with White House; 1 official says trust fund 'is not in John's name' and that Fed investigators know where money is; question of Dean's handling of cash is reptd to be provoking some partisan discussion among Sens and Sen Watergate com staff members; some are believed to think that Dean misappropriated funds; another source says Dean did not place $14,000 in special trust acct until he was advised to do so in late Mar or early Apr this yr by his atty C N Shaffer; Justice Dept official confirms that $4,000 was 'borrowed' from acct shortly before Oct wedding and describes act as technical crime; money is believed to come from $350,000 Haldeman acct, which is believed to be source of funds which helped pay off 7 Watergate defendants in return for their silence
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mayor and Cawley Hail Citizens on Aid In Seizing Suspects
response.abstract: bystanders, in 3d incident in 1 wk, capture crime suspect on June 18 when 12-yr-old boy runs to street from his Brownsville apt screaming that man had broken in and was hurting his 9-yr-old sister; several dozen angry people pounce on man as he runs from bldg and beat him into unconsciousness; suspect, D Hill, is in fair condition with collapsed lung, cuts and bruises; is charged with burglary, attempted rape, sexual abuse and endangering welfare of minor; Mayor Lindsay expresses hope that incidents mark beginning of trend of people helping each other; Police Comr Cawley, while praising citizen participation, voices concern lest public take law into its own hands
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2 CREWMEN DEAD; BODIES REMOVED FROM SUBMARINE
response.abstract: bodies of oceanographers E C Link and A Stover are removed from research submarine Johnson-Sea-Link on June 19, 29 hrs after vessel is untangled from debris on submerged destroyer F T Berry, and following gradual depressurization of aft compartment; spokesman for Smithsonian Inst, owner of vessel, says intensive inquiry is planned into tragedy; physician on mother ship Dr D Youngblood attributes divers' deaths to exposure, noting chilling 40-degree temperature in their compartment was coupled with rising carbon monoxide level, rendering 2 men unconscious; pressure in forward chamber was maintained at surface level allowing survivors A Menzies and R Meek to be released from submarine immediately and spend only 90 mins in decompression chamber as precaution; says initial rescue efforts were balked by swiftness of Gulf Stream current; support ship Sea Diver is tied up at Key West Naval Base on June 19; rev of events of submarine's entanglement in scuttled destroyer; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Voluntary Overtime a Key U.A.W. Issue
response.abstract: demand that overtime be made voluntary has become key and decisive issue in upcoming negotiations for new contract between UAW and auto cos; negotiators for cos have warned that they are on collision course unless UAW modifies its demands on overtime; there is still optimism that peaceful settlement can be reached; heavy overtime during last 2 yrs has enabled auto indus to enjoy record sales and profits and has swelled paychecks of workers; it has also left many workers fatigued and angry, wondering if it is worth disruption that it has caused in their lives; wages and fringes will still be important in talks, but noneconomic issues such as health and safety in plants, reform of grievance procedures and whether man can be ordered to work overtime have become dominant; cos have warned that voluntary overtime would decrease efficiency and hurt their competitive position, forcing them to expand plant capacity that would often stand idle in highly fluctuating auto mkt; issue is not new; it has been raised during negotiations since '67, but never before has it agitated so many of industry's 700,000 production workers; most of them have been working Saturdays and extra hrs each day, and in some key plants 7 days a wk with every other Sunday off; big 4 cos have put together 8.2-million cars, which is 11.2% higher than figure for '72 model yr and will easily exceed standing record production of 8.8-million cars in '65; extra production has been achieved mainly through overtime rather than new hiring or expanding plant capacity; GM hourly employes averaged 42.9 hrs a wk during 1st '73 qr, earning avg $270 a wk as compared to 40.1 hrs a wk and pay of $236 for same '72 qr; some workers and co officials comment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRESIDENT YIELDS IN FIGHT TO SLASH DOMESTIC FUNDS; Signs Three Bills Exceeding Budget by $671‐Million in Compromise Move; VICTORY FOR CONGRESS; Nixon Hard‐Line Is Dropped on Health, Economic and Airport Aid Programs
response.abstract: Pres Nixon on June 19 signs legis authorizing expenditures of $310-million per yr for next 2 fiscal yr for contract authority for airport development grants

response.headline: COURT TELLS CITY TO STAY RENT LAW
response.abstract: NYS Sup Ct Justice Gellinoff on June 19 orders that NYC postpone implementing new law that repeals city's maximum base rent formula; action does not affect rents in city's 1.2-million rent-controlled apts because next round of increases under maximum base rent formula is not scheduled until next Jan and repeal law would not roll back past increases; Gellinoff's order will permit city to continue computing rent increase authorizations and delays possibility of widespread strike by apt bldg employes; dispute over repeal of maximum base rent formula does not affect apts under rent stabilization
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. Says 2 Realty Groups Fixed Fees in Co‐ops Here
response.abstract: Justice Dept files civil complaint June 19 in Fed ct against Real Estate Bd of NY and Tenant-Owned Apt Assn, alleging that 2 groups had engaged in conspiracy to fix fees for sale and management of co-op apts in NYC; complaint asks Fed ct for injunction to prevent real estate groups from maintaining or recommending comm rates to be charged for sale or mananagement of co-op apts; E T Hume, pres of Real Estate Bd of NY, says bd believes that establishment of comm rates protects public and offers sensible guidelines to brokers; Govt is concerned with collusion regardless of whether fees increase or decrease but believes renewed competition would eventually result in reduced fees
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dean Reportedly Says Nixon Wanted List of ‘Trouble’ Newsmen
response.abstract: Sen sources say ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d has told Sen investigators that Pres Nixon asked him to keep list of newsmen who were giving Pres 'trouble' during last yr's election campaign; say Dean related that Nixon told him that newsmen would be 'taken care of after election; sources quote from summary of June 16 int between Dean and Sen Watergate com attys; AP repts June 19, on basis of summary excerpts, that Nixon asked Dean to see that IRS tax audits 'be turned off on friends' of Pres; men who have read summaries by S Dash and F Thompson say Dean promised to provide com with documents showing that he, H R Haldeman and J D Ehrlichman began immediately after Watergate break-in at Dem hq last June to concoct cover-up story; sources discuss theories that might explain why there is no mention of evidence tying Nixon to cover-up in summaries
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Will Seek to Learn If Funds for Campaign Were Misused
response.abstract: Sen sources say on June 9 that Sen Watergate com plans to investigate personal finances of participants in bugging and cover-up episode to determine whether large sums of Repub campaign money were misappropirated or in other ways wrongfully used; this area of case emerges publicly with repts that ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d might have 'borrowed' $4,000 from cash fund, which was initially set up by Repub campaign contributions, to pay for his wedding and honeymoon last Oct; sources say Sen com has been quietly subpoenaing personal bank records and other data in attempt to determine whether there was personal profit-taking among involved Re-Election Com members; most of specific cash disbursements during campaign have not been accounted for; Watergate conspirator J W McCord says on June 19 that he used leftover money, which totaled about $18,000, to pay attys' fees, telephone int; says he planned to rept cash as income on his '72 income tax return; discrepancies in testimony with respect to cash noted; there have been repeated but unconfirmed repts to NY Times that some of White House personnel who were handling payoff money, which reptdly originated in part from $350,000 cash fund held in office safe of former White House chief of staff H R Haldeman, were living beyond their means
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: YONKERS LIBERAL WAS DURYEA AIDE
response.abstract: I P Nach, Liberal party candidate for NYS Assembly in Westchester County's 87th AD in '72, discloses on June 19 that he was hired as consultant to Repub Assembly majority after he became Liberal candidate; disclosure comes as Albany and NYC Dist Attys begin their own inquiries into possible schemes under which Repubs allegedly supported Liberal candidates to siphon off voters from Dem candidates; Nach says that he was questioned about piece of campaign literature signed by H J Relkin, Action Com Chmn for Liberal party, several mos ago by Atty Gen Lefkowitz, whose investigation of campaign literature during '72 Assembly contests has focused on Assembly Speaker Duryea's office; recounts events that led him to run as Liberal candidate in 87th AD and to become member of Duryea's staff from June 29 through Dec; says that he has worked for Duryea before and that he sees no conflict of interest in running on 1 party line and working for another; Duryea spokesman confirms that Nach was on Duryea's payroll and recd $2,500 for his 6 mos of consulting work; Gov Rockefeller says that Lefkowitz has acted correctly in investigating 'any smoke' in state's pol parties; Duryea says that he is confident that 'no violation' of law will be found on part of Assembly campaign committee
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONRAD BRINGS IN SKYLAB SUN FILM
response.abstract: Skylab crew members Capt Conrad and Comdr Weitz retrieve exposed film from space station's telescope unit during 'space walk' on June 19; remove dust from lens of telescope, repair battery and inspect blistered paint on side of Apollo command module; Conrad places fresh supply of film for solar photography by 2d Skylab crew; crew receives congratulatory message from Soviet astronaut Maj Gen Shatalov, who lauds them for their 'courageous' achievement; TV picture of astronauts returning to space station after space walk
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Police to Use TV to Scan Times Sq. Areafor Crime
response.abstract: NYC Police Dept plans to use closed-circuit TV for crime crackdown in Times Square area; cameras will be monitored in trailer in area expected to be in operation by summer, from which assistance will be directed by radio to scenes of crimes; details of camera surveillance are being withheld; successful use of camera in other cities noted

response.headline: BREZHNEV TAKES APPEAL FOR TRADE TO CONGRESSMEN
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, June 19—Leonid I. Brezhnev took his case for a major expansion in Soviet‐American trade to lead ing members of Congress today and urged them not to let quarrels about Jewish emigra tion stand in the way of broad cooperation.

response.headline: ROCKEFELLER HALTS EFFORTS TO BUILD L. I. SOUND BRIDGE
response.abstract: Gov Rockefeller, in major reversal, orders end to all plans for LI Sound bridge project; seeks to avoid total concession by announcing that he will revive his proposal, defeated by voters in '71, for billion-dollar bond issue for mass transit construction and hwy projects which do not involve 'ecological problems'; '71 referendum for $2.5-billion in mass transit and hwy funds was defeated by vote of 2.4 million to 1.5 million

response.headline: U.S.‐BACKED LOAN IN SOVIET VENTURE REPORTED AT HAND
response.abstract: USSR and US Export-Import Bank are reptd close to final agreement on June 20 on extension of $180-million in credits to help finance construction of Soviet-Amer fertilizer complex in USSR that could lead to as much as $8-billion in trade over 20 yrs; Govt backed loan would represent 45% of total capital outlay, while private Amer banks would provide another 45% and Soviet Foreign Trade bank would provide remaining 10%; Export-Import Bank credit would spur construction of fertilizer complex, to be built by Soviet Govt and Occidental Petroleum Corp; credit has been under negotiation for several wks by Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Min V S Alkhimov with bank officials
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Court Is Told Laird Sought Information On S. E. C. Inquiry
response.abstract: SEC atty T Levine, at Fed Dist Ct, Washington, dosed hearing on June 15,says M Laird, as Sec of Defense, asked aides to seek information about SEC's investigation of Fla East Coast Ry as favor to rr's chmn, E Ball; investigation led to Jan, '73, charges that rr, Ball and others were guilty of fraud and other violations of securities laws; comm seeks ct order to compel Ball to answer questions about his purpose in utilizing high Defense Dept officials to obtain information about probe; in transcript of hearing, made public on June 20, Levine tells ct that Pentagon aides made 2 calls about probe to SEC staff at Laird's request; Laird says inquiries were 'routine' reaction to Ball's complaint about probe; SEC case against Ball and others alleges fraud and misrepresentation in rr's plan to issue common stock in swap for outstanding bonds that had been quietly bought up by officers and trustees of line on basis of inside information; testimony detailed; Laird illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: H.E.W. Said to Kill Health Aid for Poor
response.abstract: Repr Rogers on June 20 says HEW Dept has taken steps to nullify provisions of important health bill before Pres Nixon signed it this wk; says dept moved to require many programs covered by bill to become financially self-sufficient; requirement would kill programs that are inherently incapable of becoming self-sufficient; bill in question extends for 1 yr several major health programs that Adm has repeatedly sought to kill; programs include Fed support for migrant workers' health services, community mental health centers, regional med programs and Hill-Burton program for hosp construction and modernization, although that program is apparently not involved in issue; says proposed regulations would seem to 'doom all migrant health programs, all neighborhood health centers, all family health centers and about 1/2 of community mental health centers; Rogers, in memorandum to HR Subcom on Public Health and Environment, of which he is chmn, says effect would be to seriously retard all health programs subcom that began in '60s; in lr to HEW Dept Sec Weinberger, Rogers says he believes regulations are illegal unless it can be shown that cong intended each of programs to become self-sufficient; asks Weinberger to delay implementing regulations for 120 days and to supply by July 2 evidence that it was intent of Cong to have all programs become self-sustaining; says he does not believe Cong had such intent, news conf

response.abstract: Japan's Sumitomo Group announces on June 26 that it has given $2-million to Yale Univ and $1-million to Japan Society of NYC to promote Japanese-Amer cultural understandings; corp's gift to Yale is largest ever received by univ from benefactor outside US; Sumitomo Metals Co pres H Hyuga and Sumitomo Bank retired pres K Asai comment; por of Koji Asai

response.headline: In Brezhnev's Baggage, A Supply of Ebullience
response.abstract: article on Brezhnev's ebullient manner in US, contrasting with his more formal manner during most of Nixon's visit to Moscow and with Khrushchev's manner during his '59 visit to US; Brezhnev illus with Nixon at Camp David; Brezhnev is wearing jacket given him by Nixon

response.headline: Nixon Committee Is Fined For Concealing Vesco Gift
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's re-election com found guilty and fined the maximum $3000 on June 20 for concealing $200,000 cash contribution from financier R L Vesco in violation of Fed Election Campaign Act of 1971; com had argued that contribution was committed in spoken promise by Vesco to M H Stans before new law took effect, and said Vesco gift fell into 'misty area' between old and new laws; Judge G L Hart rules that actual delivery, 3 days after law took effect, constitutes reptable contribution under new law, comments that he has 'difficulty finding any doubt to shroud this in'; $200,000 contribution at issue in case has also led to indictment in NY of Vesco, former Atty Gen Mitchell, former Commerce Sec Stans and NJ Repub H L Sears on charges of conspiracy and obstruction of justice; details of that indictment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WHITE HOUSE DATA AND DEAN'S DIFFER ABOUT WATERGATE
response.abstract: White House acct of Pres Nixon's conversations with ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d charges that Dean, despite constant pressure from Pros, withheld from Nixon all information about White House involvement in Watergate burglary and cover-up until Mar 21; summary prepared by attys on Sen Watergate com of their interrogation of Dean on June 16 contains material bearing on Dean's assertion that Nixon knew about cover-up plot as far back as Sept; much of evidence against Nixon that Dean gave com staff is hearsay, according to summary, but Dean told of some direct conversations with Nixon in which aspects of cover-up were discussed; Dean's account refers to request to meet with Nixon Mar 21 'to tell the Pres all he knew' about Watergate, but com's summary does not indicate whether Dean did so; new allegations charge former White House counsel C W Colson and former White House aide J D Ehrlichman with seeking permission from Nixon to promise exec clemency to Watergate conspirator E H Hunt Jr; Dean says he 'heard this' from Colson and later this spring had 'discussion with the Pres' about clemency offer; that Dean was instructed by Ehrlichman and former White House chief of staff H R Haldeman to enlist aid of CIA Deputy Dir Walters in covering up Watergate conspiracy; Dean's acct is that White House aides said that Walters 'owed his allegiance to the White House' but that CIA official had declined to help; White House acct, prepared by special counsel to Pres J F Buzhardt Jr, contains White House's version of substance of 18 meetings this yr between Pres and Dean; Dean and White House have agreed that there were more than 35 discussions between Nixon and Dean between late Jan and Apr '73, some face-to-face, some by telephone; acct says that from Mar 1 to Mar 23 Nixon and Dean met about Watergate affair almost daily; says that Dean, in response to Nixon's questions, repeated often that there was no White House involvment in burglary or cover-up; says that Nixon was told by Dean on Mar 13 that G Strachan, then top asst to Haldeman, 'could be involved'; says it was not until Mar 21 that Dean told Nixon that J S Magruder, J N Mitchell and Strachan probably knew, that Haldeman had possibly seen fruits of wiretaps through Strachan and that Ehrlichman was vulnerable because of his approval of Kalmbach's fund-raising efforts; summary presents vivid picture of widespread attempts within upper reaches of White House and Repub Re-Election com to cover up magnitude of Waterate case; Dean accuses Haldeman of having ordered destruction of information obtained from Watergate wiretap, of having joined in planning efforts to obtain White House influence over Repub members of Sen investigating com members and of attempting to persuade ex-Atty Gen Mitchell to 'take the heat' off other officials by assuming blame for Watergate break-in; Dean says, in summary, that Ehrlichman had instructed him to throw wiretapping equipment 'in (the) river' after material was discovered in Hunt's White House safe; summary alleges that Dem ex-Chmn O'Brien was probed by White House as early as '70 and that Nixon special counsel R A Moore tried unsuccessfully in Feb to persuade Mitchell to raise funds for Watergate defendants; Dean illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Cox Weighs Grand Jury On Campaign ‘Extortion’
response.abstract: Special Watergate prosecutor A Cox is considering grand jury investigation to determine whether Pres Nixon's reelection orgn used extortion and other illegal forms of fundraising while collecting over $50-million in campaign contributions, according to sources close to case; sources say T F McBride, special asst to Cox, is expanding his staff to conduct long inquiry into fund-raising practices of H W Kalmbach and M H Stans; say McBride has accumulated allegations indicating Repub officials drew up list of corps and individuals 'who had problems with Govt' and solicited funds in late '71 and early '72 on that basis; copy of Repub rept provided to NY Times by another source shows contribution quotas were set for large corps; rept alludes to 'our goal of $30,000 per corp'; sources say an alternative to convening special grand jury as authorized in 1970 Safe Streets and Crime Control Act would be to convene another 23-member grand jury in Washington, DC, or to require current grand jury now hearing testimony about Watergate cover-up also begin handling fund-raising material; source close to McBride investigation says some large Repub contributors had complained privately about trying to contribute in checks and 'being told to go back and get cash'; says McBride inquiry will embrace all possible criminal violations in connection with handling of campaign funds, including violation of income tax laws
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Return of Astronauts
response.abstract: The Skylab 1 astronauts are scheduled to splash down today at 9:50 A.M. in the Pacific Ocean, ending their 28‐day mission. Page 22.

response.headline: PRICE INDEX ROSE SHARPLY IN MAY
response.abstract: Labor Dept repts on June 21 that food prices rose strongly in May, but increase of 1% was smallest in '73; Pres Nixon's Council of Econ Advisers Chmn Stein, in statement on Pres Nixon's 60-day wage and price freeze, says that freeze on retail food prices will indirectly set ceilings on raw farm products; holds that key aspect or Phase 4, impending program of price controls, is that rise of avg food prices after freeze 'must be very small'; in related development, Agr Dept estimates that food prices for all of '73 will avg about 12% above prices in '72, but refrains from firm estimation of food prices from June until end of yr; graph shows food price increases during last 12 mos

response.headline: 5 DECISIONS BY 6‐4
response.abstract: Sup Ct on June 21 hands down new set of guidelines that will enable states to ban books, magazines, plays and motion pictures that are offensive to local standards, even if they might be acceptable elsewhere

response.headline: U.S. UNIT RELAXES RULE RESTRICTING DIVIDEND PAYOUTS
response.abstract: Com on Interest and Divds announces June 21 new divd guidelines under which co can choose between increasing divds no more than 4% over amt in preceding yr or an amt equal to co's ratio of divds to profits for yrs '68-72 inclusive; com chmn A F Burns statement noted; procedure on calculating divd payments for this calendar yr explained; NYSE chmn Needham lauds com's relaxation of divd guidelines as helping considerably in making common stocks more attractive investment; other analysts favor ruling
