response.headline: 20 Policemen Told to Issue 4,000 Parking Tickets in 2‐Day Test
response.abstract: NYC Police Dept's Traffic Div head W T Bonacum discloses that 20 police officers, each accompanied by superior, have been told to issue 2,000 summonses on June 21 and 2,000 more on June 22 to parking violators in midtown Manhattan area; officers are part of 210-member police team, 170 on intersection control duty and 40 on scooters, plus 25 tow trucks and 125 parking enforcement agents, seeking to reduce traffic congestion in Manhattan between 30th and 66th Sts from river to river; only 15 designated policemen and 13 superior officers are on duty on June 21; they issue 549 summonses in 8-hr period; Bonacum, commenting on low yield, says motorists may have avoided midtown area because of publicity; may expand geographical area covered by policemen in order to increase summonses issued; PBA accuses dept of engaging in 'quota system'; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hunt Said to Get $72 ,000 After a Threat to ‘Tell All’
response.abstract: Sources close to Watergate case say that E H Hunt Jr recd final cash payment of $72,000 in mid-Mar after he had warned J L Ehrlichman that he was ready to 'tell all' about White House operations against Dr D Ellsberg in '71; warning was in lr sent to J W Dean 3d for relay to Ehrlichman; another source says that a few days before lr was sent Hunt told former White House official that he was planning to write book about Watergate unless he got more money; number of sources rept that on either Mar 20 or 21, days on which key White House advisers were discussing Watergate with Pres Nixon, pkg containing $72,000 was delivered by F C LaRue to office of W O Bittman, Hunt's atty; LaRue has been identified as recipient of over $400,000 in cash that was ultimately used to help finance cover-up to Watergate defendants
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Corporate Infighting Noted
response.abstract: ITT memoranda reveal rift within corp over approach toward Chile; hard line of corp relations dept, headed by E J Gerrity Jr, is sharply criticized by legal dept in what seems like interdepartmental rivalry for attention of corp chmn and chief exec H S Geneen; sr counsel R R Dillenbeck warned in 1970 when corp was trying to influence Chile's pres election that forceful approach could jeopardize ITT's future efforts to obtain compensation from US Govt for properties expropriated by Pres Allende; another Dillenbeck memo to co's gen counsel H J Aibel critized letter to pres adviser H A Kissinger by W R Merriam, former head of ITT's Washington office, which he said showed lack of concern for corporate coordination and further risked rejection of corp's claim to compensation; ITT's claim for $92.5-million has since been rejected; memo shows Dillenbeck in substantial disagreement with Gerrity and corp dir of international relations J Neal; says activities by public relations dept are demoralizing and self-defeating to ITT's business goals; ITT staff atty D Crassweller says Gerrity's approach would support leftist assertions about Amer econ imperialism and lead to blacklash against foreign private investment generally; some execs at ITT were said to resent particularly influence of H Hendrix, co dir of public relations for Latin Amer whose headquarters are in NYC and R Berrellez, his counterpart in Latin Amer; despite co's problems in obtaining compensation, its Latin-Amer affairs are reptdly still being shaped by hard-liners
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Exchange Scans Finances Of Nine Brokerage Firms
response.abstract: DuPont Glore Forgan and Walston & Co say June 21 they will close or consolidate 30 to 40 of their branch offices in econ move; also indicate they have recently laid off 150 employes in NY and will lay off additional workers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.S. AND SOVIET PLEDGE SPEED‐UP IN ARMS PARLEY
response.abstract: Nixon and Brezhnev, in White House ceremony on June 21, sign a statement of principles to accelerate SALT talks now under way in Geneva so that a permanent treaty on limiting offensive missiles and bombers can be achieved by end of '74; appear to lay groundwork for a signing in Moscow in '74 when they announce later that Nixon has been invited to visit USSR again next yr and has accepted; both leaders, in toasts at a Soviet Embassy dinner, laud accord to accelerate talks; Dr Kissinger holds news briefing on accord; main points from statement and from his briefing outlined; 2 sides now aim for permanent offensive agreement next yr instead of waiting until interim accord runs out in '77
keywords: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: POP MUSIC INQUIRY BROADENED BY US,
response.abstract: Justice Dept is reptdly widening probe of Columbia Records that arose from connection between former co exec D Wynshaw and alleged heroin trafficker P Falcone; Falcone was indicted by Newark, NJ, grand jury on charge of conspiring to smuggle 5 kilograms of heroin from Canada to US; dept is auditing expense records to co and its subsidiaries seeking evidence of payola and organized crime participation in pop music indus; co is conducting internal investigation seeking links between employes and Falcone
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: State Welfare‐Work Law Upheld by U.S. High Court
response.abstract: US Sup Ct, 7-2, on June 21 reverses lower ct and upholds NYS law that requires able-bodied welfare recipients to demonstrate that they have sought employment or be put to work on public works projects; reverses 3-man Dist Ct in Buffalo that had exempted recipients in aid to dependent children category; Justice L F Powell writes in majority opinion that NY has legitimate interest in encouraging those of its citizens who can work to do so, and thus 'contribute to soc well-being,' in addition to their personal and family support; holds Sup Ct should not interfere with NY's attempt to promote self-reliance and civic responsibility; argues that limited state welfare funds should be spent on behalf of those genuinely incapacitated and most in need
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Allende Target of Proposals
response.abstract: Sen Foreign Relations subcom on multinational corps says on June 21 that ITT 'overstepped the line of acceptable corporate behavior' when in 1970 ITT chmn H S Geneen offered CIA chief of clandestine services in Latin Amer W V Broe a substantial fund to be used to help a conservative opponent of Dr S Allende for pres of Chile, and again after his election when he put $1-million at CIA's disposal in support of any plan that would bring about a coalition in Chilean Sen to defeat Allende; corp dir and former CIA head J A McCone transmitted offer to then CIA dir R Helms and pres adviser H A Kissinger who is chmn of Forty Com, the interdepartmental group that reviews CIA's clandestine operations; plan was never accepted; subcommittee also repts that Broe, on instructions of Helm, offered ITT vice pres E J Gerrity plan for creating econ chaos in Chile, which corp declined thinking it unworkable; subcom also critizes Forty Com, though subcom chmn Sen F Church says it is not clear whether Forty Com was informed in advance of the CIA's proposal to ITT to create econ chaos in Chile or whether it considered consequences for US or Amer business abroad of using cos like ITT for clandestine assignments; subcom proposes clandestine operations of CIA be subject to responsible and effective review both within exec branch and by Cong; proposes bill that would make it a criminal offense for a US citizen to make or offer to make a contribution to a govt agency or officer to influence a foreign election or for govt agency or officer to solicit such a contribution
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Decisions Protested by Nation's Media
response.abstract: Assn of Amer Publishers issues statement on June 22 which echoes reactions of much of book indus toward Sup Ct obscenity decisions; assn exec K D McCormick calls actions 'retrogressive,' warning they will 'impede operations of natl communications companies'; Random House pres R L Bernstein denounces decision as 'call to arms by every crazy vigilante group in this country'; Farrar Straus & Giroux pres R Giroux is echoed by Atheneum head M Bessie in terming strictures as 'terrible'; B Rosset, head of Grove Press which has already fallen afoul of cts under existing obscenity rulings, says legis is 'part of the era of Nixon'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STRESS ON TRUST
response.abstract: Pres Nixon and USSR leader L I Brezhnev fly from Washington to Calif White House on June 23; will spend wk-end there

response.headline: Agenda for Europe Talks Approved by 33 Nations
response.abstract: 33 nations from Soviet and Western blocs have agreed in Helsinki on detailed agenda for forthcoming Eur security conf, including such proposals as exch of mil observers between NATO and Warsaw Pact and advance notice of major mil movements; conf to open formally with meeting of foreign mins in Helsinki on July 3 which is expected to last about wk; 2d phase will consist of series of comms and subcomms working on various issues; what happens in 3d phase, according to Western diplomats, will depend on what comms accomplish; it could be an East-West summit meeting producing new document of principles formally ending cold war or, diplomats say, it could be nothing at all; agenda includes major areas of security, human contacts and cooperation in econ, scientific and tech affairs; other major points noted; 33 participating nations listed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Energy ‘Czar’ Choice
response.abstract: Administration and oil in dustry officials report that Gov. John A. Love of Colo rado, a Republican, is Presi dent Nixon's choice to head the proposed Department of Energy and Natural Re sources. Page 11.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ASTRONAUTS BACK, WEAK AND WOBBLY
response.abstract: Apollo spacecraft with astronauts Capt Conrad, Comdr Weitz and Dr Kerwin splash down in Pacific 840 mi southwest of San Diego on June 22 after crew spends 28 days aboard orbiting Skylab space station; is recovered by USS Ticonderoga; physicians rept that astronauts are experiencing dizziness, nausea, fatigue and low blood pressure as result of exposure to prolonged weightlessness, but that they are recovering gradually; Pres Nixon sends message welcoming return of crew 'from the Skylab spaceship to Spaceship Earth'; tells them: 'You have given conclusive evidence that even with the most advanced scientific and technological support...the courage and resourcefulness of good men are still central to the success of the human adventure'; extends invitation for crew to visit at Western White House at San Clemente, Calif; Skylab project dir Schneider repts that astronauts were able to accomplish 80% of their assigned work with solar telescopes during mission and 90% of med experiments, and that they took earth-surveying photographs of 31 states and 9 countries; map of recovery area in Pacific; astronauts illus on deck of Ticonderoga; illus of Apollo command module being hoisted aboard vessel; TV picture of Skylab space station taken by astronauts from Apollo spacecraft
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Some Stores Here Raise Food Prices Higher Than Ceiling
response.abstract: NY Times survey of food mkts in NY, northeastern NJ and Conn finds that some concerns have raised prices of substantial number of food items above their ceilings--highest levels at which items were sold during wk of June 1 to June 8; points out that in NY-northeastern NJ area 16 of 84 items priced weekly by NYS Agr and Mkts Dept were selling 1 to 10c a pound above ceiling prices; Conn Agr Dept found that 29 of state's mkt basket of 95 food items were sold for 1 to 39c a pound above ceilings; some evidence indicates that a few food items have disappeared, possibly because they could not be sold at ceiling price without substantial loss; IRS, upon learning of results, sends out immediately for state bulletins listing range of prices; agency spokesman says that IRS must make its own audits to develop legal evidence of violations; claims that agency investigators will make spot checks and audits to verify validity of findings; list of foods selling above ceilings in NYC cited
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Experts Agree Prosecutions Will Rise, But Differ on the Over‐all Impact
response.abstract: Sup Ct's June 21 obscenity ruling has provoked massive confusion and contradiction with attys and prosecutors agreeing on only 1 thing--prosecution of pornography will increase--but do not agree on when, how and to what extent it will come; religious leaders in NYC area applaud Ct's action, predicting passage of tougher obscenity laws and renewed assault on pornography; civil libertarians, pornography dealers and fans, and some publishers of erotic material denounce decision as infrigement on 1st Amendment freedoms; various persons who are affected by ct decision comment; illus of Adult City bookstore, Cincinnati, which was closed as result of decision
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TALK BY BREZHNEV
response.abstract: Brezhnev tells group of businessmen on June 22 that cold war is over and that expanded trade relations will be boon to both countries, 90-min speech, Blair House, Washington; notes many things have changed in world in recent yrs, including goods, merchandise and machinery, and says this serves to raise advantageous exchs, which mean trade and cooperation; some of businessmen interviewed after meeting say they were surprised by Brezhnev's warmth and humor and impressed by sincerity of his desire to expand commercial and econ relations between USSR and US; D M Kendall says everybody is convinced that Brezhnev is serious about improved relations and increased trade; following Brezhnev speech, Soviet Min Patolichev and US Sec Shultz sign protocols designed to promote increased cooperation in US-USSR commercial relations and to expand and improve facilities for commercial purposes in both Moscow and Washington; 1 protocol is agreement to help establish USSR-US chamber of commerce with membership from Amer business and financial community; other is agreement that 2 Govts will provide space for trade centers in each other's capital; Patolichev tells Natl Assn of Mfrs luncheon that he is devout supporter of more contacts; says USSR will do anything and everything to help Amer businessmen develop trade with USSR and that he hopes they will do same; NAM announces it will work with other US trade assns to gain approval by Cong of most-favored-nation status for USSR, which would give Moscow same tariff rates as US grants some non-Communist nations
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Costa Rican Court Rejects U.S. Plea to Return Vesco
response.abstract: Panamanian investors in R L Vesco's condominium apt corp have formed an orgn to bring suit to recover $1.3-million in dividends that they contend is due them; name of orgn is SOS Hemispheres, SA; Hemispheres is name of condominium development in Hallandale, Fla
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U.N. Admission of 2 Germanys Approved by Security Council
response.abstract: UN Security Council, by unanimous agreement, on June 22 recommends that 2 Gers be admitted as 133d and 134th members of UN; agreement, reached after yrs of negotiations, is described in Council as 'historic' and reflection of relaxation of East-West tension; also considered landmark advance towards UN goal of universal membership and as possibly setting pattern for other divided countries such as Vietnam and Korea; full UN membership at Gen Assembly session must act on Council's recommendation; US and USSR laud Council action; problems that were posed by admission of 2 Gers detailed; assessments that are expected to be levied on 2 Gers noted; action also seen encouraging membership application for Switzerland; Bahamas is expected to receive recommendation for membership after it becomes ind from GB on July 10; only negative vote at Council is cast by Guinean repr Mrs J M Cisse who expressed Guinea's reservations about granting membership to W Ger; she cited alleged W Ger econ and 'other sabotage' against Guinea and W Ger's cooperation with white minority govts in southern Africa; Kenya repr Odero-Jowi, however, lauded W Ger admission; Council action was taken on basis of consesus of 15 members; Soviet delegate Malik, currently Council pres, did not call for formal vote; illus of W Ger and E Ger flags
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Merrill Lynch Is Charged With Fraud by the S. E. C.
response.abstract: Scientific Control Corp: SEC announces June 22 fraud charges by its enforcement div against Merrill Lynch based on div allegations that in '68-69 Merrill Lynch misled at least 4,000 customers with research repts on Scientific Control Corp; div charges co, research officials P E Albrecht and W Pierce disseminated to branch offices series of optimistic repts and recommendations on Scientific Control, which were without adequate basis and misleading; alleges failure to conduct diligent research analysis, failure to disclose that its recommendations were based largely on unverified information provided by Scientific, and that co and 47 of its salesmen made untrue statements of material facts to prospective Scientific stock buyers; other allegations noted; SEC regional admr W D Moran estimates loss to customers possibly as high as $14-million; says investigation had been in progress for 2 1/2 yrs; Merrill Lynch chmn D T Regan disputes charges; says co already won dismissal of 2 civil ct cases involving Scientific Control; complains co was rebuffed by SEC when it requested copy of complaint after news leaked out, causing trading in Merrill Lynch stock to be halted; Moran, chief enforcement officer T R Beirne and asst regional admr W Nortman illus
keywords: VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES ACTS AND TRADING RULES
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: The President
response.abstract: Article gives preview of testimony ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d is expected to give to Sen Watergate com on June 25; says Dean's testimony is crucial to Watergate case because more than anyone else he was by all accts at center of buggings, burglaries, pol espionage, cover‐ups and pay‐offs; notes other recent developments

response.headline: NEW DEAN CHARGE ON NIXON AWAITED
response.abstract: Sources close to J W Dean 3d say that Dean will tell Sen Watergate com that Pres Nixon indicated to him in mid‐Mar that he had discussed exec clemency for E H Hunt Jr with C W Colson; say that Dean will testify that Pres seemed upset as he described conversations; David I Shapiro, Colson's law partner, holds exec clemency charge is nonsense; Colson has denied published repts that he relayed request for exec clemency to Dean and J D Ehrlichman; White House reptdly prepared to counterattack as soon as Dean's testimony is completed; sources close to White House say that Dean's most damaging testimony will concern matters not related to Watergate; Dean reptdly preparing statement of over 150 pages to read at opening of his testimony

response.headline: Pilic Case: Pros Attack at the Net

response.headline: Hope for Meat Price Cuts Fades Despite the Freeze

response.headline: Beame Stepping Up Drive In the Runoff With Badillo
response.abstract: NYC Dem mayoral aspirant Controller Beame intensifies campaign; is fearful that low turnout among orgn Dems could help Badillo, who has hard‐core support of liberals, Puerto Ricans and Negroes; begins radio‐TV drive; B Beame comments; Beame campaigns on Lower E Side, Badillo in Bklyn; illus of both; both sides expected to spend amts up to $250,000; Beame and party leaders such as Councilman Troy counting on local Dem capts to get out vote; Badillo is being aided by New Dem Coalition clubs and primary will be major test for antiorgn groups

response.headline: Pirates Beat Mets, 3‐2, On Sanguillen Hit in 10th
response.abstract: PITTSBURGH, June 23 — It took 10 innings and some alert play by the Pirates to return the. New York Mets to their losing ways tonight. A line single by Manny Sanguillen with the bases loaded gave Pittsburgh a 3‐2 victory.

response.headline: U.S., SOVIET SIGN PACT TO STEP UP AIRLINE SERVICE
response.abstract: US and USSR on June 23 sign agreement, which will expand commercial air service between both nations; pact calls for 'a modest expansion' in passenger service by Pan Amer and Aeroflot, which presently operate flights between NYC and Moscow; will give Pan Amer landing rights in Leningrad and Aeroflot landing privileges in Washington, DC, and will permit both carriers 3 round‐trip flights per wk instead of current twice‐wkly limit; will allow Pan Amer to use Boeing 747s for flights to western Eur, where it would transfer Moscow‐bound passengers to smaller Boeing 707s; under agreement both carriers have pledged to facilitate charter flights between both nations; Pan Amer carried 7,000 travelers to USSR in '71 and '72, and Aeroflot 11,500 and 17,000 during same period; US and USSR established commercial airline service in '68; agreement is signed by US Transportation Sec Brinegar and Soviet Civil Aviation Min Bugayev, and is 9th Soviet‐Amer agreement made public during Amer visit of USSR Communist party leader Brezhnev

response.headline: New Vietnam Accord Brings Reduction In the Fighting but Little Other Change
response.abstract: Fighting has dipped to about same level as in late May in wk since Vietnam cease‐fire was reaffirmed but little else has changed; most of directives of joint communique that was to have led to stricter carrying out of Jan peace agreement have been ignored; Saigon and Vietcong remain deadlocked in talks on working out mil aspects of accord; Saigon wants zones of control to be temporary and for strictly mil purposes while Vietcong wants them to be permanent sectors for both mil and pol activity

response.headline: Brokers in City Moving Toward Rise in Fees
response.abstract: Combination of Govt pressure and econ factors indicates that after 60‐day Fed price freeze, which began earlier in June, NYC real estate brokers intend to charge more for virtually all transactions; last mo firm of Douglas Gibbons‐Hollyday & Ives raised its commission from 5% to 6% on sales of co‐op apts, marking 1st time that major firm has ignored commission schedule suggested by Real Estate Bd of NY Inc; for more than 10 yrs bd has recommended commission rates for sales of real estate in Manhattan but now Fed Govt has challenged this practice on antitrust grounds and though brokers say fee increase would be result of purely econ factors, there are indications that increase is also response to Govt pressure to make fees more competitive; Justice Dept spokesman says Govt is not concerned if fees go up or down but only about collusive acts through which any group sets prices in violation of open competition; brokers comment
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Vast Famine Toll Is Feared in Africa by October
response.abstract: article on plight of African farmers suffering as result of 5‐yr‐long drought notes that more than 25‐million people depend on almost daily food deliveries to stay alive; points out that for many people in Niger, Mali, Mauritania, Sengal, Upper Volta and Chad hunger is normal part of life; UN relief workers warn that vast numbers of people could die of starvation by Oct; estimate that more that 1/3 of area's livestock have perished; Govt spokesmen rept that hunger and weakness have contributed to untold deaths from disease; AID mission dir D McAdams says that if supplies are halted and summer rains isolate communities in area, nations could be 'standing on brink of disaster'; article notes that many farmers have abandoned their farms and moved to cities in search of food; plight of several farmers discussed; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A.M.A. Speaker Declares
response.abstract: Dr R R Fieve on June 24 says that manic phase of milder forms of manic-depression may be positive energizer that drives some of most creative and productive over-achievers in current soc, speech before AMA symposium on depression as major US health problem; calls depression 'probably most widespread of all psychic illness'; estimates that some 6-million Amers suffer 'recurrent bouts' of manic-depression; says that such gifted individuals as outstanding writers, politicians, business execs and scientists have been enabled by condition to achieve heights of imagination, energy and success; says that without proper treatment, these persons may suddenly crash into depression that is evident only after successful suicide; describes symptoms; suggests treatment with lithium carbonate; Dr N S Kline says gen practitioner who avoids treating psychiatric patients is 'med truant'; Dr W E Bunney Jr says fact that most of nation's 30,000 recorded suicides each yr by victims of depression heightens need for research in diagnostic differentiation between types of depression; theatrical producer and dir J Logan describes his bouts with manic-depression

response.headline: RACISM IS CHARGED BY FOES IN RUNOFF IN CITY TOMORROW
response.abstract: Controller Beame and Repr Badillo on June 24 exch racism charges during final TV debate before NYC Dem mayoral runoff primary, WNEW-TV town meeting; confrontation is 'strident' and 'raucous'; Beame charges Badillo urges Puerto Ricans to vote only for Puerto Rican, Badillo cites allegedly racist Beame ad in Jewish Press; Badillo calls Beame 'malicious' little man; Beame disavows ads; other charges; Badillo says he met with Biaggi aides to seek help, not of Biaggi, but of some of his Italian supporters; Rabbi S Rubin says he paid $1,000 for Beame ad in Jewish Press

response.headline: Ziegler, Two Others Implicated by Dean In Cover‐Up Effort
response.abstract: ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d implicates White House press sec Ziegler, special counsel to Pres R A Moore and former White House aide W H Johnson Jr in Watergate cover‐up attempt; Dean says Ziegler attended Oct 15 '72 meeting to discuss strategy for dealing with 'cascading leaked stories' regarding activities of D H Segretti, who has been described as dirty‐tricks operative in Nixon re‐election campaign; suggests that Segretti's role was to have been minimized, as it in fact was at subsequent news briefings by Ziegler; discusses discrepancies between announced version by Ziegler of reasons for then‐apptmts sec Chapin's resignation and actual reason of his links to Segretti; says that when he confronted then‐White House aide Ehrlichman with data he had gathered about wiretaps on telephones of newsmen and White House staff members, Ehrlichman confirmed existence of taps; says when he asked Ehrlichman what Ziegler should say Ehrlichman told him that Ziegler should 'flatly deny it'; says Moore knew great deal and that he flew to NY to urge ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell to raise money demanded by 7 original Watergate defendants as price for silence; Dean says Johnson was principal in effort to defuse Sen Watergate hearings by planting either Sens or minority counsel likely to take White House point of view

response.headline: Warrant Issued for Hecht in Vase Sale
response.abstract: Italian authorities have issued warrant for arrest of R E Hecht Jr, who sold 2,500‐yr‐old Euphronios vase to Met Museum of Art last yr for $1‐million; charge he bought and exported vase illegally; say they have enough evidence to arrest him, should he return to Italy, and to make successful claim for recovery of krater in US, although such a step would not be taken in near future; police chief Col F Mambor says that nature of evidence tends to support account of vase's discovery given by bootleg excavator A Cenere, who has said that he and 5 others found vase in Etruscan tomb near Cerveteri in '71; says that Italian officials are checking out various information before effort is made to confront museum officials in NY
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PETERSEN CALLED CONDUIT FOR DATA
response.abstract: ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d tells Sen Watergate com on June 25 that H E Petersen, while head of Justice Dept's criminal investigation of Watergate case, passed information on grand jury testimony to White House and arranged for high White House aides to be questioned outside presence of grand jurors; Dean describes repeated attempts by White House staff members to seek confidential information from Fed agencies investigating scandal and, in some cases, to alter direction or substance of investigation; says he once called Petersen to ask how a Nixon re‐election com official 'had done before the grand jury'; says Petersen later informed him that official J S Magruder, then Nixon campaign deputy dir, 'had made it through by the skin of his teeth'; says Petersen also arranged for 5 high White House aides, including C W Colson, to be questioned by Watergate prosecutors away from grand jury; recounts number of contacts with other Adm officials he alleges were involved in cover‐up and were with Justice Dept; tells of attempts by Haldeman and others to persuade then‐Atty Gen Kleindienst to abandon his 'passive role in the investigaton and prosecution' and later, to convince him to work 'closely' with Repub vice chmn of Watergate com; says Sen Baker had requested Kleindienst as his 'contact point' in Adm; tells of alleged interference with civil lawsuit related to bugging, of attempts to squelch FBI inquiry into Repub campaign contributions that might lead to 'unnecessary embarrassment,' and of telling Pres himself that Justice Dept 'had held off as long as possible the return of the indictments' in case, which were handed down Sept 15; says he learned late last summer that R McPhee, gen counsel for Repub Natl Finance Com was having private discussions with the Fed judge presiding over a civil suit brought by Dems in connection with bugging; charges that ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell was also aware of alleged ex‐parte contacts as were attys for re‐election com; Judge Richey says on June 25 that he cannot remember discussing Dem suit with McPhee, telephone int; re‐election com atty Parkinson says he never 'had any private communications, direct or indirect, with Judge Richey' in connection with suit; Dean describes his dealings with then‐FBI Acting Dir Gray; Dean describes his own role in cover‐up as 1 of reptg to White House and Re‐Election com officials 'all the information I was receiving about the case from the Justice Dept and the FBI'; acknowledges that he was given by Gray some 80 FBI repts on FBI's Watergate investigation; contradicts earlier statements by Petersen when he says he 1st asked Petersen for materials but was told to 'deal directly with Gray'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HOUSE APPROVES CUTOFF OF FUNDS TO BOMB CAMBODIA
response.abstract: article on US HR approval on June 25 to cut off additional funding for bombing in Cambodia notes that Presidential deputy press sec at Western White House, San Clemente, Calif, tells newsmen that Pres Nixon feels such restrictions endanger viability of structure of peace achieved in Laos; antiwar provision adopted by HR and drafted by Sen T F Eagleton (Mo) specifies that none of money provided by supplemental appropriations bill and no funds left over from any previous appropriations may be used to support combat activities in Cambodia or Laos
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DEAN TELLS INQUIRY THAT NIXON TOOK PART IN WATERGATE COVER‐UP FOR EIGHT MONTHS; HE ALSO NAMES HALDEMAN AND EHRLICHMAN
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, June 25 —John W. Dean 3d, asserting that President Nixon had failed to heed a warning that the Watergate case was “a cancer growing on the Presidency,” testified today that the Presi dent had taken part in, the Watergate cover‐up for as long as eight months.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Private School Aid in State Upset by Supreme Court
response.abstract: US Sup Ct on June 25 invalidates Penna law designed to reimburse parents of private school pupils for part of their tuition expense

response.headline: Dean Hearing Highlights
response.abstract: highlights of ex‐White House counsel J W Dean 3d's June 25 testimony before Sen Watergate com

response.headline: BREZHNEV LEAVES U. S. FOR FRANCE
response.abstract: communique, as amplified by Pres Nixon's natl security adviser H A Kissinger at end of talks between Nixon and Soviet Communist party leader Brezhnev on June 25, notes that both sides concurred on need to avoid big‐power conflict in Middle East; says that 'you have no idea how close we came to war' because of fighting in Jordan in '70, when Syrian tank forces, advised by Soviet mil men, crossed briefly into Jordan on side of Palestinians and then engaged in clashes with Jordanian Army; Kissinger illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Victory Today Is Predicted By Both Beame and Badillo
response.abstract: NYC Controller Beame and US Repr Badillo on June 25 both predict they will win Dem mayoral primary runoff election; 600,000 Dems expected to vote; winner will emerge as prohibitive favorite to win Nov gen election; aspirants' campaign activities during day detailed; Beame takes walking tour in Flatbush sec, Bklyn; Badillo appears at exuberant rally in garment dist, Manhattan; Beame and Badillo engage in final TV debate, which is dull and unemotional in sharp contrast to their 'ill‐mannered' clash during TV debate on June 24; Repr Biaggi aides say Biaggi will vote for Beame; Beame is accompanied in Flatbush by Bklyn Boro Pres Leone and NYS Assembly Minority Leader Steingut; rancorous runoff primary campaign revd; Beame and Badillo illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: STATEMENT CITED
response.abstract: White House deputy press sec G L Warren says on June 26 that Nixon stands by his May 22 statement on Watergate case, which conflicts with J W Dean 3d testimony to Sen com that Pres was involved in cover-up; statement held Nixon was unaware of his aides' cover-up efforts; Warren refuses to comment directly on Dean testimony; gives impression Nixon is more concerned with carrying out duties on domestic and foreign affairs than with Watergate case; says he seems in 'very good mood'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Vase Is Again Defended By NICHOLAS GAGE
response.abstract: Met Museum of Art pres C D Dillon says on June 26 that museum officials have concluded on basis of available evidence that vase was not smuggled out of Italy, press conf held to release rept of special trustees com headed by R L Gilpatric that was assigned last Mar to examine museum policies; states that while no investigation was conducted to explain contradictions surrounding acquisition of calyx krater, museum recd no evidence to contradict assertion of R E Hecht Jr, who has been charged by Ital police with illegally exporting vase from Italy, that vase had belonged to Lebanese art dealer D A Sarrafian; says that museum invited Ital Govt to send reprs to NY to examine vase more than 7 wks ago but it has yet to receive reply; cites sworn affidavit, obtained 'through' Hecht, of Swiss vase restorer F Buerki contending that vase was restored several mos before admitted bootleg digger A Cenere said it was dug up in Etruscan tomb in Cerveteri in '71; neither Dillon nor Gilpatric express any concern that Hecht's account has been contradicted in part by Sarrafian, who has claimed that several pieces of vase were missing and that bulk of money paid by museum for vase was kept by Hecht; Dillon says that museum's vase is complete and that Sarrafian may have thought some pieces were missing because he did not see assembled vase; states that museum in future will require more evidence of ownership when buying art objects but maintains that in present instance proof requested was more than adequate; holds that arrest warrant issued by Ital authorities for Hecht did not come as surprise to museum officials since they felt Italians had to take some action by this time or drop whole investigation; says, when asked whether museum would return vase to Italy should it be proven that it came from there, that it would be up to trustees but that if museum were to give it back, it would be only as gesture of goodwill because museum would not have violated any laws in buying vase; vase illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 1971‐73 Deals Studied
response.abstract: Met Museum on June 26 makes public new procedures governing removal and sale or exch of works from its collections; also issues Rept on Art Transactions 1971-73, concerned with dealings that gave rise to recent controversy, prepared by special 8-member com of trustees; museum, in statement accompanying announcements, says its previous procedures on deaccessioning and disposal 'apparently were inadequate in preventing doubts and misunderstanding in public mind concerning art transactions and perhaps contributed to that misunderstanding'; principal changes in museum procedures listed; museum says it will continue to explore with other museums possibility of joint purchases of works of art; museum spokesman says new procedures were adopted earlier this mo by bd of trustees; museum pres D Dillon, com head R L Gilpatric and dir T P F Hoving hold news conf; Hoving admits museum may have miscalculated tenor of the times in acting 'the way we had always acted'; says he believes 'we were out of pace with desire for public disclosure'; NYS Atty Gen Lefkowitz announces that inquiry his office conducted on museum's transactions has been concluded with adoption by museum of 'safeguards of the public interest in the museum'; his office issues statement noting Lefkowitz's inquiry showed that much of public criticism directed to his office was result of museum's own indifference to public's legitimate and understandable interest in museum's activities; asserts it would have been better for museum and public interest if museum had revealed the full facts; special com attributes museums controversial decision to sell Rousseau painting The Tropics to impact of its puchase-fund reserves caused by '70 acquisition of work by Velazques; defends sale of work by Rousseau from de Groot bequest; Dillon, in reply to question on whether NY Times carried on 'vendetta' against museum, absolves NY Times 'as such' but maintains that Times reporter J L Hess did carry on vendetta; Hess says he stands by accuracy of his repts; illus of Hoving, Gilpatric and Dillon
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Johnson Reportedly Told F. B.I. to Check on Agnew
response.abstract: Pres Johnson ordered FBI to 'check' Vice Pres-elect Agnew's long-distance telephone calls in Nov, '68, according to Govt sources and full rept provided to Sen Watergate com; FBI inquiry did not confirm White House suspicions linking Agnew with what White House considered to be South Vietnamese sabotage of Paris peace negotiations in '68
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A 3‐10‐2 VICTORY;Controller Is a Heavy Favorite to Become 105th Mayor Here
response.abstract: Controller Beame easily defeats opponent US Repr Badillo by 3-to-2 margin in June 26 runoff primary election for NYC Dem mayoral nomination; tally of votes in 5 boros; victory, in which Beame lost only Manhattan and nearly doubled his 34% vote in initial June 4 primary, makes him 'commanding' favorite to be elected Mayor in Nov; is not only personal triumph but victory for city's Dem orgn, which is believed to be at least partially responsible for record turnout of about 900,000 voters, 125,000 more than voted in 1st primary; Beame will face in Nov 2 Dems he defeated in June 4 primary, Conservative party candidate US Repr Biaggi and Liberal party candidate NYS Assemblyman Blumenthal, as well as Repub nominee NYS Sen Marchi; tells cheering supporters at Biltmore Hotel, where he appears with his wife, S Terry and son, both of whom are Beame co-campaign mgrs, that his victory is 'double' one, meaning Dem nomination and triumph over 'myth of apathy'; predicts that he will unify party; Terry retorts, when asked whether win was anti-Puerto Rican reaction, that it was reaction against Badillo; Badillo does not congratulate Beame or indicate whether he will back him in Nov in his concession speech at campaign hq, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel; scene there described; 1 of keys to Beame victory was switch of voters who had backed Biaggi in earlier primary, as evidenced by Beame's lead in all 10 Assembly dists carried earlier by Biaggi; victory makes it more likely that Beame can unify badly-split Dems and thus cut Blumenthal's chances of capturing liberal Dem vote in Nov; campaigns of Beame, who tried to update his generally staid appearance by wearing 'mod' shirts, and Badillo, who tried to tone down his 'short-fused' personality by dressing conservatively, described; illus of Badillo and wife; illus of Beame and wife; illus of polling station
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Medicare Aid Is Extended To Major Kidney Patients
response.abstract: US Govt on June 26 announces regulations extending Medicare coverage to persons of any age who need kidney transplants or regular periodic treatment with artificial kidney machines; coverage, which goes into effect on July 1, is expected to cost Govt nearly $250-million in initial yr and much more thereafter; some estimates have indicated it could cost as much as $1-billion yrly within a few yrs; new Medicare coverage is of crucial importance to thousands of patients with advanced incurable kidney disease; artificial kidney treatments cost between $4,000 and $25,000 yrly, depending on circumstances, and must be continued for rest of patient's life unless transplant is involved; total cost of transplant often is estimated at about $20,000; rules anounced are interim regulations; HEW Dept needs more time to work out final regulations in the unprecedented situation; regulations outlined
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Dean Says Ziegler Didn't Know ‘ Truth’ of Watergate Cover‐Up
response.abstract: J W Dean 3d tells Sen com investigating Watergate affair on June 26 that White House press sec Ziegler did not know truth when he repeatedly denied any White House involvement in affair and attempted cover-up; says Ziegler often asked to be briefed on the facts but that he told Ziegler he was under instructions from Ehrlichman not to brief him; suggests Ziegler acquiesced to role in cover-up by following guidance of himself, Haldeman or Ehrlichman to take 'offensive approach' in news confs and 'hedge and bob and weave' without actually lying; gives com text of 'practice session' last Oct in which several White House aides assumed parts of reporters and quized Ziegler aggressively on stories linking Nixon aide D L Chapin to D Segretti; says, under questioning by minority counsel F D Thompson, that he knows of 'no impropriety' on party of Asst Atty Gen H E Petersen, who originally headed Justice Dept probe of case; says Petersen was trying 'to be very fair with the White House' because he knew appearance of White House staff members before grand jury could embarrass White House in 'pol yr'; Petersen holds he has done nothing to be ashamed of; Atty Gen Richardson on June 26 stands by earlier statement that there is no evidence to cast doubt on Petersen's integrity; Ziegler illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: U. S. TRADE IN MAY FELL INTO DEFICIT
response.abstract: Japanese Trade Min says in white paper released on June 26 that Japan should take 'fresh look' at its foreign aid
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HOUSE AGAIN‐ACTS TO CURB BOMBING
response.abstract: HR votes on June 26 to extend proposed ban on US bombing in Cambodia by attaching amendment to continuing resolution which permits Fed agencies to continue operating into new fiscal yr even though Cong has not yet approved needed money
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A NEW CHALLENGE
response.abstract: Ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d testifies on June 26 before Sen Watergate com that Pres Nixon misled nation in his public statements on Watergate case and insists that his charges of Pres complicity in Watergate cover-up are factual; disputes each of series of Pres explanations of Watergate burglary, describing them as misleading, unfounded or overly 'broad'; White House repr says Pres Nixon will stand on his May 22 statement disavowing any participation in planning of Watergate break-in or subsequent cover-up; Dean acknowledges that he was in position of presenting his word, as deposed White House atty, against that of Pres; insists his only motive in testifying is to end his personal involvement in cover-up and to respond to com's request for knowledge of it; says he did not provide any basis for Nixon to declare on Oct 5 that Watergate investigation conducted by FBI had pursued every possible lead 'to the end'; says he is 'quite aware' that Nixon never recd rept on Watergate from him when Nixon said on Mar 17 that Dean had undertaken such an investigation; says he does not believe Nixon was telling truth when he asserted on Apr 17 that he would 'condemn any attempts to cover up this case'; details his quarrel with Nixon's May 22 statement; testifies White House maintained, and constantly updated, 'enemies list' of individuals unfriendly to Adm; says that, in his opinion, Haldeman would have been advised in advance of plans to wiretap Dem hq and that Haldeman 'probably would have reptd it' to Pres; says, when asked by minority counsel F D Thompson about how he became involved in cover-up, 'I was in the process before I began thinking about the process'; Thompson elicits from Dean statement that Dean did not mean to imply on June 25 that Asst Atty Gen Petersen acted unethically in providing information to White House about scope and conduct of Govt's inquiry into case last yr; Dean asserts he refused, at direction of then-White House aide J D Ehrlichman, to brief Ziegler and C MacGregor on facts of Watergate case; illus of Dean, Sen Montoya and com room
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Panel Is Told White House Urged I.R.S. Political Acts
response.abstract: documents submitted to Sen Watergate com by ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d show that members of Pres Nixon's White House staff made repeated unsuccessful attempts to get IRS to conduct 'pol actions and investigations'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A MEMO FOR PANEL
response.abstract: White House says on June 27 that J W Dean 3d was 'mastermind' of Watergate cover-up and that former Atty Gen Mitchell, Dean's 'patron,' was responsible for intelligence gathering scheme that led to Watergate break-in; charges are contained in long White House interpretation of Dean's testimony before Sen Watergate com, prepared by White House special counsel J F Buzhardt; Sen D K Inouye reads what is widely considered to be White House's counterattack into record, saying it would be fair to use it to test Dean's believability and to give Pres 'his day in ct'; document strongly suggests that Dean became active participant in Watergate cover-up to protect Mitchell, his former employer at Justice Dept; refers to meetings Dean had with Mitchell and others after Watergate burglary and attributes to them the planning for cover-up activities; says it was Dean, 'purportedly acting on behalf of Mitchell,' who proposed raising hush money for Watergate defendants; says Dean and Mitchell prepared for a witness at Jan Watergate trial to commit perjury; says Mitchell sponsored Dean for his job at White House; during reading of White House document Dean interrupts frequently to dispute its rationale or facts; White House counterattack says although it would have been embarrassing to Pres if true facts about Watergate became known right after June 17 break-in, Nixon, 'an immensely popular Pres,' could have weathered pol embarrassment if only he had been fully informed at that time; says because of Dean's cover-up, pol problem now has been 'magnified 1,000-fold' because truth is coming to light belatedly and because of insinuations that White House was party to cover-up; says 'the added consequences were J Dean's doing'; White House document follows 3 hrs of questioning of Dean by Repub Sen Gurney, considered a friend of White House; illus of Dean, his wife, spectators and com members
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Soybeans and Cottonseed Under Export Embargo
response.abstract: US Govt, in effort to prevent outright shortage of feed for cattle, hogs and poultry, imposes on June 27 export controls on soybeans and cottonseed and their products; Agr Sec Butz says that if move succeeds in bringing down feed prices, there will be less need to raise recently imposed price ceilings on meat products
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SCORES OF NAMES
response.abstract: former White House counsel J W Dean, in testimony to Sen Watergate com, says White House lists of political enemies included names of prominent academicians
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Earl Browder Dies
response.abstract: Earl Browder, who led the Communist party of the United States as general secretary from 1930 to 1946, its years of greatest influence, died yesterday at 82. Page 50.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FIVE YOUTHS RIOT IN BROOKLYN RIOT
response.abstract: at least 5 youths are shot and 5 policemen are injured on June 27 as rioting erupts along tense thoroughfare in Pk Slope section of Bklyn; bands of teen-agers roam neighborhood, smashing windows, stoning and fire-bombing passing cars and hurling garbage from curbside; gunfire is interspersed amid hundreds of firecrackers that explode in air as police attempt to quell disturbance, which broke out at about midnight; police rept that violence originated between Hispanic and Italian residents; say that hostility between 2 groups has persisted for months; nearby youths give accounts of disturbance; A Navas, 17, contends that when policemen attempted to rescue youth who had been shot in neck, police were confronted by hostile group of youths; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pentagon Says Truce Permits Cut in Aid to Vietnam and Laos
response.abstract: Deputy Sec W P Clements Jr says on June 27 that cease-fire agreements will permit reduction of at least $500-million in planned mil aid to S Vietnam and Laos in fiscal '74, testimony to Sen Armed Services Com; proposes that over-all ceiling on actual deliveries of mil aid be reduced from level of $2.1-billion originally requested; says that $1.2-billion in mil aid appropriations will be sufficient; warns against further reductions; opposes proposal to transfer mil aid for 2 countries, now included in defense budget, back to regular mil aid legis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SIRICA GETS PLEA
response.abstract: F C LaRue, J N Mitchell's asst at Nixon re-election com, pleads guilty in Fed Dist Ct on June 27 to charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice; agrees to cooperate with special prosecution force investigating Watergate break-in and to testify as Govt witness at any future trials; reads short statement to ct in which he says he attended Mar '72 meeting at which Watergate bugging was discussed; says plan, which he recommended against, was not approved in his presence; says his knowledge and involvement increased after Watergate burglars were arrested inside Dem hq; says 3 days after break-in he learned from G G Liddy that he (Liddy) was 'involved in this fiasco'; LaRue says he sat in on meetings with J S Magruder and others when they discussed 'protective' story Magruder would tell Fed investigators; says 'I joined in that cover-up, at least by acquiescence'; says he received and distributed cash to Watergate defendants and their attys; LaRue, by pleading guilty to information filed with ct by special prosecutor A Cox, waived his right to go before grand jury to weigh an indictment against him which cites 7 'overt acts of conspiracy'; Cox had arranged with LaRue's atty a plea of guilty to conspiracy charges, and agreed to drop all other charges against LaRue; Judge J J Sirica delays sentencing of LaRue until after disposition of any new indictments which, he said, would presumably include 'references to activities in which LaRue has been involved'; LaRue could face as much as 5 yrs in prison and $10,000 fine; Cox says extent of LaRue's cooperation 'will be brought to ct's attention before sentencing'; illus of LaRue
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Doctor Charged With Murder In ‘Mercy Killing’ in Nassau
response.abstract: Dr V A Montemarano, chief surgical resident of Nassau County Med Center, NY, on June 27 is indicted on charge of 'willful murder' in death last Dec of E Bauer, 59, who had been suffering from cancer of throat and had been given 2 days to live; allegedly injected lethal dose of potassium chloride intravenously while Bauer was 'in comatose state'; is arraigned before Judge F X Altimari; pleads not guilty and is released on $25,000 bail; sources rept that case initially came to attention of Dist Atty Cahn last wk through Nassau County Exec R G Caso, who was approached several wks ago by county hosp's superintendent J F Collins; Collins is said to have raised possibility of a killing at the hosp; findings of preliminary investigation by hosp's bd of managers, ordered by Caso, were turned over to Cahn; Cahn says that a nurse witnessed the injection and notes there are other witnesses but declines to say who they are; also declines to say whether the family had requested Montemarano to admr drug in lethal dose; says ct order will be sought for exhumation of body, although no trace of drug will be found because it does not remain in the body; S D Rosoff, counsel of Euthanasia Soc of Amer, says this is 1st indictment of dr in NYS and 1st in nation since '49, when Dr H Sander was accused of killing female patient who had incurable cancer by injecting air into her veins; death certificate signed by Montemarano lists only cancer as cause of death; Cahn says his office is examining cases of all Monetmarano's former cancer patients since he joined med center in '70; Montemarano illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Top Democrats Endorse Beame in a Show of Unity
response.abstract: top Dems, including Sen McGovern and H J Samuels, endorse NYC Controller Beame for Mayor in rare display of Dem party unity; Beame forces hope action will help head off large-scale defections to 2 other Dems in race: Conservative candidate Repr Biaggi and Liberal nominee Assemblyman Blumenthal; several leading Dems affiliated with New Dem Coalition, which supported Repr Badillo in June 26 runoff primary, also endorse Beame, long identified with Bklyn Dem orgn; among them are Sen Goldin, running for Controller on Dem and Liberal lines, Repr Koch and former coalition chmn D Collins; 2 notable exceptions are Badillo and Lindsay; Lindsay aides hold Lindsay has not ruled out eventual Beame endorsement; Beame aides says liberal Dems who supported Beame in primary, including East Side dist leader M Begun and antiorgn Queens Dem J Kroll, are seeking to persuade other liberal Dems to support Beame; New Dem Coalition chmn A Weiss says no decision will be made until meeting of orgn's officers next wk; substantial coalition support for Beame would deprive Blumenthal of prime source of campaign workers and money; S Mott and M Fife, 2 of Badillo's top fund-raisers, say they have no plans to finance Blumenthal candidacy; there is little personal hostility toward Beame among Dems; Dem City Council Pres nominee P O'Dwyer also expected to back Beame; maps show ADs carried by Beame and Badillo in June 26 runoff primary and ADs won by Beame, Badillo, Biaggi and Blumenthal in June 4 primary
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TEST INTENSIFIES
response.abstract: Sen opponents of US bombing in Cambodia put rider calling for cut off of funds for bombing to bill which extends debt ceiling; debt ceiling legis is needed to keep Govt operating at full strength after end of fiscal yr June 30
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AIDES DENY NIXON APPROVED CHARGE
response.abstract: Spokesmen for Pres Nixon try again on June 28 to dissociate Pres from any personal involvement in or approval of document submitted by White House to Sen Watergate com June 27 which labeled J W Dean 3d 'principal author of pol and const crisis Watergate now epitomizes' and accuses Dean of master-minding unsuccessful cover-up of Watergate burglary; document was prepared by Pres's special counsel, J F Buzhardt Jr; in related matter, deputy press sec G L Warren says Nixon will not accept invitation or subpoena to appear before Sen com; says 'we feel Pres should not testify' and 'subpoena...would be const inappropriate'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Judge Orders U.S. Funds Released for Youth Corps
response.abstract: Fed Dist Ct Judge L I Garth on June 28 orders US Labor Dept to release $239-million budgeted for nationwide Neighborhood Youth Corps and orders Office of Mgt and Budget to refrain from taking steps that would allow funds to revert to US Treas Dept
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Gross Gets 3 Years For Taking Bribo
response.abstract: T Gross, former NYC Youth Services Comr, is sentenced to 3 yrs in prison on June 28 for having taken kickbacks on city contracts during his 16 mos in office; Gross, just before sentence is imposed by NYS Sup Ct Justice G P Culkin, tells ct he apologizes to people of NYC and to his close friends who had trust in him; pleaded guilty in April; could have been sentenced to 7 yrs; Asst Dist Atty L R Genge, who prosecuted case, tells ct that Gross had been asked repeatedly to cooperate with Manhattan Dist Atty's office to get information about possible criminal activity within city adm and that Gross had refused; Gross was indicted on 8 counts on Feb 20 for accepting $41,000 in bribes; 2 mos ago he pleaded guilty to taking $2,500 in bribes from Urbanomics Corp, mgt consultant firm; H Borg is Gross's atty; Gross illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Panel in Congress To Study Charges On Tax‐Audit Use
response.abstract: Joint Com on Internal Revenue Taxation of Cong, headed by Repr W D Mills, on June 28 orders investigation of allegations made at Sen Watergate com hearings that Nixon Adm, through IRS, used tax audits to punish its enemies and help its friends
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: TEAMSTERS AGREE TO 7%‐A‐YEAR RISE IN 33‐MONTH PACT
response.abstract: US trucking indus and Teamsters union on June 28 agree to new 33-mo master freight contract providing wage and benefit increases averaging 7% a yr to 400,000 truck drivers; contract continues pattern of moderate wage settlements established by collective bargaining agreements in other major industries in '73; will take effect on July 1 if ratified by Teamsters membership; calls for increases of 35c an hr in 1st yr, 30c more in 2d yr and 30c additional in 3d yr for drivers paid on hrly basis; wages for these drivers now avg $6 an hr; increase will be 3-qrs of a cent in 1st and 2d yrs and half a cent in 3d yr on top of current 12.5c a mi for drivers paid by mi; settlement is close to Govt's econ stabilization program standard that seeks to limit wage increases to around 5.5%; Labor Sec Brennan hails settlement as 'good news for Amer public and for nation's econ,' statement; says agreement will assure that vital means of transportation will continue to operate uninterrupted; Teamsters also win increases in health and welfare pension programs; these fringe benefits add another 40c an hr to package; cos, there are 1,200 of them party to contract, also agree to pay cost of living increase of at least 8c an hr and no more than 11c an hr in 1st and 3d yrs of contract; wage-benefit increases total 7.2% in 1st 2 yrs and 6.6% in 3d yr, with additional holidays, vacation time and funeral leave; contract will expire in 33 mos instead of 3 yrs at insistence of Teamsters pres Fitzsimmons

response.headline: ERVIN INDIRECTLY ASKS PRESIDENT TO TESTIFY ON ROLE UNDER OATH; WEICKER ACCUSES NIXON BACKERS
response.abstract: J W Dean's 4th day of testimony before Sen Watergate com brings indirect request from com chmn Sen S J Ervin Jr and vice chmn Sen H H Baker Jr that Pres Nixon testify under oath before com; Baker, terming Dean's testimony 'mind boggling,' says com will have to determine some way to 'gain access to Pres's knowledge' of events Dean says persuaded him of Nixon's involvement in cover-up; Ervin tells Dean that 'only reliable way' to test credibility of principal in criminal case was to examine him under oath, then tells reporters they can 'draw any deduction you want' as to his meaning; in long series of questions posed to Dean, Ervin strongly suggests Pres Nixon violated, at least briefly, 4th Amendment to Const by approving domestic intelligence gathering plan that called for wiretapping, burglaries and other clandestine activities; Pres has said he withdrew his approval of plan after 5 days; com's June 28 inquiry is seen as focusing more than ever on what Sen Baker describes as 'central question' of what Pres Nixon knew about Watergate cover-up and when; Baker tells Dean that crucial to inquiry is his description of meeting on Sept 15, '72, with Nixon and H R Haldeman, at which Dean says he told Nixon he did not know if Watergate criminal investigation could be 'contained' indefinitely; Dean is seen as sticking to his original testimony throughout hrs and days of questioning; S Dash, com's chief counsel, tells reporters White House counsel J F Buzhardt Jr, who prepared document submitted to Watergate com June 27 which labeled Dean 'mastermind' of cover-up, had not meant for document to be read publicly, as it was, but only to be used to suggest possible lines of inquiry to Sens; illus of Sen Ervin and Sen Baker
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BAKER SAYS PANEL WILL INVESTIGATE

response.headline: PROSECUTORS QUIT WATERGATE CASE
response.abstract: 3 original Watergate prosecutors, telling special Watergate prosecutor A Cox that 'transition...is basically complete,' withdraw from case on June 29, still maintaining their investigation had been 'conducted forthrightly, vigorously and professionally'; the 3 Asst US Attys, E J Silbert, D E Campbell and S Glanzer, offered to resign from case when Cox took office in May, but stayed on at Cox's request; in resignation lr attys answer some of criticism that has been brought against them; say they had no solid evidence that J S Magruder, former deputy campaign dir, was perjuring himself at Jan trial; say re-election com treas H W Sloan Jr did not convince them or grand jury that Magruder asked him to lie; say they did not call Magruder's asst, R Reisner, to testify because they had no reason to think Reisner had evidence to give; say they agreed to allow high level officials such as M H Stans, campaign finance chmn, to give sworn depositions rather than testimony before grand jury in effort to limit publicity surrounding case; say at no time were they ever subjected to intimidation or suggestions that they not pursue case vigorously; call Asst Atty Gen H E Petersen a 'man of unquestioned integrity' and say they know of nothing improper Petersen has done; say 'with benefit of hindsight, there are many things we'd do differently'; illus of Silbert, Campbell and Glanzer

response.headline: Chilean Revolt Crushed As Army Backs Allende
response.abstract: rebel forces seize control of downtown Santiago, Chile, at 9 AM on June 29 and fire at Defense Ministry and Pres palace; at 1 PM Pres Allende, who was away from palace at time of outbreak, announces in nationwide broadcast that revolt was quelled and that rebel troops, part of armored regiment, have surrendered to Gen C Prats Gonzalez; navy and air forces gave Allende immediate assurance of loyalty; 7 people are killed, 22 wounded; Allende decrees state of emergency, gives armed forces control of public order and calls for calm; no communique is known to have been issued by rebels and no civilian sectors or parties have broadcast support of them, but Allende hints at a plot; says members of right-wing Patria y Libertad took part; leftist demonstrators try to storm anti-govt paper La Tribuna and right-wing National party headquarters, but are repelled by police; Allende identifies Col Ramirez as leader of revolt; it is not clear yet if revolt is connected with 'barracks revolt' uncovered by army on June 27; center-left Christian Democrats, main opposition party, calls for support of Govt; shortly after revolt, pro-Govt demonstrators march through streets; there is wide disagreement on what role traditionally neutral mil should play in Govt; moderates of left and right want mil participation to assure stability; extremists of left and right want mil out; revolt shows that mil is also divided on issue; map of Santiago; illus of shooting

response.headline: Social Security Increase Is Approved by Congress
response.abstract: US Cong on June 30 approves 5.6% increase in Soc Security benefits, effective June 1 '74, for some 30‐million Amers; increase is approved in HR, 327‐9, and by voice vote in Sen with no audible dissent; bill is sent to Pres Nixon for signing; measure faced threat of Nixon veto because of its estimated impact of $1.4‐billion on Adm's over‐all budget estimates for fiscal '74; Sen‐HR conferees, seeking to make increase more acceptable to Adm, agreed to postpone effective date of increase from Apr 1 to June 1; increased benefit checks will not go out to recipients until early July '74, thus delaying impact of increase until start of fiscal '75; Repr W D Mills (Ark), who is HR Ways and Means Com chmn, asserts that in light of changes, Treas Sec G P Shultz will recommend that Nixon sign bill containing increase; Nixon's counselor for domestic affairs M R Laird, at Western White House, San Clemente, Calif, asserts that Nixon is pleased with Cong cooperation and bill is being flown to Calif for immediate signing; as approved by Sen‐HR conferees, avg monthly benefit for retired worker and his wife will rise to $293 from present $277, and minimum benefit will rise to $89.30 a mo from present $84.50; to help pay for increased benefits, maximum annual wage base on which Soc Security taxes are levied will rise to $12,600 beginning Jan 1 instead of to $12,000 as had been previously scheduled; maximum Soc Security tax in '74 will be $737.10, instead of $631.80 on current maximum wage base of $10,800; under measure, amt that Soc Security recipient under age 72 can earn in yr and still be paid full benefits will be raised to $2,400 from present $2,100 staring in Jan; benefits paid to aged, blind and disabled will rise $10 a mo to $140 for individuals and $15 to $210 for couple

response.headline: Sihunouk Says That No Negotiations Are On

response.abstract: Iraqi Defense Min Lt Gen H Shihab is shot dead and Interior Min Lt Gen S Ghaidan is wounded on July 1 in what state‐controlled Baghdad radio describes as assassination engineered by chief of internal security Col N Kazzar; 2 police officers are also killed; Shihab and Ghaidan are members of ruling Revolutionary Command Council, 15‐man exec authority under Pres A H al‐Bakr; Baghdad radio announcement conveys impression that Kazzar might have been working for neighboring Iran; statement says that Shihab, Ghaidan and several army and security officers were lured to banquet given in Baghdad on June 30 by Kazzar and that as soon as they arrived they were taken prisoner; says authorities soon learned about plot and loyal security men arrived; holds Kazzar and his men took Shihab and Ghaidan and escaped to town of Zarbatiya on Iraqi‐Iranian border, apparently with intention of crossing into Iran; says that Kazzar and his men were captured in Zarbatiya but not before they killed Shihab and wounded Ghaidan; mil funeral for Shibab is scheduled for July 2; Bakr returns to Iraq on June 30 from visits to Poland and Bulgaria, where he concluded deals for sale of Iraqi crude oil; repts from Baghdad in last 2 wks talked of rising tension in north after Kurdish nationalists under Gen M al‐Barzani accused Govt of failing to live up to its '70 promise to give Kurds autonomy in areas where they form majority; Govt has accused Barzani and his followers of collusion with Iran; illus of Shihab and Ghaidan
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Transfer of Patients Blocked by Strikers AtWyckoff Hospital
response.abstract: striking nonmedical employes of Wyckoff Heights Hosp, Bklyn, on July 1 use picket lines to block transfer of 78 patients from annex to hosp's main bldg so that nonmedical services might be consolidated, easing problems and personnel shortages created by strike of nurses' aides, orderlies, housekeepers, porters, guards and kitchen workers; hosp spokesman says transfer plan has been abandoned to avoid further trouble with union; says hosp will seek bed space for patients at other hosps in NYC if walkout by 351 strikers continues; 3 patients were successfully transferred before union pickets intervened; police were at both insts, but were not asked to intervene and they made no arrests; E J Lewis of Hosp, Nursing Home and Allied Health Services Union Local 144 says he has no idea what will happen if another attempt is made to transfer patients; strikers have demanded payment of 2% wage increase retroactive to Dec '71; last negotiated contract provided for 7.7% increase, but this was later reduced by Cost of Living Council to 5.5%; hosp contends that money is not available and says payment of full increase will have to await approval of Blue Cross, Medicare and Medicaid rate adjustments‐process being held up by 60‐day price freeze; NYS Sup Ct Justice J B Wegman on June 28 signed order directing union to show cause on July 2 why strike should not be halted and union penalized

response.headline: Europeans Fear Boom‐Bust Cycle in U.S.
response.abstract: OECD, in survey of US econ issued on July 1, warns that econ policy will be put to crucial test over next 12 to 18 mos and urges Govt adopt more flexible fiscal arrangements and Cong to grant Pres some extra, although limited, powers to deal with problem; survey reveals concern over resurgence of inflation and boom conditions which, if allowed to go unchecked, could lead to bust later; says that even with restoration of stricter wage and price controls, maintenance of satisfactory price performance will become virtually impossible if excessive demand pressures and widespread bottlenecks and shortages should develop; also cautions that overheating of econ accompanied by stronger inflation and spillover of domestic demand into higher level of Amer imports could jeopardize improvement of current foreign balance, which it says is now in sight; on money policy, warns that if whole burden of policy adjustment is put on tightening up of availability of money, resulting interest‐rate squeeze could provoke serious downturn later; says some tax action may be necessary, particularly if Fed expenditures rise faster than suggested in fiscal '74 Fed budget presented last Jan; notes however that, judging from past experience, enactment of tax changes could take considerable time and thus come too late from point of view of good demand mgt; stressing need for prompt action in a modern econ, calls on Cong to give further consideration to possibility of granting Pres limited standby authority to vary tax rates and certain types of outlays without prior legis consent
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: COLSON SAYS DEAN MISLED PRESIDENT ABOUT WATERGATE
response.abstract: C W Colson, former White House aide, says on July 1 that Pres Nixon had complained to him of not being told truth about Watergate scandal even after J W Dean 3d had supposedly disclosed all facts to him, int on CBS program Face the Nation; Colson says Pres called him on March 21, saying he (Nixon) was not being told truth about Watergate, that he had to get to bottom of Watergate, had to find out truth; March 21 is date Dean has testified he told Nixon all he knew about Watergate, and warned him there was 'a cancer on Presidency'; Colson says he thinks Dean was 'at very center of that conspiracy to keep truth away from Pres'; says Pres probably does not know yet who ordered original break‐in at Dem's Watergate hq; denies that he urged executive clemency for Watergate conspirator E H Hunt, as alleged by Dean, and also denies ordering break‐in at Brookings Institution
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Israeli Attache Shot Dead At Home Near Washington
response.abstract: Israeli mil attache Col Y Alon is shot to death on July 1 after parking his car in driveway of his home in Washington (DC) suburb of Chevy Chase, Md; US Sec of State W P Rogers sends message to Israeli Foreign Min A Eban pledging 'every effort to find the perpetrators of this crime'; Pres Nixon makes available jet that leaves for Israel with Alon's body and his family; orders Secret Sevice to increase protection of diplomatic community in Washington; Nixon's personal condolences are conveyed to Israeli Amb S Dinitz by Gen B Scowcroft; FBI and local Maryland police say they have no clues to who committed crime or reason for it; refuse to speculate on whether murder was purely criminal act or work of Arab terrorists; Israeli Embassy says that 'we're being careful not to jump to any conclusions'; broadcast in Arabic from Cairo over Voice of Palestine radio asserts that Alon was executed in reprisal for death of M Boudia in Paris on June 28; US State Dept official says that it is not possible to determine whether Palestinians are claiming responsibility for killing or are merely seizing event as opportunity for propaganda; Alon, who is listed as asst armed forces attache under Maj Gen M Gur, is 1st Israeli official ever slain in US; sketch of Alon's career; illus of Alon, his widow and children at memorial service held before flight to Israel and honor guard at Andrews Air Force Base
keywords: FOREIGN DIPLOMATIC CORPS AND CONSULAR OFFICES

response.headline: Soaring Economy Is Sparking Debate Over Its Consequences and Duration
response.abstract: NY Times survey (H E Heinemann) of US econ in mid‐'73 finds econ at crest of roaring boom that appears to carry within itself the seeds of next business slowdown; there is broad concern among dozens of businessmen, bankers, economists and others interviewed that upward surge in econ will not last; various factors include skyrocketing interest rates, soaring prices, sagging stock mkt, overly rapid business expansion, and shortages of critical materials and skilled labor; most of people interviewed applaud Nixon's expressed determination to hold line on prices but there is widespread skepticism among economists that inflation will subside in absence of slowdown; there is much debate whether slowdown will reach proportions of recession; there is little doubt that it will hit most heavily those who have benefited least from boom; various economists, businessmen and others quoted on issue; unemployment rate as calculated by Labor Dept and Fed Reserve Bd's index of capacity utilization in mfg discussed as pressure gauges possibly leaving room for further econ expansion; among economists quoted is M K Evans, who holds that Nixon's new controls will worsen shortages that were already acting as brake on overall business; excerpt from late W C Mitchell monograph 'Business Cycles and their Causes' on how prosperity breeds crisis; Mitchell por
keywords: COMMODITIES AND COMMODITY EXCHANGES AND BROKERS
