response.headline: U.S. CONFIRMS PRE‐1970 RAIDS ON CAMBODIA
response.abstract: Sec J R Schlesinger acknowledges, July 16, that US B-52s were secretly attacking Cambodia in '69 and '70 while the US was publicly professing its respect for Cambodia's neutrality in the Vietnam war, lr to Sen S Symington; defends unannounced and unreptd raids as 'fully authorized' and necessary for the protection of US troops; says that because of the 'sensitive operational and diplomatic situation, special security precautions were taken to insure that the operations would not be compromised'; H M Knight testifies before Sen Armed Services Com that he and others deliberately falsified highly classified repts made after missions to prevent any officials recording of the bombings; says he destroyed all evidence of the actual targets in a special burner constructed near his unit; Symington says he will continue the com inquiry in attempt to determine why high Govt officials deemed it necessary to order subordinates to violate mil law by falsifying official documents; question of how widespread was the falsification of documents left unanswered; Gen G S Brown, who commanded 7th Air Force, at time of unreptd bombings, says destruction of documents and other procedures outlined by Knight were authorized at higher levels; says there was no deception by Knight since he acted according to orders designed to conceal the secret bombing operations; says special security was designed to provide for maximum security, not to mislead; Knight says there was an intent to deceive; says a superior officer told him object of falsification was to keep facts from Sen Foreign Relations Com and Sen Fulbright; Sen Hughes notes that after 2 yrs of repeated requests, he finally got a Defense Dept list of bombing missions, but that the document does not list any B-52 raids over Cambodia before May '70; says he is 'baffled' by reference in Schlesinge'rs lr about the sensitive diplomatic situation, a reference to the conducting of the raids with the tacit approval of Prince Norodom Sihanouk; Symington and Knight illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SURPRISE WITNESS Butterfield, Ex‐Aide at White House, Tells of Listening Devices
response.abstract: FAA Admr and ex-White House aide A P Butterfield testifies on July 16 before Sen Watergate com that Pres Nixon had listening devices in White House that would have autommatically tape-recorded his conversations with ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d and other key figures in Watergate case; White House confirms that virtually all of Nixon's official conversations in White House and on his personal telephones since early 71 have been recorded; tape recordings, which Butterfield says Secret Service has stored in Exec Office Bldg, could prove or disprove undocumented charge by Dean that Nixon was deeply involved in Watergate cover-up; Dean's assertions during his testimony noted; Sen com schedules exec session on July 18 to consider formal request to White House for recordings of certain meetings described by witnesses; chief com counsel Dash says there is 'no question' that recordings will be sought; Butterfield says recordings were meant to serve as part of record 'for posterity' of Nixon Adm and that they would ultimately have gone into a Nixon library; says that, following instructions he was told came from Pres, he supervised installation of automatic recording devices sometime in '70-White House says it was yr later--in Nixon's Oval Office and hideaway Nixon often uses in Exec Office Bldg; says another recording device, which could be turned on and off, was installed in White House Cabinet Room; says recording equipment was also installed on telephones in Lincoln sitting room at White House and in Nixon's personal lodge at Camp David; says existence of devices was unknown to all but handful of Nixon's assts; says only bug that was occasionally disconnected was 1 at Camp David; says it was not used when foreign official was guest in Nixon's cabin, as was L I Brezhnev recently; says, in reply to question about whether tapes could have been destroyed or altered, that they 'shouldn't be' because Secret Service is 'highly trustworthy' and solely responsible for marking and storing tapes; suggests, and White House counsel J F Buzhardt Jr flatly declares, that Pres Johnson recorded conversations in similar way; Secret Service officially denies having operated recording system for Johnson; list of recordings that are certain to be sought by com; Sen Ervin, in prelude to hearings, quotes Nixon's attitude toward Cong investigations from Nixon's book Six Crises; says he regards Watergate investigation as 'crucial' because it deals with allegations that individuals with great power 'have impaired, if not destroyed' integrity of election process; illus of Nixon's Oval Office, H W Kalmbach, Pres Nixon's former atty, and Butterfield
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 5 TOP OFFICIALS OF WALL ST. FIRM INDICTED ON FRAUD Conspiracy to Falsify Books and Earnings of Weis Charged by Grand Jury
response.abstract: Fed grand jury in NYC on July 16 indicts 5 top officials of Weis Securities on charges that between Jan '71 and June 4, '73 defendants agreed to falsify books and records of Weis in order to conceal fact that co was experiencing substantial losses which threatened its ability to remain solvent; alleges at end of Weis's fiscal yr in May '72, co actually had losses in excess of $1.5-million but books and records were altered to show profit of $1.7-million; defendants to be arraigned in NYC ct on July 23; co liquidation and other disciplinary charges revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KALMBACH'S TURN
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's ex-personal atty H W Kalmbach describes on July 16 in testimony before Sen Watergate com how, during series of meetings and clandestine calls from telephone booths, he raised $220,000 for 7 Watergate defendants; says his instructions for raising and disbursing money came chiefly from J W Dean 3d and that he recd personal assurances from J D Ehrlichman that work was entirely proper; says he believed, while he was raising funds, that money was to be used for legal fees and family support for 7 men who were convicted or had pleaded guilty in Watergate burglary; Kalmbach has reptdly agreed to testify for prosecution in any further Watergate criminal trials; says it was Dean who suggested that A T Ulasewicz act as distributor of funds; says his telephone calls with Dean were always made from pay telephones and they used code names; says bulk of $220,000 was recd from other campaign officials and $75,000 from T V Jones, pres and chmn of Northrop Corp; Jones says in July 16 statement that he donated only $50,000 and that he was 'assured that it would be handled in a proper and legal way'; Kalmbach and Jones say that Kalmbach had said that cash contribution was to be used for legitimate campaign purposes; Kalmbach says most of money he raised was to be passed from Ulasewicz to Mrs E H Hunt Jr and that she presumably distributed money among 7 defendants; says that by July '72 he was disturbed about Dean's authority to instruct him to raise money, about 'propriety of the assignment' and secrecy; says he therefore asked for and recd assurances about assignment from Ehrlichman; says he was temporarily relieved by Ehrlichman's assurances until Jan 19 meeting with Dean, F La Rue, and ex-Atty Gen Mitchell at which it became clear that they were trying to persuade him to obtain more money for defendants, at which point he left meeting; says he met with Pres Nixon only 4 or 5 times since '69 and talked with him by telephone another 4 or 5 times; White House media expert R A Moore testifies July 16 and maintains that Nixon was kept in dark until last Mar 21; Kalmbach says he kept surplus money from '68 Pres campaign in various checking accts and safety deposit boxes until beginning of '72 campaign; illus of Kalmbach and his atty J O'Connor, Moore and his atty H J Miller Jr, and Sen com asst chief counsel T Lenzner
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Case‐Fixing Linked To Koota's Office By Bond Swindler
response.abstract: Convicted bond swindler G M Zelmanowitz tells Sen Subcom on Investigations on July 13 of 2 examples of case-fixing in Bklyn Dist Atty's office during tenure of A E Koota, new NYS Sup Ct Justice; testifies that middleman in case-fixing was W Light, whom Sen investigators say had given 'large parties' for Koota; Light has record of 3 convictions for attempted grand larceny, bail-jumping and income-tax evasion, but there is no record that he served any time; Sen com reveals that it began to scrutinize operation of Dist Atty's office in mid-'60's to see whether Light's parties were fund-raisers; Light described himself as professional fund-raiser; Zelmanowitz details case in which $5,000 was given to atty from Dist Atty's staff so that the case, which involved bootlegging cigarettes, would not be processed; says 2d case involved J Colombo and W Buchbinder, then chief investigator for Dist Atty's office; Colombo obtained delay in testifying, and Bookbinder recd new Buick from Colombo's dealership; Zelmanowitz also implicates law firm of Evseroff, Newman and Sonenshine, in whose office Light had office space; Koota por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Computerized Signs To Help L.I. Drivers
response.abstract: NYS Transportation Comr Schuler on July 18 announces that dept will install computer-operated system to 'guide' and inform motorists along 30-mi congested corridor including LI Expressway and parallel hwys; says system will cost $11-million and take 3 yrs to have electronic sensors and flasing message boards in place; says main feature of complex system is that 6 rds adjacent and roughly parallel to LI Expressway will be monitored at same time; discloses that Fed Govt has approved LI stretch for 1st installation of new system; transportation officials contend that system will save motorists $4-million a yr in time saved and accidents prevented; Fed Hwy Adm has approved $800,000 to $1-million allocation for design costs and has agreed to share costs with state on installing equipment; master computer will be in new state office bldg in Hauppauge, Suffolk County; map

response.headline: French Clergy, Army Clash Over A‐Tests
response.abstract: ch and mil of France seen clashing over protests of high RC prelates against France's imminent nuclear tests in S Pacific; in recent yrs some high-ranking clergymen have become more vocal against mil and, for 1st time, mil men are lashing back; Pres Pompidou's Govt is keeping its own counsel despite attacks at home and mounting outrage abroad over scheduled nuclear explosions in atmosphere; it seems determined to proceed with tests; Most Rev G Riobe, Bishop of Orleans, beginning ecclesiastical offensive recently, has declared that no pol or econ interests of any people justify testing or use of such weapons; navy chief of staff, Adm M de Joybert, tells clergy not to meddle in affairs of natl defense; mil response to clergy outlined; widening chasm between clergy and mil cited

response.headline: Senate,77‐20,Votes For Alaska Pipeline
response.abstract: Sen, 77-20, on July 17 approves bill mandating immediate construction of trans-Alaska pipeline after passing, 50-49, bill immunizing legis from ct review, with Vice Pres Agnew casting tie-breaking vote; approval removes bar on this or other pipelines and Sen Gravel amendment removes environmental bars for failure to satisfy strictures of '69 Natl Environmental Policy Act; Sen W F Mondale charges State Dept misrepresented position of Canadian Govt on MacKenzie River alternative; Sen Jackson deplores State Dept action, but asserts vote on Mondale-Bayh amendment to delay licensing for 8 mos to study alternatives would not have changed; Sierra Club and Environmental Defense Fund hold they will challenge law; Sierra Club repr challenges validity of a law forbidding cts to rev laws; Sen T Steven amendment to require further ct action be brought before 3-judge panel in Alaska and authorize direct Sup Ct appeal is defeated; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Afghan King Overthrown; A Republic Is Proclaimed
response.abstract: Afganistan is proclaimed repub on July 17 in coup led by former Premier, Lt Gen Mohammad Daud Khan, brother-in-law of King Mohammad Zahir Shah, who is on visit to Italy; Daud says in radio broadcast that he led coup to replace 'corrupt and effete' rule of Zahir Shah with 'genuine democracy' and to save nation from ruin; places nation under martial law; does not mention fate of royal family or members of ousted Govt of Premier Mohammad Musa Shafiq; UPI repts that Zahir Shah, who was on island of Ischia near Naples since July 8 for vacation and mineral-water digestive treatments, went to Rome after hearing of coup; Daud, who is also cousin of Zahir Shah, pledges that Afghanistan will continue its policy of nonalignment and will not join any mil pact; nation, which depends heavily on foreign aid, has recd substantial assistance under Zahir Shah from USSR, China and US; its armed forces are equipped mostly by USSR; key points in Kabul, Afghanistan capital, are reptd under mil guard; US Embassy sources say they have recd repts of shooting at Zahir Shah's palace and of rebel assault on house of his son-in-law, Prince Abdul Wali; Abdul Wali reptdly is under arrest along with Defense Min Lt Gen Khan Mohammad; Afghanistan appears virtually sealed off from outside world; there are repts that Kabul airport is closed and closely guarded, and that telephone lines are cut; Zahir Shah, who is 59 yrs old, has occupied throne since '33; illus of Daud and Zahir Shah
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PRICE CONSPIRACY BY 8 OIL CONCERNS CHARGED BY F.T.C. 23‐Year Bid to Monopolize the Refining of Petroleum Products Is Alleged
response.abstract: FTC on July 17 charges 8 major oil cos with conspiring over 23 yrs to monopolize petroleum refining, resulting in shortages of gasoline and other products and substantially higher prices in some areas; alleges conspiracy forced independent retailers out of business and gave 'excess' profits to cos; charges cos pursued common action to keep profits from sale of crude petroleum artificially high and profits of refined goods low to make it unattractive for independent cos to enter refining indus; asserts cos have refused to sell gasoline and other products to independent marketeers; says cos controlled and limited crude supplies available to independent refiners by exploiting their ownership or control of crude gathering and transportation; assert exchs of crude oil between cos to save transportation costs and transporting crude and refined products has operated to detriment of independents; repts cos not mentioned in complaint have engaged in some of allegedly illegal practices; list of cos charged; allegations, grounded as violations of Sec 5 of Fed Trade Comm Act, seen based on comm rept made public by Sen H M Jackson over objections of Chmn L A Engman; study concluded indus acted in manner of 'classical monopolist' in attempting to increase profits by restricting output
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CLASH ON SECRECY Senators in Appeal to President in ‘Spirit of Conciliation’
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, citing exec privilege, orders Secret Service on July 17 to withhold from Sen Watergate com all information about secretly made recordings of Nixon's White House conversations; earlier White House press sec Ziegler said contents of tapes would be withheld because they fell into category of Pres papers; Sen com appeals directly to Pres to make available tape recordings of discussions and relevant documents that may be crucial to Watergate case; Sen Ervin sends Nixon lr emphasizing that request for 'all relevant documents and tapes' under White House control is urgent; suggests staff-level discussions of dispute if Nixon is unable to discuss them directly 'in the next day or 2' because of his illness; Nixon's ban on testimony by Secret Service agents is contained in lr dated July 16 to Treas Sec Shultz, who has jurisdiction over Secret Service; lr was forwarded to Sen com; Sen Baker notes questions that may be answered by tapes; illus of Ervin, Baker, chief minority counsel F Thompson and asst counsel R Silverstein
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mosbacher Named
response.abstract: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman, Republican fund‐raiser and chief of pro tocol in President Nixon's first administration, was named by Governor Rocke feller as the $65,000‐a‐year chairman of the newly creat ed State Racing and Wager ing Board. Details, Page 25.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: No Talk on Succession
response.abstract: Pres Nixon will leave hospital on July 20 and will go to Camp David for long weekend of recuperation; he will be back in Washington by July 24; his condition discussed
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Secret Raids on Cambodia Before ‘70 Totaled 3,500
response.abstract: US Defense Dept sources disclose, July 17, that B-52 bombers made at least 3,500 secret bombing raids over Cambodia in a 14-mo period beginning Mar '69; dept spokesman J W Friedheim acknowledges at news briefing that falsified repts were officially ordered and made after the strikes in effort to prevent disclosure of the raids, fully authorized by Pres Nixon and then Sec M R Laird; says 'hundreds of missions' were flown monthly; dept sources indicate that as much as 20% of the over-all SE Asia operations were officially going unreptd to the pub; Sen Hughes issues previously classified Defense Dept statistics that he says shows dept deliberately lied to Sen Armed Services Com in '71 and '73 repts on bombing in Cambodia; Friedheim says '69-70 air raids in Cambodia were 'deliberately not included' Defense Dept statistics supplied to Hughes; Hughes announces Sen com will expand its probe to determine how and why Defense Dept submitted the false statistics; ints with high Govt officials produce no evidence that any high-level orders for false reptg were issued, as reptd by Gen G S Brown in his July 16 statement
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kalmbach Says Strangers Got $400,000 From Hint
response.abstract: H Kalmbach, Pres Nixon's former personal atty, testifies on July 17 before Sen Watergate com that he now suspects that all or part of $400,000 he provided to strangers over 3-yr period was used in unsuccessful attempt to defeat G C Wallace in '70 Dem primary campaign for Ala Gov; testimony outlined
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Kennedy Had Tapes On ‘Sensitive’ Talks
response.abstract: D H Fenn Jr, dir of J F Kennedy Library, says on July 17 that Pres Kennedy made tape recordings of 'highly sensitive' phone conversations and staff meetings in White House; search of archives turns up 68 Dictabelts of Pres phone conversations and 125 magnetic tapes of Pres meetings; Fenn says library staff has not revd material nor has it been screened for public release; says it appears that on at least some of recordings there were indications that principals knew they were being recorded; says some of tapes seem to be of conversations with one person, but most seem to be of larger meetings; David Powers, former apptmts sec to Kennedy, and Prof Schlesinger, former Kennedy aide, say they know of no monitoring of conversations during Kennedy Adm
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LaRue and Ulasewicz Plead Ignorant On Who Ordered $450,000 Payments
response.abstract: F La Rue and A T Ulasewicz describe on July 18 in testimony before Sen Watergate com how they funneled $450,000 of Pres campaign money to 7 original Watergate defendants and their attys; La Rue, former re-election com official, says he had concluded that break-in at Dem Natl Com hq was sanctioned 'at some high level' and that $230,000 he distributed surreptitiously was to 'satisfy commitments' to conspirators; Ulasewicz says he quit making payments last Sept after becoming concerned that the $220,000 was going for more than mere 'humanitarian' support of criminal defendants; both insist they did not know who was ultimate authority for payments; Ulasewicz says he assumed instructions originated from 'someone like' ex-White House aides Haldeman and Ehrlichman; La Rue disputes ex-Atty Gen Mitchell's testimony when he says he did not hear Mitchell reject out of hand, at Mar 30 '72 meeting, the $250,000 intelligence gathering plan that ultimately led to break-in; does not endorse J S Magruder's acct that Mitchell reluctantly 'signed off-on,' ie, consented to, electronic eavesdropping plan; swears Mitchell, despite his denial, advised Magruder last June to destroy campaign documents relating to eavesdropping scheme; most of July 18 testimony deals with confirmation of previously published repts that nearly $500,000 of funds left over from Nixon's '68 campaign or collected in '72 was distributed to Watergate defendants to maintain their silence; Ulasewicz says most of arrangements were made with Mrs Hunt who dealt with him on behalf of other defendants; La Rue discusses how he gradually assembled $230,000 he disseminated mostly to Hunt's atty W O Bittman; says he was advised that participants in arrangements included 2 re-election com attys P L O'Brien and K Parkinson; Parkinson says he never advised La Rue to make payments to lawyers for Watergate defendants; Sen Weicker elicits from Ulasewicz confirmation of fact that Ulasewicz had explored sex habits, drinking habits, domestic problems and 'personal social activities' of individuals who were regarded as potential pol opponents of Nixon; authoritative sources say that White House will soon face delicate problem concerning tapes of White House conversations as special Watergate prosecutor A Cox is preparing to make his own request for recordings; White House press sec Ziegler insists tapes have never been transcribed; illus of Ulasewicz and La Rue
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: House Passes Bill to Curb President's War Powers
response.abstract: HR, despite threat of veto, on July 18 passes measure that would limit Pres power to commit US armed forces to hostilities abroad without Cong approval; vote is 244-170, 32 short of 2/3 needed to override veto; during 7 hrs of debate, HR turns back numerous efforts to weaken measure, which was approved last mo by HR Foreign Affairs Com and provides: that within 72 hrs after commitment of US forces to hostilities in foreign nations, Pres would be required to rept to Cong on circumstances that prompted action, his authority and estimated scope of action; that within 120 days after Pres rept, he would have to terminate commitment unless Cong enacted declaration of war or special authorization for use of forces; that within 120-day period Cong could adopt concurrent resolution, not subject to Pres approval or veto, terminating commitment of forces; Repr Ford, as HR begins debate, reads telegram from Pres Nixon, dated June 16, warning that he would veto message because of its 'dangerous and unconst restrictions'; Nixon said that he would welcome 'appropriate legis' giving Cong 'proper role in war powers,' but offered no specific compromise; Ford hails 'flexibility' and 'new policy' at White House, urging HR to accept substitute bill offered by Repr Dennis; HR, 250-166, rejected substitute, which would have required Cong, by bill or resolution, either to approve or disapprove commitment of forces within 90 days of action; measure would also require similar Cong action every 6 mos during continuation of hostilities; Sen also begins debate on war powers measure
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Port Police Vote To Report Today But Not to Work
response.abstract: Nearly 200 members of NY-NJ Port Auth PBA vote on July 18 to perform only emergency work at NYC met area airports as part of job action

response.headline: Albany Session Put Off 2 Days As Transit‐Bond Drive Falters
response.abstract: special session of NYS Legis scheduled to open July 23 is postponed to July 25 after Gov Rockefeller fails to win support of NYS Legis leaders Duryea and Anderson for his plan to put transportation bond issue on agenda; before meeting Rockefeller predicted 'historic' action by legis on solving state's transit crisis; following meeting, series of conflicting points of view were presented by Rockefeller's press sec, R Maiorana, Rockefeller and legis leaders; Anderson denies that transit question advanced at all during meeting while Rockefeller insisted that all had gone well
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SKEPTICISM VOICED Leaders of Business and Labor Contend Little Will Change
response.abstract: Grocery Mfrs of Amer pres G W Koch, commenting on Pres Nixon's Phase 4 econ policy, says on July 18 that food prices will rise, possibly higher than they would have without controls; commodities traders in Chicago and NYC express relief over Phase 4 regulations, but foresee that higher food prices might eventually move from current 'price rationing' to real rationing if supplies fail to meet demand
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Front Page 1 ‐‐ No Title
response.abstract: Valery N Kubasov and Col Aleksei A Leonov, Soviet astronauts who will participate in joint US-USSR space mission in '75, illus practicing water rescue with Soyuz spacecraft
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: `To Be a Little Humble’ Shultz Confirms Shift by President, Who Concedes Confidence Is ‘Low’
response.abstract: analysis of Pres Nixon's and Treas Sec Shultz's statements on Phase 4 points out that tone of statements reflects an unmistakable change on part of Nixon Adm toward humility; notes that Nixon, 35 days after imposing 60-day price freeze, disclosed his mistake by saying that food has given 'clearest evidence of harm that controls can do to supplies'
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MILITARY DISPUTE Ex‐Secretary Rejects Pentagon Version of Cambodian Issue
response.abstract: Former Defense Sec M R Laird and his retired top mil adviser, Gen E G Wheeler, criticize the falsification of official repts dealing with the secret bombing of Cambodia and disavow knowledge of any such actions, phone ints, July 18; Laird rejects US Defense Dept suggestion that he and other high Defense Dept officials had authorized a 'special security reptg procedure,' involving falsification, to prevent disclosure of the bombing; suggestion was made July 17 by Defense Dept spokesman J W Friedheim, who told newsmen that the bombing operations itself 'and the special security reptg procedures were fully authorized and directed by sr mil and civilian officials here in Washington;' White House has confirmed that Pres Nixon personally authorized the bombing raids, with the approval of his key advisers, and urged that they be kept secret; Friedheim repts that 3,630 unannounced raids were carried out with more than 100,000 tons of bombs dropped; Laird says he is baffled by fact that Defense Dept did not include Cambodian statistics in classified documents sent earlier this yr to Sen Armed Services Com at request of Sen H E Hughes; ints in last 2 days with a number of high-ranking past and present mil and govt officials bring forth disavowals of any link to false bomb repts; purport of pub and private comments is to contradict officials justification for the falsifications detailed by Friedheim; Vice Adm N C Johnson (ret), dir of Joint Staff under Wheeler in '69, says he also did not 'know of any authority for falsification,' phone int; Wheeler por
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Board Head Struck In Brawl at School; Fuentes Power Cut
response.abstract: fist fights break out at July 19 bd meeting of Lower East Side School Dist 1 after bd member H Ramos punches bd pres A Roher as panel moves to strip controversial dist supt, L Fuentes, of much of his power; 25 club-swinging policemen attempt to clear area and several persons are injured; in melee following Ramos's attack on Roher, tables are upended and chairs break under weight of masses of people; as brawling continues, 6 anti-Fuentes bd members who took office on July 1 vote swiftly among themselves to approve 10 proposals reducing Fuentes's authority; 4 policemen and at least 6 other persons are injured before night is over; 3 of civilians hurt are innocent bystanders injured in surrounding sts by roving bands of youths who go on spree of brick- and bottle-throwing and window-breaking; meeting illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PHASE 4 OFFICIALS EXPECT LENIENCY ON TIGHTER RULES
response.abstract: 1,200 persons to be added to staffs of Cost of Living Council and its enforcement agency, IRS, bringing total complement of econ stabilization officials to 5,000
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: LIDDY SAID TO LINK NIXON TO ‘71 PLOT
response.abstract: former Asst Atty Gen R C Mardian testifies on July 19 to Sen Watergate com that he had related to former Atty Gen Mitchell statement by G G Liddy, Watergate conspirator, that eavesdropping scheme had Mitchell's approval and that Mitchel I 'didn't deny it'; denies testimony of other witnesses that he (Mardian) had been central character in Watergate cover-up; insists that knowledge of break-in and cover-up came to him as atty for re-election com and that he was therefore obliged by atty-client ethic of confidentiality to withhold information; says that J W Dean 3d was 'dead wrong' in testifying that Mardian had been given access to confidential repts on FBI probe; refuses to concede that he had ever taken part in discussions of plan of J S Magruder to advance cover-up by giving perjured testimony last fall; denies awareness of discussion of efforts that led to enlistment of H W Kalmbach in raising funds to make payments to Watergate conspirators; swears that Magruder is mistaken in saying that he (Mardian) once suggested altering Magruder's apptmt calendar to hide truth about meeting on Feb 4 '72 that was related to intelligence gathering scheme; insists that M H Stans is in error about Mardian efforts to secrete $81,000 of campaign funds that had not been reptd; disputes Dean's testimony that Mardian suggested that CIA might provide break-in defendants with 'silence money'; quarrels with statement of F La Rue that it was Mardian who arranged June 20 '72 interview of Liddy in La Rue's Washington apt; says that Liddy at time tried to convince him that there was no chance that break-in might be traced to re-election com officials
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Food Prices Steady Here, but Rises Are Imminent
response.abstract: egg prices in NYC met area, reacting to Pres Nixon's Phase 4 econ policy, rise 5c a dozen at wholesale level
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Aide Declares President Won't Turn Over Tapes
response.abstract: White House official says on July 19 that Pres Nixon has decided not to give Sen investigators access to tape recordings of his personal and telephone conversations with Watergate suspects in '72 and '73; says it has already been made clear that Pres papers will not be turned over and that White House considers tapes to be Pres papers; Capitol Hill sources say that Pres counselor M R Laird has informed Repub Cong leaders that he believes pertinent sections of tapes should be released and that he is arguing that position within Adm; says Laird has admitted that Nixon has not been willing recently to take his advice on Watergate matters; White House aides who would like Nixon to make tapes public have proposed apptmt of special reviewing officer who would listen to tapes and decide which are relevant; former Repub Sens J J Williams and J S Cooper have been named as possible candidates; Sen com counsel S Dash says com will 'settle for nothing less' than full tapes; White House press sec Ziegler says tapes are not being reviewed by White House counsel's office; status of proposed meeting between Nixon and Sen Ervin is unsure; hoax perpetrated on Ervin, in which someone calling himself Sec Shultz phoned Ervin and told him tapes would be made available, noted; illus of Ervin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Judges Bar Police Protest At Tunnels and Airports
response.abstract: Hundreds of Port Authority policemen refused to work at the authority's bridges, tun nels and airports yesterday, and there were several traffic tie‐ups, mainly at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and at Newark Airport.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Senate Votes Bill to Raise Minimum Wage to $2.20
response.abstract: Sen, amid predictions of Presidential veto, passes on July 19 bill that would extend minimum wage law to seasonal farm workers; bill, which passed 64-33, would raise minimum wage for agr workers from $1.30 per hr to $1.60 after 60 days, to $1.80 after 1 yr and eventually to $2.20 after 2 more yrs
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Governor Including 35c‐Fare Guarantee In Transit Proposal
response.abstract: Albany sources indicate on July 19 that some sort of guarantee of 35c NYC transit fare and comparable promises for suburban and upstate transit riders will be keystone of Gov Rockefeller's transit subsidy and bond plan; thus far, Rockefeller has not discussed details in Public; Assemblyman Duryea and Sen Anderson, NYS Legis leaders, indicate that they need more information about effect of bond issue; Anderson, who appears more receptive to placing transit issue on agenda of special legis session, asserts that if soundness of plan can be demonstrated, the sooner it is enacted, the better; Duryea notes plan gets NYS into area of direct fare subsidies for 1st time
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH SLOWED SHARPLY IN JUNE QUARTER
response.abstract: Commerce Dept repts on July 19 that 'real' GNP rose by only 2.6% in '73 2d qr, compared with growth rates of over 8% in 2 previous qrs and 4% long-term target set by Adm; Asst Commerce Sec S L Jones sees 'unhappy combination of much sharper inflation and much less real growth in the econ'; sees possibility of some flukes in figures that overstate econ slowdown by making 1st qr figures too high and 2d qr too low; expects recovery in growth rate in 3d qr to 4% zone; says he personally feels any Govt moves to restrain econ growth further would be unwise; says major factor affecting 3d qr will be whether business spending for new plants and equipment will hold up in face of downturn in consumer spending and Phase 4 profit controls; consumer spending rose by $15.7-billion in 2d qr, compared with $26.8-billion in 1st; 2d qr GNP figure, when not adjusted for inflation, rose 9.5%; inflation in GNP is estimated at 6.8%, highest for any qr since '51; economist A M Okun doubts slowdown will be 'pause that refreshes the boom'; sees chance for improvement in 3d qr; opposes further Govt restraints on growth
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: KISSINGER DENIES WHITE HOUSE ROLE IN FALSE RAID DATA
response.abstract: H A Kissinger says White House 'neither ordered nor was it aware of any falsification of records' on the secret bombing of Cambodia ordered by Pres Nixon in Mar '69, phone int, July 19; says White House has begun probe into the falsifications; thinks official mishandling of records is 'deplorable'; Kissinger's comments come hrs after Defense Dept spokesman J W Friedheim tells newsmen that Strategic Air Command, which controls all B-52 flights, may have been responsible for ordering the falsification; dept later issues clarification in Friedheim's name saying that falsified reptg procedures 'were authorized and directed from Washington, not from SAC; says dept will respond to Sen Armed Services Com's question on the matter and will not comment further pending that response; Friedheim indentifies Deputy Sec W P Clements Jr and Adm T H Moorer, Joint Cs/S Chmn, as officials 'ultimately responsible' for Defense Dept's decision earlier in '73 to withhold information on Cambodian bombing from statistics supplied to the Sen com; says that in retrospect 'that was not the wisest thing to do'; Sen Hughes has called for resignation of any officials responsible for decision to give false data to Cong; Friedheim continues to defend falsification, press briefing
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: How the Markets Reacted
response.abstract: The reaction of the markets yesterday to the Ad ministration's Phase 4 anti‐inflationary price program, announced Wednesday afternoon, was as follows:
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: GOVERNOR ASKING 3.5‐BILLION BONDS FOR TRANSIT PLAN
response.abstract: Gov Rockefeller on July 20 proposes to put $3.5-billion bond plan to voters this fall to finance new mass transit operations and hwys and to provide $183.8-million in state aid for subsidizing 35c NYC transit fare and commuter fares for next 2 yrs, news conf; proposal would require localities to provide matching funds, $150 million a yr for NYC, to avoid fare rise; bond money, if approved, would favor mass transit over hwys on 60-40 ratio, $2.1-billion for mass transit and $1.4-billion for hwys, but hwy allotment is seed money that would eventually be multiplied 10-fold through Fed grants; Rockefeller offers few details about how bulk of money will be spent throughout state for capital items but plan would peg all upstate regional authority bus fares at 35c, which would mean rollback in some areas, and would retain present commuter rates for 2 yrs, avoiding increases projected as high as 70%; plan would mark 1st direct fare subsidy offered by state; $183.8-million in aid would be continued annually but would not be enlarged after 2-yr fare-holding period; NYC Mayor Lindsay offers support for plan but says proposal is only short-term solution; NYC Controller Beame expresses opposition but says there is room for discussion; Repub legis leaders Duryea and Anderson await further details; MTA spokesman sys approval of bond proposal would basically mean raft of construction plans would be retrieved from planning limbo they have been in since '71 bond issue was rejected; illus of Rockefeller
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATE APPROVES CUT IN WAR POWER OF THE PRESIDENT
response.abstract: WASHINGTON, July 20 — The Senate today overwhelm ingly approved legislation that would limit the power of the President to commit United States armed forces to future hostilities without Congres sional approval. The vote was 71 to 18.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Pentagon Admits It Gave Senate False Raid Report
response.abstract: Defense Dept spokesman J W Friedheim acknowledges, July 20, the dept knowingly provided Sen Armed Services Com with a false rept in June that did not reveal the secret Cambodian bombing; concedes he authorized the distribution of the rept, which he knew to be false, to newsmen who regularly rept on the dept; calls it 'a blunder of some magnitude'; says 'we weren't smart enought to foresee' H M Knight's testimony to the Sen com; says he knew at the time it was wrong and he is 'sorry'; later issues 'clarification' in which he says, upon further recall, he had not realized the B-52 bombing statistics were 'incomplete' until the rept was given to the Sen com; says dept top command was 'in a state of flux' May and June, when the decision was made to withhold information from the Sen and the press; gives impression he had been overruled at high levels when he tried to get the correct information to the press; Sen Hughes renews his call for resignations from the Defense Dept; Adm Moorer and Sen Symington reptdly meet in attempt to resolve deepening dispute; com reptdly decided tentatively to proceed with full-scale hearings into secret bombings; Sen Hughes says he filed objection to pending retirement at 4-star rank of USAF C/S Gen J D Ryan; controversy revd
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Liddy Balks at Oath and Panel Cites Him
response.abstract: Repr Nedzi discloses on July 20 that HR Armed Services subcom studying involvement of CIA in Watergate affair voted unanimously to cite Watergate conspirator G G Liddy for refusing to take oath as witness; says Liddy's atty P Maroulis presented 'detailed, lengthy, sophisticated and novel legal argument' attempting to justify his client's refusal to be sworn; if HR upholds subcom's citation matter will be turned over to US Atty for presentation to grand jury; past citations for contempt of Cong, which have been infrequent, noted; Nedzi describes confrontation between Liddy and subcom; says Maroulis's basic argument was that a defendant could refuse to take oath and to testify in his own ct trial and that he was equally within his const rights in refusing to take oath before Cong com; that to force him to take oath would violate his 5th Amendment rights and perhaps also 6th Amendment guarantee, which provides for speedy trials, right to be confronted with witnesses against a defendant and right to obtain witnesses in defendant's favor; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Japan Jet With 145 Hijacked, Forced To Fly to Mideast
response.abstract: Japan Air Lines: Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 with 145 aboard on Amsterdam-Tokyo flight is commandeered on July 21 by hijackers who claim they are members of Al Fatah guerrilla orgn and 'the Japanese Red Army acting for the people of Palestine'; bandits make unsuccessful attempts to land in Basra, Iraq, and Bahrain, but finally force craft to land in Dubai, Persian Gulf, where United Arab Emirates Defense Min Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid is allowed aboard to negotiate; body of female hijacker, killed after grenade she was holding exploded, is removed from aircraft and crew member injured in blast is also released; police say no demands have been made; map of hijacked craft's route
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Conferees Designate Part Of Road Fund for Transit
response.abstract: Sen and HR conferees complete action on July 20 on Fed hwy bill that has been stalled for 10 wks by deadlock over whether to use part of Hwy Trust Fund for mass transit; deadlock was broken when conferees agreed upon compromise proposal that would keep trust fund intact for 1 yr before gradually opening it up to rail and bus expenditures; Repr Wright, conf chmn, predicts that 3-yr, $20-billion bill will be passed by Cong before Aug recess; bill would allow $200-million in urban hwy funds to be spent on buses in fiscal '75 and entire $800-million earmarked for urban rds could be spent on bus and rail systems in fiscal '76; compromise represents major concessions by both sides; amendment to Sen version, introduced by Sens Muskie and Baker, called for spending trust fund money on mass transit over entire 3 yrs of bill; in effort to avoid Pres veto, conferees dropped Sen provision that would have provided $800-million in operating subsidies for failing transit systems; Sen conferees also agreed to drop their version of interstate transfer provision which would have allowed states to cancel controversial sees of interstate hwy system and spend money on mass transit instead
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SENATE APPROVES CUT IN WAR POWER OF THE PRESIDENT
response.abstract: Sen, 71-18, on July 20 approves legis that would limit to 30 days power of Pres to commit US armed forces to future hostilities without Cong approval; bill approved despite warnings of veto; vote indicates that Sen can muster 2/3 needed to override veto; Sen Griffin, Repub whip, votes against bill and tells Sen that veto by Pres Nixon is certain; Sen Scott, Repub minority leader, votes for bill; says he would vote to override veto; bill contains following provisions: in absence of declaration of war by Cong, Pres could commit forces to 'repel armed attack upon US, its territories and possessions, to take necessary and appropriate retaliatory actions and to forestall direct and imminent threat of such attack; Pres could also use forces to repel armed attack against Amer forces outside US and to protect Amer citizens being evacuated from another country because their lives were threatened; Pres would be required to rept to Cong 'promptly' on commitment of forces and their use would be limited to 30 days unless Cong was unable to meet as result of armed attack on US or unless Pres certified that 'unavoidable mil necessity' required use of forces in 'bringing about prompt disengagement from such hostilities'; Cong could terminate action before 30-day limit expired with bill or joint resolution which would be subject to veto; HR bill compared; Sen rejected Eagleton amendment which would have prevented 'secret' and 'proxy' wars by civilian employes of Govt or foreign troops paid by US; Sen Stennis, in lr to Sen Muskie, floor mgr of bill, warned against major changes; measure now goes to Cong conf
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Strachan Testifies Haldeman Knew About Spy System Before Watergate
response.abstract: G Strachan, former aide to ex-White House chief of staff Haldeman, testifies on July 20 before Sen Watergate com that Haldeman was advised more than 2 mos before Watergate break-in that Pres Nixon's re-election com had set up 'a sophisticated political intelligence-gathering system'; says that 2 or 3 days after break-in, he destroyed memo informing Haldeman of intelligence system; says that after speaking to Haldeman he destroyed a sample intelligence rept and 'several other documents' that he feared might link burglars to White House; says he 'refused' to commit perjury when he appeared Apr 11 before Fed grand jury investigating Watergate cover-up; acknowleges that he was courier who transmitted $350,000 of White House 'polling' funds to others who used part of cash to pay off 7 original Watergate defendants; denies having been aware of intended use of money; disputes J S Magruder's statement that Strachan was kept informed of 3 meetings in early '72 at which Watergate conspirator G G Liddy's intelligence-gathering schemes were pared from $1-million to $250,000 and reluctantly approved by ex-Atty Gen Mitchell; tells Sens where to find 'documentary proof that it was not he but ex-White House counsel J W Dean 3d who was responsible for keeping Haldeman abreast of campaign intelligence matters; describes how he advised Haldeman when Magruder told him that intelligence plan was approved in Apr '72; says he showed memo to Haldeman titled 'Sedan Chair 2' which other witnesses have testified was code name of double-agent in Pres primary campaign of Sen Humphrey; says this memo was 1 he destroyed; com source says Stachan described, in private staff ints, an attempt to persuade him to commit perjury; says Magruder, who was installed at campaign com by Haldeman, was supposed to rept through Strachan but that he would often give 'full rept' either to Haldeman or Haldeman aide Higby; suggests Magruder's testimony that Strachan, and through him Haldeman and, by ultimate extension Nixon, had been kept abreast of Liddy plans for wiretapping, kidnapping, mugging and other methods of gaining information or disrupting pol opponents; says Magruder never gave him that information
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: BREW PLEDGE ON JEWS REPORTED
response.abstract: Kissinger tells prominent Jewish leaders M M Fisher, J Stein and R Maas on July 20 that Brezhnev has assured Pres Nixon that large number of Soviet Jews who have repeatedly been denied permission to leave USSR would soon be allowed to emigrate to Israel, White House meeting; participants in meeting rept that Kissinger stressed his own personal belief that Soviet leadership is now moving to accommodate concern of US over problems faced by Soviet Jews; 1 participant repts that Kissinger produced written breakdown supplied by Brezhnev on fate of 738 'hardship' cases, Jews who repeatedly failed to obtain permission to leave; Soviet statement says 268 Soviet Jews recd permission to leave, 30 no longer live in USSR, 177 no longer want to leave, 80 are being cleared for permission to leave and 149 were denied permission; 34 are unaccounted for; spokesman for 3 leaders says they told Kissinger of their disappointment in the lack of visible results so far in release of more Soviet Jews; illus of Stein and Fisher
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.7% FOR JUNE; FOOD AGAIN LEADS
response.abstract: Labor Dept repts on July 20 that Consumer Price Index, led by increases in food, increased by 0.7%, or 0.6% after seasonal adjustments, in June; Council of Econ Advisers Chmn Stein holds that food prices accounted for 60% of rise in index during 1st half of '73; food prices in June rose 1.4%, less than in most earlier mos but still high by normal historical standards; food prices after seasonal adjustment rose 0.9%, smallest increase in '73; chart of food price increases in Consumer Price Index in US and NY-northeastern NJ area
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON DENOUNCES RESIGNATION TALK; TAPING IS HALTED
response.abstract: White House officials on July 20 say that Pres Nixon's conversations with Shah of Iran, who is scheduled to arrive in US on July 24 for state visit, will not be recorded
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Electronic Vigil Fails to Stem Mexican Alien Influx
response.abstract: Article on electronic detection system operated by US along Mexican border to stem Mexican alien influx; system is being extended along 1,550-mi border, except for certain areas regarded as inaccessible; installation, for which $1.5-million has been budgeted in '73, may be completed as early as mid-'74; criminal orgns formerly engaged in narcotics traffic have turned to alien smuggling because profits are large and involve far fewer risks; R Batchelor, deputy chief patrol agent at Chula Vista sector hq of Immigration Service border patrol division, says his division lacks manpower; agents at Chula Vista sector caught 94,220 people in '72 attempting to sneak into US illegally; they expect to catch 150,000 in '73; patrol officers estimate that 2 or 3 times that number will sneak past them to take jobs in US; aliens sneaking across border paths represent only part of problem; thousands more simply drive through normal border hwy checkpoints, show counterfeit border crossing cards or alien registration cards that have been stolen or sold; Batchelor says that without Fed law making it illegal for Amers to hire aliens who enter illegally, problem will grow and remain out of control; there is no effective way, and apparently no official or public desire, to prosecute illegal Mexican aliens; sympathy exists for their plight as underpaid, overworked and exploited labor force; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Soviet Bid for Police Role With the U.S. Is Reported
response.abstract: authoritative Western officials rept that original USSR proposal for what became Nixon-Brezhnev agreement to prevent nuclear war contained clause that would have committed US to intervene jointly with USSR anywhere in world if there was danger of conflict; say that US rejected idea but considered it necessary to give Moscow note stating clearly Amer interpretation of meaning of document in order to prevent future misunderstanding; say that although assumption was that USSR had China principally in mind as country to be restrained, clause could have applied anywhere; accord signed in Washington on June 22 obliges US and USSR to enter immediately into 'urgent consultations' if relations between them or between one of them and some other country 'appear to involve risk of nuclear conflict'; also says that two shall 'make every effort to avert risk' but docs not include requirement for joint intervention; US note reptdly stresses that accord imposes only obligation for US-USSR consultations to prevent outbreak of nuclear war; reptdly makes clear that US is not pledging never to use nuclear weapons in wartime, that accord does not limit US nuclear commitment to allies and that accord does not require US intervention beyond existing commitments; USSR once before sought and failed to obtain formal pledge from US for joint action against China in event of danger; John Newhouse book Cold Dawn reveals that in July '70 during talks on limiting strategic nuclear weapons USSR made similar proposal; Pres Nixon and Dr Kissinger have briefed NATO allies on US interpretation, partially allaying their fears that they would lose US nuclear umbrella
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: HOSPITAL BOMBING IN 1969 REPORTED
response.abstract: Former US Capt G J Greven says in phone int, July 20, that he told Sen H E Hughes that he participated in the planned bombing of a Vietcong hosp in S Vietnam in '69; says deliberate attempt took place late in Mar or early in Apr '69 in a Vietcong-held area in S Vietnam near the Cambodian border; says he decided to tell Hughes about incident after reading press repts about US secret bombing of Cambodia; Hughes to demand that Greven testify at a Sen hearing on 'circumstances that could have called for US to deliberately bomb hospitals'; Greven, in int, says that target information about possible sites of Vietcong activity was routinely provided by Army intelligence personnel before USAF men took off in their planes; US is party to Hague and Geneva Convs which prohibit the destruction of hospitals, as does US Army's own law of land warfare; Greven says he was provided with coordinates of suspected Vietcong hosp sites at least 3 or possibly as many as 6 times by Army intelligence; provides name of a fellow forward observer, still in service, to give independent verification of his assertions; officer confirms he flew with Greven, but says that as an officer on active duty, he is 'not at liberty' to discuss allegations; adds that 'this nation's going to have a guilty conscience about this war for a long time'; says that all the targets were cleared through the Vietnamese province chief
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: City Bank to Erect A 54‐Story Tower At East 53d Street
response.abstract: 54-story skyscraper to be erected on NYCs East Side will include new 900-seat St Peter's Luth Ch, whose home is being torn down to make way for new structure
keywords: OFFICE BUILDINGS AND OTHER COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON REPORTED TO FEEL INQUIRY IS AIMED AT HIM
response.abstract: Reliable sources rept on July 21 that Pres Nixon has told Sen Watergate com Chmn Ervin that he will not supply Pres papers to Sen investigators because he is convinced com is seeking to incriminate him; Ervin says on July 21 that Nixon's position is making it 'more difficult' for him to 'continue to cling to the presumption' that Nixon was not involved in Watergate conspiracy; authoritative sources at com say Nixon made accusation about com's motives, in sources' words, that com was 'out to get him,' when he talked with Ervin by telephone on July 12; Ervin says in Atlantic Beach on July 20 that he was mystified by Nixon's apparent decision to withhold from com secret tape recordings of Nixon's White House conversations with key figures in Watergate affair; says he can think of no rational reason for Nixon not to turn tapes over unless evidence found in them would be against him; Nixon confers with aides July 21 at Camp David as he prepares what aides intimate will be 'irrevocable' statement rejecting com's request for tapes and various White House documents; telephone conversation between Nixon and Ervin described; article in issue of New Republic, to be released July 23, contends that White House attys have determined that evidence on tapes is, in article's terms, 'mixed and confusing'; J Osborne, pub's White House correspondent, says in article that 'some of the tapes in question were played back and drawn upon by the lawyers and others who helped Mr Nixon draft his May 22 statement of innocence, ignorance and denial' of involvement in Watergate break-in and cover-up; article says Osborne learned that some of conversations on tapes supported Nixon's 'contentions and recollections' but that other portions, 'often on the same tape, could be interpreted if read alone to dispute his contention and make him out a liar'; Sen Gurney tells UPI on July 21 that it will 'hurt' Nixon politically if he withholds tapes although he agrees with Nixon's contention that Pres has right to withhold tapes or other material classified as Pres papers; illus of Nixon and Ervin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Hijackers Continue to Hold Japan Jet With 145 Inside
response.abstract: July 22: hijackers on July 21 continue to hold hostage Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 jet with its 123 passengers and 22 crew members and threaten to blow up aircraft if anyone approaches it; jetliner, hijacked on July 20 after leaving Amsterdam on Paris-Tokyo flight, is standing on desert airstrip in Persian Gulf sheikdom of Dubai under broiling sun, its engines stilled; hijackers demand release of K Okamoto, member of Japanese Red Army who is serving life sentence in Israel for his part in massacre of 26 people at Lydda Internatl Airport near Tel Aviv on May 30, '72; among plane's passengers is A Shoda, cousin of Japanese Crown Princess Michiko; 3 or 4 men, Arabs and Japanese, are reptd to be holding plane; woman, also identified as hijacker, is reptd to have been killed when her own hand grenade went off as plane was taken over; United Arab Emirates Defense Min Sheik M bin Rashid goes aboard plane to negotiate; Japan Air Lines pres S Asada arrives near Dubai with food, medicine and clothing; hijackers tell Dubai control tower over jet's radio that they are 'awaiting instructions,' but do not say from whom, or from where; officials in Dubai say they believe hijackers became isolated from their command as plane cruised around Middle East before putting down in Dubai; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Watergate Costing G.O.P. Political Help and Money
response.abstract: NY Times survey of GOP leaders in more than a dozen states reveals that party as a whole and many individual members are being hurt by Watergate Affair, which has resulted in decrease of money and volunteer help for Natl Com and local orgns; pol organizers at Natl Com reptdly cannot afford to hire secretary; in private, many Repubs say there is loss of confidence in Pres; leading party figures such as natl chmn G Bush and vice-pres Agnew are touring country, stressing distinction between party and Com for Re-Election of the Pres; contributors in some states are receiving guarantees that money will be used in local races; because of drop in contributions to natl com, Bush has ordered 25% staff cut; media are reptg that re-election com has $4.5-million surplus, but natl com staff members assert money is being kept by re-election com in case it has to pay damages in several pending lawsuits, and is unavailable to natl com; many donors gave more money than usual to Nixon campaign and do not want to contribute again so soon, while others feel betrayed by stories of secret payoffs and cover-ups; natl com is now shouldering blame for re-election com's misdeeds; former Nixon adviser R Finch, whose name constantly appears on White House orgn charts displayed at Watergate hearings, is reptd leaning against entering race for Gov or Sen in Calif; state and local GOP officials comment on Watergate's impact on Repub fortunes in their areas
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Valuation Cut 4.5‐Million Without Usual Realty Data
response.abstract: NYC property tax records just made public by ct order show that property tax reductions were granted to several bldgs without usual realty data; investigation by Dist Atty F S Hogan into tax-assessment reductions is reptd by his office to have progressed to subpoenaing individuals and records; investigation has been under way since Mar following rept by NYS Comm of Investigation alleging that reductions were improperly granted by then-pres of NYC Tax Comm N A Levy and other comrs; records show that new 50-story bldg at 1515 Bway at 44 St, also called One Astor Plaza, owned by partnership Astorill Associates including J Minskoff, received $4.5-million reduction in assessed valuation from Levy in '72 without having filed requisite income-and-expense statement with city's Tax Comm; owner's application for reduction in assessor's valuation asserted that bldg was 'still in the course of construction' and that while small part of space was rented, it was 'not occupied'; check showed that bldg had at least 2 major tenants occupying 5 1/2 floors and paying well over $50,000 a mo rent at time; reduction represented tax loss to city of $268,650; real estate atty who prepared application, A M Lindenbaum of Lindenbaum & Young, says no income and expense data was supplied because bldg was incomplete; Levy declines to state reasons for having granted reduction; property tax records also show that in other cases financial data considered irrelevant and misleading by NYS Comm of Investigation were submitted by property owners in support of applications for reduced assessments that resulted in $2.2-million in lowered valuations; these were items such as mortgage amortization, interest, depreciation and ground rent, which state panel says should not be considered expenses because property is considered to be free and clear of all debts and encumbrances; in case of bldg at 475 Park Ave South, which won $500,000 reduction in valuation to $9-million from Levy in '72, financial statement by partner Sherman Cohen listed under expenses $891,889 for interest, $350,000 for depreciation and $75,833 for rent; listing those expenses put property into red by nearly $2-million; Lindenbaum, who also prepared application for Cohen, says that it is tax comr's job to disregard items that are improper; similarly, statement for bldg at 127 John St, which won reduction from Levy in '72 of $1.4-million to $12.6-million, listed $312,499 figure for rent that put property into red by $154,536; Robert Kaufman, son of property holder William Kaufman, insists rent is proper expense because IRS accepts it as such in its acctg; 4th financial statment disclosed is for bldg at 95 Wall St, which received $300,000 reduction in valuation to $14,150,000 from Levy in '72; submitted in name of partner Seymour Cohn, financial statement also listed as expenses over $2-million in interest and depreciation; Cohn's atty M Chertok says statement was prepared for gen acctg purposes and therefore all figures were included; financial statement was also unusual in that it was submitted separately after application was filed and did not bear customary time-and-date stamp attesting to its official receipt by Tax Comm; acting Tax Comm pres A J Ranieri says 'improprieties could come in'; Levy illus; illus of One Astor Plaza
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 100 Pursue Gunman
response.abstract: Morel, Mario: Drunken gunman D Nenaya is beaten unconscious by local residents after he shoots and kills M Morel and wounds 2 of his brothers P and C Morel, 19, on July 22; is charged with homicide, felonious assault and weapon possession; incident appears to lend support to hopes of trend seen last mo among New Yorkers toward involving themselves in welfare of their neighbors
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Holdup Victim Shoots 4
response.abstract: Queens construction worker J Winfield on July 22 goes on shooting spree, killing 1 man and wounding 3 others; tells police he was furious at having been beaten unconscious and robbed for 6th time preceding incident; dead is R Winn; other victims are W Crawford, H King and J Wilson; Winfield is treated for head injury and missing teeth knocked out in robbery
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Mennonite Dissident Shunned by Church and Wife
response.abstract: R L Bear, Mennonite farmer and father of 6, has been cast as heretic and excommunicated from his ch for challenging the faith; heresy charges are based on number of public denunciations of ch doctrine and its bishops and accusations that ch hierarchy has lied; his wife also has shunned him; it is ch's position that excommunication and shunning are not punishments to be meted against sinners, but to bring them back 'to the fold'; Bear and his wife were excommunicated in '65 but were allowed to return to ch; Bear contends bishops must be discredited and that he will fight to accomplish that goal; illus; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: SHOWDOWN TODAY LIKELY IN DISPUTE OVER NIXON TAPES
response.abstract: Article says that showdown between Sen Watergate com and Pres Nixon over com's urgent request for tape recordings made in Nixon's office is expected to come July 23; says com is scheduled to meet in closed exec session July 23 and expects to receive Pres lr on matter; insiders rept that Nixon, despite stresses of Watergate scandal, continues to rely largely on advice of 3 men--Gen Haig, R Ziegler and H A Kissinger; Gallup Poll repts that 3/4 of Amer people continue to believe Nixon was involved to some extent in Watergate case and almost half still consider it a 'very serious matter'; list of witnesses scheduled to appear before com and of potential witnesses; com sources say they expect Sens to vote to subpoena tapes and documents if White House does not release them voluntarily; Labor Sec Brennan says he does not condone people taping conversations without other person knowing, int, ABC TV program Issues and Answers; Agr Sec Butz says he thinks such recordings for historical record are 'proper,' int, NBC TV program Meet the Press; special Watergate prosecutor's office announces apptmts of 3 attys to its Watergate investigative staff, including C F C Ruff, T P Ruane and J W Volner
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Wall St. Is Again Gripped By Serious Financial Crisis
response.abstract: Article discusses financial crisis in Wall St amid profit squeeze and falling revenues for brokerage cos; describes current situation as even more precarious because of onset of summer doldrums, noting almost everyone agrees central problem has been declining revenues in face of sharply rising costs; sketches gloomy picture of current scene; cites comments of several indus execs; notes profit squeeze of major brokerage cos such as Merrill Lynch, E F Hutton, D Witter & Co and Reynolds Securities; graphs of losses for all NYSE cos, employment in exch community and decline of member orgns
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Census Finds Rise In Economic Gaps Between the Races
response.abstract: US Census Bur on July 22, in rept on econ gap between blacks and whites, finds blacks scoring largest gains in educ; 727,000 blacks were enrolled in coll in '72, almost double number in '67; over same period, proportion of blacks 20-29 yrs old who are high school grads rose from 54% to 65%; black women with coll degrees are now earning as much money as their white counterparts
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Wall St. Is Again Gripped By Serious Financial Crisis
response.abstract: July 23: hijackers and hostages swelter through 2d day of torrid desert heat on July 22 on board Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 jet at airport in Dubai; hijackers demand food and that plane be refueled; continue to hold 122 passengers and 21 crew members hostage and give no indication of their intentions; plane remains surrounded by 100 armed policemen; refueling prompts speculation among officials and newsmen of possible new destination for plane; in Jerusalem, Israeli Premier Meir says at meeting of Cabinet that number of security procedures are in effect to keep hijacked jet from being used on suicide mission over Israel; during jet's flight from Amsterdam to Dubai, hijackers demanded release of K Okamoto, only survivor of Japanese 'Red Army' suicide squad that killed 26 people at Lod (Lydda) Internatl Airport, near Tel Aviv, Israel, on May 30, '72; Okamoto is serving life sentence in Israel; Israeli Govt spokesman says Okamoto will not be released and hijackers have not repeated demand since landing in Dubai; Beirut newspaper An Nahar says hijackers demanded $5-million ransom but officials of Dubai and Japan Air Lines pres S Asada deny rept; hijackers identify themselves as 'sons of occupied territory,' orgn described as unknown in Palestinian guerrilla quarters; Arab guerrilla orgns Al Fatah and Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine deny any connection with hijackers; Japanese parliamentary vice transport min B Sato leaves Tokyo for Dubai to make 'all out efforts' to secure release of hostages; illus of Y Miyashita, plane's chief purser who was released by hijackers on July 21 after he was wounded by grenade that killed woman believed to be 1 of hijackers
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nixon Adviser Confident Of Stability Under Phase 4
response.abstract: Agr Sec Butz says on July 22 that sharp rise in food prices is 'behind us,' int on NBC's Meet the Press
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FRENCH A‐TESTS BRING PROTESTS BY FIVE NATIONS
response.abstract: French nuclear test July 21 on Mururoa atoll in S Pacific is protested on July 22 by Japanese Foreign Min, NZ Prime Min Kirk, Australizn Prime Min Whitlam, Canadian Sec Sharp and Swedish Foreign Min; Kirk says NZ frigate Canterbury will relieve frigate Otago and stay in test site area; Australian Council of Trade Unions to continue boycotting French goods; ICFTU sec gen O Kersten protests test; French Govt has given no details on test or responded to protests; Reuters repts from Tahiti that French State Sec for Armed Forces A A Fould says test was carried out satisfactorily; D Moodie, skipper of schooner Fri, towed from Mururoa danger area on July 17 by a French warship, gives his version of confrontation; says scooner was towed to Mururoa and he and others aboard flown to island of Hao; says craft will be returned to him when tests are over; 2 illustrations of mushroom cloud from blast photographed from frigate Otago
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: DELAYS ARE CITED ON CALLS TO 911
response.abstract: increasing number of callers to NYC Police Dept's 911 emergency phone service say they must wait long periods--from 5 to 45 mins on busy Saturday nights--before getting response since summer began
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Intruder in Police Station Shoots 2 Officers, Is Slain
response.abstract: Apparently deranged man with 2 fire-bombs and revolver shoots NYC Police Sgt D Brennan and Lt F DarConte in 19th Pct stationhouse on July 23 before being killed by police bullets; assailant is tentatively identified as V L Camacho-Rivera; after firing at sgt, gunman leaped behind desk to attack other policemen; Mayor Lindsay and Police Comr Cawley denounce cheap handguns, such as 1 used in attack; map; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: President Based Decision On Two Legal Doctrines
response.abstract: article discusses legal doctrines of separation of power and exec privilege upon which Pres Nixon based his July 23 refusal to furnish White House tapes to Sen Watergate com; says neither principle has been tested in cts in anything resembling current Watergate context, but Nixon's action seems certain to precipitate such test; notes definitions of principles; discusses Nixon's lr to Sen Ervin and C A Wright's lr to special Watergate prosecutor A Cox defining refusal to release tapes; possible action by Sen com and by Cox; says com will probably issue and serve subpoenas to Pres Nixon for tapes
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Boy, 16, Is Slain for $1 While on Park Pool Job
response.abstract: Caserta, Gary: 16-yr-old G Caserta, NYC Parks Dept summer worker, is robbed of $1 and stabbed to death on July 23 in maintenance bldg of Hamilton Fish Pool in Lower East Side park; other criminal and violent incidents occuring recently at pool noted

response.headline: 116 Reported Dead In Two Air Crashes
response.abstract: A Pan American jet bound from Tahiti to California with 69 passengers and 10 crewmen crashed in the Pacific just after take‐off yesterday. There was only one known survivor.
