response.headline: Vaccine for Rabies Developed, Cutting Shots From 14 to 1
response.abstract: new rabies vaccine has been developed and is expected to greatly reduce number of deaths from disease, particularly deaths that occur in less developed areas where it is estimated that from 5 to 10 unreptd cases occur for every one that is reptd; new vaccine, developed at reference centers of World Health Orgn, is being tested in France, US and Latin‐Amer countries in both man and animals; Dr M Abdussalam, chief of orgn's veterinary public health div, says effectiveness of vaccine has been confirmed; notes more tests will be conducted however, before vaccine is released for gen use; comparison of old and new vaccine indicates that new vaccine is injected once instead of previous 14‐21 times and that new vaccine is produced in cells of human origin while old vaccine originated from horses and sometimes produced severe reactions; World Health Orgn expert com repts show dogs continue to be chief source of rabies infection and that wild meat‐eating animals appear to be primarily responsible for maintaining disease in a particular environment; in Western Eur and US, foxes are also chief culprits of disease; other animal carriers of disease noted

response.headline: WHITE HOUSE FILES ON I.T.T. GIVEN COX

response.headline: Secret Service Calls Plot Against Nixon ‘Serious’
response.abstract: Secret Service continues on Aug 21 to press its investigation of what was described as 'very serious, very large' conspiracy by 'nonmentals' to assassinate Pres Nixon during his Aug 20 visit to New Orleans, La; sources close to investigation say they used term 'nonmentals' to distinguish reptd assassination plot from more common threats of harm from mentally unbalanced individuals that Pres receives when he travels outside Washington, DC; Secret Service announced on Aug 20, in unprecedented move, that it had 'strongly recommended' to White House that route of Nixon's motorcade through short section of downtown New Orleans be changed; White House aides later said that Pres himself had ordered motorcade be canceled but in San Clemente, Calif, where Nixon flew after New Orleans visit, reporters overheard him say to his personal sec R M Woods, They called me last night. They canceled. They'll never cancel another time'; White House deputy press sec Warren says on Aug 21 that Nixon was alluding to another matter that Woods was working on with Pres and not to motorcade; Secret Service agents and score of heavily armed state and local officers search near Taos, NM, on Aug 21 for E M Gaudet, ex‐New Orleans policeman who has been charged with making separate threat against Nixon's life; J P Jones, chief of NM Secret Service says on Aug 21 that local officers exchanged gunfire on Aug 20 with man they believed to be Gaudet, who disappeared into nearby arroyo after firing 2 shots from high‐powered rifle; arrest warrant issued Aug 20 alleges that Gaudet said in a New Orleans bar last wk, 'Somebody ought to kill Pres Nixon. If no one has the guts, I'll do it'; Secret Service officials say they have found no evidence to connect Gaudet to reptd assassination conspiracy, but will not preclude possibility that connection might turn up; officials of FBI and Secret Service insist that alleged conspiracy is both broad and intensely serious and that its threat had not been 'blown out of proportion'; New Orleans police officials say they are unable to explain why change in route of Nixon's motorcade was publicly disclosed in advance of Nixon's arrival, a move that presumably would have alerted any conspirators that their plot had been uncovered and providing them time to flee; police officials say decision to make announcment was that of Secret Service, which said on Aug 20 that move was response to expected inquiries from reporters about change in Pres's plans
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FAITH REAFFIRMED

response.headline: TAPE CASE ARGUED IN FEDERAL COURT

response.headline: BURGLARIES LAID TO AGENTS OF F.B.I. IN 30‐YEAR PERIOD
response.abstract: Informed Justice Dept sources disclose on Aug 23 that what 1 of them called ‘illegal and unlawful’ burglaries by FBI agents took place in US over 30‐yr period that began during Pres F D Roosevelt's Adm and ended in ‘66; 1 source says burglaries, ‘obviously’ barred by 4th Amendment, were conducted not only in connection with natl security investigations, but also in criminal cases against alleged crime figures; says practice was ‘old, established investigative technique,’ but that its use was never known by any of Attys Gen who served during time it was employed, or by anyone else outside FBI; disclosure follows Pres Nixon's Aug 22 statement that such burglaries took place ‘on a very large scale’ during Adms of Presidents Johnson and Kennedy; sources say on Aug 23 that approval of technique never came from any authority higher that late FBI Dir J E Hoover, who ordered practice ended in ‘66; say that in some instances, breaking and entering by specially trained FBI men was used against foreign embassies and missions in US in hopes of finding ‘cryptographic materials’ or code books; say that whenever code books were found they were turned over to Natl Security Agency, arm of exec branch that specializes in code‐breaking and other top‐secret functions; 1 ex‐Justice Dept official says Hoover halted practice because he disliked lending his agents to such risky enterprise and because ‘benefits we got out of it were for NSA, not the FBI'; source says that 1 rule employed by FBI agents on such cases was that ‘you never take anything except information'; says, when asked whether burglaries had actually stopped in ‘66, that ‘basically’ they had, but that there have been ‘sporadic’ approvals since then; 1 source, when asked how Nixon Adm might have learned of prior existence of practice, says he believes that information was included in series of memos prepared over last few mos by W C Sullivan, who recently retired from Justice Dept after having been former asst to Hoover; illus of former Atty Gen Clark
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: New Brain X‐Ray Device May Transform Therapy
response.abstract: Brit and US radiologists are X‐raying patients' brains with new device that allows them to see cross‐sectional views of brain by technique that can have major impact on health indus by reducing costs, risks and length of hospitalization for patients suffering from wide variety of brain disorders; some drs view new technique, which provides more detail than conventional skull X‐rays, as most revolutionary advance in radiology since Rontgen's discovery of X‐rays in 1895; note that more experience with technique is required to determine its precise role; scannner, developed by EMI Ltd, Brit Co, will be installed in 7 additional hosps by end of '73; device costs $350,000; neurologists Dr R Bannister and J Ambrose laud machine's potential; operation of device, which combines conventional X‐ray tubes with computers and a Polaroid camera, described; G Hounsfield, computer engineer, is credited with developing machine; illus of brain section from Gray's Anatomy; machine allows drs to see brain in cross‐section just as it appears in Gray's; 5 hosps that currently have machine are: Mayo Clinic, Massachusetts Gen, Atkinson Morley (London), Natl Hosp for Nervous Diseases (London) and Royal Infirmary (Manchester); hosps to which device will be delivered include: NYU and NY Hosp‐Cornell Med Center

response.headline: 35‐Nation Study Seeking Cause of Tropical Storms
response.abstract: 35 nations are curently engaged in most elaborate and ambitious internatl scientific experiment ever undertaken to seek out causes of hurricanes and tropical ‘heat engines’ that control much of world's weather; project, for which final rehearsal was held early in Aug, will use 25 to 30 research ships during summer of ‘74 stationed in broad band spanning tropical Atlantic and will employ specially instrumented planes, buoys, balloons and Amer and Soviet earth satellites, which will transmit continuous data on region; purpose of latest rehearsal was to insure that data collected by variety of instruments and observing systems can be reduced to common ‘language'; primary goal of project, known as GATE, for GARP Atlantic Tropical Experiment, is to explore proposition that great assemblages of tropical thunderheads play critical role in lifting humid, energy‐laden air from sea to be swept to other parts of earth; difficulties encountered during Aug rehearsal described; full experiment of GATE, which is 1st step for GARP, will take place from June 15 to Sept 30, ‘74; goal of GARP, which is long‐term internatl project, is to develop methods of global data acquisition that will enable computers to produce long‐range weather forecasts; GATE is headed by Natl Oceanic and Atmospheric member Dr J P Kuettner and World Meteorological Orgn official Dr Y V Tarbeev; research uses of equipment described; map

response.headline: $4 Wheat a Mixed Blessing to Farmers
response.abstract: survey of profits earned by US wheat farmers notes that farmers are making so much money that they are trying to avoid higher income‐tax brackets; points out that wheat selling at over $4 a bu has caused several problems for farmers, including run on farm machinery, and thus shortage; notes that high prices have induced farmers to plant more wheat in ‘74, causing price of wheat land to rise; holds that most important effect of trend is fact that steady annual exodus of farm families from Midwest may be stemmed, restoring vitality and community to Great Plains; notes that wheat farmers have taken interest in foreign mkts since US began mass exports of wheat in ‘72; claims that farmers have little sympathy for Amer consumers, asserting that it is about time that Amers started paying ‘reasonable’ prices for their goods; illus; map

response.headline: Uneven Gains Deepen Pressures on Blacks
response.abstract: 2d article of NY Times series discusses uneven econ, pol and social gains made by blacks and blacks’ difficult quest for their own identity, findings of mo‐long series of ints to discover how blacks see themselves and society they live in; says that for nearly all blacks interviewed, despite increased opportunity for some blacks, Amer remains dual society in which attitudes are shaped by social reality; mktg analyst P J Anderson (Standard Oil), Atlanta Urban League dir K Crooks, mktg mgr C Thompson (IBM), welfare mother M Ford, research asst L Jackson (Inst of Black World), antipoverty worker E Perkins discuss views on black consciousness, self‐realization and increased opportunities; illus; Harvard psychiatrists Drs A Poussaint and C Pierce and psychologist Dr K Clark also comment; several quotes from G Brooks’ poetry in ‘49 and ‘68 noted as indicative of shift in black attitudes from simple desire to be accepted into white society to assertion of individual blackness and identity; Brooks illus

response.headline: REBOZO IDENTIFIED AS HELPING NIXON TO BUY COAST LAND
response.abstract: White House on Aug 27 identifies C G Rebozo, close friend of Pres Nixon, as 1 of 2 financial backers in Pres's real estate purchases in Can Clemente, Calif; disclosure comes in detailed analysis of San Clemente purchases, which White House press office says is aimed at ending speculation about where Nixon got money to buy San Clemente property and his home in Key Biscayne, Fla; other backer has been identified as R H Abplanalp; analysis, made by Coopers & Lybrand, is based on documents and financial records submitted by Nixons; White House press sec Warren says Nixon paid acctg firm; C J Simon, gen partner, R H Kaiser, partner and M S Fishman, sr associate of co, formerly known as Lybrand Ross Brothers & Montgomery, were convicted in ‘68 of distributing false financial statements and of mail fraud growing out of false ‘62 financial statement of Continental Vending Machine Corp; they were fined total of $17,000; Nixon gave all 3 unconditional pardons on Dec 20 ‘72; White House press sec Ziegler says men pardoned by Nixon had all withdrawn from co and that White House staff had checked to find that Coopers & Lybrand had no pending Govt business on which a charge of conflict of interest might be based; rept by accountants shows Nixon was seriously overextended when he obligated himself to pay $1.4‐million for 25.5‐acre Calif estate, and then bought adjoining 2.6 acres for $100,000 4 mos later; Nixon was able to complete transaction on July 15 ‘69 by borrowing $450,000 from Abplanalp; on July 15 ‘70, when 1st $100,000 mortgage payment came due, Nixon borrowed that sum, plus yr's $75,000 interest from Abplanalp, raising his total indebtedness to Abplanalp to $625,000 plus interest; role of Rebozo began in Dec ‘70 when Nixon and Abplanalp set out to regularize their financial relationship by substituting some sort of real property for unsecured notes totaling $625,000 that covered Nixon's indebtedness; undivided interest in trust was transferred to Abplanalp and Rebozo, who were co‐partners in Title Ins & Trust Co, which administered Nixon's Calif holdings; Abplanalp said in int with Washington Star‐News several wks ago that he had bought out his partner, which presumably means that Rebozo no longer has interest in Calif property; supporting documents issued to reporters on Aug 27 shows that B & C Investment Co would own about 23 acres of land and that Nixons would own about 5.9 acres when parties eventually make division; sales agreement of Dec 15 ‘70, signed by sellers, Pres and Mrs Nixon, and buyers Abplanalp and Rebozo, says that property would be divided by use of ‘certain map entitled boundary survey map’ drawn by civil engineer W A Ayer
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Prime Rate 9¾%
response.abstract: Several major banks raised their prime rate yesterday to 9¾ per cent, a new high, from 9½ per cent. The Chase Manhattan Bank began the move. This appears to be the start of the fifth general rise in five weeks in the prime rate, the interest that commercial banks charge on loans to their most creditworthy corporate customers. Bankers said that strong demand for loans showed no sign of letting up. Also, short‐term interest rates in the money market continue to move upward. Page 45.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Civilians Begin Directing Traffic on City Streets
response.abstract: 25 civilian traffic control agents on Aug 27 take up posts at NYC midtown intersections; NYC govt spokesman says it is 1st time that civilians have been hired to direct traffic in city; 9 of 25 agents are women; some agents confess to queasiness before stepping out into traffic; purpose of agents is to have more policemen available for regular patrols by relieving them of traffic duty; Mayor Lindsay says there will be 200 agents within 8 wks; says NYC is saving about ‘half a salary’ in using them; agents are being paid $8,500 to $9,600, depending on seniority, whereas regular police officer starts at $11,200 and goes up to about $16,000; agents are members of Traffic Dept who up to now have been working as meter maids; Ptl P Burns, who assisted in 1‐wk training of civilians, says women agents are ‘scared stiff'; illus

response.headline: KISSINGER SEEKING ADVICE OF ENVOYS
response.abstract: State Sec‐designate H A Kissinger has decided to address UN Assembly for US in gen debate if his nomination is confirmed by that time; Amer delegate is due to speak about Sept 20
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Trudeau Calls Parliament To End Railroad Walkout
response.abstract: Canadian Prime Min Trudeau, in nationwide TV‐radio broadcast on Aug 27, summons Parliament into special session ‘at earliest possible date’ to legislate end to 4‐day‐old strike by non‐operating employes that has halted almost all train service; says strike could have drastic econ effects if not immediately halted; decision to recall legislators, who were to be in recess until Oct, is made after breakdown of intensive behind‐the‐scenes negotiations between rrs and striking Associated Non‐Operating Ry Unions; opposition leader R Stanfield supports call for emergency session of Parliament
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: MAIL BOMB HITS BRITISH EMBASSY IN WASHINGTON
response.abstract: letter‐bomb blows off left hand of mil attache's sec, Mrs Nora Murray, in Brit Embassy in Washington, DC, on Aug 27 as she opens morning mail; bomb packet, which arrived in pouch of Brit Forces Post Office mail, is described as type similar to 30 lr‐bombs dispatched in London, Eng, area in last wk and attributed to IRA terrorists; packet was addressed to Brig Giles H Mills, predecessor of current attache Brig Henry Woods; explosion touches off large‐scale investigation by FBI, metropolitan police, US Secret Service and Brit security officials; Brit Embassy information officer John G Taylor says that embassy tightened security more than 1 yr ago as result of increasing threats; declines to say whether there had been previous lr‐bombs or bomb threats; US State Dept says ‘US Govt strongly deplores this shocking act of violence against a diplomatic mission'; illus of Murray and Brit Embassy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Governor Picks 16 Judges To Act on New Drug Law
response.abstract: NYS Gov Rockefeller on Aug 27 appts 16 judges to state's expanded narcotics cts to handle narcotics cases, which are expected to increase on Sept 1 after enactment of state's new stringent antidrug law; appointees include: Fordham Univ Prof R G Denzer, NYS Narcotic Addiction Com chmn H A Jones, Chemung County, NY, Dist Atty J F O'Mara, former Dem assemblyman M Ramos, R L Rubin and D Zimmerman
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Ban on Utilities’ Shift to Oil Is Proposed to Save Fuel
response.abstract: Energy Office Dir J A Love on Aug 27 announces plans to prohibit utilities and industry from shifting from coal to oil as source of power; proposed new regulation, which will not apply to NYC because of its failure to meet primary air quality standards, is not seen as saving great amts of oil but in making more supplies available to residential consumers; could interfere with long‐term programs to substitute oil for coal to meet air pollution standards; extends to changes from residual fuel to low‐sulphur grades; API endorsement noted; public hearing set; savings estimated
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2 Cities, North and South, Show Progress by Blacks
response.abstract: article in NY Times series on Negro progress in last 10 yrs discusses conditions in cities of Dayton, Ohio, and Jackson, Miss, including data on income and unemployment; table
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 2 TOP DISSIDENTS ON TRIAL IN SOVIET
response.abstract: Tass repts that V A Krasin and P I Yakir go on trial Aug 27 in Lyublino, outside of Moscow, on charges of being paid agents of Western group aimed at overthrowing Soviet regime; says in brief summaries of secret trial provided for foreign consumption that two pleaded guilty to having received instructions, money and subversive publications from West Ger‐based People's Labor Alliance (NTS); repts that Krasin and Yakir are accused of having been in regular contact with agents of NTS, who were alleged to have come to Soviet Union under guise of tourists; says that they seem willing to talk freely and cooperate with prosecution in evident hope of receiving reduced sentences; both Yakir, who was arrested in June ‘72, and Krasin, arrested in Sept ‘72, have been kept in pretrial detention longer than 9 mos allowed by law; Yakir, who is a son of famous Red Army general executed in ‘37, has devoted himself in recent yrs to fighting what he regards as Stalinism in Soviet society; Krasin became involved in dissident activities in ‘68 and was exiled to Siberia in Dec ‘69 on charges of leading antisocial, parasitic life; both are long‐time friends; Krasin and Yakir pors
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 98° Heat Record for Year; City Power Usage at Peak
response.abstract: Eastern Seaboard utilities are unable to aid each other with surplus power as heat wave spurs large demand
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: AN AGNEW FRIEND SAID TO AIDI NQUIRY
response.abstract: Maryland's investigations into possible role of number of officials, including Vice Pres Agnew, in kickbacks from Md contractors on Aug 28 broadened to another front involving official charges against Baltimore Chief Judge D Foster, who has been under investigation for personally appearing to request zoning change on property he owned in Westminster, Md; he won zoning change and sold most of land to Monumental Properties Inc at profit of £470,000; exec council of Baltimore bar assn held that Chief Judge was in violation of judicial ethics and assn's findings were forwarded to Judicial Disabilities Comm, which will recommend action to Md Ct of Appeals; Monumental and its officers were listed as contributors of more than £10,000 to Agnew benefit dinner on May 19, ‘72
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: ‘Culture’ Bus Route To Run Weekends
response.abstract: NYC Transit Auth to begin experimental ‘culture loop’ bus route on Sept 1 to run 17 mi through midtown and upper Manhattan with all‐day, multiride tickets costing $1; passengers will be allowed to get on and off as many times as they want at cultural insts along 22‐stop route, which incudes museums, churches, Lincoln Center, Rockefeller Center, Central Park Zoo and UN; buses will operate on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays from 10 AM to 6 PM; map of route and stops; MTA Chmn Ronan comments; says that other routes are planned if culture loop is success
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Solzhenitsyn Tells Of Threats to Life
response.abstract: MOSCOW, Aug. 28—Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in a rare and bluntly outspoken interview with two Western newsmen, has declared that his life has been threatened. The Nobel Prize novelist, whose writings are banned in his homeland, added that if he was imprisoned or killed, “the main part of my works will be published.”
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: WIDE PRICE SURGE INCREASING COSTS PAID BY FACTORIES
response.abstract: Survey by Natl Assn of Purchasing Mgt, reinforced by telephone ints with corporate officers across US, finds mfrs in last 2 wks have experienced strongest surge of price increases for materials they buy since Nixon Adm's original Phase I price freeze ended in 71; new increases represent bulge Adm said would appear at end of 2d freeze on Aug 13; higher costs certain to be passed on to consumers; E F Andrews, noting many cos will be permitted price increases next mo after pre‐notification, says ‘this is just the beginning'; purchasing agents survey finds some 70% of buyers reptd paying higher prices for supplies and raw materials during last 2 wks; equivalent figure for July was only 39%; some corporate execs quoted on situation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 1,000 Trapped in an IRT Tunnel Accident
response.abstract: Archway of ancient Flushing line subway tunnel under East river collapses on first car of Queens‐bound IRT train during evening rush‐hour on Aug 28, trapping 1,000 Queens‐bound passengers in 115‐degree heat and heavy smoke; 1 man dies and 18 passengers are carried from tunnel on stretchers by police and firemen; scores of other passengers require assistance to st and receive treatment before they are sent home; normal service is restored at 8:46 PM after site where archway collapsed, near 1st Ave and 42d St, is cleared; trapped passengers did not panic despite heat, smoke, terror and chaos; accident is 1st in subways since ‘71 involving passenger fatality; occurred at Manhattan end of Steinway tunnel linking Long Island City and Grand Central Terminal; tunnel is oldest in city and was built at turn of century for trolley cars; illus of passengers from train; map showing location of accident; 20‐ft‐long chunk of concrete apparently worked loose from iron retaining rings at archway of tunnel and crashed into side of 1st car of 11‐car train; description of accident as given by passengers and police; killed man is identified as R Beyer, 37; Mayor Lindsay lauds rescuers and courage of passengers; MTA chmn Dr Ronan deplores mishap; MTA announces 3‐member special advisory bd will probe accident; 3 members are: L Braun, H L Fisher and L Bailey; most recent subway fatality was on May 26, ‘71, when woman died of heart attack when 7,500 passengers were trapped in same Flushing tunnel
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Robert Dowling Dies
response.abstract: Robert W. Dowling, former president and chairman of the City Investing Company, died yesterday at his home in the Pierre Hotel. He was 77 years old. He served on many civic, cultural, educational and professional organizations. Details on Page 40.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: INDIA TO RELEASE 90,000 PAKISTANIS IN PEACE ACCORD
response.abstract: India and Pakistan sign agreement in New Delhi on Aug 28 clearing way for release of most of 90,000 Pakistani POWs held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war in Dec ‘71; agreement, reached after 19 days of difficult negotiations spread over 2 mos in Islamabad and New Delhi, also provides procedure for Pakisani recognition of Bangladesh; Bangladesh did not participate in negotiations since its independence has not yet been recognized by Pakistan; Bangladesh Prime Min Sheik Mujibur Rahman had been consulted by India during negotiations; other key provisions call for release of Bangladesh and Pakistani nationals stranded in 2 countries; most crucial point is tacit agreement by Bangladesh, in exchange for recognition by Pakistan, to drop its threat to hold war‐crimes trials; Pakistan reptdly has dropped plan to hold 203 Bengalis for trial as reprisal for war‐crimes action in Bangladesh; Bangladesh had named 195 of 90,000 Pakistani POWs as persons to be tried on charges of war crimes; details of agreement, signed by Indian chief negotiator P N Haksar and Pakistani chief negotiator A Ahmed, are to be made public on Aug 29; other provisions given: Pakistan agrees to firm timetable for recognizing Bangladesh and discussing POW issue on understanding that it will not oppose Bangladesh's admission to UN; is to release all stranded Bengalis, their number to be ascertained by ‘neutral agencies'; is to admit from Bangladesh unspecified number of Biharis; number of Biharis eligible for Pakistani citizenship is to be determined in negotiations with Bangladesh and by verification of ‘ind internatl agency'; agreement is based on joint declaration by Bangladesh and India 4 mos ago offering 3‐way repatriation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Civil Rights Unity Gone In Redirected Movement
response.abstract: 4th article of NY Times series discusses what has become of civil rights movement of ‘60s; holds movement to those who knew it as mass protest and deep, widespread feeling of interracial fellowship no longer exists and that quest for racial equality continues but its targets have changed, its goals and efforts have been redirected; notes 10 yrs ago, NAACP, SNCC, CORE and SCLC dominated black community but that only NAACP retains its original identity as increasingly blacks have directed their commitments to smaller groups with more narrowly defined purposes, such as Natl Welfare Rights Orgn, Movement for Econ Justice, Operation Push and Black Panthers to name a few; says Natl Urban League, led by late W M Young Jr, was not regarded as civil rights orgn but nevertheless provided movement with key leadership; holds few of gains made in decade would have been possible without movement and, in particular, legis such as Public Accommodations Act of ‘64, Voting Rights Act of ‘65, and secs of Elementary and Secondary Educ Act of ‘65; describes movement during decade for econ opportunity as well as legal parity, noting that continuing and pervasive sense of econ injustice has done much to damage movement and discredit feeling of black‐white unity; asserts movement also suffered from increasingly abrasive relations between whites and blacks from violence that characterized black protests, from fragmentation of leadership and from increased complexity and difficulty of problems that movement confronted as it shifted its concerns to industrial centers and urban ghettos of North; details history of SNCC as indicative of rise and fall of ‘60s movement, noting that SCLC is today broken and disorganized, that CORE is expounding philosophy without a program, and that SNCC is out of business altogether; lists many of leaders of defunct SNCC such as J Lewis, J Bond, R Zellner, B Moses, M Barry, H R Brown and S Carmichael, who still consider themselves activists but chiefly from inside system that they fought so hard to change; also lists some leaders of other defunct orgns, such as A P Randolph, B Rustin and Rev J Jackson; illus of late Rev Dr M L King and new SCLC leader Rev R D Abernathy, then SNCC leaders H R Brown and S Carmichael, then CORE leaders F McKissick and J Farmer; maps showing ‘60‐70 migration of blacks, based on estimates supplied by Bur of Census; illus of NAACP leader R Wilkins
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: West Point Simplifies Cadet Regulations
response.abstract: West Point supt Lt Gen W A Knowlton reveals school has rewritten book of regulations, replacing decades of accumulated restrictions with simplified ‘blue book’ code stressing self‐discipline in most comprehensive rule change in acad s 171‐yr history; commandant of cadets Brig Gen P R Feir cites examples of change, including banning ‘confinement,’ new system of granting privileges, and reduction in allowable ‘hazing’ of plebes, or entering cadets; honor code remains unchanged; some innovations are geared at reducing attrition rate; black officer Col H G Robinson int on acad's tactics; illus
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: 180,000 Hit by Blackout In Four Areas of Queens
response.abstract: 180,000 Queens residents are blacked out on Aug 29 when Con Ed feeder cables fail; cables and entire co system had been working at capacity because of record‐breaking high temps; La Guardia Airport, Jackson Hts and parts of Elmhurst, Woodside and Corona are affected; 5,000 Great Kills and Richmondtown, SI, residents are blacked out when 7 area feeder cables fail; co, which had cut voltage 5% for 2d consecutive day, had warned Jackson Hts customers about power use because of burn‐out in 3 of 8 cables serving area and fear that rapid upsurge in demand could jeopardize system; says late afternoon upsurge in appliance and air conditioner use burned out 2 of 5 remaining cables and forced shutdown of remaining 3; effects of shutdown and other heat‐related impacts noted; map
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: APPEAL UNCERTAIN
response.abstract: White House says on Aug 29 that Pres Nixon will not comply with Judge Sirica's order to turn over his Watergate tape recordings to ct; says Pres is considering possibility of appeal or 'how otherwise to sustain the Pres's position'; legal experts say Nixon's attys could ask Sirica to reverse his own ruling on some point of law; say more likely course would be simply to refuse to carry out ct order; illus of Sen Ervin
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Nadjari Studying Charge Of Plan to Bribe a Justice
response.abstract: NYS Deputy Atty Gen M H Nadjari office discloses on Aug 29 that it is investigating alleged conspiracy to pay $50,000 bribe to NYS Sup Ct justice; details of conspiracy are not disclosed but sources close to investigation say that it grew out of case involving Citizens Casualty Co of NY, which was declared insolvent in '70 after fighting long ct battle to stay in business; in that battle, co, whose lawyer was Repr M Biaggi, won brief victory before Acting Sup Ct Justice A C Orlando, interim appointee who is now sitting in Claims Ct; Orlando was reversed and ct was ordered dissolved; Biaggi was paid $240,000 but was later ordered to return $100,000 of fee; ct order held that $100,000 was contingent on Biaggi's winning complete victory for co while Biaggi maintained that he was obligated only to win aspect of case that came before Orlando; NYS Sup Ct Justice J M Murtagh on Aug 29 refuses to quash subpoena issued by Nadjari to Century Natl Bank and Trust Co; J A Phillips, chief asst special prosecutor, asserts that bank records will be able to shed light on sources of moneys used to pay bribe and to account for moneys obtained as result of case; tells Murtagh that in course of investigation, evidence developed by grand jury indicates that principal officers of Century Bank have information and evidence relating to alleged bribery; maintains that conspirators, as result of alleged bribe, obtained substantial sums of moneys due to the determination of case; contends that all of leads produced indicate that bribe money went to Century Bank; bank exec officers are V F Albano Jr, Manhattan Repub Chmn, and L Marchini; Phillips holds that Marchini has impeded investigation; charges that Marchini has 'refused' to sign gen waiver of immunity and that he will not testify or give information about some of financial transactions unless he recd immunity; J Marchese, who says he represents Albano, calls NY Times on Aug 29 and contends that Albano and Marchini have been before grand jury more than once and have testified; adds that Albano has signed waiver; investigators assert that inquiry into bank's affairs has revealed 'extremely suspicious' transfers of moneys and manipulations of accts; Phillips observes that alleged manipulations have taken place over long period of time and are 'most complex'; notes that investigators have uncovered at least 4 aspects of bank's transactions that lead to his 'extremely suspicious' characterization; they are: city deposits in interest‐free accts, loan obtained by Marchini on behalf of unnamed public official, a 'peculiar' transaction between Albano and F S Rice, city tax collector, and 'commissions' or 'investments' by Albano that required no effort or work on his part; Phillips contends that Albano's influence with NYC officials has obtained for bank 'entirely disproportionate' amt of NYC's bank deposits; holds that city has lost $1‐million in interest during period of investigation as result of one acct alone; states that city funds have been kept in Century despite objections by Finance Admr R Lewisohn; pors of Albano and Marchini
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: The Soviet Dissidents
response.abstract: article sees Soviet trial of P I Yakir and V A Krasin and moves to counter dissident activities of A I Solzhenitsyn and A D Sakharov as evidence Soviet Govt is determined to pursue policy of improved relations with West without giving in to domestic pressures for liberal reform; notes that US has once again come under attack in Soviet media after moratorium coinciding with summit between Pres Nixon and Brezhnev; says although there is no evidence to suggest Soviet leaders are intensifying their crack down on dissidents, developments suggest that effort is being made to eliminate domestic opposition in preparation for dealing with the West on plan for closer econ collaboration; notes Soviet Union maintains that desire for better pol relations with West does not include freer dissemination of people and ideas across their borders; says concern among Soviet dissidents is that they will be losers as East‐West relations improve unless domestic liberalization is also included; cites concern expressed by V Y Maksimov and A D Sakharov; notes that Soviet leaders appear to be responding to criticism by publicizing trial of Yakir and Krasin and by steps that may be taken to silence Sakharov and Solzhenitsyn
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Judge Sirica's Order
response.abstract: text of Judge Sirica's Aug 29 decision ordering Pres Nixon to turn White House tapes over to him and text of White House reply
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: PEKING DISCLOSES 5‐DAY CONGRESS OF CHINESE PARTY
response.abstract: People's Republic of China discloses on Aug 29 that 10th Cong of its Communist party was held in Peking from Aug 24‐28; official press agency Hsinhua, which makes announcement, says Cong formally expelled Defense Min Lin Piao and former Politburo member Chen Po‐ta from party; Lin was designated Chmn Mao Tse‐tung's successor during last Cong in '69 and is reptd to have been killed in '71 with his wife Yeh Chun after attempting to assassinate Mao; Lin and Chen are denounced as renegades and traitors; Cong also adopts revised party const, selects new Central Com and approves political rept delivered by Premier Chou En‐lai; Cong, at which Mao presided, is briefest in history of Chinese party; was attended by 1,249 delegates and held in secrecy; appears to have been more of rubber stamp than any of its predecessors, with delegates hearing repts and approving actions already taken by party leadership; brevity and secrecy of conf indicate that there was difficulty in organizing it and desire to avoid any appearance of rifts; Hsinhua communique gives party membership as 28 million, figure much higher than any previous total made public; says 67% of delegates were workers, soldiers and peasants and 20% are women; says delegates included natives of Nationalist China; Wang Hung‐wen, newcomer since Cultural Revolution, reptd on revision of party const at Cong, following Chou's political rept; communique gives no details of either rept but says they were adopted 'unanimously'; total of 195 members and 124 alternate members were elected 'by secret ballot' to new Central Com; new Central Com includes as full members Teng Hsiao‐ping, newly rehabilitated former sec gen of party, Wang Chia‐hsiang, former Politburo member purged during Cultural Revolution, Ulanfu, Mongol who was purged during Cultural Revolution, Tan Chen‐lin, former Politburo member purged during Cultural Revolution, Foreign Min Chi Peng‐fei, Deputy Foreign Min Chiao Kuan‐hua, UN repr Huang Hua, Huang Chen, head of liaison office in Washington (DC), Chuang Tse‐tung, 3 times world table tennis champion, Yang Yung, newly appointed commander of Sinkiang; Cong presidium included Chmn Mao, Chou, Wang Hung‐wen, Kang Sheng, veteran Politburo member, Yeh Chien‐ying, another veteran, and Li Teh‐sheng, head of gen political dept of armed forces, as deputy chmn; Chang Chun‐chiao was named sec gen; Mao's wife, Chiang Ching, who is usually ranked 3d or 4th in party hierarchy, was not named deputy chmn although she is listed member of presidium; 3 of deputy chmn, Li, Chang and Wang are often associated with Chiang
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Sadat and Qaddafi Act on Unification
response.abstract: Egyptian Pres Sadat and Libyan leader Col M el‐Qaddafi on Aug 29 proclaim 'birth of new unified Arab state' but make it emphatically clear that actual unification of their 2 countries is still long way off; declaration issued in name of Sadat and Qaddafi satisfies every point of Egyptian Govt's wish for slow, gradual approach that can be broken off at any stage; falls far short of immediate full union that Qaddafi demanded; says that on Sept 1 following measures will be taken: 2 countries will form mixed constituent assembly to work out const for new state and choose candidate for chief of state but with no deadline by which to complete 2 tasks, new monetary unit, called dinar, will be adopted for trade, accounting and other transactions between 2 countries and there will be free‐trade zones along their border, 2 Govts will exch resident mins and will form so‐called higher planning council consisting of their Premiers and key members of their Cabinets and that 2 countries will set up joint central secretariat to help constituent assembly and resident mins; makes it clear that 2 Govts will remain fully independent pending completion of work of contituent assembly; assembly is to consist of 50 members of Egyptian People's Assemby and 50 elected reprs of so‐called peoples' coms from Libya; referendum will be held in both countries once assembly has written const for new state and agrees on chief exec; illus of Sadat and Qaddafi
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Union Aides Indicted
response.abstract: Peter Ottley, president of the 20,000‐member Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Service Employes Union, and Peter Byrne, its secretarytreasurer, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling union funds. Page 44.
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: NIXON'S LAWYERS ASSAIL COMMITTEE
response.abstract: Pres Nixon's attys charge on Aug 29, in papers filed in Fed Dist Ct, that Sen Watergate com conducted 'criminal investigation and trial' that exceeded authority granted to Cong by Const; reject com's demand for tape recordings of Nixon conversations on ground that Sens are illegally attempting to determine 'whether or not criminal acts have been committed and guilt or innocence of individuals'; contend that ct has no jurisdiction over their client, either as individual or as Pres, and that Nixon 'owes no duty,' in either capacity, to Sen com to provide it with recordings of his confidential meetings or other related documents; Sen com, in countermove, files with Judge Sirica motion for summary judgment in same case, request that judge enforce 2 subpoenas already served on Pres with minimum of further ct proceedings; Nixon's attys assert that ct has no jurisdiction over controversy because it does not involve more than $10,000, lowest amount with which a Fed Dist Ct is required to deal in civil suit; that subpoenas served on Pres are 'null and void' because they had never been authorized by vote of full Sen; that com members have not 'suffered any legal wrong, nor have they been adversely affected or aggrieved' as result of Pres's rejection of subpoena to produce documents; say Nixon 'is without information or knowledge sufficient to form a belief as to Sen com's claims that information in tapes is relevant to Cong investigation
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: A HISTORIC RULING
response.abstract: Judge Sirica on Aug 29 orders Pres Nixon to make tape recordings of White House conversations involving Watergate case available to him for decision on their use by grand jury; Pres aides announce, however, that Nixon 'will not comply with the order' on ground that inspection of tapes by a judge 'is inconsistent with Pres's position relating to the question of separation of powers as provided by Const and necessity of maintaining precedents of confidentiality of private Pres conversations'; White House statement says Nixon's attys, led by Prof Wright, are considering appealing Sirica's decision, and hints they might find some other method of sustaining Pres's legal position; special Watergate prosecutor A Cox, if faced with refusal by Nixon to accept ct's ruling or to challenge it by appeal, might initiate contempt proceedings or begin appeal of his own, based on ct's refusal to give him tapes directly; decision marks only 2d time in US history that a ct has required a Pres, against his will, to produce his personal records as evidence; 1st case involved Pres Jefferson; Sirica says he is 'simply unable' to decide whether Pres's refusal to release tapes and related documents is valid without inspecting recordings himself; upholds authority of ct to take such action; says that if he finds evidence relating to criminal activity in tapes, and it can be successfully separated from privileged statements dealing with Nixon's official duties, he will excise privilege portions and pass unprivileged portion along to Watergate grand jury; says if privilege and unprivileged evidence are so inextricably connected that separation becomes impossible, then 'whole must be privileged and no disclosure made to grand jury'; relies heavily, in decision, on decision by Chief Justice J Marshall that required Pres Jefferson to furnish lr for treason trial of A Burr; bases his decision to considerable extent on need for all citizens, regardless of their soc or pol position, to cooperate with grand jury investigation; calls it immaterial' whether ct has physical power' to enforce an order against Pres, because ct 'has a duty to issue appropriate orders' under any circumstances; says he disagrees with Pres 'that it is the exec that finally determines whether its privilege is properly invoked'; says that giving Pres special immunity from ct rulings 'tends to set White House apart as a 4th branch of govt'; says in his decision he found it necessary to answer only 2 questions: whether ct has jurisdiction to decide issue of privilege and whether ct has authority to enforce subpoena by way of an order requiring production for inspection in camera; concludes answer to both questions is yes; illus of Sirica and Cox
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Questions and Answers on the Drug Law
response.abstract: article answers questions pertaining to practical applications of new stringent NYS narcotics law, which becomes effective on Sept 1; chart categorizes drug offenses and penalties for each under new legis
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: FARM PRICES SOAR 20% TO ANEW HIGH
response.abstract: Agr Dept, signaling more potential food increases, repts on Aug 30 that avg price of all raw farm products soared by record 20% to new high in mo ended Aug 15; says prices topped 100% of parity for 1st time in 21 yrs; rept covers prices realized by farmers for their products but does not correlate them to wholesale or retail prices; rept shows farmers' costs in Aug rose 3%; finds, however, that farm prices rose to 102%, highest level since Aug '52; priceswere at 88% July 15 and 75% in mid‐Aug '72; notes that number of commodities were above 100% of parity figure, which is considered 'fair' price for farm products in comparison with cost of things farmers buy
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: THIRD DAY IN 90's, POWER CUT AGAIN: NO RELIEF IS SEEN
response.abstract: temperatures in NYC on Aug 30 reach over 90 degrees for 3d consecutive day, forcing voltage cutbacks and opening illegally of many fire hydrants; Natl Weather Service predicts heat to continue through Labor Day‐weekend; table of official temperatures
keywords: PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS AND OTHER RECREATION AREAS
response.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

response.headline: Chinese Add New Faces To the Party's Politburo
response.abstract: People's Repub of China on Aug 30 announces new ruling Politburo that includes Mao Tse‐tung, Chou en‐lai and other seasoned leaders as well as a former textile worker and farmer; members of Politburo, which runs country on daily basis, were named at 1st session of Chinese Communist party's new Central Com, which was elected at recently concluded 10th party Cong; Cong was held to set up new party structure to take acct of developments of last 2 yrs, especially events of Sept '71 when Defense Min Lin Piao reptdly was killed in air crash after attempting to assassinate Mao; new Politburo named standing com of 9 and designated 5 vice chmn, returning to structure that prevailed before Cultural Revolution of later '60s; naming of vice chmn seen preparatory move for collective leadership when Mao dies; move is viewed in light of fact that just‐concluded 10th Cong designated no single deputy and successor to Mao; Chou is now seen as 2d in command but he is not seen as having been given any formalized status as Mao's deputy; Politburo includes Wang Hung‐wen, 36‐yr‐old cotton mill worker, Wei Kuo‐ching, leader of Chuang minority people and Kwangsi pol boss and Chen Yung‐kuei, head of model commune at Tachai; selection marks 1st time that workers and farmers have been made members or alternate members; 5 vice chmn are Chou, Wang, Yeh Chien‐ying, Kang Shen and Li Teh‐sheng; those named to Politburo standing com are: Mao and all 5 vice chmn as well as Chu Teh, Chang Chun‐chiao and Tung Pi‐wu; their backgrounds noted; new power line up seen containing mix of old and new civilian leaders and mil men; Chiang Ching, Mao's wife, is notably absent from top leadership; also missing is Yao Wen‐yuan; announcement confirms dramatic jump into top leadership of Wang Hung‐wen, usually viewed as protege of Chang Chun‐chiao; Wang career sketch; phrase and composition of Central Com and Politburo seen indications that main concern of Cong is succession; Mao will be 80 in Dec and reptdly is increasingly fragile and reptdly has periods of mental lapses; 13 of 21 full members of Politburo who were members of old Politburo are: Mao, Chou, Chiang Ching, Yeh Chien‐ying, Chu Teh, Chang Chin‐chiao, Yao Wen‐yuan, Kang Sheng, Tung Pi‐wu, Liu Po‐cheng, Li Hsien‐nien, Hsu Shih‐yu and Chen Hsi‐lien; 3 of members who were alternates in last Politubro are Chi Teng‐kuei, Li Teh‐sheng and Wang Tung‐hsing; 5 new members include Hua Kuo‐feng and Wuh Teh besides Wang Hung‐wen, Wei Kuo‐ching and Chen Yung‐kuei; those named as new alternates include Wu Kuei‐hsien, Su Chen‐hua, Ni Chih‐fu and Saifudin; illus of Mao, Chou and Wang Hung‐wen at party Cong

response.headline: PARLIAMENT GETS CANADA RAIL ISSUE
response.abstract: Canadian Parliament convenes on Aug 30 to consider legis providing for wage increases and further bargaining in attempt to end rail strike which has jolted nation's econ; Govt of Prime Min Trudeau and Opposition leader R Stanfield try to make maximum pol capital of emergency session; striking unions reject Govt's terms as 'meager,' raising possibility that strike may not be ended as easily as observers expected; officials still predict trains will be running by next wk; rr workers charge through police ranks and break windows in Parliament bldg before session, but disorder is quickly contained

response.headline: Two in Nonsecurity Posts Were on Wiretapping List
response.abstract: 2 Adm officials in nonsecurity posts were reptdly wiretapped by Govt despite Pres Nixon's assertion that wiretapping was conducted only against those privy to secret foreign policy plans between '69 and 71; telephones of J W McLane, ex‐White House Domestic Council staff member, and J P Sears, ex‐deputy White House counsel, were reptdly wiretapped, as was telephone used by then‐Defense Sec Laird's top mil asst Lt Gen R E Pursley; McLane, now deputy dir of Cost of Living Council, says he knew 'absolutely nothing about natl security'; Laird says he knew 'absolutely nothing' about wiretapping of Gen Pursley; Pres Nixon has said those whose telephones were tapped were selected by natl security affairs adviser H A Kissinger, ex‐Atty Gen Mitchell and late FBI dir J E Hoover, 'on basis of access to information'; Sears illus

response.headline: LAWYERS FOR NIXON WILL REQUEST U.S. APPEALS COURT TO OVERTURN SIRICA ORDER TO SURRENDER TAPES
response.abstract: Pres Nixon, after meeting on Aug 30 with attys C A Wright and J F Buzhardt, decides to appeal Judge Sirica's ruling that he must turn over White House tapes of talks involving Watergate to judge to Appeals Ct; decision to appeal through normal channels rather than ignore order or take other legal steps virtually assures that issue will go to Supreme Ct; Nixon aide Gen A M Haig Jr, who earlier met with Nixon's attys, says reason for White House Aug 29 statement that spurred speculation on alternatives to appeal was that a number of options were open;' says Nixon's firm stand against release of tapes has not changed

response.headline: STEEL CONCERNS INDICTED BY U.S.
response.abstract: US Steel, Bethlehem Steel and Armco Steel are indicted on Aug 30 along with 14 smaller cos and 16 present and former officials of cos on charges of price‐fixing and mkt‐sharing in $40‐million Texas mkt for steel re‐inforcings bars, charges filed in 2 separate indictments and criminal information by Fed Dist Cts in Texas; 3 big corps are named in only one indictment, the other and the criminal information charging smaller fabricators with conspiracy to allocate among themselves contracts in Houston and Dallas‐Forth Worth areas, respectively; indictments detailed; other defendants listed
